title: Cooperative Research Platform - Modular Automated Driving System for Prototypical Research Activities
authors: Dávid Jóozsa, Gergo Ignéeczi, Mátyás Mesics, Erno Horváth
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Symposium on Computational Intelligence and Informatics (CINTI)
abstract: Automated Driving functions have widely spread in last years, not only in research, but also in the automotive industry. Many car manufacturers and their suppliers have funded different software systems to fulfill the driving requirements. By the growing number of innovations, the rapidly changing technology and newer players in the automotive industry requires academy and industry to collaborate on their automated software developments. To do so, a common research and development framework is needed which inherently provides smooth transition of new solutions from one world to the other. Even though there are many open source research framework for rapid prototyping of automated driving functions, these solutions are often concentrated on low speed maneuvering, especially for the higher automation levels, such as robo-taxis. However, major automotive companies require developments of up to SAE (Society of Automotive Engineers) level 2 and 3. Therefore, a new prototypical, open source software architecture<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup> is proposed, that uses well-known tools and technology as basis, such as Robot Operating System or Autoware Universe, but also being closely in compliance with industrial architecture aspects. It is proven that the proposed architecture, along with its abstraction layers and interfaces provide modularity, and interchangeability of basic components, while the hardware and vehicle dependencies are well separated from the application software layer. Via few exemplary functions the usability of the system is demonstrated, and fellow researchers are highly encouraged to advise on the generalization of the system.<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup>https://github.com/jkk-research/CooperativeResearchPlatform/tree/release

title: AI-Powered Vision System Using OpenCV and MediaPipe for Real-Time Silent Emergency Hand Gesture Recognition in Privacy-Constrained Spaces for Women’s Safety
authors: Devika, Anushree Raj, Pallavi M O, Khadersab Adamsab
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems and Pioneering Innovations in Robotics and Electric Mobility (INSPIRE)
abstract: The security of women in private indoor settings— including dormitories, restrooms, and bedrooms—continues to be a significant challenge. Conventional safety solutions, such as mobile phones or wearable devices, are frequently ineffective in emergencies where silent and discreet communication is paramount. To address this limitation, this paper introduces a vision-based system powered by artificial intelligence for the real-time identification of emergency hand gestures, tailored for use in privacy-sensitive locations. Our proposed methodology utilizes MediaPipe's 21-point hand landmark model in conjunction with a computationally efficient rule-based classifier. This classifier is designed to identify two distinct gestures: the internationally recognized SOS signal (characterized by the sequence: open palm, followed by a thumb tuck, culminating in a closed fist) and a newly defined gesture wherein the index finger makes contact with the center of the opposite palm. To enhance reliability, a spatial-temporal validation component assesses the intent behind the gesture by examining the geometric relationships of the landmarks and the consistency of motion across consecutive video frames, thereby substantially reducing false alarms. The entire processing pipeline is implemented locally using OpenCV, which guarantees user privacy and achieves a processing latency of under 150 milliseconds. Experimental results indicate that the system attains an accuracy exceeding 95% across diverse lighting scenarios, confirming its robust real-time performance on standard consumer-grade hardware. This research offers a practical, cost-efficient, and privacy-centric framework for silent emergency alerting, thereby contributing to the advancement of AI-driven safety applications for women in enclosed private spaces.

title: Operational Design and Performance Analysis of CSP-PV-BESS Hybrids in Azerbaijan
authors: Faig Kalbaliyev
publish: 2025 14th International Symposium on Advanced Topics in Electrical Engineering (ATEE)
abstract: This study examines a potential hybrid solar power plant that integrates concentrating solar power (CSP) with thermal energy storage (TES), photovoltaic (PV) generation, and a gridscale battery energy storage system (BESS) to provide continuous electricity in Azerbaijan. The analysis focuses on the Nakhchivan region, which offers strong solar resource potential. We formalize a relation that links the firm night-time demand to available TES capacity and a predefined battery block, and evaluate two representative configurations under a common dispatch policy. In both cases, PV supplies daytime demand, the CSP unit stores midday solar heat for later use, and the BESS (500 MW) manages ramps and short-term fluctuations. The first configuration is a larger-scale option intended to deliver <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2 5 0 M W}$</tex> of firm power, supported by approximately 450 MW of PV, about 300 MW of CSP, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 14 \mathrm{h}$</tex> of TES. The second configuration is a smallerscale option designed for a continuous 100 MW supply, supported by roughly 300 MW of PV, 100 MW of CSP, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 12 \mathrm{h}$</tex> of TES. Under the stated assumptions, both configurations meet a 24hour supply target with modest energy margins. The results indicate that CSP-PV-BESS hybrids can enhance reliability and reduce midday curtailment. Among the two options, the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 0 0 M W}$</tex> configuration appears to be the more practical starting point for near-term deployment, with the potential to scale as local capabilities develop.

title: Evaluating the position accuracy of Sentinel’s Interferometric Wide Swath Synthetic Aperture Radar Images in SNAP
authors: Avgustin Hristov
abstract: This paper presents a methodology for evaluating the position accuracy of Sentinel-1 Interferometric Wide Swath (IW) Ground Range Detected (GRD) products using the SNAP application. The research considers the ESA's specifications and additional limiting factors. The study measures the positions of passive radar corner reflectors with known coordinates. Results from seven acquisitions are processed, analyzed, and compared to determine the achieved positional accuracy

title: Micro-Doppler Extraction from Ground-Based SAR Data using Interferometry Approach
authors: Fathin Nurzaman, Yuta Izumi, Giovanni Nico, Masato Komuro, Kaoru Ota, Mianxiong Dong
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: An experiment has been conducted to measure an object's vibration frequency and amplitude through micro-Doppler extraction using an interferometric approach from ground-based SAR data. This is performed by simply subtracting the range-compressed beat spectrum with another one from a different acquisition considered as the reference, similar to the displacement measurement in interferometry. This presents a simple and cost-effective method for retrieving an object's vibration information compared to previous microDoppler extraction techniques. This method is easily implementable in a continuous Synthetic Aperture Radar Interferometry (InSAR) monitoring campaign which would increase the measurement's capability from only monitoring displacement per acquisition to also monitoring the object's vibration which could increase its usefulness for infrastructure health monitoring applications.

title: Analysis of The Effect of Distance-Based Clustering on Ensemble Model Performance for Cellular Signal Prediction in Urban Areas
authors: Fikry Adam, Iskandar, Hajiar Yuliana
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Telecommunication Systems, Services, and Applications (TSSA)
abstract: Accurate cellular network coverage prediction presents a significant challenge in complex urban areas. This research provides a comprehensive analysis of the influence of distance-based clustering on the performance of Ensemble Learning models for cellular signal prediction. The methodology involved collecting drive test and operator data, followed by data preprocessing and feature engineering. The data was then clustered by distance using Quantile Binning and Fixed Interval methods. Various ensemble models were evaluated across three modeling scenarios: a specific model per cluster, a global model (baseline), and a global model with an added cluster feature. The results consistently demonstrate that the global model (baseline) approach delivered the most accurate and robust performance, with the Stacking model achieving the best results (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> = 0.80). The initial hypothesis, which stated that prediction error would increase with distance, was definitively rejected. In-depth analysis revealed that the error peaked at mid-range distances (100-250 meters), attributed to the high volatility of the actual signal in complex local environments like urban canyons. This finding proves that unmodeled local environmental factors have a more dominant influence on prediction difficulty than signal attenuation due to distance alone, offering the insight that more detailed geospatial features are needed to improve model accuracy in the future.

title: A Deeper Look into Stable Diffusion in Generating Building Images
authors: Dewi Tresnawati, Vitradisa Pratama, Fitri Nuraeni, Dody Kusmana, Tanto Trisno Mulyono, Nina Lestari
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Telecommunication Systems, Services, and Applications (TSSA)
abstract: The field of Artificial Intelligence has grown since the 1950s, with the development of Generative AI going in full blast in recent years. Art generation based on text-to-image prompts has been researched since 2015 with the development of Align Draw and has only grown since, with one of the most commonly known models being Stable Diffusion, a generative AI model based on Latent Diffusion Model. Stable Diffusion is trained by feeding images as training data into the model, where they are gradually reduced to pure noise, and then go through a reverse diffusion process where the noises are converted back into their initial states. In this paper, the process of diffusion model training in Stable Diffusion will be explained more thoroughly and applied to the training of a model to generate a specific building type. The model training itself took 7 minutes to complete all 10 epochs and a total of 240 steps. The loss during each epoch was shown. The loss peaked at epoch 8 at 18.3% but went down significantly at epoch 9 to only be at 13.8%. With the loss during training to be less than 20% at most, it is feasible to assume that the image generated by the model will hopefully be similar to the real thing.

title: Logic for Computer Engineering
authors: Vladimir Hahanov, Marina Abashidze, Abdullayev Vugar Hacimahmud, Tetiana Borysenko, Hanna Khakhanova, Nataliya Maksymova, Irina Hahanova
abstract: The system issues of using computing logic to solve practical engineering problems are considered. It is demonstrated that the logic in a computer encompasses the existence and development of all emerging architectures, models, and algorithms. Relations are given that show the commonality of logical data structures for various types of computing, including quantum and Artificial Intelligence. A map of science and practice is provided, illustrating the relationship between key concepts such as science, engineering, education, and scientific results, all of which are essential for the creative activities of scientists, students, and engineers. A map of model minimization, its pros and cons for verification procedures, is given modelling for simulation. It is shown that to perform verification successfully, it is necessary to meet the requirements of testable standards to reduce the time for modeling and simulation procedures. To do this, it is essential to redesign (remodel) the digital product to maximize the enlargement of the logical elements of the new circuit model. A vector-matrix technology is presented for building a map to test functions and structures without relying on algorithms or processor instructions. Mechanisms for rendering any structure, function, truth table, and matrix using graph construction for any logical vector are given. Structurally logical constants are determined, enabling the solution of the problem of modeling a testing map for functionality or structure in a more technologically advanced manner.

title: Synthetic Training for Real Scripts: A Deep Learning Approach to Hungarian Cursive Digitization
authors: Erik Ferenci, Elemér Balázs, Sándor Szénási, Zoltán Vámossy
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Symposium on Computational Intelligence and Informatics (CINTI)
abstract: Nowadays, the digitization of writing is becoming more and more widespread, and image processing is an essential technique for this. In addition to the basic image correction methods, examining the data in the image is a much more complex task. For example, when discussing character recognition or face detection, it is necessary to build a more flexible and adaptive unit. In this paper, we introduce a new approach to building a written text recognition system based on deep learning. For training the system, we used “synthetic” handwriting words and also tested both synthetic and real handwritten words. The results are compared with two of the most commonly used systems.

title: From Multi-Dimensional Polsar Data to Efficient Crop Classification: An Feature-Enhanced Multi-Attention FMD-Unet Framework
authors: Isabella Lee, John Trinder, Arcot Sowmya, Qianqian Zhang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: PolSAR data often introduces computational complexity and redundancy, limiting analytical efficiency. To address this, Shapley Additive Explanations (SHAP) were used for feature interaction analysis, extracting key decomposed features such as PauliRGB, Cloude-Pottier, and van Zyl, which were combined into a multi-dimensional PolSAR feature cube. This served as input to the proposed feature-enhanced multiattention Dual U-Net (FMD-Unet), which integrates multiple attention modules for end-to-end, pixel-wise classification. Experiments on quad-polarization NASA/JPL AIRSAR L-band benchmark datasets demonstrate the superior performance of the proposed FMD-Unet, achieving a test accuracy of 99.89 percent across 15 classes. The model is computationally efficient, requiring under 3 hours for 1000 training epochs. Comparative evaluations against state-of-the-art architecture, including dual-branch PSPNet, FCN, DeepLabv3Plus, and USquareNet, confirm its superior classification performance. Furthermore, the model's flexibility allows it to function as a plug-and-play component for PolSAR classification tasks, enhancing its adaptability. These findings underscore the potential of PolSAR-based methodologies for agricultural monitoring.

title: Integrating Remote Sensing and Water Quality Proxies to Monitor Harmful Algal Blooms in Lake Windermere and Haiderpur Wetlands
authors: Abhinav Galodha, Maria-Valasia Peppa, Sam Wilson, Brejesh Lall, Shaikh Ziauddin Ahammad, Sanya Anees
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Monitoring cyanobacterial harmful algal blooms in small freshwater lakes and reservoirs through satellite imagery presents unique challenges. The configurations and resolutions of current satellite sensors, which were primarily created for larger terrestrial applications, are the main source of these difficulties. This study uses the recently curated and modified open-source <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{R}$</tex> package, water quality, to suggest an efficient methodology for detecting and quantifying signs of dangerous algal blooms using remote sensing data. Our research focuses on algal blooms in Lake Windermere, England, and the Haiderpur wetlands in Muzaffarnagar-Bijnor, Uttar Pradesh, India. Using high-resolution satellite data gathered during August and September 2024, we investigate the characterization of BGA, MCI, and NDCI for Lake Windermere and the same period for the Haiderpur wetlands. Pre-processing steps specifically to extract water-leaving reflectance calculations were adopted using Sen2Corr and ACOLITE for both Sentinel-2 (MSI) and Landsat 8 (OLI). This conversion from TOA data to surface reflectance is crucial for estimating chlorophyll-a concentration, leveraging methods such as empirical indices, BDA, NDCI, and FAI. The result highlights the application of water quality proxies, including chlorophyll-a, phycocyanin, FAI and turbidity, to assess the quality of inland lake and wetland designated site. With the help of the water quality package, integrating high resolution UAV imagery and related literature, researchers and water managers may improve water quality monitoring and make well-informed decisions more easily. By working together, we hope to improve our knowledge of the dynamics of water quality and direct decision-makers toward all-encompassing management plans that adhere to the concepts of SDG 6 (clean water and sanitation) and 14 (life below water) for coming generations.

title: TGAPneumoSeg: A Text-Guided Attention Network for Pneumothorax Segmentation in Chest X-rays
authors: Yashashvi Mann, Rethvik Jain, Vedant Gupta, Chhavi Dhiman
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Computing and Communication Technologies (CONECCT)
abstract: Pneumothorax is a life-threatening condition caused by collapsing of lungs due to the presence of air in chest cavity between chest wall and lung. For its diagnostic purposes, a chest radiograph is commonly used to identify the affected regions (lesions). The manual diagnosis of pneumothorax has been challenging due to image variability in terms of contrast and uniformity in radiographs. Hence, to address this issue, we present TGAPneumoSeg, a Noval deep learning architecture that helps in pneumothorax diagnosis through improved chest X-ray interpretation. The model addresses these challenges by using an architecture that combines multi-scale attention mechanisms, text-guided embedding fusion, and a two-stage progressive denoising attention (PDA) process. We used the SIIMACR Pneumothorax Segmentation dataset to train our model TGAPneumoSeg achieving Dice score of 0.8394 and a Jaccard index of 0.8198, outperforming established models like U-Net, ResNet34 U-Net, Attention U-Net and PTXSeg-Net pretrained on ImageNet. The model integrates textual embeddings with visual features, which ensures precise lesion boundary detection while maintaining clinical relevance. Further experimental results demonstrate robustness and adaptability of TGAPneumoSeg improving patient care through faster and more accurate diagnosis.

title: Task Execution and Dynamic Re-Planning with a Mobile Robot and Manipulator: A Real-Robot Study Using RDK X3 and myCobot 320 – Part 2
authors: Danail Slavov, Anastasiya Slavova
abstract: This paper presents the experimental evaluation of two graph-based search algorithms – Breadth-First Search (BFS) and D* Lite – implemented on a cooperative robotic system consisting of a mobile wheeled platform (RDK X3) and a six-axis manipulator (myCobot 320). The system performs transport, loading, and unloading tasks on a physical grid-based track using a low-cost sensor suite composed of a camera and an ultrasonic distance sensor. The experiments evaluate algorithm performance in terms of memory consumption, execution time, queue operations, and physical movement duration under both obstacle-free and obstacle-rich conditions. Results show that BFS provides a stable reference baseline for static environments, while D* Lite achieves efficient dynamic re-planning with minimal computational overhead. These findings validate the feasibility of low-cost, real-world autonomous navigation for industrial applications.

title: AI in Computer-Aid Design of Components and Assemblies in Mechanical Engineering Education
authors: Anton Bashev, Stanislav Asenov
abstract: This study investigates the impact of Artificial Intelligence (AI) integration on learning outcomes in the education of computer-aided design of components and assemblies in mechanical engineering for students specializing in Mechanical Engineering Technology. Sixteen participants were divided into two equal groups: an experimental group utilizing AI tools (ChatGPT for guidance and AI-powered SolidWorks plug-ins for optimization), and a control group relying entirely on traditional methods. Quantitative results show that the AI-supported group completed tasks 26% faster and made 35% fewer geometric errors, but scored 11,5% lower on tests assessing the acquisition of fundamental knowledge. Qualitative analysis reveals that participants in the AI group developed stronger skills in information filtering but demonstrated weaker abilities in collaborative problem-solving. The study provides evidence-based recommendations for balancing the efficiency gains offered by AI with the development of essential engineering competencies.

title: Data-Driven Process Drift Detection in ICT Testing Using EWMA and CUSUM Methods
authors: Stoyan Daskalov, Stanislav Asenov
abstract: This paper presents a lightweight data-driven framework for process drift detection in In-Circuit Testing (ICT) of electronic assemblies using Exponentially Weighted Moving Average (EWMA) and Cumulative Sum (CUSUM) control methods. The proposed solution is implemented in a fully open-source environment combining Bash scripting, Telegraf, InfluxDB 2.0, and Grafana. The architecture enables real-time anomaly detection and historical analysis of component-level measurements collected from ICT equipment. Experimental results show that the proposed approach effectively identifies gradual performance deviations before the process exceeds tolerance limits, providing a foundation for predictive maintenance and continuous process improvement in Industry 5.0 environments.

title: Optimization and Application of Lightweight Convolutional Neural Network Models for Adult Education
authors: Yuying Jiang, Shan Luan, Mario Di Nardo
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Modern Education and Information Management (ICMEIM)
abstract: Adult education faces the challenges of fragmented learning time, diverse resources, and limited device performance, which restrict the effective deployment of intelligent learning systems. To address these issues and support Quality Education within the framework of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), this paper proposes EduLite-CNN, a multi-strategy lightweight convolutional neural network optimized for adult education scenarios. The model integrates depth wise separable convolution, Ghost modules, and a lite attention mechanism to enhance feature representation while significantly reducing computational cost. Furthermore, pruning, quantization-aware training, and knowledge distillation are applied to achieve high efficiency and compactness without compromising accuracy. Experiments on multi-modal datasets including textbooks, lecture slides, handwritten notes, and classroom behavior images demonstrate that EduLite-CNN outperforms representative lightweight baselines in resource classification, behavior detection, and layout segmentation, achieving both higher accuracy and lower latency on mobile devices. The findings confirm that EduLite-CNN provides a feasible and scalable solution for intelligent education applications, promoting the accessibility and sustainability of adult learning systems.

title: A Novel Pulse Shape Optimization Approach for Eliminating Armature Capture in Reluctance Coilguns
authors: Vasim H. Ghanchi, Ketan P. Badgujar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems and Pioneering Innovations in Robotics and Electric Mobility (INSPIRE)
abstract: Electromagnetic coilguns are increasingly recognized as a promising alternative to conventional projectile launch systems due to their ability to deliver high velocities through contactless acceleration. Among various configurations, reluctance-based coilguns are particularly affected by the issue of armature capture, where residual coil current continues to exert a retarding magnetic force after the projectile passes the optimal acceleration point. This undesired effect significantly reduces the projectile’s exit velocity and overall efficiency. Conventional mitigation techniques— typically employing SCR-based switching to abruptly interrupt current—often lead to substantial energy losses and offer limited flexibility in control. In response, this study introduces a novel pulse-width modulation strategy that employs IGBT or MOSFET switches to precisely regulate coil excitation. By tuning the switching frequency and duty cycle, the coil current is shaped to decay at the exact moment the projectile exits the magnetic influence zone, thereby minimizing reverse forces without dissipating stored magnetic energy. A digital twin of a reluctance coilgun is developed and simulated using ANSYS Maxwell and Twin Builder platforms to evaluate the proposed method. Simulations at charging voltages of 400 V, 500 V, and 600 V revealed a pronounced reverse force in each case, significantly degrading launch efficiency. To counter this, the SCR was replaced with an insulated gate bipolar transistor (IGBT), and the coil was driven using a 500 Hz switching frequency with a duty cycle of 0.8. This configuration effectively suppressed the reverse force and maintained the projectile’s velocity near its maximum across all tested voltages, confirming the practicality and efficiency of the proposed approach.

title: An Adaptive Decomposed Proximal Policy Optimization Approach for Multi-Objective Home Health Care Routing and Scheduling
authors: Jichao Lv, Ying Li, Hui Liu, Huizhi Liu, Xiaoxu Zhang, Jie Tian
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Trends in Computational Intelligence (NTCI)
abstract: The rising demand for Home Health Care (HHC) makes its operational efficiency a critical issue. The HHC routing and scheduling problem is a complex, multiobjective combinatorial optimization challenge that aims to balance conflicting goals, including minimizing travel distance, maximizing skill matching, and ensuring punctuality. To tackle this NP-hard problem, this paper proposes the Adaptive Decomposed Proximal Policy Optimization (ADPPO), a novel reinforcement learning framework. The core of AD-PPO is the integration of a decomposition strategy into a Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) agent. This breaks the problem into a set of directionally-focused subproblems guided by reference vectors. The key innovation is its adaptive mechanism: the agent dynamically evaluates the current solution’s position in the objective space and selects the most relevant reference vector to guide policy improvement adaptively. This allows the agent to focus its efforts on the most critical performance weaknesses intelligently. Extensive experiments on HHC benchmark instances demonstrate that AD-PPO significantly outperforms state-of-the-art multi-objective evolutionary algorithms in terms of both convergence and the quality of the obtained Pareto front, offering an effective new paradigm for complex scheduling problems.

title: PaSSER: A Platform for Evaluating LLMs in RAG
authors: Miroslava Dimitrova, Ivan Popchev, Irina Radeva
publish: 2025 International Conference on Big Data, Knowledge and Control Systems Engineering (BdKCSE)
abstract: This paper describes PaSSER, an open-source platform designed for the evaluation of RAG. Current evaluation tools operate with fixed configurations. This restricts researchers' ability to study the impact of retrieval settings on model performance. PaSSER addresses this issue by enabling the systematic variation of retrieval parameters while ensuring reproducible results. The platform integrates three key components. A web-based interface supports both normal and score retrieval modes with configurable similarity thresholds. A computational backend aggregates eleven evaluation metrics into a weighted composite performance score. Blockchain-based logging ensures that parameter settings and results are immutable and can be verified independently. A controlled evaluation using the Mistral 7B model demonstrates the platform's capability. Two similarity thresholds (0.85 vs. 0.55) were compared on a domain-specific dataset. The evaluation reveals measurable differences between lexical precision and semantic breadth approaches. The scope of this paper is limited to demonstrating the functionality of the platform. Blockchain integration provides tamper-proof experimental records. This addresses the challenge of reproducibility in RAG research, where parameter variations can significantly impact results, yet are often inadequately documented. Future development will focus on automated parameter exploration, expanded metric libraries, additional model integrations, and multi-domain dataset management to support larger-scale comparative studies.

title: Disturbances of the Electromagnetic Field of Maritime Vessels
authors: Samoilescu Gheorghe, Bordianu Adelina, Ciocioi Iancu, Solcanu Vasile
publish: 2025 14th International Symposium on Advanced Topics in Electrical Engineering (ATEE)
abstract: Electromagnetic disturbances influence the proper functioning of electrical and electronic equipment on board, with negative effects on communications, target location, navigation and overall ship control. Based on the electromagnetic map of the ship, the most effective anti-perturbative protection measures, methods and solutions can be established to ensure the functionality of the ship. The sources of electromagnetic disturbances on a seagoing vessel are presented. Also, the different types of attenuations are underlined.

title: Infrared Turbidity Sensors Application for the Water in Diesel Emulsion Stability Control
authors: Oleksandr Zabolotnyi, Andrii Khodieiev, Roman Trishch, Vitalii Zabolotnyi
publish: 2025 XXXV International Scientific Symposium Metrology and Metrology Assurance (MMA)
abstract: The main factor for using water-fuel emulsions as an alternative energy carrier is the homogeneity of the emulsion or its stability over time. Currently, emulsion homogeneity is checked by taking samples for analysis. This process takes time and requires additional human resources. This paper describes a technical solution for emulsion homogeneity monitoring. It consists of turbidity sensors mounted in existing emulsion storage tanks, an electronic module, and corresponding measuring instruments. An experimental setup was developed to test the metrological characteristics of the turbidity sensors using standard kaolin suspension samples. Experiments have shown that turbidity sensors have an extensive measuring range, high sensitivity, and a close-to-linear transfer function. Using turbidity sensors allows for monitoring the stages of emulsion breakdown, such as sedimentation, coalescence, and complete separation into two liquids. Fixing the moment of emulsion breakdown in real-time makes it possible to apply three different modes to restore emulsion homogeneity by repeated mixing at different time intervals. It will significantly reduce the time to restore the homogeneity of the water-fuel emulsion.

title: Case Study: Enhancing Customer Trust Through AI-Driven Post-Purchase Management
authors: Milena Kumurdjieva, Lyubka Doukovska, Nehla Ghouaiel, Ahmad Dhanani, Rodrigo Arenas
publish: 2025 International Conference on Big Data, Knowledge and Control Systems Engineering (BdKCSE)
abstract: Artificial Intelligence (AI), broadly defined as computational systems capable of performing tasks that typically require human intelligence, has advanced rapidly in recent years. A particularly transformative development is the rise of agentic AI, autonomous, goal-driven, and adaptive systems capable of reasoning and acting independently in dynamic environments. These technologies are becoming powerful drivers of innovation in the e-commerce and retail sectors, fundamentally reshaping how businesses engage with consumers and manage operations. One critical area in retail is customer satisfaction and brand trust, where online reviews serve as a key post-purchase feedback channel. Despite a benchmark maximum response rate of 69%, at least 30-40% of reviews remain unanswered, negatively impacting customer satisfaction and trust. In this paper, we propose an AI-driven solution designed to enhance the speed, efficiency, and quality of responses to negative customer reviews. Our approach outperforms current manual, automated, and semi-automated methods, offering a scalable and effective tool for improving customer engagement and brand perception. This solution is intended to assist product quality and customer experience teams, not to replace them, by augmenting their capabilities with intelligent automation.

title: Contact Force Control for Surface Electric Impedance Measurements
authors: Martin Ralchev, Valentin Mateev, Iliana Marinova, Georgi Kotlarski, Stefan Valkov, Maria Ormanova
publish: 2025 XXXV International Scientific Symposium Metrology and Metrology Assurance (MMA)
abstract: Here is presented a contact force control measurement setup and a new methodology for surface electric impedance testing. It is based on Agilent/Keysight 4294A impedance analyzer and 16451B test fixture, where a pressure sensor is added for precise contact force control. Results about contact static resistance characteristics against the contact force applied are presented. A new measurement methodology for electric contact resistance determination by force component from total film-coated sample electric impedance is introduced in this research. Contact resistance is isolated from the total resistance results by the force difference approach, applied by the proposed measurement setup.

title: Selection of Measures to Reduce the Risk of Road Accidents
authors: Vladimir Klyavin, Svetlana Galkina, Anatoly Pogodaev, Anton Sysoev, Galina Borovkova
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: The article discusses the methodology for selecting measures to reduce the risks of road accidents. The proposed methodology is characterized by minimizing the necessary data for the selection of measures with limited funding or to achieve the required level of risks of road accidents, which ensures its effectiveness and cost-effectiveness. The methodology is based on an algorithm for managing organizational systems based on the method of inverse calculations to reduce by a given amount and an integer linear programming method in conditions of limited funding. The use of a point system makes the justification of the choice of events simple and convenient for making management decisions.

title: Robot Trajectory Tracking with Pid Control
authors: Zayar Aung, Nu Nu War, Stanislav Viktorovich Shidlovsky, Phyu Linn Thet Tin
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: This article presents the implementation and evaluation of a scalable integral derivative PID controller for tracking the trajectory of a Turtlebro56 mobile robot. The controller is designed to accurately follow preset trajectories, minimizing errors in location and tilt angles. The system has been tested as part of the robot operating system(ROS) platform both in simulation and in real conditions. According to the PID testing results, this approach can provide reliable and trouble-free navigation, and comparative studies show its effectiveness compared to basic methods.

title: Human Daily Activity Recognition using Spectrogram and 2D-CNN Through Doppler Radar
authors: Sachin Bhingikar, Rishi Raj Sharma
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Computing and Communication Technologies (CONECCT)
abstract: The identification and analysis of human daily activities has garnered substantial attention in recent years, driven by its expansive applications in areas including healthcare, surveillance, and intelligent environments. This study introduces an approach for the recognition of human daily activities through Doppler radar. The Doppler radar technology efficiently captures micro-Doppler signatures associated with various human activities. These signals undergo pre-processing involving noise reduction and filtering through low pass filter and spatial filter which enhances data quality. Subsequently, a 2D-CNN has been utilized to develop a system which recognize daily activity and, achieved an accuracy of $99.74 \%$. This validates the robustness and reliability of the proposed analytical framework. Results indicate the promising potential of leveraging Doppler radar technology in conjunction with deep learning for accurate and non-invasive monitoring of human activities.

title: English Classroom AIGC Conversation Partner Emotion Perception Transformer Teaching Strategy Alignment Mechanism
authors: Ying Wang
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Modern Education and Information Management (ICMEIM)
abstract: This study constructs the Emotion-Strategy Dynamic Alignment Transformer (ESDA-Transformer) mechanism. This mechanism collects multimodal data, including facial expressions, speech, and text, through a distributed heterogeneous terminal architecture. By integrating emotional features and dynamically adjusting teaching strategies, it achieves precise matching of teaching strategies with student emotions. Experimental simulation results show that ESDA-Transformer achieves an average emotion recognition accuracy of 85.6%, a maximum improvement of 20.4% over single-modality approaches. In a cross-chain communication scenario, when the data volume increases from 10 MB to 1 GB, the verification accuracy remains stable at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$99.7 \%-99.8 \%$</tex>, with a throughput of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$435 \text{MB} / \mathrm{s}$</tex> and an average latency of 2300 ms, meeting real-time requirements. Furthermore, the experimental group using this mechanism showed significant improvements in English scores, particularly in listening and speaking skills, and a significant increase in learning interest scores, demonstrating its effectiveness and adaptability in English teaching.

title: Resilience and Vulnerability in Electrical Power Systems
authors: Ghiulnar - Yelda Cherim, Cristina - Gabriela Saracin
publish: 2025 14th International Symposium on Advanced Topics in Electrical Engineering (ATEE)
abstract: The very fast digitalization of electrical systems has brought remarkable opportunities and significant risks. Infrastructures that were once largely isolated are now significantly interconnected, relying on Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA) platforms, Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT) devices, and cloud-based services. Considering this transformation has improved efficiency and flexibility, it has also broadened the attack surface available to malicious actors. Highprofile incidents over the past decade, such as the Stuxnet worm in 2010, the cyberattacks on Ukraine's power grid in 2015-2016, and the SolarWinds supply chain compromise in 2020, have exposed the vulnerability of power systems to sophisticated threats. This paper explores resilience and vulnerability as two complementary aspects of protecting electrical infrastructures. Vulnerabilities are examined from many perspectives, such as technical, organizational, and supply-chain, while resilience is understood as the ability to anticipate, withstand, and recover from many disruptive events. More particular attention is given to emerging approaches, including the integration of artificial intelligence (AI) with Security Information and Event Management (SIEM) tools, the use of microgrids for redundancy, and the role of cross-border regulatory frameworks. The discussion is highlighting the need for a holistic approach that combines technology, governance, and international cooperation. Such approach is essential for building adaptable, flexible infrastructures that are capable of maintaining energy security in an increasingly complex and uncertain threat landscape. The major importance of this work is that it brings together cybersecurity and engineering perspectives, showing how real incidents are translated into measurable impacts on power systems and suggesting practical ways such as AI based monitoring and digital twin models, to empower their resilience.

title: Teaching Innovation Research and Practice of “Robotics” Course from the Perspective of Data-Driven and Dual U Empowerment
authors: Shuai Cui, Bo He, Xuechao Ma
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Modern Education and Information Management (ICMEIM)
abstract: This article addressed a “data-driven, dual-U empowerment” teaching innovation system, taking the course “Robotics” as an example. because the rapid iteration of robotic technology and the changing application scenarios that have led to traditional teaching lagging behind social needs. Real-time collection of learning behavior data and the generation of personalized strategies were achieved, by using the intelligent monitoring system for talent development quality and the Deepseek-R2 large model. Established a method of “Exchange-Fusion-Dismantling-Combination” to form a three-tier progressive case. And innovated the PDCA engineering quality management model to form the PTDCA-U teaching design. Implement PTDCA-U teaching design through interactive learning and learning communities, to promote students threestage leap of “thinking - knowledge and action - values”. Practical experience shown that this system significantly enhanced overall capabilities and improved their chances of winning awards in subject competitions. It provided a replicable paradigm for the reform of new engineering courses.

title: Improving Accuracy in Dynamic Systems Through Adaptive Identification of Model Errors Within the Kalman Filter Structure
authors: Dimitar Dichev, Iliya Zhelezarov, Tsanko Karadzhov, Borislav Georgiev, Oleksandr Kupriyanov, Ralitza Dicheva
publish: 2025 XXXV International Scientific Symposium Metrology and Metrology Assurance (MMA)
abstract: This article presents an adaptive method for determining the variances of model errors in the structure of the Kalman filter, applied to dynamic systems with variable load. The method relies on the real-time discrepancy between predicted and measured values to update the variances in the system's dynamic model. The approach has been validated on an electrohydraulic system, where both the load condition and the angular velocity of the drive shaft are estimated using an extended Kalman filter structure. The results demonstrate improved estimation accuracy under conditions of unstable dynamics. The study also addresses metrological aspects related to the influence of model uncertainty on the final estimate, which is critical for enhancing the reliability of measurement applications.

title: FusionOM: A Dual-Channel LLM-KG Framework for Intelligent Operations and Maintenance Strategy Generation
authors: Keyu Liu, Siqi Wang, Xunchun Li, Jian Zhang, Xin Yao, Danhuai Guo
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Trends in Computational Intelligence (NTCI)
abstract: Operations and Maintenance (O&M) strategies in safety-critical systems often rely on manual workflows that are time-consuming and error-prone. Recent advances in Large Language Models (LLMs) and Knowledge Graphs (KGs) enable new opportunities for intelligent, automated O&M decision support. This manuscript proposes FusionOM, a dual-channel retrieval and reasoning framework that integrates semantic Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) with Graph-based RAG (GraphRAG). The framework combines natural language understanding with structured domain knowledge to generate accurate, explainable, and context-aware maintenance strategies.Using 74 civil aviation accident reports as a case study, FusionOM improves cross-report knowledge coverage and reasoning faithfulness, shortens strategy generation from weeks to hours, and outperforms recent RAG/GraphRAG variants in coverage and consistency. The framework enables standardized, reusable reports and offers a scalable foundation for domain-adaptive O&M decision support across industries.

title: Demagnetization in V-shaped IPMSM: A Fusion of Finite Element Analysis and Machine Learning
authors: S Guru Raghu Raman, S Hari Venkatesh, R Manuprabha, H Renill, N Praveen Kumar
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Computing and Communication Technologies (CONECCT)
abstract: This work is based on stator current analysis for diagnosing demagnetization faults in interior permanent magnet synchronous motors (IPMSM). The fault severity level ranges from $5 \%$ to $25 \%$, with intermediate levels of $10 \%, 15 \%$, and $20 \%$ being assessed. The investigation is carried out on a 0.55 kW finite element IPMSM model and stator current datasets were extracted for each severity for diagnosing demagnetization. The early detection of demagnetization fault is a key issue concerning efficiency, maintenance, and operation failure to be avoided. Machine learning techniques are employed to estimate the degree of demagnetization. A systematic data-pipeline preprocessing based on feature scaling and supervised learning was established for training able models that interpret nonlinear relationships in motor current signals. The proposed approach would be able to detect the fault at the earliest stage of $5 \%$ severity. The gradient boosting regressor algorithm provides maximum accuracy with better values for mean squared error and mean absolute error.

title: A Multi-Preference Modified Inverted Generational Distance Indicator Guided Algorithm for Multi-objective Optimization
authors: Xiang Huang, Bingyang Wang, Zhenpeng Xu, Fei Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Trends in Computational Intelligence (NTCI)
abstract: By directing the search toward regions of the Pareto front that are of interest to decision makers, preference-based multi-objective evolutionary algorithms have received significant interest. However, research that integrates performance indicators into the design of preference-based algorithms remains limited. In this work, we propose a Multi-Preference Indicator-Guided Algorithm (MPIGA), which aims to assist decision makers in identifying the most relevant optimal solutions. A coordinate transformation based multi-preference framework is introduced to more effectively reflect the preferences of decision makers. Subsequently, a preference-modified inverted generational distance indicator (PIGD${ }^{+}$) is designed to effectively guide the search process. Finally, comparative experiments conducted on the DTLZ benchmark suite against several representative preference-based evolutionary algorithms demonstrate that MPIGA outperforms the competing algorithms.

title: Filtering and Batch Processing of Correlations in R: A Prototype Framework
authors: Adam Bela Horvath
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Symposium on Computational Intelligence and Informatics (CINTI)
abstract: Exploratory Data Analysis (EDA) is a cornerstone of quantitative research, providing the foundation for uncovering descriptive statistical patterns and preparing data for inferential modeling. While descriptive statistics and visualizations are well-established, the methodological bridge between descriptive and inferential analysis-association measures-remains complex. Different correlation measures must be selected depending on data types, and issues such as significance testing, spurious associations, and the exponential growth of pairwise comparisons in large datasets present significant challenges. Existing R functions such as cor.test() and cor() (base R), as well as rcorr() (Hmisc) and correlation() (easystats), each offer partial solutions. However, these functions are either limited to pairwise outputs, lack significance filtering, or introduce dependencies on external packages, which constrains their usability for large-scale exploratory tasks. To address these shortcomings, this paper presents a prototype algorithm implemented exclusively in base $\mathbf{R}$. The algorithm is capable of compactly reporting results, returning structured outputs suitable for further processing, and filtering associations based on statistical significance. By accepting flexible parameter ranges, it reduces the computational burden of testing all possible variable pairs, focusing only on theoretically meaningful relationships. Although the current version is a prototype, essential future developments include handling missing values, validating user-defined intervals, expanding support to multiple association measures, and enabling automated result export. This contribution provides a scalable, extensible framework that enhances the efficiency and interpretability of association analysis, offering researchers a practical tool for managing complex, high-dimensional datasets.

title: Mathematical Modeling of the «Artificial Lungs–Isolation Breathing Apparatus» System: Assumptions, Structure, and Validation Approaches
authors: Kirill Slezin, Nikolay Gomzov, Yuri Gromov, Vasiliy Pogonin
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: A mathematical model of the "Artificial Lungs – Insulating Breathing Apparatus" (AL–IBA) system is proposed to analyze gas exchange, sorption, and thermal processes. The model reproduces real breathing modes, predicts protective action time, and serves as a tool for virtual experiments and design optimization.

title: Circular Slot Antenna Array: A Design for Ultra-Wideband Applications
authors: A J Sharath Kumar, T P Surekha, H M Nethravathi, R Anusha
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Computing and Communication Technologies (CONECCT)
abstract: Objectives: To design a small size planar microstrip antenna for use in ultrawideband applications. Methods: To make the antenna work in the ultra-wideband frequency range of 2 to 13 GHz the microstrip antenna of round shape is considered for the design. A circular slot in the antenna is made to obtain the desired operating frequency in the ultrawideband range. Along with obtaining the desired operating frequency it is important to obtain the gain the frequency range. So to do so the antenna array structure is considered. To reduce the burden of input signaling a single but unique inset fed power divider is considered to feed signal to the antenna. Findings: In this study, a circular slot-shaped antenna array is suggested. The suggested antenna has an ultrawide band frequency range of operation. Antennas with a circular shape provide lower return loss, higher gain, and greater directivity. The array’s primary purpose is to increase the antenna’s gain. The antenna is created using the inset feed approach. Design formulae are used to establish the size and feed method. The simulation findings demonstrate an excellent return loss (reflection coefficient) of -40 dB, which is well below the benchmark of 10 dB, and an estimated 8 GHz bandwidth ($2.42-18.21$ GHz). At the target frequency, the values for gain and VSWR are 6 dB at 13 GHz and 1.8034, respectively. At the intended frequency, the suggested antenna exhibits acceptable impedance match characteristics. Novelty: A round circular shaped antenna was considered in the literature to design ultra-wideband applications. But this leads to spurious radiation because of the continuous patch structure. To guide the currents and reduce the spurious radiation a circular slot is considered in the design which is by itself novel according to the knowledge of the author.

title:
Two-Layer FFR with Dynamic R
                    <sub>th</sub>
                    : Impact of User Composition
authors: Muhammad Yaser, Iskandar Iskandar, Mohammad Sigit Arifianto, Khoirul Anwar
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Telecommunication Systems, Services, and Applications (TSSA)
abstract: We investigate a two-layer Fractional Frequency Reuse (FFR) macrocell where bandwidth is split into inner/outer pools and the outer layer uses reuse-3. A dynamic threshold radius Rth follows the inner/outer user composition to balance load under equal bandwidth sharing and equal-share scheduling, with propagation modeled by 3GPP UMa and noise scaled with bandwidth. The Monte-Carlo simulations also estimate total cell capacity, spectral efficiency, and Jain’s fairness. With the composition changes from 75/25 to 50/50 and further to 25/75 (inner/outer), the distribution of capacities moves to the right and the mean-capacity increases by about 25% and then 34% (cumulative 68%), which is equal to the shift of the median CDF 28-31% per step (cumulative 69%). Spectral efficiency increases by about 23.5% and then 37.5% (cumulative 67.6%), with very small error bars indicating low variability between replications. Meanwhile, Jain’s Fairness Index decreases from 0.73 to 0.69 and 0.41, also confirming the efficiency-fairness trade-off for the baseline policy. These trends align with interferer-thinning in the reuse-3 outer layer and better utilization of effective spectrum as the outer pool serves more users.

title: Task-Driven Dynamic Metadata Mapping for Scalable and Privacy-Aware Blockchain-Based Content Governance
authors: Yangfei Lin, Chen Zhang, Hasibageng Boerzhijin
publish: 2025 International Conference on Trustworthy Big Data and Artificial Intelligence (ICTBAI)
abstract: Blockchain-based systems ensures data immutability and traceability, making them well suited for decentralized content governance. However, conventional metadata anchoring strategies remain static and task-agnostic, resulting in suboptimal trade-offs between auditability, privacy, and scalability. To address this limitation, we propose a Task-Driven Dynamic Metadata Mapping (TDMM) mechanism that adapts anchoring strategies based on task semantics and user roles. TDMM classifies metadata into three distinct anchoring types: full on-chain anchoring for audit-critical tasks, selective disclosure via zero-knowledge proofs (ZKPs) for sensitive attributes, and off-chain reference anchoring for general-purpose metadata. A dedicated mapping controller dynamically routes metadata fields to the appropriate anchoring mode according to predefined task policies. To preserve privacy without sacrificing verifiability, TDMM incorporates a hybrid ZKP architecture that processes proofs off-chain while anchoring verification results on-chain. We implement TDMM on a Hyperledger Fabric network, augmented with IPFS and Circom-based ZKP tooling. Experimental results show that TDMM significantly reduces on-chain storage overhead, lowers re-identification risk, and supports task-appropriate latency and throughput trade-offs, demonstrating its effectiveness in balancing transparency, privacy, and scalability in decentralized metadata governance.

title: Transient Analysis of Symmetrical Three-Phase Sudden Short-Circuit at Stator-Winding Terminals of a Loaded Salient-Pole Synchronous Alternator
authors: Mircea M. Radulescu
publish: 2025 14th International Symposium on Advanced Topics in Electrical Engineering (ATEE)
abstract: Only sudden short-circuits at the open-circuit stator terminals of synchronous alternators are analytically studied in monographic and periodical technical literature, even if they hardly ever occur in industrial practice. Hence, an analytical approach is developed in this paper for the transient response to a symmetrical three-phase sudden short-circuit occurring at stator terminals of a stand-alone three-phase salient-pole synchronous alternator, which is initially operating under loaded steady-state conditions. Closed-form analytical expressions are derived for the transient temporal functions of electrical current strengths in stator-phase, rotor-field and short-circuited-damper windings, as well as of the resistant electromagnetic torque of the considered salient-pole synchronous alternator, during the three-phase sudden short-circuit process. The transient analysis is corroborated by meaningful case-study numerical results.

title: On the Benefits of Teaching and Learning Symmetries Using AR and VR
authors: João Guerreiro, Miguel Sales Dias, José Barros, Rosário D. Laureano, Patrícia Costa
publish: 2025 International Conference on Graphics and Interaction (ICGI)
abstract: This study explores the use of Augmented Reality (AR) and Virtual Reality (VR) in teaching-learning geometric transformations, with a particular focus on translation and glide reflection, when compared to Traditional teaching methodologies (T). Mobile applications were developed to deliver interactive lessons through both AR and VR modalities. Three student groups-AR, VR, and T-were compared using performance tests and user feedback. Inference statistics analysis indicates that both AR and VR significantly enhance learning outcomes when compared to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$T$</tex>, with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$V R$</tex> offering a slightly greater sense of presence. The findings support the integration of immersive technologies into mathematics education to improve conceptual understanding and foster student engagement.

title: mAP-C: A Coverage-Based Metric for Robust Cross-Instrument Sunspot Detection Using YOLOv8
authors: Ignacio Martínez Hernández, César A. Astudillo, Claudio Tenreiro, Sergio A. Velastin
publish: 2025 15th IEEE International Conference on Pattern Recognition Systems (ICPRS)
abstract: Sunspot detection is critical for mitigating space weather impacts, yet evaluating models across datasets with divergent annotation granularities remains challenging. Traditional IoU-based metrics often misrepresent performance when predicted and ground truth bounding boxes differ in precision (e.g., tight predictions vs. loose annotations). We propose Coverage-based Mean Average Precision (mAP-C), which measures the fraction of a predicted box overlapping any part of a ground truth region, enabling fairer cross-instrument evaluation. Using YOLOv8 trained on two datasets (OGAUC: tight annotations; ROB: loose annotations), we demonstrate that models trained on OGAUC achieve mAP-C@0.6 > 0.81 on ROB—indicating robust detection—while traditional IoU metrics fall to <0.12 due to strict geometric alignment requirements. Training on a fusion of both datasets yields balanced performance (mAP-C@0.6: 0.77 on OGAUC, 0.80 on ROB). These results validate mAP-C as a more reliable metric for multi-instrument sunspot detection, supporting consistent evaluation in operational space weather monitoring.

title: A Novel Rat Robot: Multi Degree of Freedom Motion Control_supp6-3648651.mp4
authors: le zhang
abstract: Objective: The development of brain-computer interface (BCI) technology has enabled animals to execute movements in accordance with human intent. The rat robot represents a novel robotic system based on BCI technology. However, due to limitations in electrode fabrication techniques and the use of simplistic control strategies, current rat robots are restricted to limited movement patterns, which hinder their applicability in real-world scenarios. To address these challenges, we have developed a portable wireless neural stimulator and a novel 3D integrated stimulating electrode. By refining the locomotion control strategy, we aim to achieve complex, high-degree-of-freedom movement in rat robot systems. Methods: 3D integrated electrodes were implanted into the rats' head, with no reward-based training required. By utilizing a wearable wireless stimulation backpack to connect the electrodes and deliver electrical stimulation to multiple brain regions, thereby enabling the rat to perform forward movement, turning, and stopping behaviors. Results: The experimental results demonstrate that under optimized stimulation parameters, the forward speed of the rat robot can be controlled to achieve 31.06 ± 1.21 m/min, the turning angle can reach up to 150 ± 1.22°, and the stopping duration can be flexibly adjusted. Furthermore, we presented a practical scenario in which the rat robot successfully executed a predefined navigation task in a real-world environment, thereby validating its high degree of movement flexibility and control precision. Conclusion: This study achieved high-degree-of-freedom motion control of rat robots without the need for reward-based training, which was previously unattainable. Significance: This research establishes a crucial foundation and provides valuable technical references for the application of animal robots in fields such as information reconnaissance and wreckage search and rescue operations.

title: An Information-Theoretic Framework for Receiver Quantization in Communication
authors: Jing Zhou, Shuqin Pang, Wenyi Zhang
abstract: We investigate information-theoretic limits and design of communication under receiver quantization. Unlike most existing studies that focus on low-resolution quantization, this work is more focused on the impact of weak nonlinear distortion due to resolution reduction from high to low. We consider a standard transceiver architecture, which includes an independent and identically distributed (i.i.d.) complex Gaussian codebook at the transmitter, and a symmetric quantizer cascaded with a nearest neighbor decoder at the receiver. Employing the generalized mutual information (GMI), an achievable rate under general quantization rules is obtained in an analytical form, which shows that the rate loss due to quantization is log (1 + γSNR), where SNR is the signal-to-noise ratio at the receiver front-end, and γ is determined by thresholds and levels of the quantizer. Based on this result, the performance under uniform receiver quantization is analyzed comprehensively. We show that the front-end gain control, which determines the loading factor (normalized one-sided quantization range) of quantization, has an increasing impact on performance as the resolution decreases. In particular, we prove that the unique loading factor that minimizes the mean square error (MSE) of the uniform quantizer also maximizes the GMI, and the corresponding irreducible rate loss is given by log (1 + mmse · SNR), where mmse is the minimum MSE normalized by the variance of quantizer input, and it is equal to the minimum of γ. A geometrical interpretation for the optimal uniform quantization at the receiver is further established. Moreover, by asymptotic analysis, we characterize the impact of biased gain control, showing how small rate losses decay to zero and providing approximations for the achievable rate under large bias. From asymptotic expressions of the optimal loading factor and mmse, approximations and several “per-bit rules” for performance are also provided. Finally we discuss more types of receiver quantization and show that the consistency between achievable rate maximization and MSE minimization does not hold in general.

title: Continuous Review and Timely Correction: Enhancing the Resistance to Noisy Labels Via Self-Not-True and Class-Wise Distillation
authors: Long Lan, Jingyi Wang, Xinghao Wu, Bo Han, Xinwang Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence
abstract: Deep neural networks possess remarkable learning capabilities and expressive power, but this makes them vulnerable to overfitting, especially when they encounter mislabeled data. A notable phenomenon called the memorization effect occurs when networks first learn the correctly labeled data and later memorize the mislabeled instances. While early stopping can mitigate overfitting, it doesn't entirely prevent networks from adapting to incorrect labels during the initial training phases, which can result in losing valuable insights from accurate data. Moreover, early stopping cannot rectify the mistakes caused by mislabeled inputs, underscoring the need for improved strategies. In this paper, we introduce an innovative mechanism for continuous review and timely correction of learned knowledge. Our approach allows the network to repeatedly revisit and reinforce correct information while promptly addressing any inaccuracies stemming from mislabeled data. We present a novel method called self-not-true-distillation (SNTD). This technique employs self-distillation, where the network from previous training iterations acts as a teacher, guiding the current network to review and solidify its understanding of accurate labels. Crucially, SNTD masks the true class label in the logits during this process, concentrating on the non-true classes to correct any erroneous knowledge that may have been acquired. We also recognize that different data classes follow distinct learning trajectories. A single teacher network might struggle to effectively guide the learning of all classes at once, which necessitates selecting different teacher networks for each specific class. Additionally, the influence of the teacher network's guidance varies throughout the training process. To address these challenges, we propose SNTD+, which integrates a class-wise distillation strategy along with a dynamic weight adjustment mechanism. Together, these enhancements significantly bolster SNTD's robustness in tackling complex scenarios characterized by label noise.

title: Low-Damping Impedance Control of Cobot With Jerk Adaptation on Biased Sliding Surface
authors: Xiangjie Kong, Silu Chen, Hongyu Wan, Chi Zhang, Chin-Yin Chen, Guilin Yang, Chenguang Yang
abstract: The model uncertainty and disturbance lead to an offset between sensed force and desired force by impedance model, which challenges stability and accuracy during compliant control especially when the impedance model is with high stiffness but low damping. In this article, a sliding hypersurface is formed by two cascaded first-order filters biased by force impulse and mismatch between desired impedance and filters’ dynamics. In this way, the force offset can be well estimated even when the impedance model is under-damped. Thereafter, the open-loop dynamics about the force offset is derived, and an adaptive jerk control is formed to attenuate the force offset exponentially. Moreover, passivity analysis demonstrates that this controller permits a wider selection range of impedance parameters, thereby enhancing its practical applicability. Specially, its sliding gain is designed as a first-order forced response to the norm of the force offset, so that no positive feedback occurs when the force offset and the composite velocity error have opposite signs. Simulation and real-time experiments on a collaborative robot validate effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: Sum Rate Optimization via Joint Beamforming in RIS-Assisted ISAC System: A Manifold-Based Approach
authors: Ahmed Samir, Ahmed S. Ibrahim, Mahmoud H. Ismail, Mohamed Elsayed
publish: IEEE Open Journal of the Communications Society
abstract: Integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) systems have emerged as a key technology for next-generation wireless networks. ISAC systems face a challenge due to the differing priorities between communication and sensing metrics: communication focuses on maximizing data rates, while sensing prioritizes accurate target detection. To address this, reconfigurable intelligent surfaces (RIS) are introduced to enhance beamforming control, thereby improving both communication and sensing performance. This paper presents an optimization framework for an RIS-assisted ISAC system, aiming to maximize the communication sum rate (SR) while maintaining an acceptable threshold for the sensing metric, specifically the signal-to-clutter-noise ratio (SCNR). The proposed framework utilizes a low-complexity Riemannian manifold optimization technique to jointly design the transmit and receive beamformers at the ISAC base station (BS) and the RIS phase shifts, following an alternating optimization (AO) approach. Specifically, the beamforming and RIS phase shifts are optimized over the complex cone and complex circle manifolds, respectively. To demonstrate the effectiveness of this manifold-based approach, the same problem is also solved using AO with classical semidefinite programming (SDP) optimization. Simulation results show that the proposed manifold-based algorithm outperforms existing methods in both communication and sensing metrics, while also reducing computational complexity.

title: Foundation Model-based Auxiliary Framework for Object Detection in Aerial Remote Sensing Images
authors: Wanjie Lu, Chaoyang Niu, Wei Liu, Chaozhen Lan, Shiju Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: When lightweight backbones pretrained on natural scene datasets are applied to object detection in aerial remote sensing images (ARSIs), the detection performance varies significantly. This variation stems from factors including the data domain gap, dataset scale, training configuration, and model architecture. Since remote sensing foundation models (RSFMs) are pretrained on large-scale remote sensing datasets and exhibit strong feature extraction capabilities, we propose an RSFM-based auxiliary framework to enable existing lightweight backbones to achieve enhanced performance on ARSI datasets of varying scales. Specifically, the RSFM is leveraged to efficiently extract features with robust and rich representational capabilities from input ARSIs. A foundation feature fusion module is designed to fuse the features extracted by the RSFM with those from the lightweight backbone, addressing the inadequacy in representational capacity of various lightweight backbones when extracting ARSI features. Furthermore, a feature aggregation and expansion module is introduced to enhance the representational power of the fused features. Experimental results on four ARSI datasets of different scales demonstrate that the performance of various lightweight backbones is improved when integrated with the proposed RSFM-based auxiliary framework. In most cases, this performance is superior to that of larger-scale networks. Specifically, on the DOTA 1.5 and DIOR datasets, the performance of these lightweight backbones (integrated with the framework) is significantly enhanced compared to that of state-of-the-art (SOTA) models. Collectively, these results validate the effectiveness of the proposed RSFM-based auxiliary framework, confirming its ability to effectively improve the performance of existing backbones and thereby facilitate the popularization and application of existing technical advancements.

title: Enhanced Counter-UAS Capabilities in Close-In Weapon Systems Using Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning
authors: Wonhyuk Yun, Seok-Won Lee
abstract: This study introduces a novel framework to enhance the counter-unmanned aerial system (C-UAS) effectiveness of Close-In Weapon Systems (CIWS) through reinforcement learning (RL). To address the challenges posed by the erratic maneuvering and swarm tactics of small UAS, we propose a hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL) architecture integrated with a curriculum learning strategy. Leveraging a high-fidelity physics-based simulation, our approach employs a two-tiered decision-making structure that decouples high-level target selection from low-level fire control and weapon aiming. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed RL-based agent significantly outperforms a sophisticated, model-based predictive controller designed to emulate the engagement logic of modern operational defense systems. The developed system exhibits robust performance across diverse engagement scenarios, including multi-drone attacks from various vectors, achieving quantifiable improvements in targeting precision and reaction time against highly agile threats. This research establishes a foundation for developing intelligent, autonomous defense systems capable of neutralizing emergent and evolving UAS threats in modern operational environments.

title: Bridging the Semantic Gap in Computational Color Design: A Neurocognitively Validated Framework_supp1-3648792.docx
authors: Lin Li
abstract: Against the backdrop of the AIGC wave reshaping the creative design landscape, color design is rapidly transitioning from intuition-driven to data-intelligence. However, a critical "semantic gap" persists between abstract human intentions and controllable parameters of generative tools. To address this challenge, this study proposes and neurocognitively validates a computational framework for semantic color design, grounded in the Chinese linguistic context. The framework integrates two core modules: 1) Semantic Deconstruction, which constructs a multidimensional color-semantic lexicon from Chinese multisource texts using natural language processing and 2) Parametric Mapping, which establishes a controllable model to map structured semantics to quantitative color parameters in the perceptually uniform CIELAB space. Critically, we employed event-related potentials to validate the framework’s semantic accuracy in this cultural context. Neuroscientific evidence has confirmed that colors generated by our framework elicit cognitive responses consistent with target semantics; the N400 effect was statistically equivalent to that of a highly congruent baseline (equivalence test, p < 0.01). The study further revealed a hierarchical contribution of color attributes to semantic conveyance: hue played a decisive role, followed by brightness, whereas the influence of saturation was limited. The proposed framework not only offers a scientific paradigm for bridging the semantic gap in color design but also provides a computational blueprint for next-generation AIGC tools, enabling them to move beyond randomness toward precise, controllable, and semantically meaningful color generation.

title: Temporal Information Reconstruction and Temporal Alignment in Spiking Neural Networks for Speech Classification
authors: Qi Zhang, Huamin Wang, Hangchi Shen, Shukai Duan, Shiping Wen, Tingwen Huang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Cognitive and Developmental Systems
abstract: Recent studies have shown that most spiking neural networks (SNNs) for speech classification only use a fixed temporal resolution, limiting their capacity to capture multi-scale temporal information. To address this challenge, we propose the Temporal Reconstruction (TR) method, which enhances its learning ability on multi-scale temporal information by leveraging the hierarchical temporal processing mechanisms of the human brain in speech comprehension, enabling efficient reconstruction of temporal representations. Additionally, we propose Temporal Alignment (TA) method to enable the residual connection being used between the data with different temporal dimensions. According to the experiment results, we have obtained a SOTA result 96.04% on Spiking Heidelberg Digits (SHD), and we have achieved a classification accuracy of 81.02% on Spiking Speech Commands (SSC). Furthermore, on the non-spiking dataset Google Speech Commands v0.02 (GSC), we can achieve the classification accuracy of 95.63%.

title: Asynchronous Event-Triggered Impulsive Decentralized Control of Complex-Valued Multilayer Large-Scale Systems under Deception Attacks
authors: Ni Yang, Liting Liu, Huan Su
publish: IEEE Transactions on Control of Network Systems
abstract: This paper develops an asynchronous event-triggered impulsive decentralized control scheme for a class of complex-valued multilayer large-scale systems with time-varying coupling strengths and delays, under deception attacks where adversaries achieve their objectives by tampering with historical data. Unlike existing studies on event-triggered impulsive control where all node controllers are activated synchronously, each node in the proposed framework independently determines its triggering instants based on its own state. Initially, the interconnection effects are neglected, and node-specific Lyapunov functions are constructed and analyzed. Subsequently, graph-theoretic techniques, combined with the Razumikhin method, are employed to handle the cross-coupling terms and to derive several sufficient conditions. These conditions guarantee the <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$p$</tex-math></inline-formula>th moment exponential stability of the closed-loop system while explicitly accounting for communication delays and attack probabilities. Finally, the theoretical results are applied to inertial neural networks, and numerical simulations demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed control strategy.

title: One-Step Network for Open-Set Jamming Detection and Parameter Estimation
authors: Wentao Wang, Yulong Gao
abstract: Jamming Detection and Parameter Estimation (JDPE) is critical for anti-jamming in wireless communication, but traditional two-step methods struggle with unknown deceptive jamming lacking training data. We propose One-step Network for Open-set JDPE (ONOJ) which using instance-level contrastive learning. In open-set scenarios, jamming of different classes have subtle feature differences due to similar generation principles, while same-class ones can vary significantly due to parameter disparities. To address this problem, we optimize the network backbone and region proposal modules, then introduce a novel aggregation method with unique prototype selection and a dynamic margin contrastive loss designed for jamming characteristics. These enhance open-set performance by balancing intra-class compactness and inter-class separability. Simulation results indicate that ONOJ demonstrates excellent adaptability and better efficiency in the real-world open wireless communication environment against unknown jamming.
