title: Probabilistic Model of Vehicle Safety Operation Risk Assessment
authors: Hui Li, YuJie Shi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Trustworthy Big Data and Artificial Intelligence (ICTBAI)
abstract: This paper first extracts driving behavior characteristics from vehicle data to establish corresponding risk scoring rules. Based on these rules, the model assigns risk levels and provides early warnings to effectively curb traffic accidents. Based on DBSCAN(Density-Based Spatial Clustering of Applications with Noise) and other methods, this paper conducts spatial and time series clustering analysis on operating vehicles after pre-processing, abstracts the normal vehicle operation track pattern, compares and discovers the characteristics of unsafe driving behavior of vehicles, and establishes a risk assessment score model to give the risk level and make early warning.

title: IoT-Integrated Microbial Bio-Batteries: A Smart Wastewater-to-Energy Framework for Sustainable Urban Infrastructure
authors: G.B. Santhi, Rajvir Saini, Mardon Rakhmatov, Mamataliev Marufjon Mamatjonovich, K. Sheela Sobana Rani, Dilli Ganesh V, Layth Hussein, Pradeepa D
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems and Pioneering Innovations in Robotics and Electric Mobility (INSPIRE)
abstract: The rising deadline and heavy pressure on clean energy, as well as the dire situation with wastewater management, are two problems that are exacerbated by the rapid rate of urbanisation and the expansion of smart cities. Traditional wastewater treatment facilities are energy-intensive and have created secondary pollution, while also posing challenges for the sustainability of the requirements of present-day urban systems. At the same time, megacities are increasing their power consumption, which is taxing centralised power grids and also contributing to greenhouse gas emissions. This paper aims to address two issues: one is the introduction of an IoT-based Microbial Bio-Battery (MBB) framework, designed to be both decentralised and sustainable for the generation of renewable electricity and wastewater treatment. The system utilises electroactive bacteria in Microbial Fuel Cells (MFCs) in conjunction with high-end graphene-based electrodes to enhance electron transfer efficiency and improve biofilm stability. An IoT-enabled sensor network, comprising pH, temperature, dissolved oxygen, and chemical oxygen demand (COD) sensors, can be utilised to monitor real-time values of critical operational parameters. Using secure protocols, data can be sent to a cloud platform such as AWS IoT Core. To achieve maximum power output and treatment performance, a robust control system is employed, utilising an adaptive AI-based optimisation model that incorporates reinforcement learning to control the system's conditions dynamically. The results of the experiments show a significant increase in conventional systems, with power densities exceeding those of the baseline MFCs. This improvement is accompanied by a COD reduction of 92.3% and a biological oxygen demand (BOD) removal of 89.7%. Moreover, the predictive analytics analysis, utilising AI, demonstrated a validity of 98.7% for the payable energy output and treatment level, which further contributes to the robustness of the framework. The offered MBB system addresses urban wastewater management and energy access issues, thereby enabling the development of environmentally friendly, self-reliant Smart city systems. Its dual-purpose concept only underscores how well it can be scaled up to fit into decentralised grids and IoT-driven urban agriculture, establishing a radical change towards resilient and sustainable urban residents. The adaptive control module employs a hybrid Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL) model combining reinforcement learning and neural networks for real-time optimisation of energy output and treatment efficiency.

title: Understanding Sarcasm in Kannada - Dataset Creation Contextual Cues and Sentiment Annotation
authors: Gayana M N, Shreenath Acharya
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems and Pioneering Innovations in Robotics and Electric Mobility (INSPIRE)
abstract: Sarcasm detection plays a crucial role in sentiment analysis and natural language understanding, especially in low-resource languages like Kannada. While existing models for sarcasm detection have achieved significant success in English—owing to the availability of large-scale annotated datasets and powerful language models—Kannada presents unique challenges. These include a scarcity of labeled data, rich morphological structure, and the frequent use of idiomatic and culturally nuanced expressions. This paper focuses on the data collection aspect of sarcasm detection in Kannada, outlining the strategies adopted to build a high-quality, manually annotated dataset. We outline the data sources, annotation standards, and protocols to guarantee data balance and quality across sarcastic and non-sarcastic classes. The language and technical difficulties that arose during the collection process are also highlighted in the report. The preliminary analysis of the data being collected has been presented as it lays a strong foundation for effective sarcasm detection in Kannada.

title: A Multi-Modal AI Model for Accurate Detection of Agricultural-to-Urban Land Transitions Using Satellite Imagery and Ancillary Data
authors: Sahana Sharma, Anushree Raj, Varuna Gangadhar, Khadersab Adamsab
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems and Pioneering Innovations in Robotics and Electric Mobility (INSPIRE)
abstract: Urban expansion often leads to the conversion of fertile agricultural land to built-up areas. However, current AI based land use change detection methods encounter difficulties in accurately separating short-term land cover fluctuations (such as seasonal farming cycles or construction phases) from enduring shifts like agricultural-to-urban transitions. These issues can result in incorrect classifications, unreliable assessments of urban growth, and ultimately obstruct effective long-term planning. This study addresses a key limitation in existing AI-driven land use change detection systems: their difficulty in clearly differentiating between temporary and irreversible land transformations. To overcome this, we integrate multi-temporal satellite imagery with detailed ancillary data, including cadastral boundaries, infrastructure overlays, and socio-economic layers. Our proposed ViT-LSTM framework captures both spatial patterns and their evolution over time, offering deeper contextual insights. This level of integration is especially vital for fast-growing urban centers like Bangalore, where informal development often conceals real land conversion dynamics. The method provides policy-makers and urban planners with a valuable tool for actively tracking, managing, and forecasting permanent land transitions with enhanced interpretability and accuracy. The research introduces a hybrid deep learning framework that fuses time-series satellite data with supporting datasets—such as cadastral maps, infrastructure plans, and socio-economic attributes—to improve the reliability of detecting permanent land use changes. Utilizing Vision Transformers (ViT) for spatial feature representation and Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks for modeling temporal sequences, the model establishes a strong foundation for analyzing where and how such transitions occur. The system is trained using Sentinel-2 multispectral imagery, ground-truth cadastral datasets, and official infrastructure records. Experimental findings show a notable increase in classification performance compared to existing models. Ultimately, this approach equips planners and decision-makers with critical insights to drive more informed, sustainable land use policies.

title: RIS-Assisted Full-Duplex Communication Systems Using ADC with Finite Bit Resolutions
authors: Ding Chen, ZengXiang Wei, Wei Zhang, Bin Zhou
abstract: Full-Duplex wireless is a promising technology in the beyond (B5G) communications, as it can in theory double the system capacity compared with the conventional half-duplex counterpart. This paper considers a full-duplex wireless system where the base station (BS) aided by a reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS) transmits signal to and receive signal from users simultaneously on the same frequency band. The key idea is to configure the RIS for mitigating the self-interference at the receiver antennas so that the analog-digital converters (ADCs) would not be saturated. By taking into account the quantization noise, we propose to maximize the weighted sum of the uplink and the downlink rates by jointly optimizing the reflection coefficients of the RIS and the precoding vector of the BS. The simulation results show the effectiveness of the proposed RIS-assisted full-duplex wireless system as its uplink-downlink (UL-DL) weighted sum-rate outperforms that of the conventional half-duplex.

title: Robust Neural Network Technologies for Predicting Power Consumption in a Robotic Integrated Energy System
authors: Nikolay K. Poluyanovich, Oleg V. Kachelaev, Marina N. Dubyago, Alexander A. Shurykin
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: The text discusses predictive control algorithms based on neural network forecasting to improve the efficiency and stability of microgrids, including mechatronic wind turbine systems, taking into account their dynamic characteristics, environmental uncertainties, and energy balance requirements. A method for implementing a decision support system is developed, enabling planned proactive control based on data collected from an electricity meter and obtained through a neural network forecasting model. The decision support system calculates deviations between forecasted and actual power consumption values and, as a result, provides recommendations to the distribution grid operator. Additionally, it allows monitoring potential surges and drops in electricity consumption by consumers, non-standard equipment operation, and further verifies the adequacy of the neural network model's performance.

title: X-Gen: Enhancing Radiology Report Generation via LLM-Driven Data Augmentation and Decoupled Training
authors: Chaohan Wang, Qi Chen, Minh-Son To, Numan Kutaiba, Jae-Gon Yoo, Yutong Xie, Qi Wu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Digital Image Computing: Techniques and Applications (DICTA)
abstract: The scarcity and limited accessibility of medical data significantly challenge deep learning applications in medical AI. Radiology report generation (RRG), a key medical AI research area, could greatly improve computer-aided diagnosis through automated X-ray image interpretation. However, obtaining paired <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$X$</tex>-ray images and reports is labor-intensive and restricted by strict regulations. Large language models (LLMs), such as GPT-4, provide a promising alternative by enabling cost-effective text data augmentation and report rewriting in varied styles. We rigorously assess augmented data's clinical accuracy and stylistic similarity to radiologist-authored reports through expert evaluations. Interestingly, augmented data enhances RRG model performance, yet performance declines when augmented data surpasses original data volume due to style distribution shifts. To mitigate this, we propose integrating a conditional variational autoencoder (cVAE) into the RRG model to separate medical semantics from writing styles during training, enabling better handling of augmented data's distribution shift. Our proposed method, X-Gen, combines data augmentation with decoupled training. Tested on two public Chest X-ray datasets and a private abdomen X-ray dataset, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$X$</tex>-Gen significantly improves the performance of baseline models, showcasing its effectiveness and versatility in X-ray report generation.

title: Single Satellite Image Super-Resolution up to X8
authors: Liuyun Duan, Michael Swaine, Nicolas Girard, Sebastien Tripodi, Sacha Lepretre
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Many applications require high-resolution and recent satellite images (e.g. mapping). Although low-resolution images lack spatial resolution, they have high temporal resolution (e.g. 5-day revisit time for Sentinel-2). When the area of interest is not covered by a recent high-resolution image or it is too expensive to acquire, we propose our super-resolution method to up-scale the recent low-resolution image in order to get a high-resolution image version of the input image. We developed a first model capable of increasing the resolution of any satellite image by a factor of 4, and a Sentinel-2-specific model that can increase the resolution by a factor of 8 (from 10 m to 1.25 m). Our method is GAN-based (faster than diffusion models).

title: Entropy-Guided Slice Selection for Weakly Supervised Binary ASPECTS Classification from Non-Contrast CT
authors: Mohammad Javad Shokri, Nandakishor Desai, Aravinda S. Rao, Yohanna Kusuma, Bernard Yan, Marimuthu Palaniswami
publish: 2025 International Conference on Digital Image Computing: Techniques and Applications (DICTA)
abstract: Timely and accurate assessment of ischemic damage is critical for acute stroke management. The Alberta Stroke Program Early CT Score (ASPECTS) is a standardized tool used to estimate infarct extent and guide treatment decisions. However, manual ASPECTS scoring on non-contrast computed tomography (NCCT) faces critical constraints: labor-intensive expert interpretation, substantial inter/intra-rater variability, time-consuming multi-region assessment, and poor sensitivity to early ischemic changes with subtle hypodensity. In this work, we propose a weakly supervised deep learning framework for binary ASPECTS classification (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\leq 6$</tex> vs. <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$>6$</tex>), the critical threshold for thrombectomy eligibility, to support treatment triage and prognosis without relying on pixel-level annotations. Our method begins with entropy-based slice selection to identify the most informative axial slices from each NCCT volume. A 3D convolutional neural network is then trained using volume-level binary ASPECTS labels, enhanced by auxiliary supervision from binary labels for each of the ten ASPECTS regions to encourage region-aware learning. This enables robust infarct pattern recognition while avoiding the need for detailed segmentation masks. Our method achieves strong binary ASPECTS classification performance (AUROC: <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 0. 3 6} \boldsymbol{\pm} \mathbf{8. 4 4}$</tex>) while substantially reducing annotation requirements, highlighting its promise for integration into realworld stroke triage workflows.

title: On-the-Fly Path Replanning Using Real-Time Road Condition Data
authors: Sushma Dubey, U. Esakkiammal U. Esakkiammal, Makhmudov Nurilla Normirza Ugli, Montater MuhsnHasan, D. Bhanu, S. Sri Gowri Reddy, M. M. Saydumarova, Deepa Deepa
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems and Pioneering Innovations in Robotics and Electric Mobility (INSPIRE)
abstract: The fast advancements in intelligent transportation call for quick and responsive solutions as roads become unpredictable. It proposes RoadAware-DIRL, which applies decentralised edge sensing, real-time data merging, and IRL to create a more effective framework for passing information between edge computing devices, thereby improving vehicular navigation. Static maps and re-updated traffic feeds are the mainstays of traditional routing, making it hard for them to deal with quick changes on the roads. With the help of decentralised sensors and an effective noise filter, RoadAware-DIRL fills this gap by keeping a constant track of the road and making sure the data is reliable. This Decision Engine behaves like a human does by using information from stressful navigation events from the past. In addition, a Predictive Obstruction Forecaster depends on recurring road changes to predict where trouble will occur and steer traffic in another direction. Hazardous routes are given higher penalties in a Contextual Cost Map, and MPC keeps making split-second adjustments to the planned path. Extra support for communication is available thanks to V2V and V2I layers, which set up a network of moving road scouts. This framework is better than existing ones since it can adapt flexibly, make decisions locally, and learn like a person. Improved performance, swifter handling of hazards, and less travel disruption support the usage of the system in both autonomous and semi-autonomous cars. The platform makes today’s urban roadways more resilient and aware of the situations they encounter.

title: CPINN-ABPI: Physics-Informed Neural Networks for Accurate Power Estimation in MPSoCs
authors: Mohamed R. Elshamy, Mehdi Elahi, Ahmad Patooghy, Abdel-Hameed A. Badawy
publish: 2025 IEEE International Performance, Computing, and Communications Conference (IPCCC)
abstract: Efficient thermal and power management in modern multiprocessor systems-on-chip (MPSoCs) demands accurate power consumption estimation. One of the state-of-theart approaches, Alternative Blind Power Identification (ABPI), theoretically eliminates the dependence on steady-state temperatures, addressing a major shortcoming of previous approaches. However, ABPI performance has remained unverified in actual hardware implementations. In this study, we conducted the first empirical validation of ABPI on commercial hardware using the NVIDIA Jetson Xavier AGX platform. Our findings reveal that, while ABPI provides computational efficiency and independence from steady-state temperature, it exhibits considerable accuracy deficiencies in real-world scenarios. To overcome these limitations, we introduce a novel approach that integrates Custom Physics-Informed Neural Networks (CPINNs) with the underlying thermal model of ABPI. Our approach utilizes a specialized loss function that constrains the data-driven model according to the system's thermal physics, complemented by NSGA-II multi-objective optimization with efficient convergence strategies to balance estimation accuracy and computational cost. In experimental validation, CPINN-ABPI achieves a reduction of 84.7% CPU and 73.9% GPU in the mean absolute error (MAE) relative to ABPI, with the weighted mean absolute percentage error (WMAPE) improving from 47%-81% to ~ 12%. The method maintains real-time performance with 195.3µs of inference time. Extensive evaluation on unseen benchmarks demonstrates robust generalization without overfitting.

title: Wafer Scale Engine as a Catalyst for LLM Evolution: Investigating Architectural Advantages and Practical Limitations of Specialized Computing Systems
authors: Said Gulyamov
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: The exponential growth of Large Language Models (LLMs) has created unprecedented computational demands, revealing critical bottlenecks in traditional processing architectures. This research examines Wafer Scale Engine (WSE) technology as a transformative solution for accelerating LLM performance, particularly analyzing recent innovations such as Mistral AI's Flash Answers technology achieving up to 1000 words per second generation speeds. Through comparative and inductive analysis methodologies, this study investigates architectural advantages of specialized computing systems while identifying practical implementation limitations. The research reveals significant performance improvements in text generation capabilities when WSE technologies are integrated with advanced inference engines. Key findings demonstrate that specialized processors can eliminate traditional memory bottlenecks while enabling parallel processing at unprecedented scales. However, implementation challenges including high infrastructure costs and technical complexity present barriers to widespread adoption. This study contributes to understanding the evolution trajectory of LLM acceleration technologies and provides conceptual frameworks for integrating WSE solutions into existing computational infrastructures, offering insights for optimizing large-scale language model deployment strategies.

title: An AI-Enhanced, Case-Based Approach to Blended C Programming Instruction
authors: Dan Zhang, Jianpeng Zhang, Dong Zhao, Xiujuan Ma, Jiawei Wang
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Modern Education and Information Management (ICMEIM)
abstract: With the rapid advancement of artificial intelligence (AI), traditional programming instruction must adapt to the evolving demands of interdisciplinary talent cultivation. This paper proposes an AI-empowered, casedriven teaching model for the “C Programming Language” course, integrating AI-assisted tools, real-world case studies, and ideological and political education to foster both technical competence and social responsibility. Practical implementation demonstrates that the model enhances student engagement, programming and data processing skills, and awareness of ethical and civic values. Comparative analysis further shows that students from different genders, regions, and programming backgrounds benefit in an inclusive manner, helping to narrow learning disparities. Future directions include expanding the case library, extending the model to other programming languages such as Python and Java, and addressing challenges related to data privacy and responsible AI use, thereby offering a sustainable pathway for curriculum reform in computer science education

title: Exploring Primitive Visual Measurement Understanding and the Role of Output Format in Learning in Vision-Language Models
authors: Ankit Yadav, Lingqiao Liu, Yuankai Qi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Digital Image Computing: Techniques and Applications (DICTA)
abstract: This work investigates the capabilities of current visionlanguage models (VLMs) in visual understanding and attribute measurement of primitive shapes using a benchmark focused on controlled <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2 D$</tex> shape configurations with variations in spatial positioning, occlusion, rotation, size, and shape attributes such as type, quadrant, center-coordinates, rotation, occlusion status, and color as shown in Figure 1 and supplementary Figures <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$S 3 \sim S 8$</tex><sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup><sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup>All Figures and Tables with the prefix ‘S’ refer to the appendix materials. Code: https://github.com/drkkgy/xploring-Primitive-Visual-Measurement. We fine-tune state-of-the-art VLMs (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2 B \sim 8 B$</tex> parameters) using Low-Rank Adaptation (LoRA) and validate them on multiple out-of-domain (OD) scenarios from our proposed benchmark. Our findings reveal that coherent sentence-based outputs outperform tuple formats, particularly in OD scenarios with large domain gaps. Additionally, we demonstrate that scaling numeric tokens during loss computation enhances numerical approximation capabilities, further improving performance on spatial and measurement tasks. These results highlight the importance of output format design, loss scaling strategies, and robust generalization techniques in enhancing the training and fine-tuning of VLMs, particularly for tasks requiring precise spatial approximations and strong <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$O D$</tex> generalization.

title: The Role of Socio-demographic Processes and Cultural Characteristics in the Economy Models
authors: Ilya Alekseevich Kozlov, Dmitrii Sergeevich Smirnov
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: This article reviews mathematical and statistical research on the interrelations between economic dynamics, socio-demographic transformations, and cultural factors. It highlights key areas such as demographic change, migration, digitalization, environmental challenges, and cultural identity, all of which significantly influence long-term economic growth. Studies demonstrate that population ageing affects labor markets, migration generates heterogeneous fiscal outcomes, digitalization alters job quality, renewable energy and green finance foster sustainable growth, and cultural identity shapes cooperation and institutional trust.Methodologically, the review covers regression models, fuzzy multicriteria indices, cluster analysis, machine learning, and system dynamics, with special attention to latent variables such as trust, cultural values, and life satisfaction. The analysis shows that most studies remain fragmented, emphasizing the need for integrative approaches that combine economic, demographic, cultural, and ecological dimensions. The article concludes that future research should expand interdisciplinary models, use big data and digital traces, and incorporate cultural and environmental factors to provide deeper insights and inform policies for sustainable socio-economic development.

title: Leveraging Machine Learning for Enhanced Open Radio Access Network (O-RAN)
authors: S.K. Maanav, Akanksha M Raj, K A Nethravathi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Computing and Communication Technologies (CONECCT)
abstract: The Open Radio Access Network (O-RAN) is transforming wireless communication by introducing flexibility, interoperability, and intelligent resource management. Traditional RAN architectures limit adaptability due to proprietary constraints, whereas O-RAN promotes vendor-neutral solutions through modular and open interfaces. This paper presents an ns-3-based simulation model integrating Machine Learning (ML) techniques to optimize O-RAN operations, focusing on handover decision-making. The study evaluates heuristic-based, distancebased, and ML-driven handover strategies, demonstrating that ML-enhanced approaches reduce packet loss, improve network throughput, and ensure seamless connectivity. Results show that the ML-driven approach dynamically adjusts handover triggers based on real-time network conditions, improving network efficiency. The ML-based handover consistently outperforms Reference Signal Received Power (RSRP) and distance-based methods, reducing packet loss to 0.5% for UE2 and 0.3% for UE3, compared to 2.7% and 1% with RSRP, and 1.3% and 1.2% with distance-based handovers. Additionally, ML achieves $\mathbf{1 5 - 2 0 \%}$ higher throughput with fewer performance dips. While distancebased handovers trigger six transitions, the ML method achieves better performance with only four, demonstrating improved reliability, lower packet loss, and more stable throughput.

title: Estimation of Missing Data in Multi-Channel Data Acquisition System using Polynomial Regression and Expectation-Maximization
authors: V Vivekanand, Deepak Mishra
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Symposium on Computational Intelligence and Informatics (CINTI)
abstract: The reception of data frames over long-distance, low-power communication networks is impacted by channel interference, often leading to partial data loss. This issue is particularly significant in systems with low-power transmitters. This paper introduces a method for reconstructing or predicting lost data samples using polynomial regression and the Expectation-Maximization algorithm. The approach separates the stationary and non-stationary components of the received signals and reconstructs them independently using various combinations of the proposed techniques. The optimal regression fit order for the non-stationary component is determined by minimizing the mean squared error (MSE) of the reconstructed signal. The proposed method iteratively estimates the distribution parameters of the signal and utilizes matrix completion to recover missing or corrupted data samples. The method is validated using sample data for launch vehicle telemetry system and evaluated under different levels of data loss. The performance of the proposed approach is analyzed across various regression configurations, with a comparative assessment of loss percentage versus MSE of the reconstructed signal. Results indicate that fitting the nonstationary signal component with polynomial regression of order higher than five, combined with Expectation-Maximization-based stationary signal reconstruction, yields superior reconstruction accuracy.

title: Electromagnetic Excitation of Acoustic Signals in Pipelines For Non-destructive Testing Tasks
authors: Vladimir Ivanovich Panin, Danil Dmitrievich Kholichev, Chye En Un
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: The author of the article consider the issues of electromagnetic excitation of acoustic signals and the possibility of its application to assess the overall corrosion condition of small-diameter pipelines. A description of a layout consisting of an electromagnetic excitation generator and an acoustic signal receiver is given. The results of experimental studies for steel pipes with varying degrees of corrosion are presented.

title: Enhancing Telemetry Link Reliability and Range in NLOS Environments Through Data Compression
authors: Daru Kristian Aji, Aldo Agusdian, Hamonangan Situmorang
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Telecommunication Systems, Services, and Applications (TSSA)
abstract: Modern remote monitoring systems critically depend on wireless telemetry links, which suffer severe degradation in Non-Line-of-Sight (NLOS) environments, leading to high Packet Error Rate (PER) and limited operational range. This paper quantitatively analyzes the effectiveness of data compression not just for bandwidth efficiency, but as a proactive channel mitigation strategy. The methodology utilizes a software simulation framework featuring a custom Channel Emulator, which combines a Log-distance propagation model to calculate large-scale path loss and a Gilbert-Elliot stochastic model to replicate the bursty error characteristics of small-scale fading. The results demonstrate that compression significantly enhances link performance, especially in challenging conditions. Specifically, in the simulated NLOS-Urban scenario, compression reduced the relative PER by 21.8%, which directly translated into a 14.3% extension of the reliable operational range. Furthermore, the corresponding reduction in ARQ retransmissions improved effective goodput by 11.8% and reduced average end-to-end latency by a substantial 41.1%. The findings prove that data compression is an essential strategy for building more robust, reliable, and responsive telemetry systems for demanding NLOS applications.

title: Assessing Empathetic Engagement in AI-Generated Clinical Dialogues: A Computational-Psychological Hybrid Approach
authors: Yoenie Indrasary, Ary Setijadi Prihatmanto, Metty Verasari, Slamet Risnanto, Wenti Frisca, Dhema Yunautama
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Telecommunication Systems, Services, and Applications (TSSA)
abstract: This study evaluates the empathetic quality of AI-generated clinical dialogues using a novel hybrid methodology combining computational text analysis and expert psychological assessment. We analyze verbatim transcripts of interactions between DeepSeek AI and role-playing patients, assessed by licensed psychologists against empathy criteria from A Computational Approach to Understanding Empathy Expressed in Text-Based Mental Health Support. Our results demonstrate significant variance in empathetic expression across dialogue segments, highlighting strengths in active listening but limitations in contextual emotional adaptation. This work bridges gaps between AI performance metrics and human-centered care standards in digital health interventions.

title: Renewable Energy based Interleaved Boost Converter
authors: Sayali Ther, Anukul Ghosh, Nimish Gotmare, Bharat Pande, Praful V. Nandankar
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: This paper highlights the design, simulation, and experimental evaluation of a two-phase Interleaved Boost Converter (IBC) tailored for photovoltaic (PV) applications. The proposed system aims to address challenges of high ripple, thermal imbalance, and low efficiency in conventional boost converters. By employing two boost converter connected in parallel with 180° phase difference in their switching, the converter achieves reduced ripple current, enhanced thermal distribution, and improved dynamic response. The system was simulated using MATLAB/Simulink and PSIM, followed by prototype testing under a 20 V solar emulator. The converter output achieved 38.2 V with <2.5% ripple and demonstrated a peak efficiency of 98.78% under controlled lab conditions. This design offers an effective solution for DC-link stabilization in solar-powered DC loads and battery interfacing systems.

title: Conformer-Driven Nonnegative Matrix Factorization: A Unified Optimization Framework for Multi-Channel Speech Enhancement
authors: Weiyu Li, Hangjun Che, Man-Fai Leung, Xiangguang Dai, Yuming Feng
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Trends in Computational Intelligence (NTCI)
abstract: A hybrid architecture integrating Conformer encoders with multichannel Nonnegative Matrix Factorization (NMF) is proposed for speech enhancement. The model leverages the global-local feature extraction capabilities of Conformer blocks while preserving the interpretable spectrospatial decomposition of NMF through differentiable multiplicative update rules. This study derive a unified optimization framework based on the majorization-minimization of the multichannel Itakura-Saito divergence, enabling joint learning of spectral and spatial parameters in an end-toend manner. The proposed approach effectively combines the strengths of deep learning and traditional probabilistic modeling: the Conformer encoder captures long-range contextual dependencies and complex acoustic patterns, while the NMF structure ensures interpretability and stability in spectro-temporal decomposition. Experimental results on the CHiME dataset demonstrate that our method achieves competitive performance across multiple objective metrics, including SDR, PESQ, and STOI, validating its effectiveness in real-world multi-channel speech enhancement tasks.

title: Learning-Based Cache Replacement Implementation in Content Delivery Network Testbed Using Machine Learning
authors: Hanif Al Falih, Akbar Febry Wahyu Andrian, Mohammad Ridwan Effendi, Ian Josef Matheus Edward
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Telecommunication Systems, Services, and Applications (TSSA)
abstract: The increasing demand for internet content has driven the adoption of Content Delivery Networks (CDNs) to reduce latency and improve user experience. However, conventional caching methods such as LRU and LFU have limitations in adapting to dynamic access patterns. This paper proposes a learning-based cache replacement strategy using the Learning Relaxed Belady (LRB) algorithm, implemented in a CDN testbed with machine learning capabilities. The system leverages user access logs and content metadata to predict future access intervals and guide eviction and prefetching decisions. The proposed system was deployed using NGINX, LightGBM, and Grafana in a multi-region CDN architecture. Experimental results show that the LRB approach achieves over 80% cache hit ratio (CHR), outperforming traditional heuristics in storage efficiency and responsiveness.

title: Multi-Channel Mobile Potentiostat for Real-Time Multi-Analyte Detection
authors: João Monge, Octavian Postolache, José M.D. Pereira
publish: 2025 14th International Symposium on Advanced Topics in Electrical Engineering (ATEE)
abstract: This paper presents a four-channel potentiostat platform developed for real-time multi-analyte electrochemical sensing. The system incorporates a printed circuit board (PCB) with the Artemis microcontroller, providing improved computational performance, power efficiency, and peripheral integration. Two sensor interface strategies were evaluated: a multiplexer-based architecture with a single LMP91000 and an independent configuration employing four LMP91000 potentiostat chips. Comparative analysis showed that the independent-chip approach offered superior signal fidelity, minimized cross-talk, and enabled pseudo-simultaneous data acquisition, making it more suitable for continuous monitoring. To support multi-sensor operation, the mobile application was updated to configure and visualize multiple analytes in real time. Additional hardware refinements included the adoption of an external programmer, compact dual-layer PCB layout, and exploration of over-the-air firmware updates. The system provides a compact, adaptable platform with applications in health monitoring, sports performance tracking, and environmental sensing. Experimental validation results are also included.

title: Interactive Feature Selection Using Differential Privacy
authors: Xiaoying Yang, Xaingyu Bai, Xinwen Zhang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Trustworthy Big Data and Artificial Intelligence (ICTBAI)
abstract: Amid increasingly stringent data privacy regulations and growing demands for cross-institutional data collaboration, vertical federated learning (VFL) has garnered considerable research interest as a privacy-preserving distributed learning paradigm. In VFL, where data is distributedly stored under strict privacy guarantees, traditional feature selection methods are not directly applicable. To address this challenge, this paper proposes an interactive feature selection approach based on differential privacy (DP-IFS). By introducing carefully calibrated noise during the processing of distributed matrices and mutual information calculations, the method enables the assessment of feature interactions and facilitates efficient feature selection without exposing sensitive data. Experimental results demonstrate that this method not only ensures robust privacy protection, but also achieves feature selection accuracy (79%~90%) comparable to state-of-the-art ciphertext-based approaches. Furthermore, it reduces the number of selected features by 25% to 55% compared to other advanced methods. This reduction not only enhances computational efficiency but also significantly lowers storage overhead, thereby improving the method's practical applicability.

title: The Earthserver Global Geo Datacube Federation
authors: Peter Baumann
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: We present EarthServer, a multi-Petabyte, multi-provider federation with contributing institutions in the US, Greenland, Europe, Israel, and Taiwan. Standards-based APIs allow location-transparent, lowcoding extraction, analytics, AI, and fusion in an extensible manner through a wide range of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3^{\text {rd }}$</tex> party clients. We give an overview on EarthServer, selected services, and the platform technology.

title: Bridging the Semantic Gap in Metadata Management using Large Language Models
authors: Valery Pyatetsky, Alexander Suleykin, Valentina Sorokina
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: Effective metadata management is fundamental to data governance, ensuring that data assets are discoverable, understandable, and usable across the enterprise. However, traditional metadata systems often remain purely technical, describing structures without conveying business meaning. This disconnect — known as the semantic gap — limits the interpretability and value of metadata for business users. To address this challenge, this paper proposes a Cognitive Data Catalog (CDC) framework that leverages Large Language Models (LLMs) to generate human-readable, business-oriented descriptions for tables and attributes using their names, data types, and sample values. A quantitative measure, the Semantic Gap Index (SGI), is introduced to assess the improvement in semantic richness achieved through LLM-based enrichment.Experimental evaluation with several LLMs demonstrates that the proposed approach substantially enhances metadata completeness and interpretability, reduces manual documentation effort, and accelerates data discovery. The results confirm the potential of LLMs to advance metadata management by transforming conventional catalogs into intelligent, semantically aware knowledge systems.

title: Decision Support System in Attendance and Payroll as a Part of IT Governance
authors: Vitradisa Pratama, Irsam Satya Gana, Fakhry Dinan Idris, Inayati Nasrudin, Audita Setiawan, Sukadwilinda
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Telecommunication Systems, Services, and Applications (TSSA)
abstract: IT Governance is a key structure that ensures that information technology (IT) serves the strategic objectives of an organization. IT Governance involves establishing policies, procedures, and structures to manage IT risks, optimize IT investments, and attain regulatory compliance. A good IT Governance structure enhances decision-making and organizational performance. One of the most critical aspects of IT Governance is risk management, which entails recognizing and containing various IT-related risks, such as data privacy and security concerns. Decision Support Systems (DSS) play a central role in assisting managers in making decisions through the collection and analysis of information from various sources. Using DSS at Super Plastin could make payroll processing and attendance tracking computerized, which could mean fewer mistakes and accurate payroll. DSS has made managing attendance and payroll easier at Super Plastin and gotten rid of mistakes. This convergence enhances decision-making through analytical models and expert databases.

title: Zero-Order Fuzzy Neural Network with Fractional-Order Gaussian Membership Function
authors: Xing Wang, Xuetao Xie, Jian Wang, Sergey V. Ablameyko
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Trends in Computational Intelligence (NTCI)
abstract: Fuzzy neural networks (FNNs) are widely used for their interpretability and efficiency. However, in high-dimensional scenarios, conventional zero-order models often suffer from numerical underflow due to the multiplicative aggregation of membership values. Existing models typically alleviate numerical underflow by increasing the width of the Gaussian membership function (GMF), which inevitably reduces semantic clarity. To achieve a similar effect while preserving interpretability, we introduce the concept of fractional calculus into the Gaussian kernel function and thus design the fractional-order GMF (FGMF). Based on FGMF, we develop an FGMF-based FNN (FGMF-FNN) to effectively handle high-dimensional challenges. Experimental results on high-dimensional datasets demonstrate that FGMF-FNN can significantly mitigate numerical underflow while achieving higher generalization performance than competing models.

title: Spanish-Mapudungun Translation using Transfer Learning for Low-resource Languages
authors: Hernan Lira, Luis Martí, Nayat Sanchez-Pi
publish: 2025 15th IEEE International Conference on Pattern Recognition Systems (ICPRS)
abstract: This work addresses Neural Machine Translation (NMT) for Spanish–Mapudungun, an endangered and digitally under-resourced indigenous language of South America with polysynthetic and agglutinative morphology. We explore transfer learning as a strategy to mitigate data scarcity, initializing Spanish–Mapudungun models from high-resource pairs (Spanish–English and Spanish–Finnish). Using a standardized 10,000-pair corpus, we show that transfer learning markedly improves translation quality in both directions over models trained from scratch. We further analyze whether the linguistic characteristics of the parent language—particularly morphological similarity—affect transfer effectiveness. Results indicate that both parent models achieve similar gains, suggesting that vocabulary coverage and tokenization dominate over morphological resemblance. These findings demonstrate the utility of transfer learning for endangered languages and underscore the need for linguistically informed methods and community involvement in revitalization efforts.

title: A model to Forecast the Impact of Chloride Ions on Concrete Systems Altered by Bio-additives
authors: Elena S. Dergunova, Margarita A. Goncharova, Valentina V. Dergunova, Inna A. Rybina, Irina I. Moiseeva, Valeria A. Goncharova
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: The article presents data on the construction of a model of chloride ion diffusion for concrete modified with urease bioadditives. The bacteria Bacillus subtilis with urease activity were used to modify the concrete. The factors influencing the inhibition of the penetration of chloride ions into the concrete have been determined: the presence of a bioadditive, the ratio of coarse aggregate to fine aggregate (sand), the water-cement ratio, as well as the concentration of chloride ions. A regression equation (estimation of the regression equation) was obtained using the Statistics software, and the overall quality of the multiple regression equation was checked using the Fisher criterion. The dependence of chloride diffusion coefficients in concrete on the age of modified concretes is considered, the model and experimental values do not contradict each other.

title: Experimental Determination of Curvature of RC Elements Subjected to Bending
authors: Ivan Ivanchev
publish: 2025 XXXV International Scientific Symposium Metrology and Metrology Assurance (MMA)
abstract: This article describes the author's experimental studies for determination of curvature of 12 RC elements subjected to bending. The deformations at different points of the cross-section were determined with strain gauges and inductive displacement transducers located in the compression and tension region of the sections. Based on the experimental results obtained, the deformed shape of the cross-section was determined and the curvature of the section was calculated at different loading stages.

title: Core Attack Mechanisms of Shellcode in Microsoft Word Memory
authors: Dora Jean Rosemond, Hluchy Ladislav, Michal Staňo, Agu Friday Ikechukwu
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Symposium on Computational Intelligence and Informatics (CINTI)
abstract: With the expansion of attacks, computer security has become a primary focus in protecting users’ privacy. When attacking a system, attackers must keep their remote shell active to perform post-attacks. That is, to maintain the stability of the connection. The injection and migration processes are suitable techniques for achieving this goal. However, it is not always easy to peacefully land on a device without prior infecting and/or bypassing the security measures set on the target device. Various techniques can be used to obtain that foothold access, for example, remote code execution, command injection, phishing, etc. Phishing is often a complex scenario; nonetheless, it can be highly significant for attackers. Due to the trust Microsoft Office has earned from companies, adversaries can exploit it through phishing to prepare a shellcode (payload) in Word memory, which is sufficient for the landing phase. In this paper, we will analyze the working techniques that usually help attackers obtain a callback upon arrival at the victim’s target.

title: Reinforcement Learning–Integrated Digital Twin for Proactive Fire Response Decision Support
authors: Renat Khabibulin
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: This paper presents a risk-oriented digital twin of fire response processes at fuel and energy complex facilities, calibrated using real data. The problem is formalized as a Markov Decision Process (MDP), where the reward function accounts for cost, time losses, and tail risks measured through Conditional Value-at-Risk (CVaR). Agent training is performed using tabular Q-learning with subsequent sensitivity analysis of criterion weights. Experimental results demonstrate that the combined strategy provides an optimal balance between average losses. Special attention is paid to the analysis of tail risks (upper 5% of the distribution), characterized by duration exceeding 120 minutes and losses 2-2.5 times higher than median values. A detailed 15-step algorithm for transforming the model into an operational decision support system is proposed.

title: The Role of Ethical Hacking in Healthcare Institutions
authors: Martin Voynov, Ivan D. Ivanov, Maya Atanasova
abstract: With the development of digital technologies, healthcare institutions are becoming increasingly dependent on connected systems, electronic health records and online communication channels. This, of course, opens up wide opportunities for more effective patient care, but at the same time significantly increases the risk of malicious attacks. To ensure real protection, it is no longer enough to use antivirus programs or firewalls - proactive, targeted and realistic security testing is needed. This is where the role of ethical hacking comes into play.

title: Integrating Data Center Infrastructure into Smart Grid Energy Management Systems
authors: Plamen Stanchev, Nikolay Hinov, Zoran Zlatev
abstract: The exponential growth of digitalization and artificial intelligence workloads has positioned data centers among the fastest-growing electricity consumers worldwide. Traditionally viewed as passive loads, modern data centers possess advanced energy infrastructures, such as uninterruptible power supply (UPS) systems, battery storage, and intelligent cooling, that can be leveraged as flexible resources for smart grid operation. This paper proposes an integration framework between Data Center Infrastructure Management (DCIM) and Smart Grid Energy Management Systems (SG-EMS) to enable bidirectional energy and information exchange. The proposed architecture coordinates local assets within data centers with grid-level control for demand response, peak shaving, and renewable energy utilization. A case study of a 10 MW data center equipped with a 1 MWh battery and 2 MW photovoltaic plant demonstrates that coordinated control can reduce peak grid demand by up to 18%, lower daily energy costs by approximately 17%, and provide sub-second frequency response without affecting IT service performance. The results confirm the potential of data centers to act as virtual energy storage units and active participants in smart grids. Future developments include AI-driven predictive control, digital twins for co-simulation, and secure interoperability between DCIM and SG-EMS platforms.

title: UAVs as an Interim Communication Solution in Cases of Emergency
authors: Ivan Ganchev
abstract: In recent years, Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) have emerged as a transformative solution for emergency communications, providing versatile, rapid, and adaptable capabilities that extend traditional networks’ reach and resilience. This paper <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">*</sup> explores the conceptual foundations, technologies, operational models, regulatory landscapes, challenges, and prospects associated with using UAVs in emergency contexts. Special emphasis is placed on case examples, comparative evaluations with traditional communication systems, and the integration of UAVs with satellite communication systems within wider emergency response ecosystems. The paper also incorporates discussions using real-world examples from China, Japan, Australia, and the United States. It assesses urban versus rural adaptations, comparative effectiveness to traditional methods, and examines key future trends, drawing on a wide spectrum of up-to-date research and development.

title: Intrusion Classification Using Machine Learning Models on Network Traffic Data
authors: Uday Chandra Akuthota, Mitesh Singh Rajpurohit, Lava Bhargava
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Computing and Communication Technologies (CONECCT)
abstract: In today’s fast-changing digital world, cyber-attacks have become more sophisticated and complex, making it challenging to accurately detect intrusions. These intrusions not only put data security at risk but also threaten the availability and integrity of important information, posing significant dangers to individuals, organizations, and society as a whole. This study proposes Machine Learning (ML) techniques for anomaly detection using the widely recognized CIC-IDS2017 dataset, which is a benchmark in cybersecurity research. The research evaluates each approach based on the performance of classifiers after preprocessing the data to remove irrelevant features that have minimal impact on attack detection. The results show that the Random Forest classifier, combined with the Correlation feature selection method, performs exceptionally well, achieving an impressive accuracy rate of $99.61 \%$. These results show the degree of efficiency of a robust data preprocessing strategy in enhancing intrusion detection systems’ capabilities in classifying attack traffic, namely DDoS, Brute Force attacks, scans, Webbased attacks, Bots, Denial of Service, and Heartbleed vulnerabilities. The comparison between total accuracy provided by these techniques makes such research valuable in terms of insights for optimizing cybersecurity defenses against dynamically correlated threats thriving in this digital age.

title: Performance Evaluation of GPU-Accelerated Molecular Dynamics Simulations with Controlled Atom Counts and Varing System Compositions
authors: Minsung Ko, Soohwan Jeong, Seong-Min Kim, Joongyeon Choi, Hyunggun Kim
publish: 2025 IEEE International Performance, Computing, and Communications Conference (IPCCC)
abstract: GPU-accelerated molecular dynamics (MD) simulations have enabled significant advances in modeling biomolecular systems and extended timescales. While system size, typically measured by atom count, is often used to estimate simulation performance, the impact of biophysical system composition remains underexplored. This study investigated GPU-accelerated simulation throughput using GROMACS on an NVIDIA Titan RTX GPU across eight atom count-controlled systems (approximately 82,000 atoms) with varying biophysical compositions. The benchmark set included water-only, protein-ligand, membrane-only, and membrane-protein systems, matched to the standard benchMEM system for controlled comparison. MD systems with high water and protein content consistently demonstrated superior GPU performance exceeding 30% compared to lipid-rich systems, despite equivalent atom counts. Membrane-protein systems exhibited modest improvements over membrane-only systems, likely due to more favorable domain decomposition properties. These findings provide quantitative insight into the influence of system composition on GPU performance and offer practical information for optimizing MD simulation systems in terms of biological complexity and computational efficiency.

title: The Implementation of the Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) for a Tourism Recommendation System in Greater Bandung Area
authors: Zidan Kurnia Arief Pratama, Bambang Sugiarto, Slamet Risnanto, Gunawansyah, Adriadi, Doni Romdhoni Witarsa
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Telecommunication Systems, Services, and Applications (TSSA)
abstract: Tourism is recognized as one of the most important economic sectors in many countries. The competitiveness of travel destinations continues to be important for local communities as well as the growth of national economies. Therefore, developing digital solutions that combine various tourism options in one system can help make it easier for tourists to choose destinations. This research aims to develop a tourist recommendation system in the Greater Bandung City using the AHP method which can help tourists choose destinations easily and precisely according to their individual preferences. Then the Rank Order Centroid (ROC) method is used to objectively determine the weight of criteria according to the priority given by the AHP decision. The result showed that the system recommendation exhibited good consistency in pairwise comparisons, with CI and CR values below 10 and it shows a satisfactory level of consistency. The digital platform is developed and successfully presents complete tourism information, including essential data about specific tourist attractions.

title: MoE-Enhanced-TTT: Advancing Medical Image Segmentation
authors: Yuming Chen, Qi Wu, Yutong Xie
publish: 2025 International Conference on Digital Image Computing: Techniques and Applications (DICTA)
abstract: Automatic medical image segmentation has become essential in clinical applications, providing valuable support for diagnosis, treatment planning, and patient monitoring. Recent research has improved segmentation accuracy by combining convolutional approaches with sequence modeling techniques such as Transformer. However, Transformerbased methods often face significant computational challenges, especially for processing high-resolution 3D medical images. In this paper, we propose an enhanced Test-Time Training (TTT) layer, called TTT-MoE, and integrate it within the advanced nnU-Net framework. Our TTT-MoE layer harnesses a Mixture of Experts (MoE) approach to enhance the internal self-supervised learning modules originally developed for the TTT layer. This methodology enables more effective extraction of clinically relevant features, improving segmentation performance across diverse anatomical structures and imaging modalities. The code is available at github.

title: On State-Space Models for Circuit Analysis : A Review of Causal Systems at the Limit
authors: Gabriel Sirbu, Dorel Aiordachioaie
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Electrical and Electronics Engineering (ISEEE)
abstract: This work looks to review the state-space representation for the case of systems with causality at the limit. Circuits with non-independent capacitors or inductors, as effect of the loops with voltage sources and, respectively, nodes with current sources, are modeled as causal systems at the limit. The effect on state-space equation is the appearance of the derivative of the inputs. This is a non-standard structure of state-space representation and sometimes creates difficulties in solving and integrating in the standard/classical form of various software tools. Two basic solutions are presented and discussed. The first one is part of the general method of similarity, which works with state-space equations. The second one decomposes the transfer function into two components, of which one is strictly causal and can generate the standard form of the state-space equations. The solutions investigated are equivalent from the point of view of the results. Two test cases are considered. A separate objective is related to the explanation of the methodology in developing a state-space representation starting from the topology of the circuit. The aspects considered are useful for engineers who work in the field of modelling and simulation and need accurate models from the system engineering domain.

title: Dynamics and Precision: Predicting Li-Ion Battery State of Charge through Voltage Analysis
authors: Elena Selim, Ion Voncilă, Mădălin Costin
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Electrical and Electronics Engineering (ISEEE)
abstract: This paper analyses and introduces a real-time method for estimating the state of charge of Li-Ion batteries using exclusively terminal voltage measurements. The study demonstrates that the battery voltage during rest period can be accurately estimated from data measurements under applied charging or discharging currents, without the need for explicit rest periods. Exponential models capture polarization and diffusion dynamics, and the predicted voltage closely matches experimental measurements during relaxation. The approach enables precise SOC estimation and can be directly integrated into battery management systems for real-time monitoring and energy management. Experimental results validate the method, confirming its effectiveness for predictive model and practical implementation in modern Li-Ion battery systems.

title: A Simplified Gate Driver Architecture for Achieving Fast Switching in Medium-Voltage SiC Power Modules
authors: Sudharsan Chinnaiyan, Qiang Wu, Pengyu Lai, Zhuowen Feng, Mohammad Dehan Rahman, Yuxiang Chen, Zhong Chen, Xiaoqing Song, H. Alan Mantooth
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th Workshop on Wide Bandgap Power Devices and Applications (WiPDA)
abstract: The gate driver is crucial for silicon carbide (SiC) based power electronics, by directly governing switching speed, efficiency, and EMI performance, while it also ensures reliability through protection against false turn-on, overvoltage, and short-circuit events. This paper presents a simplified gate driver layout for SiC-based medium-voltage power modules. The design employs dual gate driver ICs per switching position to supply the required gate current, thereby enhancing the switching performance of the power module. The proposed gate driver adopts a two-level hierarchical PCB design: one level integrates the driver components closely with the SiC dies for reduced gate loop inductances and fast switching speed, while the other provides high isolation to support medium-voltage operation. The connections from the gate driver to the power module are provided through co-axial pins for improved noise immunity. The proposed gate driver architecture was evaluated using a discrete half-bridge switch setup, demonstrating high switching performance with measured slew rates of 104.23 V/ns for turn-on and 152.38 V/ns for turn-off.

title: Modelling of 2-port MIMO Antenna for Sub-6 GHz 5G using Parametric Analysis
authors: Rahul Porwal, Nikhil Raj, M. V. Deepak Nair
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Computing and Communication Technologies (CONECCT)
abstract: A line-fed rectangular shaped 2-port planar antenna is presented with inner removal of metal suitably chosen in hexagonal shape for radiation in sub-6 GHz 5 G band. The Multiple-Input Multiple-Output (MIMO) antenna is designed through combining the techniques of space diversity with connected ground structure. A thin metallic connecting ground line is used to make it a true MIMO. The optimization of design is done using parametric analysis on the placement and thickness of connecting ground line. The size and operating bandwidth of the structure are $53 \times 20 \mathrm{~mm}^{2}$ and 3.17 GHz to 5.25 GHz, respectively. The final design offers a percentage bandwidth of 49.40% and a peak gain of 2.7 dBi at 5.00 GHz with minimum isolation value of 15.168 dB in the band of interest which covers 3.3 GHz to 5.0 GHz. A hardware prototype of the final design is fabricated and tested for S-parameters with suitable matching. The envelope correlation coefficient (ECC) <0.0015, mean effective gain (MEG) ${\lt}-3 \mathrm{~dB}$, and diversity gain (DG) approaching to 10 have been achieved. This antenna is suitable for sub- 6 GHz 5 G communication applications in today’s world.

title: An Intelligent System for Predictive Maintenance and Automated Troubleshooting in Laboratory Environments
authors: Abhijith L Kotian, Shivani Kamath, Sowmya Shetty, Shravya S M, Sharanya Acharya
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems and Pioneering Innovations in Robotics and Electric Mobility (INSPIRE)
abstract: Effective fault handling in university laboratories is important to ensure uninterrupted academic operations and prolong the useful life of technical equipment. Traditional fault handling practices are usually performed through manual time-delayed reporting that is isolated from inventory and maintenance systems. To overcome these limitations, an all-encompassing AI-powered fault reporting and resolution system is designed for academic settings. Developed on a contemporary full-stack web framework, the system follows a role-based approach in which students can report failures, technicians can monitor repair progress, and administrators can monitor overall maintenance activity. The main innovations include an AI-supported fault category prediction module utilizing the Random Forest algorithm, workload analysis employing a Workload Balancer algorithm, and a smart NLP-powered chatbot that helps users follow simple troubleshooting steps. The chatbot is driven by a locally trained model with the capability to understand natural language queries about technical equipment faults. In addition, an integrated analytics dashboard provides real-time insights into fault patterns, equipment status, and technician workloads, thus supporting data-driven decision-making. The smart and combined solution improves the time to fix faults, optimizes resource allocation, and increases the overall efficiency of laboratory maintenance processes.

title: Impact of Fuzzy Number Shapes and Aggregation Techniques on Evaluation Results via Fuzzy Signatures in Higher Education Accreditation
authors: József Hegedüs, Adam Schiffer, Kóczy T. László, Hatwagner F. Miklós
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Symposium on Computational Intelligence and Informatics (CINTI)
abstract: Ensuring objectivity in expert-based educational program evaluations remains challenging due to inherent subjectivity and uncertainty of the assessment processes. In this study, we apply fuzzy signature models to address these issues within the evaluation framework of the Hungarian Accreditation Committee (MAB). A generalized fuzzy signature structure was developed, that supports discrete answer categories and hierarchical question groups. We systematically investigated how key parameters-fuzzy number shape, aggregation operators, and defuzzification methods-affect final evaluation outcomes. Two types of fuzzy coverage sets (core-based and support-based) were tested across multiple configurations using simulated data $(k=100,000)$ aligned with typical expert response distributions. Statistical analysis, including paired t-tests and normality tests, revealed that the Largest of Maximum (LoM) defuzzification method combined with arithmetic mean aggregation and a core-to-support ratio of 0.75 yielded the highest classification accuracy ($83.77 \%$) and the most stable results. Core-based (Type 1) coverage consistently outperformed support-based (Type 2) coverage in 98% of tested configurations. These findings provide practical guidance for the design of robust and interpretable fuzzy evaluation systems and support the development of more transparent quality assurance tools in higher education. This work goes beyond mere comparison by systematically analyzing the sensitivity of fuzzy evaluation systems to parameter choices, which is critical for robust system design of accreditation models.

title: Enhancing Tiny Object Detection in Super-Resolved Sentinel-2 Imagery for Naval and Airbase Analysis
authors: Juan Francisco Amieva, Christian Ayala, Roland Perko, Sebastian Aleksandrowicz
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Detecting tiny objects in satellite imagery is a crucial task with diverse applications, such as environmental monitoring, urban development, disaster management, and the surveillance of critical transportation infrastructure. While Sentinel-2 (S2) satellite data provides rich spectral information, its moderate resolution poses challenges for identifying small-scale features due to limited spatial detail and mixed pixel effects. This study explores the use of super-resolution techniques to enhance S2 imagery, improving its capacity for tiny object detection. An annotated dataset was developed to identify aircraft and vessels across various areas of interest, enabling a comprehensive and detailed evaluation. The detection process leveraged a hybrid approach that integrates a YOLO object detector with a vision-transformer-based object density estimator. By combining these methods, false positives were significantly reduced, leading to notable improvements in precision and F1 score. These results highlight that super-resolved S2 imagery can serve as an effective and economical alternative for detecting tiny objects, particularly in scenarios where very high-resolution imagery is unavailable or cost-prohibitive.

title: Ground-Based Observations for Validation (GBOV): Latest Updates in Validation Products Generation
authors: Dc. Christophe Lerebourg, Rémi Grousset, Dc Jean-Sébastien Carrière, Dc. Marco Clerici, Dc. Nadine Gobron, Pr Esnerto Lopez Baesa, Dc Ana Pérez-Hoyos, Pr Jadu Dash, Dc. Somnat Paramanik, Msc Finn James, Pr. Jan-Peter Muller, Dc. Rui Song, Dc. Jasdeep Anand, Dc. Darren Ghent

abstract: The Copernicus Ground Based Observation for Validation (GBOV) service has provided Analysis Ready Validation data for almost a decade. This validation dataset covers several Essential Climate Variables (ECVs), including short and longwave radiation, vegetation products and Surface Soil Moisture. Initially dedicated to supporting the Copernicus EO (Earth Observation) product validation effort, GBOV has reached a worldwide community of users. In recent years, the final validation products, the so-called Land Products (LPs) have undergone major revision to address users' needs better and most importantly improve their relevance and quality. The work presented in this paper details the GBOV service evolution and achievements over the past 5 years.

title: Distributed Relative Localization for Homogeneous Multirobot Systems Through UWB Ranging and Limited Communications
authors: Zhiqiang Cao, Ran Liu, Billy Pik Lik Lau, Chau Yuen, U-Xuan Tan
abstract: Accurate and reliable relative localization is crucial for multirobot applications like exploration, search, and rescue missions. LiDAR-based solutions offer high accuracy in localizing surrounding objects; however, distinguishing homogeneous robots with similar appearances remains challenging due to the lack of distinctive identification features. In this article, we propose a fully distributed relative pose estimation approach by integrating LiDAR, ultra-wideband (UWB), and odometry measurements, allowing each robot to accurately and continuously localize its teammates without external infrastructure. Specifically, potential anonymous teammate robot clusters from LiDAR scans are tracked by a dynamic tracker. We then identify teammate robots from these tracked anonymous clusters using a joint matching strategy, ensuring reliable data association between robots and clusters. Finally, by combining the corresponding LiDAR observations, UWB ranging, and odometry measurements, each robot precisely localizes others while minimizing data exchange. The system requires only odometry data exchange through onboard UWB, eliminating the need for additional communication infrastructure like WiFi routers or mesh networks. Extensive simulation and real-world experiments demonstrate the effectiveness and reliability of the proposed relative localization approach.

title: DADS-SAM: DALoRA and DSCA Enhanced Fine-tuning for Port Oil Spill Detection Using UAV Imagery
authors: Shen Guo, Ying Li, Jiashuo Shang, Zi Wang, Jingyi Yuan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: With the increasing frequency of port trade activities, oil spill incidents pose severe threats to marine ecosystems. The complex port environments, characterized by diverse land cover types and intricate land-water interfaces, present significant challenges for oil spill detection (OSD). To address this, we propose a parameter-efficient fine-tuning (PEFT) approach based on the segment anything model (SAM) for port OSD tasks utilizing unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) remote sensing imagery. The proposed DADS-SAM freezes most parameters of SAM and performs PEFT only on adapters. Dynamic adaptive low-rank adaptation (DALoRA) enhances the model’s adaptability to port OSD tasks by incorporating dynamic adaptive low-rank matrices into the self-attention modules of the SAM encoder, while dual scale convolutional adapter (DSCA) improves the model’s capability to capture local features and spatial dependencies in oil spill regions. Since the original SAM model lacks class-specific segmentation capabilities, we further design a multi-class segmentation head (MCSH) for oil spill segmentation. This head obtains the output masks from the SAM decoder, adjusts their dimensions, and transforms them through two linear layers to generate class-specific segmentation results. To the best of our knowledge, this study is the first to apply a PEFT approach to port OSD tasks. The proposed method was evaluated on both publicly available port oil-spill datasets and marine oil-spill datasets acquired via synthetic-aperture radar (SAR). Quantitative comparisons demonstrate that DADS-SAM outperforms conventional approaches and achieves state-of-the-art performance across all evaluated metrics. Models and data are publicly available at https://github.com/PetrichorAsh/DADS-SAM.

title: A Spectrum-Controlled Wideband Impedance Measurement Method for Power Grid
authors: Dangsheng Zhou, Yihui Huang, Shiyao Qin, Hao Wang, Jiaming Chen
abstract: With the increasing penetration of renewable energy in power systems, wideband oscillation issues have become increasingly prominent, necessitating the accurate acquisition of grid wideband impedance characteristics to support stability analysis. Existing measurement methods face significant limitations, stemming mainly from the inability to control the spectrum of the injected wideband disturbance. This lack of spectral controllability leads to two major drawbacks: insufficient energy concentration in the target frequency band, compromising measurement accuracy, and the introduction of substantial non-target frequency components into the grid, resulting in additional harmonic pollution. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a spectrum-controllable wideband disturbance injection method based on AC-AC modulation. To begin with, an improved chopper-controlled AC voltage regulation circuit featuring relatively simple topology is designed, injecting wideband disturbance into the power grid based on AC-AC modulation. Furthermore, in order to eliminate harmonic cancellation effects caused by multi-frequency disturbance injection, a novel Non-overlapping Band Optimized Injection (NBOI) method is proposed. Lastly, the Schroeder’s phase optimization algorithm is employed to reduce the crest factor of modulation signals, resulting in higher disturbance energy in measurement frequency band, within the range of modulation signal’s amplitude. The proposed method enables direct control of the harmonic spectrum, allowing precise acquisition of wideband impedance characteristics in a single test, offering an effective approach for the stability analysis of grid-connected converters. Experimental results demonstrate that the method achieves over 99% energy concentration in the target measurement band. The proposed method achieves a Harmonic Distribution Uniformity (HDU) metric approaching 0, indicating near-perfect spectral distribution uniformity across the target frequency range. The impedance measurement accuracy shows less than 2% deviation from theoretical values, validating the method’s effectiveness for rapid, accurate wideband impedance characterization with minimal grid impact.
