title: Quantum Computing for Telecom KPI Optimization: Advantages Over Generative AI
authors: Ashok Kumar, Gourav Jain
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Computing and Communication Technologies (CONECCT)
abstract: Quantum computing represents a paradigm shift in computational power, offering unprecedented potential for optimizing Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) in telecommunications. This paper explores the application of quantum computing to telecom KPI optimization, contrasting its capabilities with those of generative artificial intelligence (AI). Telecom networks face increasing complexity due to rising data demands, 5 G deployment, and user expectations, necessitating advanced optimization techniques beyond traditional methods. While generative AI has shown promise in modeling network behaviour and predicting KPIs, it struggles with scalability and computational efficiency for large-scale, real-time systems. Quantum computing, leveraging principles like superposition and entanglement, excels in solving combinatorial optimization problems inherent in telecom networks, such as resource allocation and latency reduction. Through a detailed comparison, this paper highlights quantum computing’s superior speed, precision, and ability to handle multi-dimensional KPI datasets. A conceptual quantum framework for telecom optimization is proposed, supported by theoretical examples. The study concludes that while generative AI offers flexibility, quantum computing provides transformative advantages for future telecom systems, paving the way for nextgeneration network efficiency. Challenges such as hardware limitations and algorithm development are also discussed, alongside future research directions.

title: Artificial Intelligence Applications in Power Electronics and Renewable Energy Systems
authors: Harshraj Pandurang Bhoite
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Electrical and Electronics Engineering (ISEEE)
abstract: The increasing penetration of renewable energy sources (RES) and the evolution of power electronics have introduced significant challenges in modern power systems, including intermittency, nonlinear dynamics, and grid stability concerns. Conventional control and optimization methods are insufficient for real-time adaptability. Artificial Intelligence (AI) has emerged as a transformative enabler in addressing these issues. This paper provides a comprehensive study of AI applications in power electronics and renewable energy systems, focusing on fault detection, predictive control, energy management, and grid integration. A hybrid AI framework integrating machine learning, deep learning, and reinforcement learning is proposed. Simulation results demonstrate improved efficiency, reduced harmonic distortion, and enhanced reliability. The study highlights both opportunities and challenges for deploying AI in future sustainable power systems.

title: An Efficient Push-Relabel Implementation for Max-Flow Computations on GPUs
authors: Avery VanAusdal, Martin Burtscher
publish: 2025 IEEE International Performance, Computing, and Communications Conference (IPCCC)
abstract: Determining the maximum possible flow (max-flow) between a source vertex and a sink vertex in a network with given capacities on every edge is a fundamental graph problem found in many domains. The Push-Relabel (PR) algorithm is the leading approach for solving the max-flow problem and has been parallelized for GPUs. However, existing approaches suffer from scalability issues and may perform poorly on large graphs. This paper focuses on improving the efficiency of the PR algorithm on GPUs, presenting several implementation and parallelization improvements compared to the state of the art. Our improvements include fast global relabeling on the GPU, worklists to minimize wasted work and CUDA threads, and a two-level parallelization scheme to improve load balancing. Our approach is, on average, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$5.75 x$</tex> faster than the fastest prior GPU implementation and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$5.08 x$</tex> faster than the fastest CPU code.

title: Machine Learning-Based Assessment of White Matter Biomarkers of Verbal Episodic Memory Impairment in Multiple Sclerosis Using Diffusion-Weighted Imaging
authors: Cristian Montalba, Pamela Franco, Raúl Caulier-Cisterna, Tomás Labbe, Ethel Ciampi, Claudia Cárcamo, Juan Pablo Cruz, Marcelo E Andia
publish: 2025 15th IEEE International Conference on Pattern Recognition Systems (ICPRS)
abstract: Cognitive impairment is a common and disabling symptom in patients with relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis (RRMS), yet early detection remains a clinical challenge. This study presents a machine learning (ML) framework for identifying subcortical white matter biomarkers associated with verbal episodic memory impairment utilizing diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI). A total of 93 participants (58 RRMS patients with cognitive preservation (RRMS-CP) and with cognitive impairment (RRMS-CI), and 35 healthy controls with cognitive preservation (HC-CP) were evaluated using the Auditory Verbal Learning Test and stratified into three cognitive groups. U-fiber diffusivity metrics—including fractional anisotropy, axial diffusivity, radial diffusivity, and mean diffusivity—were extracted from 100 white matter regions. Feature selection via Sequential Forward Selection was combined with multiple classifiers, including Random Forest and Linear Discriminant Analysis. Our models achieved up to 100% accuracy (sensitivity: 98.64%, specificity: 98.17%) in distinguishing between HC-CP and RRMS-CP patients, 96.37% accuracy (sensitivity: 100%, specificity: 97.50%) between HC-CP and RRMS-CI, 97.23% accuracy (sensitivity: 98.75%, specificity: 96.00%) between RRMS-CP and RRMS-CI, and 89.2% accuracy (sensitivity: 91.09%, specificity: 91.58%) across all three groups. We acknowledge limitations, including potential information leakage in feature selection, limited diffusion directions, and the need for advanced preprocessing pipelines. These limitations will be addressed in future work with larger cohorts and nested cross-validation. The findings demonstrate the potential of interpretable ML for identifying DWI-based biomarkers of cognitive dysfunction in MS.

title: Design And Implementation of A Bluetooth Low Energy (Ble) Anti-Theft System For Motorcycles Using Esp32
authors: Jejen Jaelani Frihatna, Raka Nursalam, Yanuandri Putrasari, Mohamad Agus Fhaizal, Kusmadi Kusmadi, Hanny Rahayu
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Telecommunication Systems, Services, and Applications (TSSA)
abstract: The increasing rate of motorcycle theft, particularly in urban environments, highlights the urgent need for modern, intelligent security solutions. Traditional physical locks and alarms are no longer sufficient to deter sophisticated theft methods. This paper presents the design and implementation of a motorcycle anti-theft system utilizing Bluetooth Low Energy (BLE) technology integrated with the ESP32 micro-controller. The system replaces traditional ignition keys with proximity-based authentication, enabling ignition only when a registered BLE device (e.g., an iTag or smartwatch) is detected within a predefined signal strength threshold, verified through its MAC address and Received Signal Strength Indicator (RSSI). he hardware design incorporates an ESP32 board, a relay module, a buzzer, and status LEDs, all powered by the vehicle’s 12V supply and optimized for low-power operation. System software was developed using the Arduino IDE, and real- time BLE scanning was implemented with RSI-based filtering. Experiments conducted in controlled and real-world environments tested BLE detection range, response time, and system stability. Results demonstrated reliable performance up to 5 meters, with response times ranging from 1.8 to 2.8 seconds depending on the BLE device type and condition. The system successfully prevented engine activation when unauthorized devices were present or when the BLE signal dropped below the threshold. This research contributes a low-cost, energy-efficient, and scalable platform to the field of IoT-based vehicle security, with a clear pathway for future integration of GPS, mobile applications, and cloud-based monitoring for comprehensive protection.

title: Piezoelectric Footpaths Convert Pedestrian Motion into Clean Electricity
authors: Ramy Read Hossain, Abhijeeta Nandha, Aswathi K, R. Padmavathy, S. Balambigai, Uganya G, K.R Deeksha
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems and Pioneering Innovations in Robotics and Electric Mobility (INSPIRE)
abstract: Urban zones are experiencing additional energy needs, with the conventional power sources failing to provide for the rapidly expanding populations at the expense of the environment. Street lights, traffic signals, and other public infrastructure require a continuous power supply, typically from the grid. However, the conservation systems are not sustainable and even contribute to the Carbon footprint. This paper gives a solution to this problem by introducing a Piezoelectric Energy Harvesting Footpath (PEHF) system. The PEHF capitalises on pedestrian foot traffic to generate clean, renewable electricity via embedded piezoelectric transducers in the footpath tiles. The system harvests mechanical energy from footsteps and converts it to electrical power, which is stored and delivered to streetlights, environmental sensors, or other infrastructure. A real-time adaptive power optimisation algorithm (RAPOA) is proposed to control energy harvesting, enhance detection accuracy, and optimise energy storage. The system's architecture combines piezoelectric materials, energy management circuits, and the IoT for monitoring and data transmission, making it scalable for urban use. The PEHF had a power density of 1.2 W/m 2, 97-98% of the step detection and 15% step energy conversion efficiency, 25-35 times better than the existing systems in voltage output and 20 times in lifetime. The system achieves a step-detection accuracy of 97-98%, enabling reliable energy generation. The suggested solution is eco-friendly and cost-effective, serving as a sustainable power supply for urban infrastructure and promoting innovative city development. In summary, the PEHF system provides a scalable solution for efficiently using pedestrian energy, reducing reliance on conventional power sources and enhancing sustainability in urban settings.

title: RepliCo: Remote Collaboration Over 3D Content in DeskVR Through Miniature Replicas
authors: Nuno Alves, Daniel Mendes, Rui Rodrigues
publish: 2025 International Conference on Graphics and Interaction (ICGI)
abstract: Virtual Reality (VR) can be an excellent platform for collaborative work. However, standing in VR and gesturing in midair can be physically exhausting. We introduce RepliCo, a collaborative DeskVR approach focused on communication in the context of 3D content reviewing. Using an interactive surface and the world-in-miniature metaphor, it addresses common challenges in virtual collaboration, such as spatially referencing points of interest and user awareness. We conducted a user evaluation with 20 participants to assess the viability of our approach in both a large and a small environment. Results revealed that RepliCo efficiently allowed users to share points of interest in a user-friendly and physically undemanding manner. Although the larger model was identified as requiring more effort, there were few significant differences in task completion times, highlighting RepliCo's versatility.

title: Smart Trolley System with Automated Product Tracking and Billing
authors: A S Krishna, B Akarshana, M Karthick, S J Ovya, M Ganesan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Computing and Communication Technologies (CONECCT)
abstract: Even though online shopping is growing, people still prefer going to supermarket. Customers often faces challenges such as in finding where the products are located, long queues for billing. In order to address these issues. Many studies aim to automate the shopping experience by integrating barcode scanner, RFID (Radio frequency Identification) technology, webapp for customers to make the shopping experience more efficient. However, existing system fails in combining the product information, efficient navigation and automatic billing system in single designed system. The project Smart Trolley provides the solution by integrating different technologies such as webapp and barcode scanner for product information and customer interaction. Ultrasonic sensor to prevent collision. Weight based pricing which avoids theft and rechargeable customer card for paying the bill. Raspberry pi 4 which interfaces sensors, webapp in lcd and other components. The product and billing information are displayed on 7-inch LCD which is mounted on the trolley. The system Smart Trolley reduces the customers waiting time in long queues, collision avoidance, theft prevention with accurate billing. Also reduces customers time in searching the product and also maintains the stock level. This system aims to enhance the shopping experiences.

title: Hierarchical Cross-Modal Attention Network for Target Re-Identification
authors: Md Asikuzzaman, Tristrom Cooke, Syed Imranul Islam, Kazi Yasin Islam, Connor Luckett, Jerome Williams, Ben Yip, Tri-Tan Cao, Sebastien Wong
publish: 2025 International Conference on Digital Image Computing: Techniques and Applications (DICTA)
abstract: Target Re-Identification (Re-ID) aims to identify the same target across multiple image or video scenes. In crossmodal target Re-ID, the challenge is to bridge the modality gap between observations from different sensors. We propose a new Hierarchical Cross-Modal Attention Network (HCMAN) for use in the cross-modal target Re-ID problem. The proposed HCMAN module uses convolutional self-attention to combine information across feature maps of different resolution. It is lightweight and can be easily integrated into the feature extractor of many available cross-modal target Re-ID architectures with negligible overhead. HCMAN requires no special handling, being optimized by end-to-end training of the Re-ID pipeline. We demonstrate improved performance of multiple state-of-the-art ReID methods through the integration of HCMAN. This improvement is observed across a variety of cross-modal target Re-ID datasets, including SYSU-MM01, RegDB, RGBNT201, MSVR310, and HITSZ-VCM.

title: Measuring the Ring Current with Cluster: Reliability of the Curlometer Method
authors: Máté Tomasik, Péter Kovács
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Symposium on Computational Intelligence and Informatics (CINTI)
abstract: The ESA Cluster mission (2000-2024) investigated the terrestrial magnetosphere and its interaction with the solar wind using a constellation of four satellites in a tetrahedral configuration. This formation enabled simultaneous measurements of spatial and temporal variations in near-Earth space. One of the key objectives was to evaluate the curlometer method, which estimates current density in space plasmas from multipoint magnetic field measurements. Among the large-scale current systems in the magnetosphere, the ring current-a westwardflowing current-plays a central role in geomagnetic variations through its close relation to space weather. In this study, we apply the curlometer technique to perform a statistical analysis of ring current observations of Cluster in 2002. The current determinations are validated with the Dst index, which quantifies variations in Earth’s surface magnetic field. Besides, we analyze the impact of geometric parameters of the satellite configuration (separation, planarity, and elongation) and the physical validity criterion ($Q=\nabla \cdot \mathbf{B} / \nabla \times \mathbf{B}$) on the reliability of the measured current densities.

title: Statistical Assessment of Tendencies of Migration Activity in the Regions of the Central Federal District (on the Example of the Lipetsk Region)
authors: Margarita Karlova, Tatiana Fomina, Elena Kuznetsova, Sergey Zhbanov, Nataliya Morozova
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: This article is devoted to the statistical assessment of migration activity trends in the regions of the Central Federal District (CFD) on the example of the Lipetsk Region. The data of state statistics, sample surveys, and administrative statistics for 2020-2023 are used. The study aims to identify and analyze the key patterns and dynamics of migration processes, their causal relationships, and their impact on the socio-economic development of the region. The study uses statistical methods to analyze migration data and factors that influence migration flows, such as the economic situation, living standards, demographic characteristics, and social infrastructure. The focus is on the specific migration trends in the Lipetsk Region, which allows for evaluating the effectiveness of existing migration management measures and suggesting potential improvements to migration policies.

title: PID-controller design for Pitch and Roll Angular Velocity of Quadcopter
authors: Vadim Alexandrov
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: Quadcopter pitch and roll control loops are considered. The most common is a cascade control system with a proportional controller in the angle outer loop and with a proportional-integral-derivative controller in the angular velocity inner loop. The problem is that the dynamics of pitch and roll angular velocities can be described by a transfer function with differentiating element. Then, a controller with an integral component results in a closed-loop system with characteristic polynomial containing a zero root. A PID-controller design procedure based on the pole placement approach is proposed for this specific case.

title: Near-Field Imaging for Defect Detection Using Space-Frequency Time Reversal
authors: Chiung-Shen Ku, Kun-Shan Chen, Cheng-Yen Chiang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: A near-field imaging approach for defect detection utilizing space-frequency time reversal (SFTR) is presented. Defect detection is vital for ensuring the safety, reliability, and efficiency of materials and structures across industries, as undetected flaws such as cracks or voids can compromise structural integrity and lead to catastrophic failures. Near-field imaging in the microwave region addresses these challenges by offering higher resolution, enhanced sensitivity, and the ability to detect both surface and subsurface defects with precision. SFTR further enhances near-field imaging by focusing energy at defect locations, suppressing noise, and improving signal-to-noise ratios. This synergy captures fine details, including evanescent waves, which are crucial for detecting subtle defects. The combination of highresolution imaging and advanced signal processing in near-field imaging based on SFTR presents a robust, reliable, and versatile solution for overcoming the limitations of traditional defect detection methods.

title: Multi-class Retinal OCT Image Analysis Based on EfficientNetV2
authors: Jipeng Luan, Hongfeng Sun, Shengpeng Yu, Jie Tian, Zhen Cui, Hong Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Trends in Computational Intelligence (NTCI)
abstract: Ocular diseases significantly affect millions of people worldwide, and if not detected and treated early, they can lead to vision impairment or blindness. Traditional manual screening methods face numerous challenges, including accuracy, timeliness, and resource limitations. This study systematically compares the classification performance of four deep learning models-VGG-19, ResNet-50, SwinV2, and EfficientNetV2-on two publicly available optical coherence tomography (OCT) datasets (OCTDL and Retinal OCT-8). The models were comprehensively evaluated using various performance metrics, including accuracy and AUC. The results show that EfficientNetV2 outperforms the other models on both datasets, particularly under conditions with limited computational resources, demonstrating exceptional accuracy and efficiency. This study highlights the advantages of EfficientNetV2 in automated retinal disease diagnosis, making it an ideal choice for clinical applications, especially in resource-constrained environments. These findings strongly validate the potential of deep learning in medical imaging, providing robust support for the early diagnosis and treatment of retinal diseases.

title: Improving Imbalance Learning in Audio Domain through Spectrogram-Based Augmentation
authors: Nikunj Dalsaniya, Pranshav Patel, Sapan H Mankad
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Computing and Communication Technologies (CONECCT)
abstract: Class imbalance is a critical concern in the machine learning domain which relies on data heavily. The model may work poorly if the underlying data are not well-formed and balanced. Several works have been proposed in the literature to address the issue of class imbalance. However, the task of imbalance learning in the audio domain still needs more attention. In this work, we provide a brief overview of current methods and discuss ways for addressing class imbalance in the audio domain especially. To further understand the impact of our suggested approach, we additionally conduct several tests on two purposefully imbalanced datasets (cats vs. dogs and major vs. minor chords) using three distinct audio representations. On both datasets, we find that the augmentation applied to spectrogram-based representations performs better than the other two approaches.

title: Monitoring LASER Pulse Energy Using a Photodiode-Based Transimpedance Amplifier
authors: Adrian-Alin Toader, Cristina-Gabriela Sărăcin
publish: 2025 14th International Symposium on Advanced Topics in Electrical Engineering (ATEE)
abstract: This paper presents the design, implementation, and experimental validation of a simplified, non-invasive monitoring circuit for detecting energy drops in pulsed pump lasers. By using a photodiode and a transimpedance amplifier, the circuit converts scattered light into a voltage signal, enabling indirect yet accurate monitoring of the LASER pulse energy. Experimental results demonstrate the circuit's effectiveness in identifying energy levels below a critical threshold, making it suitable for integration into laser safety and diagnostic systems for high power lasers infrastructures.

title: Development of an Algorithm for Automating the Management of Current Academic Performance Based on Markov Chains with Fuzzy States
authors: Anna Loskutova, Natalia Alejnikova
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: The basis for managing student performance is the results of its monitoring. Performance monitoring includes, among other things, both current and periodic types of control. Current monitoring determines the quality of mastering the current study sections—current performance. Periodic monitoring is aimed at determining intermediate performance and is conducted over an entire course section at times scheduled by the teacher or educational institution, with the purpose of assessing the quality of material assimilation and, if necessary, adjusting the student's performance trajectory. The article proposes an algorithm to automate the management of current performance based on the analysis of the dynamics of a student’s grades accumulated up to the next periodic monitoring point. The goal of the algorithm is to provide the teacher with a timely signal that the student needs learning process correction. As a model for analyzing current performance, a model of discrete Markov chains with fuzzy states and the Kolmogorov–Chapman formula is proposed. The fuzzy states of student performance characterize the degree of mastery of different sections of the curriculum. Using discrete Markov chains with fuzzy states allows solving the following tasks: automatic classification of the degree of mastery of a course section at the current moment, considering the dynamics of the student's academic results; the classification is performed based on a relatively small amount of current performance grades.

title: Issues for increasing the geometric accuracy of the land registry base map database
authors: János Katona
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Symposium on Computational Intelligence and Informatics (CINTI)
abstract: In Hungary, the nationally accessible national land registry base map database was created in 2000s. Although the database is based on the same principles and rules, the geometric accuracy of the database is not homogeneous due to different data sources. The introduction of electronic land registries does not in itself solve mapping errors, but poses new challenges. This paper attempts to summarize the reasons for the inhomogeneity of mapping accuracy and guidelines for correcting errors that exceed tolerances. The research demonstrates a strong correlation between survey age and error correction frequency, with maps from the 19th and early 20th centuries showing significantly higher correction rates compared to modern surveys.

title: A Multi-Strategy Enhanced Slime Mould Algorithm for Engineering Optimization Applications
authors: Zhiwei Guo, Limin Wang, Guosen Lin
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Data Mining (ICDM)
abstract: To address engineering challenges such as multi-constraint conflicts, nonlinear coupling, and high material costs, this paper proposes a Multi-Strategy Enhanced Slime Mould Algorithm (MESMA) for parameter optimization, aiming to achieve cost-effective and reliable solutions. Slime Mould Algorithm (SMA) is limited by slow convergence, low precision, and a high risk of local optima entrapment. These drawbacks are mitigated in MESMA through the integration of multiple strategies: the pinhole imaging inverse learning mechanism enhances search capability; individual mutation helps avoid premature convergence; and greedy selection ensures that superior solutions are retained. Extensive evaluations on the CEC2022 benchmark suite demonstrate that MESMA outperforms not only existing state-of-the-art algorithms but also enhanced variants of the SMA. Moreover, case studies on three engineering design problems confirm its feasibility and robustness in practical engineering applications.

title: LAIStega-Edge: A Lightweight Adaptive Steganographic Architecture with Texture Mining for Robotic Edge Computing
authors: Xiaoting Chen, Mingfei Ouyang, Yibing Chen, Tao Hua, Lei Zhang, Mianjie Li
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Data Mining (ICDM)
abstract: Addressing the challenge of coordinating embedding capacity and computational efficiency in image steganography for resource-constrained edge scenarios like robotics, we propose LAIStega, a lightweight adaptive architecture. Key innovations: 1) Data-driven texture mining using multi-scale Gabor filters to generate embedding weight maps, increasing texture region capacity by 28%; 2) Cascaded model compression via pruning-quantization-distillation, reducing model size to 32 MB (23.1% of ADeep); 3) Adversarial learning with a gradient reversal layer to enhance anti-analysis robustness. Evaluated on BossBase/COCO-Edge: PSNR 39.3 dB, error rate 34.5%, outperforming SteganoGAN and HiDDeN; Jetson Nano achieves 21.5 FPS at 0.31 J/frame. Results show LAIStega excels in concealment, security, and edge efficiency.

title: AIoT-Driven Smart Agri-Grid (ASAG) for Sustainable Precision Agriculture
authors: N. Kalyana Sundaram, Megala Rajendran, Muhamed Ehssan, Aakansha Soy, K. Anandhi, T Ummal Sariba Begum, Guma Ali, Dhananjaya B
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems and Pioneering Innovations in Robotics and Electric Mobility (INSPIRE)
abstract: By advising and teaching farmers on how to apply modern farm practices that embrace Artificial Intelligence (AI) and the Internet of Things (IoT), precision agriculture is revolutionising sustainable farming by optimising for usages that are as much as possible and waste as little as can be afforded. In this research, we propose an AIoT-driven Smart Agri Grid (ASAG) framework that integrates real-time nanosensor networks, an AI-operational control microclimate, an autonomous decision-support system, and secure data sharing via a blockchain using encrypted statistical data. To achieve real-time analytics, edge computing is used in the framework for real-time data analytics, predictive algorithms for dynamic irrigation & nutrient management, and federated learning for distributed AI training, which maintains privacy and scalability. In addition, the system uses AI-based waste-minimisation techniques, such as predictive harvest timing and the conversion of bio-waste into organic fertilisers, thereby reducing post-harvest losses. Experimental results show that ASAG can improve crop yield by 20 to 30%, reduce water waste by up to 50%, and reduce chemical overuse by up to 30%, with its economic and environmental benefits. The feasibility of such deployment on a large scale in precision agriculture is further confirmed by a cost-benefit analysis. The results reinforce the power of AI and IoT in transforming contemporary farming into a self-optimising, climate-resilient system. For long-term sustainability in global agriculture, quantum AI will be used to predict soil health, monitor AI-assisted carbon sequestration, and enable genomic AI for climate-resistant crops.

title: Multi-Region Heterogeneous Picking Robot Task Allocation and Scheduling in Smart Farms
authors: Ying Bi, Hongyan Sang, Hengwei Guo
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Trends in Computational Intelligence (NTCI)
abstract: This paper investigates the multi-region heterogeneous picking robot task allocation and scheduling (MRHPRTAS) problem with regional operation constraints, round capacity constraints, and heterogeneous robot characteristics, aiming to minimize the maximum completion time. To address this NP-hard problem, a multi-region heterogeneous discrete artificial bee colony (MRHDABC) algorithm is proposed, integrating multi-region heuristic initialization, critical robot-oriented optimization, and round-based load balancing strategies. The algorithm employs multi-region NEH and IG heuristics to generate high-quality initial solutions, followed by collaborative optimization through three bee colony phases. Comparative experiments demonstrate that MRHDABC achieves substantially superior optimization performance and exhibits notably greater robustness compared to state-of-the-art approaches.

title: Distributed Embedding Indexing For Real-Time Vector Search At Scale
authors: Abu Imran Ahmed
publish: 2025 International Conference on Big Data, Knowledge and Control Systems Engineering (BdKCSE)
abstract: The escalating scale and dynamic nature of modern retail product catalogs demand sophisticated AI-driven solutions for enhanced discovery, personalization, and operational efficiency. Central to these advancements is the capability to semantically understand and compare product information through high-dimensional vector embeddings. This paper presents the architecture and design of a comprehensive, end-to-end vector embedding system developed for large-scale retail catalog management. This system leverages a combined textual representation from product title, short description and long description to generate discriminative embeddings. For this, we employ the Hugging Face sentence-transformers all-MiniLM-L12-v2 model, deployed and managed on Google Vertex AI Platform for scalable inference. This study details a robust pipeline that supports both real-time embedding generation for new and updated items via an event-driven Spark Streaming job, and efficient batch embedding generation for historical data through a dedicated BigQuery based process. This dual mode approach ensures data freshness and comprehensive coverage, critical for managing a vast retail inventory. The generated embedding dataset is instrumental for a multitude of retail use cases, including advanced semantic search, personalized recommendations, and crucial duplicate item detection. This research provides a blueprint for building scalable, real-time vector embedding systems in demanding enterprise environments, contributing insights into architectural choices, technological integration, and operational strategies for managing large-scale product data.

title: VANET Communication: Neural Network-Based Scaled Conjugate Gradient for Link Adaptation and Doppler Effect Mitigation
authors: Etienne Alain Feukeu, Sumbwanyambe Mbuyu
abstract: Road traffic accidents remain a leading global public health challenge, causing approximately 1.19 million fatalities annually, with significant social and economic consequences. To address this issue, Vehicular Ad Hoc Networks (VANETs) have emerged as a promising solution, enabling real-time communication between vehicles and infrastructure to enhance road safety. However, the dynamic nature of vehicular environments, particularly the Doppler Effect (DE), poses significant challenges to reliable communication in VANETs. This study proposes a Neural Network (NN)-based approach combined with a Scaled Conjugate Gradient (SCG) optimization algorithm to predict the optimal Modulation and Coding Scheme (MCS) based on the Signal-to-Noise Ratio (SNR) and relative node mobility. Simulation results demonstrate the model’s robustness, achieving an overall prediction accuracy of 95.8%. The proposed solution not only mitigates the impact of the Doppler Effect but also enhances the reliability and efficiency of safety message transmission in high-mobility scenarios, contributing to improved road safety and the overall effectiveness of VANETs.

title: Subsurface Utility Mapping Using Ground Penetrating Radar in Bogor Strategic Area
authors: Dody Kusmana, Dea Yunita Sari, Muhammad Syukri, Doni Romdhoni Witarsa, Hendra Garnida, Rosadi
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Telecommunication Systems, Services, and Applications (TSSA)
abstract: The increasing intensity of infrastructure development in Bogor City, West Java, has created an urgent need for accurate spatial information regarding underground utility networks. This study aims to map subsurface utilities—including fiber optic cables, electrical lines, water pipelines, and gas pipelines—using the Ground Penetrating Radar (GPR) method. The survey was conducted along 19 transects in the Baranangsiang area utilizing the MALÅ Easy Locator Core system operating at 450 MHz. Radargram data were processed through noise filtering, amplitude normalization, and static correction to enhance clarity and interpretability. Hyperbolic reflections in the radargrams were used to identify discrete underground objects, while planar reflectors represented soil layers. The depth of identified utilities ranged from approximately 0.12 m to 3.00 m, depending on the type and installation standard. The results confirm that GPR is a reliable and non-destructive method for detecting underground utilities with varying material properties and depths. This research supports the development of utility maps and contributes to the integration of geospatial data into sustainable urban infrastructure planning in Bogor City.

title: Performance Evaluation of Quantum Kalman Filter for Target Tracking: A Quantum Information Perspective
authors: Manjukiran B, Shantaramara Rai C, Gnane Swarnadh Satapathi, Suhandas, Santhosh S
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems and Pioneering Innovations in Robotics and Electric Mobility (INSPIRE)
abstract: The Quantum Kalman Filter (QKF) emerges as an innovative approach to address the challenges of state estimation in quantum systems, adapting classical Kalman filtering to the complexities of quantum mechanics. This paper examines the theoretical framework, practical implementation hurdles, and potential applications of QKF in quantum information processing and sensing. By incorporating quantum measurement principles and stochastic dynamics, QKF offers a solution for optimal state estimation in noisy quantum environments. The study presents simulation results and comparative analyses with classical Kalman filtering for tracking single targets, underscoring the advantages and limitations of QKF in advancing quantum technology applications.

title: Natural Electromagnetic–Thermal Analysis of a Magnetic Resonance Imaging Birdcage Coil
authors: Ana-Maria Brumă, Alexandru-Mihail Morega, Yelda Veli
publish: 2025 14th International Symposium on Advanced Topics in Electrical Engineering (ATEE)
abstract: This paper presents the numerical modeling and optimization of a low-pass radiofrequency birdcage coil dedicated to human brain imaging at 1.5 T Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) systems. A three-dimensional numerical model was developed using COMSOL Multiphysics and realistic anatomical geometries of the human head (scalp, skull, and brain), constructed in Blender. Electromagnetic simulations evaluated field symmetry, circular polarization, and safety parameters, including specific absorption rate (SAR) and thermal effects. Comparative results between 8-rung and 12-rung coil configurations demonstrated that the 8-rung design ensures optimal field symmetry and SAR compliance, while the 12-rung design increases local absorption beyond recommended safety thresholds. The numerical simulation results confirm that electromagnetic and thermal analysis of birdcage coils can support performance optimization for improved MRI field distribution while ensuring compliance with safety constraints.

title: Profitability of Financial and Production Investments for Investors
authors: Olga I. Gorbaneva
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: In the article the condition under which the production investments are more profitable than financial for investors is found. The mathematical model in which production functions and functions of private income are linear or power concave is built. The optimal share of production investments foe investors are found. The conditions under which production investments are beneficial for investors are found.

title: High-Performance Optoelectronic Oscillator Using Lithium Niobate Optical Modulator
authors: K Divya Sree, B Renuka, Meena Dasan, Mandeep Singh
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Computing and Communication Technologies (CONECCT)
abstract: Optoelectronic oscillator (OEO) has emerged as a key component for generating high-purity microwave and millimeter-wave signals, crucial for modern communication, radar, and sensing systems. This paper presents an OEO design based on a lithium niobate (LiNbO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf>) optical modulator, known for its excellent electro-optic properties, low insertion loss, and high modulation bandwidth. The proposed system integrates a (LiNbO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf>) Mach-Zehnder modulator (MZM) within a feedback loop, converting optical modulation into stable microwave oscillations. The use of lithium niobate enhances signal stability, reduces phase noise, and broadens the operational frequency range compared to conventional OEOs. A 15 GHz microwave signal is generated with 75.20 dB RFSSR and 20.71 dB OSSR. The experiments confirm phase noise of $\mathbf{- 1 1 2} \mathbf{~ d B c} / \mathbf{H z} \text{@} \mathbf{1 0 ~ k H z}$ offset frequency. Our results highlight the potential of lithium niobate-based modulators in advancing optoelectronic oscillators for high-frequency applications.

title: Fault Estimation Based on LSTM-UKF for Nonlinear Systems with Unknown Noise Covariance Matrices
authors: Wenya Yan, Li Sheng, Ming Gao, Yuechao Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Trends in Computational Intelligence (NTCI)
abstract: This paper presents a real-time fault estimation method for augmented systems with unknown noise characteristics, utilizing a hybrid neural network and unscented Kalman filter (UKF) approach. The hybrid approach implicitly learns system dynamics components from data while retaining the efficiency and interpretability of classical algorithms. The state space model of the nonlinear system is first established, and the UKF prediction step constructs input features for long short term memory network to adaptively estimate the noise covariance. Subsequently, the UKF performs real-time updates of system states and fault estimates. These updated values are utilized as loss functions to facilitate end-to-end training of the network. During the training process, a joint target loss function is proposed, and truncated backpropagation through time is adopted to enhance training efficiency. Finally, numerical simulation experiment is conducted which has proved that the estimation accuracy of the hybrid filter is higher than the standard UKF and the extended Kalman filter under unknown noise covariance.

title: The Influence of Head-Mounted Displays and Sex on Presence and Cybersickness in Cinematic Virtual Reality
authors: Pedro Reisinho, Cátia Silva, Rui Raposo, Mário Vairinhos, Nelson Zagalo
publish: 2025 International Conference on Graphics and Interaction (ICGI)
abstract: With virtual reality's potential expanding to diverse scientific domains and the growing variety of visualisation devices with differing technical specifications, the appropriate selection of a head-mounted display has become an important factor in achieving a satisfactory experience. The present study sought to examine whether head-mounted displays influence the sense of presence and the manifestation of cybersickness symptoms during a cinematic virtual reality experience, and whether participants' sex affects these outcomes. A total of 48 participants (24 female, 24 male) were exposed to a 360° video using one of three headmounted displays: the HTC Vive, Meta Quest 2, and Oculus Go. The results support the existing evidence that a greater immersion - characterised by higher technical specifications increases a device's capacity to elicit both presence and cybersickness, with these two elements being inversely correlated and cybersickness exerting the dominant force. Sex also emerged as a differentiating factor, with female participants reporting more severe symptomatology than male participants.

title: Machine Learning Models for Predicting Suicidal Ideation in University Students
authors: Fernanda Rubio
publish: 2025 15th IEEE International Conference on Pattern Recognition Systems (ICPRS)
abstract: Suicidal ideation among university students represents a growing public health concern. This study presents a predictive modeling approach using machine learning to identify suicidal ideation based on psychological and demographic data. Five classifiers were evaluated: Logistic Regression, Random Forest, Support Vector Machine (SVM), Neural Networks, and XGBoost, using optimized feature selection (RFECV) and class balancing. The optimized Logistic Regression and XGBoost models achieved the best trade-off between recall and accuracy. Feature importance analysis revealed that depression, hopelessness, loneliness, and a neurodivergence diagnosis are key predictive factors. The results support the utility of interpretable machine learning methods for identifying psychological patterns associated with suicidal ideation, laying the groundwork for future research on early detection in mental health.

title: Design And Implementation Of Branch Line Coupler For Dual Band Applications
authors: K. Keerthi Naidu, S. Imaculate Rosaline, Alphonse Arokiaswami
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Computing and Communication Technologies (CONECCT)
abstract: Branch Line Couplers (BLCs) are inevitable components in many microwave networks. As the evolving technologies demand the components to work in multiple frequencies, there is a need to explore and modify the conventional components to work for more than one frequency. In this work, the design and implementation of Branch Line coupler that supports the dual band operation is introduced. The proposed coupler differs from the conventional design with respect to length of the transmission line. This paper discusses two BLCs. The first coupler is constructed without a stub and it works for a particular frequency ratio of $\mathbf{2}(\mathbf{1. 1 5 ~ G H z} / \mathbf{2 . 3 ~ G H z})$. In the second coupler design, stubs that are center-tapped in the horizontal (series) arms of the coupler are used $(0.92 \mathrm{GHz} / 2.4 \mathrm{GHz})$. These stubs help in widening the two frequencies of operation by increasing the frequency ratio to 2.6. The coupler designed with stubs can be used to operate at desired frequencies by parameterizing the stub length. The design, simulation and fabrication of the coupler is done and is verified through the scattering parameters and the phase response of the coupler.

title: Integration of Hyperspectral Data Segmentation Methods with QGIS and PDAL: From Theory to Reproducible Practice
authors: Michal Staňo, Ladislav Hluchý, Lenka Skovajsová, Michal Hucko, Jean Rosemond Dora
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Symposium on Computational Intelligence and Informatics (CINTI)
abstract: Hyperspectral imaging (HSI) records reflectance across many narrow spectral bands and enables fine-grained scene understanding. We consolidate three major segmentation paradigms-(i) pixel-wise convolutional networks, (ii) objectbased/superpixel methods, and (iii) graph neural networks (GNNs)-and demonstrate how to execute them end-to-end in open-source geospatial workflows using Quantum GIS (QGIS) and the Point Data ion Library (PDAL). We provide a technically detailed, GIS-centric workflow with an emphasis on data models, coordinate reference systems (CRS), and reproducible deployment via Docker. On a public benchmark scene, we report quantitative accuracy and runtime for all three paradigms. We also distill tested best practices that resolve recurrent bottlenecks (ENVI header inconsistencies, PDAL provider availability, raster-vector alignment, tiling, and containerized execution). All steps are scripted for headless processing, enabling FAIR (Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, Reusable) and auditable pipelines adoptable in QGIS/PDAL environments.

title: Low-Complexity LDPC Decoder for Cloud Based Architectures
authors: Satya Kumar Vankayala, Tirthankar Mittra, Thirumulanathan D, Srihari Das Sunkada Gopinath, Varigonda Srinivasa Mohan Kumar, Seungil Yoon
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Computing and Communication Technologies (CONECCT)
abstract: LDPC code structure allows high parallelism to deliver the high demanding data rates, but the LDPC decoder does not perform well concerning the low latency requirements needed for high-speed applications. This is partly due to the soft decoder involving the computation of non-linear functions with high computational complexity. Virtualized radio access networks (VRANs) are a new paradigm that brings software-based network functions to run on the cloud. In this paper, we propose four LDPC soft decoder approximations: a piecewise linear (PL) approximation, a polynomial approximation, a machine learning (ML) based approximation, and a modification of min-sum approximation using regression methods. We show that the approximations retain a comparable BLER performance and, at the same time, bring down the computational complexity of the decoder. We also show that the BLER performance of our approximations is significantly better than the well-known min-sum approximation. Our methods are suitable for direct implementation in cloud based VRAN systems.

title: Implementation of I2C Protocol with Adaptive Baud Rate for N Number of Bits Using VERILOG
authors: S Aparna, C. Padma
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: For low-speed peripherals in embedded systems, the Inter-Integrated Circuit (I2C) protocol is a popular serial communication standard. In order to accommodate variable communication speeds depending on system requirements, this paper outlines the construction of an I2C protocol with an adaptable baud rate. The design is appropriate for FPGA-based applications because it is built using Verilog HDL. N-bit data width is supported by the suggested system, enabling capability for a range of applications. To maximize efficiency and minimize battery usage, the adaptive baud rate system constantly modifies the transmission speed. Key elements of the I2C master-slave communication framework include clock stretching, data transmission/reception, start/stop condition detection, and acknowledgment processing. Results from simulation and synthesis show how well the architecture works to provide dependable, fast communication while preserving compatibility. A result from simulation and synthesis is showing how well the design works to achieve dependable, fast communication while being compatible with common I2C devices. Applications need low power consumption and adjustable data transfer speed, effective serial transmission, including FPGA-based embedded systems, real-time data gathering, and sensor interface would benefit greatly from the suggested approach.

title: New Fiber-Optic Transducers of Physical Quantities
authors: Nikolay Koshevoy, Tatiana Rozhnova, Olena Kostenko, Oleksandr Zabolotnyi, Vitalii Siroklyn, Andrii Andriushko
publish: 2025 XXXV International Scientific Symposium Metrology and Metrology Assurance (MMA)
abstract: New fiber-optic transducers of such physical quantities as pressure, pressure difference, liquid level, angular displacements and acceleration have been developed. The proposed sensors allow to increase measurement accuracy, simplify designs, expand functionality by providing information about the measured value in digital form, and provide built-in control and spark-explosion-fire safety of the design. Ukrainian utility model patents protect the developed fiber-optic converters (FOC).

title: Fabrication Process Refinement Enabling High-Performance DSC 1.2 kV SiC Power Modules
authors: Yuxiang Chen, Riya Paul, Khandoker Asif Faruque, Yuyang Wang, Qiang Wu, Alan Mantooth
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th Workshop on Wide Bandgap Power Devices and Applications (WiPDA)
abstract: The adoption of double-sided cooled (DSC) module packaging remains limited by fabrication complexity, despite its promise for high-power silicon carbide (SiC) applications. This work presents fabrication-process advancements for a 1.2 kV half-bridge DSC SiC power module with integrated gate driver and decoupling capacitors. The objective is to establish manufacturable strategies that enhance insulation reliability and functional integration. Key improvements include optimized topside chip pad re-metallization for robust double-sided die attachment, a revised assembly sequence enabling modular gate driver integration with reworkability, and enhanced alignment control to ensure structural consistency. Using the optimized process, 1.2 kV/164 A full-SiC MOSFET half-bridge prototypes were assembled. Static and dynamic evaluations confirm that the refined process effectively supports reliable DSC module realization.

title: Machine Learning Approach for Integrated Sensing and Communication in 6G Radio Standard: A Systematic Literature Review
authors: Daniel Wiyogo Dwiputro, Hendrawan
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Telecommunication Systems, Services, and Applications (TSSA)
abstract: Integrated Sensing and Communication (ISAC), also known as Joint Communication and Sensing (JCAS), is a cornerstone technology for 5G-Advanced and 6G networks, enabling environmental perception alongside data transmission. Machine Learning (ML) is increasingly pivotal in realizing the full potential of ISAC. This systematic literature review analyzes the current state of research on ML applications within ISAC for 6G wireless systems. Our analysis reveals a vibrant research landscape focusing on leveraging ML, particularly Deep Learning (DL) and Reinforcement Learning (RL), for diverse ISAC functions including beamforming, localization, resource allocation, and enhancing security. While significant benefits such as improved performance, accuracy, and efficiency are reported, key challenges remain, notably concerning security, privacy, real-time processing latency, computational complexity, and robustness. Emerging trends highlight the integration of ML-driven ISAC with technologies like Reconfigurable Intelligent Surfaces (RIS), Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs), Terahertz (THz) communications, Edge Al, and Digital Twins. Furthermore, ML is shown to be instrumental in enabling advanced 6G applications, including autonomous driving, extended reality (XR), satellite communications, and environmental sensing. This review synthesizes the advancements, identifies persistent challenges, and outlines future research trajectories for ML in the evolving field of ISAC.

title: PDSNet: A Lightweight Convolutional Neural Network for English Word Recognition in Complex Environments
authors: Jiahao Sun, Zijian Yang, Zhiqiang Mao, Tianqi Huang, Jia Liu
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Modern Education and Information Management (ICMEIM)
abstract: English letter recognition is widely used in OCR and intelligent signage systems, yet traditional models often struggle with diverse fonts and complex backgrounds, leading to suboptimal accuracy and high computational cost. To address these challenges, this study proposes PDSNet, a lightweight convolutional neural network that integrates Partial Convolution, Separable and Adjustable Convolution (DOConv), and Channel Shuffle to enhance feature extraction and maintain high efficiency. Experimental results demonstrate that PDSNet achieves a precision of 70.8%, recall of 61.5%, and F1 score of 65.8% on handwritten letter datasets, surpassing models like ResNet18 (57.3% F F1, 11.2M params) and MobileNet (58.8 % F1,2.2M params), while containing only 0.9M parameters.

title: Multiview Collaborative Learning to Handle Noisy Label for Building Extraction from Remote Sensing Image
authors: Panle Li, Xiaohui He, Xijie Cheng, Mengjia Qiao, Zening Wu, Jiandong Shang, Renyi Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Volunteered geographic information (VGI) provides an efficient means of generating large-scale labels for building extraction from remote sensing imagery. However, the inherent noise in these labels often compromises the performance of deep convolutional neural networks (DCNNs). Existing label correction methods heavily rely on unreliable early-stage predictions and are prone to error accumulation, which impedes their performance in building extraction tasks, particularly in complex scenes with localized noisy labels. To overcome these challenges, we propose a Multiview Collaborative Learning (MCL) framework that enables robust DCNN training for building extraction tasks under noisy supervision. MCL introduces multiview predicted probabilities produced by multiple late-stage networks, offering more reliable and diverse priors for correcting noisy labels. A Hidden Denoising Inference Model (HDIM) is further developed to infer latent clean labels by modeling the confidence of multiview predictions through an EM-based optimization process. Additionally, a Syloss function is designed to integrate inferred and observed labels, ensuring stable joint supervision throughout training. We evaluate the proposed MCL framework on two large-scale benchmarks—the newly collected Phoenix-building dataset (908.3km2) and the widely used WHU-Aerial dataset. Experiments show that MCL effectively alleviates the impact of noisy labels and consistently surpasses state-of-the-art noise-robust methods, demonstrating its strong reliability and scalability for large-scale building extraction. The code will be publicly available at https://github.com/leo85-cc/MCL.

title: Evolutionary Knowledge Transfer via Graph Learning for Many-Task Heterogeneous Routing Problems
authors: Haoyuan Lv, Ruochen Liu, Jianxia Li
abstract: Evolutionary multitasking optimization (EMTO) is widely applied to solve combinatorial optimization, notably routing problems. While existing handcrafted-rule-based knowledge transfer operators facilitate inter-task information exchange and overall convergence in EMTO, they face key limitations: (1) reliance on excellent solutions as carriers hinders knowledge transfer between dimensionally heterogeneous tasks; (2) limited rule generalization impedes modeling complex mappings in many-task environments. To address these, this work proposes evolutionary knowledge transfer via graph learning (EKT-GL). Its core module is an online-updated neural network. EKT-GL introduces a model-based knowledge carrier to transfer common knowledge, replacing solution-based carriers. It employs end-to-end learning to seamlessly integrate similarity measurement, knowledge extraction, and transfer, overcoming manual rule limitations and ensuring superior generalization through data-driven training. In comparative experiments, two routing problems are used to construct many-task heterogeneous data sets with different scale (the maximum number of tasks is 100). Experimental results indicate that EKT-GL have competitive performance compared to other five state-of-the-art EMTO algorithms.

authors: Miroslaw Staron, Silvia Abrahã
abstract: Large language models are changing how we write, analyze, and reason about requirements. As this shift presents both challenges and opportunities, we examine recent developments in the field of requirements engineering.

title: Dynamic Two-Level Buffer Monitoring and Control of Critical Chain Projects Considering Activity Overlapping
authors: Dan Wan, Qingqing Gui, Chuanwang Sun, Anwar Khan
abstract: To address the limitations of existing buffer monitoring methods, which overlook activity coupling characteristics and suffer from imbalanced monitoring granularity, this paper proposes a two-level buffer monitoring and control method for critical chain projects considering activity overlapping. The method first analyzes the overlapping execution pattern among coupled activities and their impact on project schedules and buffer consumption. It then determines activity rework time and buffer allocation amount based on the Poisson distribution of information exchange, project attribute factors, and an information evolution model. A phase-level buffer monitoring trigger is set to decide whether to refine monitoring granularity to the activity level, and buffer consumption at the activity level is dynamically triggered and monitored in a rolling manner. This forms a dynamic buffer monitoring system that coordinates phase-level and activity-level control. Experimental results show that the proposed method outperforms classic approaches across project sizes, reducing project duration by up to 33.28%, project cost by up to 22.71%, and schedule overrun proportion by up to 34.94% under increasing uncertainty. While higher uncertainty slightly decreases the monitoring efficiency of the proposed method, it consistently remains above 0.70, higher than that of the established approaches. By considering overlapping task execution and employing a two-level trigger with rolling updates, the method effectively avoids lagging or excessive buffer warnings, achieving more efficient buffer management.

title: Towards Dataset Copyright Evasion Attack against Personalized Text-to-Image Diffusion Models_supp1-3648660.pdf
authors: Yiming Li
abstract: Text-to-image (T2I) diffusion models enable high-quality image generation conditioned on textual prompts. However, fine-tuning these pre-trained models for personalization raises concerns about unauthorized dataset usage. To address this issue, dataset ownership verification (DOV) has recently been proposed, which embeds watermarks into fine-tuning datasets via backdoor techniques. These watermarks remain dormant on benign samples but produce owner-specified outputs when triggered. Despite its promise, the robustness of DOV against copyright evasion attacks (CEA) remains unexplored. In this paper, we investigate how adversaries can circumvent these mechanisms, enabling models trained on watermarked datasets to bypass ownership verification. We begin by analyzing the limitations of potential attacks achieved by backdoor removal, including TPD and T2IShield. In practice, TPD suffers from inconsistent effectiveness due to randomness, while T2IShield fails when watermarks are embedded as local image patches. To this end, we introduce CEAT2I, the first CEA specifically targeting DOV in T2I diffusion models. CEAT2I consists of three stages: (1) motivated by the observation that T2I models converge faster on watermarked samples with respect to intermediate features rather than training loss, we reliably detect watermarked samples; (2) we iteratively ablate tokens from the prompts of detected samples and monitor feature shifts to identify trigger tokens; and (3) we apply a closed-form concept erasure method to remove the injected watermarks. Extensive experiments demonstrate that CEAT2I effectively evades state-of-the-art DOV mechanisms while preserving model performance. The code is available at https://github.com/csyufei/CEAT2I.

title: Fault Ride-Through Strategy of Grid-Forming Converters Based on Two Stage Virtual Admittance Control: Enhancing Transient Stability and Grid Support Capability
authors: Mengqi Liu, Wenhao Xie, Jianbo Gao, Qiwu Wang, Wei Wang, Guofeng Dong, Tong Ni, Fangfang Zhang, Yu Li
abstract: Grid-forming (GFM) converters are required to meet multiple operational and control demands in power systems. Under grid fault conditions, maintaining transient synchronization stability (TSS), suppressing fault overcurrent, maximizing fault current support, and preserving voltage source characteristics are all of critical importance. However, achieving effective coordination among these objectives remains challenging. To overcome these limitations, this paper proposes a systematic fault ride-through control strategy capable of rapid current limiting while ensuring the existence of a stable equilibrium point (SEP). Specifically, a novel concept of the GFM operational region is introduced, where the existence of the SEP is rigorously determined via a geometric interpretation, providing a solid stability foundation for the control design. Subsequently, a two-stage virtual admittance (VA) control strategy with accurate current-limiting capability is developed. This strategy employs a predominantly inductive steady-state VA for precise fault current regulation, while incorporating a transient virtual resistance to increase the resistive component of the transient VA, thereby dynamically suppressing current surges. Compared to conventional fixed virtual impedance methods, this approach achieves a balance between steady-state accuracy and transient suppression performance. Furthermore, a coordinated active and reactive power reference strategy is proposed to enhance TSS and ensure maximum fault current injection. Experimental results demonstrate that, the proposed control strategy exhibits superior comprehensive performance in maintaining system stability, achieving fast current limiting, and providing enhanced fault current support, validating its effectiveness.

title: Adaptive DOA Estimation Method Based on Frequency Agile Radar with Joint Transmit-Receive Processing
authors: Ruofan Liu, Bo Jiu, Danlei Xu, Youlin Fan, Hongwei Liu
abstract: Frequency Agile (FA) radar achieves superior antijamming capabilities by modulating the carrier frequency across different pulses. However, the array manifold changes with the carrier frequencies of different pulses, making it challenging to utilize multi-frequency information for Direction of Arrival (DOA) estimation effectively. This paper presents a DOA estimation method for FA radar in both random frequency mode and adaptive mode. Initially, in random frequency mode, the algorithm runs at the receiver while the transmitter’s carrier frequency varies randomly. A dictionary matrix that integrates multi-carrier frequency information is developed to estimate the DOA of multiple targets using Sparse Recovery (SR) theory. Subsequently, the theoretical performance bounds for DOA estimation in the random frequency mode are analytically derived. Utilizing the pre-estimated DOA results obtained from the random frequency mode, the adaptive mode jointly optimizes both carrier frequency and dictionary matrix to lower theoretical performance bounds, thereby improving the accuracy and resolution of multi-target DOA estimation. The experimental results validate the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm, showing significant improvements in DOA estimation performance compared to traditional methods.

title: Unified MPC for Primary Control of Distributed Energy Resources with LCL Filter under Safety Constraints
authors: Dave Figueroa, Ignacio A. Acosta, Jaime Guzmán, Juan C. Agüero, César A. Silva
publish: IEEE Journal of Emerging and Selected Topics in Power Electronics
abstract: This paper presents and experimentally validates a unified primary model-based predictive control (MPC) strategy for distributed energy resources (DERs). The proposed primary control simultaneously regulates voltage, frequency, and internal filter voltages and currents, eliminating the need for traditional internal control loops. Additionally, the method can set a predefined operating point while imposing constraints on the inverter’s output current. To achieve these objectives, the MPC incorporates the dynamics of the LCL filter, improving the system’s prediction accuracy. The MPC problem is formulated as a quadratic programming (QP) task solved using the OSQP solver for computational efficiency. Experimental results validate the effectiveness of the proposed primary control approach, demonstrating its practical feasibility and robust performance.

title: Modulation-Aware OFDM Design For DF-FD Cooperative Broadcast Systems
authors: Hala Mostafa, Mohamed Marey
abstract: We develop a modulation recognition algorithm for orthogonal frequency division multiplexing (OFDM) signals in decode-and-forward (DF) full-duplex (FD) cooperative broadcast systems. In such networks, accurate detection of the source modulation scheme is critical for reliable data detection at the destination. The proposed method jointly exploits the temporal delay diversity inherent in DF-FD architectures and feedback from the data decoding process to refine recognition decisions while maintaining manageable complexity. An iterative expectation–maximization procedure is designed for the maximum-likelihood estimate of the modulation format, with the additional capability of estimating timing information and frequency-selective channel parameters. Simulated evaluations under various OFDM scenarios verify the steady superiority of the proposed solution over conventional techniques.
