title: Real-World Gait Speed Estimation: an AI-based Approach for Adaptive Wearable Devices Integration
authors: Michele Zanoletti, Carlo Vallati, Nicola Carbonaro, Alberto Greco, Alessandro Tognetti, Marco Laurino
abstract: Real-world gait speed assessment, has recently gained recognition as an important health indicator particularly in patients with chronic conditions such as Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD). This study proposes an AI-based method for estimating gait speed in the real-world context in COPD patients using different combinations of three wearable devices: a smartphone, a smartwatch, and a pair of sensorized shoes. An analysis pipeline is developed and trained using laboratory datasets, then validated on an independent dataset acquired under free-walking conditions, demonstrating strong performance in both walking detection and gait speed estimation with mean accuracies across different device combinations of 0.81, 0.93, and 0.90 for resting, walking, and stair climbing activities, respectively, as well as a mean RMSE of 0.118 m/s and an ICC of 0.80. The estimated speed, obtained by applying the developed pipeline to daily life data of COPD patients, showed a strong and significant correlation with the clinical standard of functional capacity, the six-minutes walking distance (6MWD) across 34 patients (Spearman coefficient = 0.854, p-value = 1.38e-10). These findings highlight the feasibility of unobtrusive, continuous gait speed monitoring in real-life conditions, offering a promising integrative tool to traditional clinical assessments. The results suggest that wearable-based mobility monitoring could enhance remote patient management and personalized care strategies for COPD and other chronic conditions.

title: Exploiting Binary Semantics: Enhancing Function Name Inference in Stripped Binaries via LLMs
authors: Kailong Wang, Han Zhang, Dongliang Fang, Zhongwei Gu, Zhanwei Song, Yongle Chen, Zhiqiang Shi, Limin Sun
publish: 2025 IEEE International Performance, Computing, and Communications Conference (IPCCC)
abstract: Function name inference in stripped binaries is a crucial task that supports various security applications, including vulnerability detection and malware analysis. Existing methods suffer from limited model capacity and insufficient exploitation of function semantics, which constrains their ability to comprehend binary code and leads to poor generalization on unseen binaries. To address these problems, we propose BinLLM, a novel framework that leverages large language models (LLMs) to exploit the semantic potential of binary code, thereby enhancing function name inference. Specially, BinLLM integrates three key innovations: (1) source code semantics-guided function name refinement, which mitigates the negative effects of low-quality semantic identifiers during training; (2) A context-aware data collection algorithm that seeks richer semantic dependencies to improve model training and inference performance; (3) parameter-efficient fine-tuning on a domain-specific dataset enriched with semantic knowledge to enhance the model's understanding of binary semantics. These components collectively enhance the model's performance in function name inference on unseen binaries. We evaluate BinLLM on a large-scale dataset comprising <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2,864,719$</tex> functions across four architectures (x86-64, x86-32, ARM, MIPS) and four optimization levels (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{O} 0-\mathrm{O} 3$</tex>). Experimental results show that BinLLM achieves substantial improvements over state-of-the-art (SOTA) methods, with relative gains of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$320.1 \%, 274.8 \%$</tex>, and 297.6 % in precision, recall, and F1-score. Ablation studies further validate the effectiveness of each component in enhancing overall performance.

title: Structural Changes in Industrial Employment of the Region's Population in the Post-covid Period
authors: Elena Kozlova, Victoria Kondratkova
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: The dynamics of the sectoral structure of employment (by economic sector) is one of the areas of analysis of the functioning of the labor market, along with the analysis of the dynamics of the employed population by profession, gender and age, education, etc. The quantitative patterns of interrelations of indicators of individual industries reflected in it are the most important economic proportion. Identification of changes in the sectoral structure of employment based on statistical observation and assessment of the volume of intersectoral structural shifts makes it possible to understand trends in the transformation of the regional economic system.

title: KAN versus MLP on Irregular or Noisy Function
authors: Chen Zeng, Jiahui Wang, Haoran Shen, Qiao Wang
publish: 2025 15th IEEE International Conference on Pattern Recognition Systems (ICPRS)
abstract: In this paper, we compare the performance of Kolmogorov-Arnold Networks (KANs) and Multi-Layer Perceptrons (MLPs) Networks on irregular or noisy functions. To ensure a fair comparison, we control for both the number of parameters and the size of the training samples. Specifically, we focus on the functions with jump discontinuities or with coherent oscillations, and analyze the results through the perspective of spectral bias. Our experimental results suggest that the performance of KANs depends heavily on whether the high-frequency components originate from the underlying signal. Furthermore, even when KANs outperform MLPs in quantitative metrics, their behavior can still exhibit undesirable artifacts. For instance, when dealing with functions with jump discontinuities, KANs show Gibbs-like oscillations near the discontinuity. We hope these experiments offer valuable insights for future neural network research and encourage further investigation into overcoming these challenges.

title: Development and Comparative Evaluation of Wound-Field Flux Switching and Flux-Switching Permanent Magnet Machines
authors: Zeynep Tüfek, Bașak Tepretmez, Emrah Çetin
publish: 2025 14th International Symposium on Advanced Topics in Electrical Engineering (ATEE)
abstract: Flux Switching Permanent Magnet Machines (FSPM) and Wound-Field Flux Switching Machines (WF-FSM) hold a critical role in modern electric machine technology. FSPM motors are widely employed in electric vehicles, wind turbines, and highperformance industrial systems due to their high-power density, compact design, and superior efficiency. In contrast, WoundField Flux Switching Machines, with their wound-field rotor structure, provide more precise and flexible torque control, offering low torque ripple, high average torque, and reduced harmonic content, which make them particularly advantageous for applications requiring accurate and stable operation. In this study, the Flux Switching Permanent Magnet Machine was first designed, and using the same design parameters, a WoundField Flux Switching Machine motor was subsequently developed. A parametric analysis was performed in Ansys Maxwell to identify the optimal Direct Current (DC) supply current for the Wound-Field Flux Switching Machine, which was determined to be 17 A. Based on this current, torque and back electromotive force (back EMF) waveforms as well as magnetic flux distribution visualizations were obtained for the WoundField Flux Switching Machine. These results were then employed to perform a comparative evaluation of the performance characteristics of both motors. The analysis revealed that the Wound-Field Flux Switching Machine exhibited a more stable operational profile with low torque ripple and high average torque, whereas the FSPM motor showed more pronounced torque fluctuations and higher harmonic content in its back EMF. Additionally, the Wound-Field Flux Switching Machine demonstrated superior performance in terms of vibration and mechanical stress. The findings of this study indicate that the Wound-Field Flux Switching Machine is a more suitable choice for applications requiring precise and stable motor control, providing valuable insights for motor design optimization and system integration decisions.

title: SoK: AI Support for Analyst Situation Awareness in Security Operation Centres
authors: Navodika Karunasingha, Mohan Baruwal Chhetri, Surya Nepal, Cecile Paris, Salil S. Kanhere
abstract: Cyber situation awareness (CSA) is critical for effective decision-making in Security Operations Centres (SOCs). However, existing research lacks a structured understanding of how AI systems support analyst CSA across different decision-making modes. This paper presents a systematisation of knowledge (SoK) that examines how AI-enabled tools contribute to the three levels of CSA: perception, comprehension and projection, across three decision-making modes: automated, augmented, and collaborative. We introduce a three-dimensional framework to assess 73 selected studies, mapping AI support across CSA levels and decision-making modes, specifically for SOC Tier 1 and Tier 2 incident detection and response activities. Our analysis reveals a dominant focus on perception-level support in automated settings, limited attention to higher-level CSA in augmented mode, and no work addressing collaborative decision-making. These findings highlight critical gaps and inform future research directions for designing AI systems that more comprehensively enhance analyst CSA in SOCs.

title: Remote Monitoring and Control of Environmental Factors in Smart Agriculture
authors: Ivo Dochev, Marin Dochev, Lilyana Docheva, Stoycho Manev
abstract: In recent years, there has been a permanent change in the climate, one of the factors being a decrease in the amount of precipitation. This leads to problems in agriculture, when growing different types of crops. In order to deal with this problem, it is necessary to apply precision (intelligent) agriculture. Precision agriculture allows for improved resource management, which in turn allows for increased yields and quality of agricultural production, which leads to a better economic effect,This article proposes an architecture and operating algorithm for a remote monitoring and control system used in precision (smart) agriculture.

title: Incoming Inspection of Vacuum Circuit Breakers
authors: Iliana Bogdanova, George Milushev, Krasimir Galabov
publish: 2025 XXXV International Scientific Symposium Metrology and Metrology Assurance (MMA)
abstract: The very high dependence of the reliability of Vacuum Circuit Breakers and Tap Changers on the quality and reliability of Vacuum Chambers (Interrupters) leads to they to be subject to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 0 0}$</tex> percent inspection before they are involved into operation. The schematic description of the work of Vacuum Arc-Extinguishing Chamber aims to establish the main procedures for their incoming inspection. Sets of equipment for Physical and Chemical Laboratories are presented, covering the necessary activities for incoming control of Vacuum ArcExtinguishing Chambers. The statistics of defects during incoming inspection over a 3-month period were analyzed and the batch acceptance control value was determined.

title: A Live Provenance & Movement Monitoring System for Digital and Physical Art
authors: Haydeer MohamadAbbas, Pokhraj Sahu, A. S. Kannan, Mahmudov Kahramon Shuhratjon Ugli, K. Karunambiga, D. Ravi Kishore, Sujitha R, S. Y. Malati
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems and Pioneering Innovations in Robotics and Electric Mobility (INSPIRE)
abstract: Although the global art industry is adjusting to digital trends, it is still troubled by forgery, losing information about a work’s past, and the difficulty in tracking all artworks at any time. This research proposes a new framework, NFTraX-ART, that leverages dynamic Non-Fungible Tokens (dNFTs), IoT smart tags, and blockchain to enable live tracking, smooth ownership transfers, and a clear asset history for art. Unlike static NFTs, dNFTs keep changing as metadata that shows where they are now, who owns them, their exhibition history, and their official appraisal information is updated. As for physical artworks, Internet of Things technology with location and movement sensors continuously sends this data to the blockchain to confirm their authenticity and provide clear traceability. Using smart contracts, royalties are automatically applied, all transactions are validated, and alerts are sent when any movements are made outside the programmed areas. Thanks to this mode, the system connects digital and physical worlds, making it safe and straightforward to track essential art pieces. It outlines the important steps for the methodology, the smart contract code, and the simulation process, and checks how the model stacks up against today’s static NFT platforms. According to the results, blockchain systems are more accurate, safer, and track transaction history. Thanks to NFTraX-ART, everyone involved has a secure, up-to-date record of every artwork. Using this approach, NFTs take on an active role in the tracking system, helping change how art is possessed, transferred, and appreciated in the art trading world.

title: Application of Combined Millisecond and Nanosecond Pulses to Increase Laser Processing Productivity
authors: Alexander Shepelev, Sergei Solokhin, Igor Shilov, Sergei Smetanin, Mikhail Ershkov
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: A method for increasing the productivity of laser processing of materials has been proposed, based on combining the advantages of high-energy laser pulses and short high-intensity pulses, while redistributing the generated energy according to the temporal profile of the pulse in accordance with the physical processes occurring in the laser processing zone. The practical implementation of this approach has been demonstrated using an YAG:Nd laser with combined pumping and Q-switched mode, which generates complex-profile pulses with a millisecond duration, including short trains of nanosecond pulses.

title: Performance Analysis of Multicast VANET Strategies in NDN-Based Vehicular Networks Using 3x2 Grid Topology
authors: Syaiful Ahdan, Juan Kevin Aritonang, Syauqi Armand, Anisa Mahadewi, Eki Ahmad Zaki Hamidiec, Iskandar, Nana Rachmana Syambas
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Telecommunication Systems, Services, and Applications (TSSA)
abstract: Named Data Networking (NDN) introduces a data- centric approach to vehicular communication, providing an efficient alternative to traditional IP-based systems. This study evaluates the performance of multicast VANET strategies in NDN-based vehicular networks using a six-grid topology as the simulation environment. The analysis focuses on various performance metrics, including data retrieval latency, Interest satisfaction rate, and network overhead, under differing parameter configurations. The six-grid topology represents a structured vehicular network scenario, enabling a comprehensive evaluation of multicast strategies. Simulation results reveal the impact of multicast VANET strategies on network performance and demonstrate their potential for optimizing data dissemination in NDN-based vehicle-to-vehicle (V2V) communication. These findings offer valuable insights into improving scalability and efficiency in Intelligent Transport Systems (ITS).

title: Study of Tripod Elastic Parallel Mechanism for Mechanical Neural Network
authors: Dobri Komarski, Dimitar Diakov, Velizar Vassilev, Hristiana Nikolova
publish: 2025 XXXV International Scientific Symposium Metrology and Metrology Assurance (MMA)
abstract: This paper presents the design and analysis of 3-Degrees-of-Freedom (3-DOF) tripod elastic parallel mechanism developed as a part of larger surface-shaping mechanical neural network that manipulates multiple of these elastic tripods. While traditional rigid-link parallel manipulators offer advantages in stiffness and precision, they are often limited by inherent issues such as friction, backlash, and wear associated with conventional kinematic joints. This proposed structure addresses these limitations by leveraging the inherent flexibility and controlled deformation of compliant elements, typically realized through flexure hinges, to achieve three degrees of freedom (e.g., one translational and two rotational motions) without the need for discrete joints. The compliant nature of the tripod facilitates monolithic structure, leading to enhanced repeatability and reduced assembly complexity.

title: Revisiting Power Measurement in FPGA Systems: Limitations of DRAM Power Models and Insights from Resistor-Based Techniques
authors: Saeideh Alinezhad, Arnab Bag, Yutong Cai, Xinyu Shi
abstract: Field-programmable gate arrays (FPGAs) are increasingly used in both academic and industrial research to evaluate new designs and systems due to their ability to deliver realistic and reliable power and performance metrics. They are especially valuable for validating simulators and calibrating models. Among these metrics, power consumption is critical—particularly for low-power designs—but measuring it accurately outside of simulation environments presents challenges in terms of cost and complexity.To address this, FPGA boards often rely on built-in sensors and monitoring systems. However, such tools are not universally available across all platforms. In this paper, We revisit power measurement using a simple shunt resistor method and demonstrate its effectiveness across FPGA platforms. Using this setup, we analyze how different workloads and memory hierarchies influence both memory and system power. Our study highlights trade-offs often missed in DRAM power models, such as the cache power overhead that can outweigh memory savings, and the shifting efficiency of on-chip memory under contention. Together, these results provide practical guidance for power-aware FPGA evaluation and model calibration.

title: A Heuristic Approach for Solving Ring Topology Network
authors: Jupriyadi, Hasan Nur Arifin, Eki Ahmad Zaki Hamidi, Nana Rachmana Syambas
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Telecommunication Systems, Services, and Applications (TSSA)
abstract: Ring topology is a topology design widely used in networks, especially backbone networks. In designing a ring topology, the problem that is solved is how to connect each node to form a ring with the optimum total cost. The optimum weight is the path with the best bandwidth and delay in the topology. To solve these problems can be modeled like the Traveling Salesman Problem (TSP). The main goal to be achieved by the TSP algorithm is to find the optimum path with a fast search time. This paper proposes a new heuristic algorithm approach to find the optimum route. The proposed algorithm will be compared with existing TSP algorithms like ant colony optimization (ACO) to validate the results of the proposed algorithm. The brute force algorithm can find the optimum path though it takes a very long time as the number of nodes increases. The ACO algorithm can find the most optimum route faster than the brute force algorithm. Based on the tests, the proposed algorithm can find the most optimal path with a faster time than the ACO algorithm. In addition, the proposed algorithm can find the optimal route that is better than the ACO algorithm.

title: Cybersecurity and AI-generated programming code
authors: Willian DImitrov, Dragostin Tsecov, Valentin Ruzhenov, Alexander Kirkov, Yoana Hadzhiyska, Svetlana Syarova
publish: 2025 International Conference on Big Data, Knowledge and Control Systems Engineering (BdKCSE)
abstract: The article aims to present a study with analysis and systematization of the consequences for cybersecurity following the application of artificial intelligence in generating program code. A systematization of the problems related to the security of program code caused by the use of AI in programming is proposed. It contains a brief analysis of the individual issues and recommendations for practical measures. In conclusion, an analysis is made, from which conclusions are drawn for a wide range of research topics related to the security of work with the capabilities of AI-produced program code.

title: Coal and Gangue Accurate Classification Based on YOLOv8-MSGA
authors: Jianyu Wang, Jun Xing, Jionghui Guo, Bing Han, Xinzhe Wang, Jianchao Fan
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Trends in Computational Intelligence (NTCI)
abstract: In the coal process, coal-gangue classification is a critical link that directly determines the subsequent processing quality and production efficiency. Statistics show that over $80 \%$ of global small and medium-sized coal mines still rely on manual visual inspection for this task. However, the high similarity in color, texture, and morphology between coal and gangue results in an average manual misjudgment rate of $15 \%-20 \%$, severely hindering the intelligent transformation of the coal mining industry. Thus, developing accurate, real-time automatic classification technology is practically significant for mining intelligent upgrading. Manual classification is susceptible to operators’ subjective experience and on-site lighting variations. Existing YOLO-series models lack adequate ability to capture subtle feature differences between coal and gangue, making it hard to balance real-time performance and accuracy in complex mine environments. In response to these challenges, this work introduces a multi-scale gated attention (MSGA) module into YOLOv8, forming the YOLOv8-MSGA framework, while further employing varied data augmentation strategies and refining the neck fusion mechanism. Using on-site samples, a 4,000-image dataset was formed after augmentation. Tests show the model achieves 96.10% MAP@0.5 and 38.52 FPS, meeting real-time sorting requirements and supporting intelligent mining.

title: AI Method for Power MOSFET I-V Characterisation of High Voltage - High Current Region
authors: Matthew Taylor, Ke Li, Neophytos Lophitis, Md Rishad Ahmed, Adam Lewis, Paul Evans
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th Workshop on Wide Bandgap Power Devices and Applications (WiPDA)
abstract: This paper presents a novel data-driven methodology for characterising the full I-V characteristics of a Silicon Carbide MOSFET using an Artificial Neural Network (ANN). The method uses a Machine Learning (ML) algorithm to extract the high voltage-high current characteristics of the device. By training the network with both static and dynamic measurement data, the method achieves high accuracy across a wide voltage and current range. It eliminates the need for extensive manual parameter extraction traditionally required by physical models, offering a more accessible and efficient pathway to device modelling. The ANN-based model demonstrates robust interpolation performance within the measured data range and shows encouraging extrapolation capabilities towards the device’s rated limits.

title: Traffic Light Recognition Method for Vehicle Platforms Based on Lightweight MobileViT Network
authors: Hengyi Yang, Wugedele Bao, Juan Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Trustworthy Big Data and Artificial Intelligence (ICTBAI)
abstract: Traffic light recognition on vehicle platforms is crucial for advanced driver assistance systems, but it faces severe challenges such as limited mobile terminal resources, high real-time requirements, and complex environmental interference. To this end, this paper proposes a traffic light recognition method based on lightweight MobileViT network. First, MobileViT, which combines the advantages of CNN (Convolutional Neural Network) local feature extraction and Transformer global modeling, is used as the backbone network. Subsequently, the network architecture and training strategy are specifically tailored to address the challenges associated with small traffic light targets. Finally, deep compression techniques are applied to ensure compatibility with the computational constraints of vehicle platforms. Experiments show that the recognition accuracy of MobileViT is 92% under normal lighting conditions, 85% under low lighting conditions, and 80% for small target recognition. The real-time reasoning experimental results show that MobileViT achieves an inference speed of 35 FPS with an input of 224x224 pixels, and the amount of calculation (Floating Point Operations, FLOPs) is 0.3B. Compared with other models, MobileViT finds a better balance between accuracy and computational efficiency, showing stronger robustness and efficiency, and is suitable for actual vehicle environments.

title: Analysis of Losses in Vanadium Redox Flow Batteries
authors: Vignesh Kumar, Mikhail Pugach, Aslan Kasimov
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: In this work, we comprehensively describe a two dimensional (2D) isothermal steady state model for a vanadium redox flow battery cell and numerically solve it to evaluate and compare the contribution of three factors to the total loss in cell voltage. The three contributors are: the activation overpotential (extra potential required to sustain reactions), the ohmic overpotential (loss in voltage due to resistances between internal components of the cell) and the diffusion potential across the membrane (a component of the membrane potential). We additionally evaluate how diffusion potential across the membrane affects the voltage efficiency of the cell and examine several kilowatt-class batteries to demonstrate the power loss caused by this diffusion potential.

title: Secure and Privacy-Preserving Data Aggregation Against Malicious Gateway in RPL-Based Internet of Things
authors: Image Bhattarai, Cong Pu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Performance, Computing, and Communications Conference (IPCCC)
abstract: In the era of Industry 4.0 (4IR), the Internet of Things (IoT) drives the transformation of conventional operation mode into intelligent systems through interconnecting smart devices to monitor, analyze, and optimize the target applications. In order to achieve energy-saving data transmission, a routing protocol, called RPL, has been specified for resource-challenged IoT devices and networks. In the context of 4IR, the IoT technology is being widely used for mission-critical systems, and the data collected by IoT devices might contain privacy-sensitive information. In addition, the IoT gateway could be compromised due to the lack of necessary and persistent physical and/or logical security protection. Hence, the protection of data security and privacy becomes a crucial factor for RPL-based IoT systems to realize their quality of service requirements and objectives successfully. In this paper, we propose a secure and privacy-preserving data aggregation approach, called SPARDA, for IoT devices and networks running the RPL routing protocol. SPARDA is realized with physical unclonable function, homomorphic encryption, and trapdoor function, and is perfectly integrated with the RPL routing protocol to prevent the malicious IoT gateway from either accessing, falsificating, or corrupting the real-time data from IoT devices throughout the data gathering and summarization phase. We choose an automatic security protocol verification tool, widely known as AVISPA, to analyze and verify the security specification of SPARDA. We also conduct an experimental study to evaluate the performance of SPARDA by comparing with benchmark methods. The experimental results indicate that not only does SPARDA protect IoT networks from malicious gateway attacks, but it also outperforms existing schemes in terms of computation and storage overheads while satisfying all critical security and privacy criteria.

title: Measurements and Artificial Intelligence: Challenges of Standardization
authors: Roald Taymanov, Kseniia Sapozhnikova
publish: 2025 XXXV International Scientific Symposium Metrology and Metrology Assurance (MMA)
abstract: Over the next several decades, the deployment of diverse artificial intelligence (AI) systems, including measuring instruments, will become a critically important and vital objective for society. Its realization necessitates intensive digitalization across all areas of life. The development of AI is associated, on the one hand, with the growth of new opportunities, and on the other hand, with risks stemming from AI-driven decision-making processes. Concurrently, there is a growing concern about constraints on AI development arising from the integration of AI-based systems within automated environments, including cyber-physical systems. The challenges of standardization in this field are examined. Following the approval of the EU AI Act in 2024, new approaches are being discussed to limit the risks associated with the application of AI systems without hindering their development.

title: Challenges and Opportunities for Circuits and Systems for Next Generation Satellite Payloads [Feature]
authors: Piero Angeletti, Salvatore D’Addio
abstract: The evolution of satellite communication systems is increasingly driven by the need for high-performance, flexible, and efficient solutions, particularly in the design and implementation of circuits and systems for next-generation satellite payloads. Software defined payloads leveraging on On-Board Digital Signal Processing (OBP), Multi-Beam Antennas (MBAs) and Beam-Forming Networks (BFNs) are pivotal technologies in addressing the challenges posed by emerging communication standards, such as 5G/6G, as well as advanced satellite communication, navigation, and remote sensing systems. The realization of these flexible payloads presents significant challenges for circuits and systems designers. These include developing high-frequency, RF and mixed-signal circuits for active phased arrays, designing power-efficient digital signal processing architectures for real-time routing and beamforming, ensuring robust power management systems, and achieving extreme miniaturization through advanced VLSI and SoC integration while maintaining radiation hardness and efficient thermal management. These demands, however, create vast opportunities for innovation in novel analog and digital circuit architectures, efficient data converters, high-speed interfaces, and integrated system-on-chip solutions that leverage advanced semiconductor processes for space-grade reliability and performance. This synergy between evolving market demands, cutting-edge payload technologies, and the continuous innovation in circuit and system design is transforming SATCOM systems, and is essential for industry’s continued growth and relevance.

title: Measurement of the vehicle pollution during fuel remap process on a gasoline engine
authors: Ilian Damyanov, Rosen Miletiev, Hristo Konakchiev
abstract: A "fuel remap" refers to economy remap, which is a process that adjusts a vehicle's Engine Control Unit (ECU) to improve fuel efficiency, to reduce the emissions or to increase the power. Regardless of the fuel remap ultimate goal, this process leads to the engine emission change. The current paper proposed a measurement system for a gasoline engine pollution detection during the remap process. The nitrogen oxides, carbon oxide and the hydrocarbons levels are monitored and also the particulate matters (PM) according to the Euro 7 standard requirements. The external temperature and pressure are measured and compared with the gas exhaust temperature and relative humidity to clarify all combustion processes. The accomplished test with the fuel remap process shows significant increase of the pollution levels of the detected gases and the ultrafine particulate matters with size up to 1µm.

title: mmDFC: Multi-Modality Dynamic Fusion and Modal-Decoupled Alternating Optimization for Retinal Vessel Occlusion Prognosis
authors: Xinyu Huo, Yige Peng, Yupeng Xu, Jinman Kim, Suqin Yu, Lei Bi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Digital Image Computing: Techniques and Applications (DICTA)
abstract: Multi-modality SS-OCTA (Swept-Source Optical Coherence Tomography Angiography), which combines structural B-scan and vascular Angio-flow data, has been shown to be an effective modality to predict Retinal Vein Occlusion (RVO) diseases outcomes. However, there is a paucity of research in leveraging complementary information via multimodality fusion of SS-OCTA, where conventional fusion strategies are limited in their ability to extract RVO prognosisrelated features. We identified three key challenges with existing methods: (1) the dominance of information-rich modalities (e.g., B-scan) over other modalities (e.g., Angio-flow); (2) static weighting in multi-modality fusion which causes sub-optimal of fusion at inference stage; and (3) the failure of 2D models to capture 3D spatial contextual information from volumetric imaging data. To address these challenges, we propose a 3D multi-modality Dynamic Fusion ConvNeXt (mmDFC) framework. Our mmDFC introduces three contributions: (1) a decoupled training approach with ConvNeXt encoders to mitigate modality dominance by preserving specified gradient information for each input source; (2) an uncertainty-aware dynamic fusion mechanism to optimally balance the weights of different modalities; (3) a 3D ConvNeXt architecture to effectively learn the spatial context from SS-OCTA slices. Our framework achieved state-of-the-art accuracy of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$75 \%$</tex> and an AUC of 71.3% for NPA prediction on clinical 3D SS-OCTA RVO dataset. Notably, our 3D approach yielded a 6.2% AUC improvement over an analogous 2D framework, demonstrating the value of volumetric spatial context. Our 3D mmDFC sets a new benchmark for SS-OCTA image analysis, providing a robust approach to prognostic assessment in RVO.

title: On the Analysis of Signals with Special Characteristics Useful in Physiology
authors: Constantin Daniel Oancea
publish: 2025 14th International Symposium on Advanced Topics in Electrical Engineering (ATEE)
abstract: There are signals with special characteristics, used to highlight the pathology of biological cells/tissues. Knowing very well the characteristics of these signals is important to avoid influencing or damaging the analyzed environment. The purpose of this article is to present some signals associated with mathematical functions and which can be used with certain precautions. In particular, functions that have Fourier spectrum, but without the direct current (DC) component, an important feature to avoid electrolysis in the analyzed environments, are sought. To analyze these particularities, the Scilab programming environment was used as an application, which also has the advantages of lower cost and portability (can be used in Microsoft and Linux operating systems).

title: Radiometric Consistency Between NOAA-21 OMPS Nadir Mapper and Geo-Compsat-2B GEMS
authors: Sirish Uprety, Banghua Yan, Trevor Beck
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: The Ozone Mapping and Profiler Suite (OMPS) and the Geostationary Environment Monitoring Spectrometer (GEMS) are satellite instruments designed to monitor atmospheric composition, primarily ozone. OMPS onboard SNPP/NOAA-20/NOAA-21 satellites are polar orbiting instruments, providing global coverage once a day. However, GEMS, onboard South Korea's GEO-KOMPSAT-2B satellite, is a geostationary satellite instrument providing more frequent observations over East Asia and adjacent areas. This difference in their orbits defines their unique capabilities and limitations, making intercomparison an essential exercise for harmonizing their datasets and validating their respective ozone retrievals. OMPS provides global coverage, delivering ozone profiles and trace gases with a lower temporal resolution but comprehensive spatial coverage. GEMS complements this by offering high temporal resolution data, allowing the monitoring of diurnal variations in ozone. The intercomparison between OMPS and GEMS helps to evaluate radiometric calibration consistency of measurements. This study focuses on quantifying the radiometric consistency between NOAA-21 OMPS Nadir Mapper (NM) radiance and reflectance measurements with GEMS. One of the benefits of GEO-LEO intercomparison is the satellites have nearly frequent simultaneous overlapping observations. The sensor intercomparison is performed near nadir for OMPS and GEMS, less than 8° view zenith angle. The radiometric bias results provide a good understanding of how well NOAA-21 OMPS agree with GEMS. The results could help to provide independent validation of OMPS data quality. The study could be further expanded to perform intercomparison of GEMS with SNPP and NOAA-20, resulting in opportunities to evaluate the OMPS radiometric consistency through double difference. This could help to further confirm the SNPP, NOAA-20 and, NOAA-21 OMPS radiometric agreements from the past studies performed using 32-day global average and using deep convective clouds. The results presented in this study are valuable for user communities to better understand how well the OMPS and GEMS agree with each other.

title: Classroom Dynamics Perception and Precise Teaching Behavior Intervention via Multi-View Transforme
authors: Xiangting Gao, Kun Yang, Mario Di Nardo
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Modern Education and Information Management (ICMEIM)
abstract: Ensuring effective teaching and learning processes is a key challenge in advancing the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), particularly Goal 4 on Quality Education. Traditional classroom behavior analysis often relies on manual observation, which is subjective, labor-intensive, and difficult to scale, thereby limiting its ability to provide timely and accurate feedback for instructional improvement. To address these limitations, this study proposes an improved multi-view Transformer framework for classroom dynamics perception and precise teaching intervention. The framework integrates cross-view geo-alignment with attention fusion to ensure semantic consistency across multiple camera views, introduces role-aware hierarchical queries to highlight teacher-student interactions, and employs decision-guided multitask learning to align recognition outcomes with practical intervention needs. Experiments conducted on real multi-view classroom videos demonstrate that the proposed model achieves superior performance in behavior classification, temporal modeling, and intervention ranking compared with existing baselines. This work not only contributes to advancing intelligent education analytics but also provides methodological support for achieving SDGs in promoting equitable, inclusive, and highquality education.

title: TriAtt-HRNet: Attention-Enhanced High-Resolution Network for Spine Landmark Detection
authors: Wenhe Bai, Yapeng Wang, Xu Yang, Sio-Kei Im
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Data Mining (ICDM)
abstract: Accurate identification of anatomical landmarks in spinal X-ray images plays a vital role in the quantitative diagnosis and clinical management of spinal disorders. In this study, we introduce TriAtt-HRNet, a novel high-resolution network designed for vertebral landmark detection, which incorporates a tri-branch attention mechanism. Built upon the HRNet backbone, our architecture integrates spatial, channel, and combined attention modules to enhance feature representations by capturing both global structural context and fine-grained local details. The proposed method is evaluated on the public BUU-LSPINE dataset using standard metrics, including MAE, MRE, and SDR. Experimental results demonstrate that TriAtt-HRNet consistently outperforms existing state-of-the-art models in terms of accuracy and robustness. These improvements underline the potential of our method to serve as a reliable tool for automated spinal assessment and may contribute to improved clinical workflows in spine diagnosis and treatment planning.

title: Advanced Techniques For Gain Regulation In Ultra High-Speed Variable Gain Amplifier Design
authors: Sargis Khachatryan
abstract: Gain control in modern Variable Gain Amplifier (VGA) designs is typically achieved through load resistor-based or current Digital to Analog Converter (DAC)-based techniques, each offering distinct advantages and trade-offs. While resistor-based methods provide simplicity, they often degrade bandwidth. Current DAC-based approaches offer finer control and faster switching but suffer from linearity issues at low current levels and require significant silicon area. These limitations pose challenges in advanced Serializer/Deserializer (SERDES) systems where area efficiency and high-speed performance are critical.To address these constraints, a new gain control technique is proposed that utilizes a controllable resistor circuit placed between the differential output nodes of the VGA. This output-stage configuration minimizes interference with the signal path and biasing circuitry, enabling effective gain reduction without compromising linearity. The design employs NMOS transistors as programmable resistive elements, controlled via a 3-bit thermometric scheme, offering discrete gain steps with minimal area and power overhead. Although the method supports only unidirectional gain control, it remains highly suitable for high-speed SERDES applications. Initial gain can be set using conventional techniques, with this approach providing fine-tuning capabilities. Despite a slight increase in output capacitance, the overall impact on performance is negligible, making this solution a compact, power-efficient alternative for advanced Analog Front-End AFE designs.

title: Robotic Hand Operated by Strings and Servo Motors
authors: Prashobh Karunakaran, Mohd. Shahril Osman, Denis Siaw
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Computing and Communication Technologies (CONECCT)
abstract: Current day robots are operated with three categories of algorithms: firstly, following a set of instructions, secondly following the movements of a human and thirdly with the utilization of AI. This research works on the second category. These robots find use in performing very critical tasks like specialized welding, handling hazardous materials or operating on a human body. Current robots that do these jobs require humans to wear a glove with numerous piezoelectric sensors within them. Failure of these sensors could lead to the robot arm not following the instruction correctly. In this research a robot is designed and built to the gestures of a human hand moving in front of a laptop camera. The motors that are actuated are placed away from the arm that does the work and elastic strings are used to transmit the actuation of the servo motors to move the fingers of the robot arm. This way the motors will not get contaminated by the hazardous material and can be more easily maintained. Two software were used, one to capture the hand movement and convert it to binary data and the second to operate the motors.

title: Agent-based Air Monitoring Platform
authors: Jordan Todorov, Stanimir Stoyanov, Veneta Tabakova-Komsalova, Ivan Stoyanov, Asya Stoyanova-Doycheva, Katharina Wassilew
publish: 2025 International Conference on Big Data, Knowledge and Control Systems Engineering (BdKCSE)
abstract: This paper presents an agent-oriented architecture for air quality monitoring, called AIRGuard, which integrates concepts from Multi-Agent Systems (MAS), event-driven architectures, and semantic ontologies. The architecture is implemented on top of the Jadex BDI platform and integrated into a Spring Boot environment with an Android client. The main active components are three BDI agents-CorrespondentAgent, OntologyAgent, and DatabaseAgent-which perform parallel processing of subtasks, including retrieving regulatory thresholds from an OWL-based ontology and empirical observations via an external REST API. A formal event model is introduced to define atomic and complex events for parameters such as PM10 and PM2.5, enabling the application of rules for exceedance detection and long-term averaging. The proposed architecture demonstrates high modularity, interoperability, and resilience, while facilitating the integration of additional agents and predictive mechanisms.

title: Innovative Research on Practice Teaching Model of Engineering Cost Specialty Based on Artificial Intelligence
authors: Jianwei Sun, Meng Liu
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Modern Education and Information Management (ICMEIM)
abstract: With the rapid development of artificial intelligence technology, digital transformation opens up a new path for intelligent reconstruction of practical teaching mode of engineering cost specialty. In order to solve the problem that traditional teaching model is difficult to dynamically adapt to students' operation differences, multi-dimensional ability evaluation and real-time error intervention, this study proposes an intelligent teaching decision-making optimization model based on deep reinforcement learning. The core adopts deep double-Q network algorithm. Through reinforcement learning framework, the model takes learning behavior parameters as inputs, combines experience playback and goal network mechanism, and dynamically generates teaching strategies. Experiments show that compared with CNN, LSTM and original DQN algorithms, deep double-Q network performs best on cumulative reward (486.2) and discounted cumulative reward (623.8), and its convergence speed is improved by about <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2 2 \%}$</tex>. It is applied to the engineering cost training platform to verify its effectiveness in 89 seconds average error response speed and personalized intervention, and the teaching efficiency improvement rate reaches 18.7%. This study provides a transferable methodological framework for the intelligent evaluation system in education field, and helps to optimize the effectiveness of the whole cycle of practical teaching.

title: Multimodal Learning for Semantic-Aware Hateful Meme Detection in Low-Resource Kannada Memes
authors: Vasukinatha Adiga, Manish M. Kumar, Deekshith Patkar, K. M. Kavitha
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems and Pioneering Innovations in Robotics and Electric Mobility (INSPIRE)
abstract: Detecting hateful content in Kannada memes is challenging given the scarcity of labeled data and the multi-modal nature of the content. This paper presents a multimodal framework, tested on a small dataset of 140 memes with OCR-extracted text. We benchmarked various machine learning and deep learning architectures, including fusion techniques involving IndicBERT, mBERT, and CNN. The most effective configuration was a multimodal fusion model that leveraged a language-specific IndicBERT for language-specific textual features and a CNN for visual analysis, achieving an F1-score of 0.81 and an accuracy of 71%. We incorporate a knowledge graph that maps hateful keywords to underlying semantic topics, providing essential interpretability. This work establishes a robust, effective and interpretable baseline for hate speech detection within the underrepresented domain of Indic language meme analysis.

title: 2D-3D Feature Fusion via Cross-Modal Latent Synthesis and Attention-Guided Restoration for Industrial Anomaly Detection
authors: Usman Ali, Ali Zia, Abdul Rehman, Umer Ramzan, Zohaib Hassan, Talha Sattar, Jing Wang, Wei Xiang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Digital Image Computing: Techniques and Applications (DICTA)
abstract: Industrial anomaly detection (IAD) increasingly benefits from integrating 2D and 3D data, but robust cross-modal fusion remains challenging. We propose a novel unsupervised framework, Multi-Modal Attention-Driven Fusion Restoration (MAFR), which synthesises a unified latent space from RGB images and point clouds using a shared fusion encoder, followed by attention-guided, modality-specific decoders. Anomalies are localised by measuring reconstruction errors between input features and their restored counterparts. Evaluations on the MVTec 3D-AD and Eyecandies benchmarks demonstrate that MAFR achieves state-of-the-art results, with a mean I-AUROC of 0.972 and 0.901, respectively. The framework also exhibits strong performance in few-shot learning settings, and ablation studies confirm the critical roles of the fusion architecture and composite loss. MAFR offers a principled approach for fusing visual and geometric information, advancing the robustness and accuracy of industrial anomaly detection. Code is available at https://github.com/adabrh/MAFR.

title: Controlling the grid inverter powers through the Synchronous Reference Frame Phase Locked Loop
authors: Ciprian Vlad, Nicolae Badea, Cristian Victor Lungu
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Electrical and Electronics Engineering (ISEEE)
abstract: This paper deals with the powers control strategies of inverter grid-tied connected by setting the Synchronous Reference Frame Phase Locked Loop (SRF-PLL). The paper addresses the powers control strategies of inverter connected to the grid presenting mathematical model based on interaction between the voltage source inverter - grid which contains an external control loop for regulating the DC-link voltage, an internal loop for the d-q grid current components and to synchronizing with the grid a Synchronous Frame Phase Locked Loop. The phase angle control done of SRF-PLL was achieved by a PI (Proportional and Integral) controller, processing either the voltage u<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">d</inf> or voltage u<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">q</inf> of the network. In the first case, u<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">d</inf> processed by a PI controller ensures the alignment of the quadrature axis voltage with the grid vector u<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">dq</inf>. In the second case, u<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">q</inf> processed by a PI controller ensures the alignment of the forward axis voltage with the mains vector u<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">dq</inf>. Both strategies were tested under Standard Test Conditions (STC), under extreme temperature conditions from -10oC to +70oC and varying the irradiance between 200W/m<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> and 1000W/m<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>, with similar results. The validation of the proposed solution was done by simulation in the PSIM software and showed that when the PLL processes u<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">d</inf>, the i<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">d</inf> current controls the reactive power Q and i<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">q</inf> the active power P exchanged with the network. If the PLL processes u<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">q</inf>, the i<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">d</inf> current controls the active power and i<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">q</inf>, the reactive power. In both cases, the obtained results are identical for the studied system.

title: A Novel Algorithm for Industrial Network Reliability Estimation and AI-Based System Optimization
authors: Daniel Denev, Silvia Nikolova
abstract: This scientific paper presents a new mathematical algorithm aimed at improving the process of work and assessing the reliability of industrial networks. The main goal is to develop a more accurate and effective method for predicting and analysing potential failures in complex network systems. The algorithm integrates innovative modelling, data analysis and optimization techniques to ensure better resource planning and minimizing downtime of the risky technical system. The research finds application in various industrial sectors, where network reliability is critical for productivity and safety. Furthermore, the study explores the integration of artificial intelligence techniques for improving the reliability and efficiency of industrial and security systems. By combining mathematical modeling with machine learning, the proposed framework enhances system adaptability, failure prediction accuracy, and overall operational safety in complex network environments.

title: Comparative Benchmarking of Floating PV Governance: A Five-Pillar Evaluation of Cirata, Hapcheon, and O'MEGA1
authors: Jack Febrian Rusdi, Vicente Pitogo, Danny Aidil Rismayadi, Didin Kusdian, Heri Sismoro, Nurhaeni Sikki
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Telecommunication Systems, Services, and Applications (TSSA)
abstract: This study proposes a benchmark framework for structural analysis of floating photovoltaic (PV) systems, adapted from the five-pillar architecture of the Cirata deployment. Rather than evaluating performance metrics, the framework assesses modularity, interoperability, and governance reproducibility across technical, institutional, regulatory, social, and digital dimensions. Three candidate projects—Cirata (Indonesia), Hapcheon (South Korea), and O'MEGA1 (France)—were selected using documented criteria for structural alignment across all five pillars. Cirata serves as the reference architecture; Hapcheon reflects government-led inland deployment, while O'MEGA1 illustrates private-sector innovation in marine conditions. Selection criteria and comparative attributes were systematically documented, forming the analytical base for cross-case synthesis. Findings show notable differences in interoperability and governance resilience, influenced by institutional coordination and regulatory embedding. The proposed framework offers a replicable model for evaluating floating PV systems, emphasizing reproducibility in multi-actor energy governance.

title: Regularization and its Development in Mathematical Remodeling
authors: Pavel Saraev
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: The purpose of the study is to analyze the method of regularization of the target functional and to develop this approach for reduction the models complexity in mathematical remodeling ans some other cases. Regularization is a way to increase the adequacy of models by increasing resistance to input data errors. This paper shows how this approach is used for solution of linear equation systems and mathematical models parameters identification, both linear in parameters, using pseudo-inversion of matrices, and nonlinear ones. A connection with the methods of ridge and LASSO regression is noted. The paper considers the ways to generalize regularization by using different norms, weight matrices and combination of norms. A generalization of the regularization approach to solve mathematical remodeling problems is proposed, an approach that is constructed to transform models of one class into another for some benefit. The approach leads to decrease complexity of models, but lose some accuracy.

title: PruneTM: Clause-Driven Feature Ranking and Pruning in Tsetlin Machine
authors: Koushik K, Bethi Pardhasaradhi, Srinivas Boppu, Ole-Christoffer Granmo, Linga Reddy Cenkeramaddi
publish: 2025 International Symposium on the Tsetlin Machine (ISTM)
abstract: There is a growing demand for explainable and interpretable model predictions in high-stake decision-making machine learning applications to ensure transparency, trust, and accountability. The Tsetlin Machine (TM) offers explainability by linking predictions to input features. However, the current TM lacks a systematic feature ranking mechanism. Feature ranking can inherently lead to the pruning of less important features, making TM more efficient in terms of memory and inference. This paper proposes a feature ranking algorithm that leverages all trained clauses. The algorithm computes the frequency of true and false literals across all clauses to assign importance scores to the features. Once the feature ranking is finalized, the less important features are discarded, and a pruned TM is initialized, trained, and used for the prediction. The performance of the proposed algorithm was compared to that of the SHAPbased feature ranking method. The algorithm was evaluated on multiple datasets and cross-validated with tree-based SHAP ranking. The results show that the proposed clause-driven feature importance method yields feature rankings comparable to SHAP while maintaining competitive accuracy with respect to other machine learning models.

title: OpenSim Validation for Healthy and Post-Stroke Gait Analysis: A Comparison with Experimental Motion Capture Data
authors: Anish Behera, Samyak Kumar Mishra, Japteshwar Singh, Jyotindra Narayan, Anil Kumar Pal, Hassène Gritli
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Computing and Communication Technologies (CONECCT)
abstract: Gait analysis is crucial for assessing post-stroke movement impairments and guiding rehabilitation. This study utilizes OpenSim to analyze joint kinematics in healthy and poststroke participants, validating simulation-generated gait data against an experimental motion capture dataset for accuracy and reliability. This study focused on elderly individuals aged 70-75 years from an existing dataset. To examine gait deviations due to stroke-related impairments, Group A included 9 healthy subjects, while Group B comprised 11 post-stroke individuals. Results indicate that OpenSim underestimates knee and ankle flexion, leading to discrepancies in range of motion (ROM) and root mean square deviation (RMSD). A two-sample Student’s t-test confirms significant hip joint deviations in post-stroke gait while Spearman’s correlation coefficient test shows a high correspondence in trend between OpenSim and experimental results, particularly the hip joint. These findings support the refinement of biomechanical simulations for stroke rehabilitation and clinical gait analysis.

title: StegaKD: Revealing Hidden Knowledge for Feature-Based Distillation
authors: Mingfei Ouyang, Xiaoting Chen, Yibing Chen, Tao Hua, Lei Zhang, Mianjie Li
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Data Mining (ICDM)
abstract: Feature-based knowledge distillation is often hindered by the semantic gap and task conflict inherent in direct mimicry strategies. This paper introduces a novel steganographyinspired paradigm, StegaKD, which reframes distillation as a process of embedding and revealing hidden knowledge. Our framework first decouples the distillation and classification tasks via lightweight projectors to shield the student's backbone. It then uses a cross-level attention mechanism to embed the teacher's high-level semantics into student features. Finally, a novel Frequency-domain Knowledge Revealing (FKR) module with a learnable filter extracts these embedded, high-frequency details characteristic of the teacher's knowledge. Extensive experiments on the CIFAR-100 dataset demonstrate that StegaKD consistently outperforms various baseline, validating the efficacy of our information hiding approach.

title: DNSHolmes: A Scalable Framework for DNS Repair Using Large Language Models
authors: Kaiqiang Hu, Haizhou Du, Ziyi Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Performance, Computing, and Communications Conference (IPCCC)
abstract: With the widespread application of large language models (LLMs), their advantages in context analysis and semantic inferencing are becoming increasingly prominent, and we are attempting to introduce them into the realm of DNS repair. As is well known, DNS, as the core of Internet infrastructure, has complex policies and a fragile system, where even a small misconfiguration can lead to catastrophic service failures. Especially in large-scale networks, analyzing detected errors and generating repair solutions often requires operators to invest a significant amount of time and effort. This paper proposes a scalable framework, DNSHolmes, designed to leverage LLMs for generating DNS configuration repair solutions. Specifically, this method first addresses the numerous potential root causes in large-scale errors by abstracting them into a small number of State Equivalence Classes (SECs). It then adopts a deterministic finite automaton (DFA) to compute a Critical Path Graph (CPG) for each class, precisely isolating the minimal set of records responsible for the failure. Crucially, the CPG serves as a focused, verifiable context for a Large Language Model (LLM), guiding it to generate accurate patches while overcoming the fundamental context-length limitations that help LLM with effective repair reasoning. Our evaluation on large-scale public datasets and a real-world campus network demonstrates that DNSHolmes can reduce operational effort by 78.4% and achieve efficient repair in large-scale DNS configuration.

title: Design & Implementation of Karatsuba Multiplier: A complete RTL to GDS II Flow
authors: Peketi Reshma, A S Surabhi, Sujatha Hiremath
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Computing and Communication Technologies (CONECCT)
abstract: Efficient multiplier design is critical for DSP, cryptography, and high-performance computing. The Karatsuba multiplication algorithm reduces computation but is significantly reliant on the adder used for partial product accumulation. The Brent-Kung adder, which has an area of $408 \mu \mathrm{~m} 2$, a power consumption of $45.78 \mu \mathrm{~W}$, and a timing slack of 1 ns, is the most efficient option for this design, based on a comparative analysis of adders, including the Brent-Kung, Carry Select, and Ripple Carry Adders. This paper introduces a 32-bit Karatsuba multiplier based on a Brent-Kung (BK) adder that is optimised for power, area, and performance. In addition, scan flip-flops are used to improve testing and reliability throughout manufacturing testing. The Karatsuba algorithm is designed and implemented with the Brent-Kung adder’s parallel prefix structure, which reduces carry propagation time and increases total computational performance. Cadence EDA tools were used to implement the RTL to GDSII pipeline. The Brent-Kung adderbased design resulted in a 27.8% reduction in area compared to the conventional design employing square root carry select adder. The existing design has a slack of 0.068 ns, indicating improved timing closure. Post-layout simulations show that the BrentKung adder-based Karatsuba multiplier outperforms traditional architectures, making it an excellent choice for high-performance, energy-efficient computing applications.

title: Piloting ModiBot: A Large Language Model-Based Moderator in Normal and Emotionally Challenging Focus Group Interactions
authors: Zsombor Zrubka, Bence Marczisák, Patrik Süli, György Eigner, Judit Gáspár, Márton Benedek, Balázs Sziklai
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Symposium on Computational Intelligence and Informatics (CINTI)
abstract: Focus groups are widely used in qualitative research, yet their effectiveness depends heavily on skilled moderation - especially under emotionally challenging group dynamics. With the rise of large language models (LLMs) in qualitative settings, their use as autonomous moderators has been proposed, though little is known about their performance in emotionally charged contexts. This study aimed to evaluate ModiBot, a customizable LLM-based focus group moderator, under simulated challenging scenarios. Using a Discord-based platform, four focus groups were conducted with role-playing researchers to simulate dynamics such as constructive discussion, anger, peer conflict, and moderator-directed protest. ModiBot guided participants through structured phases including onboarding, discussion, AI-mediated synthesis, and reflective validation. Quantitative evaluations and qualitative sentiment and thematic analyses revealed that ModiBot was perceived as objective and able to ensure anonymity and structure, but struggled to de-escalate emotional conflict, adapt to complex group behaviors, and manage conversation pacing. The emotional flatness and rigid message flow led to reduced empathy and cohesion. While the tool successfully facilitated data collection, its social intelligence was limited in group contexts. Further interdisciplinary development is needed to enhance emotional responsiveness and adaptability in LLM moderators for sensitive or volatile research environments.

title: UruDendro4: A Benchmark Dataset for Automatic Tree-Ring Detection in Cross-Section Images of Pinus taeda L
authors: Henry Marichal, Joaquín Blanco, Diego Passarella, Gregory Randall
publish: 2025 15th IEEE International Conference on Pattern Recognition Systems (ICPRS)
abstract: Tree-ring growth represents the annual wood increment for a tree, and quantifying it allows researchers to assess which silvicultural practices are best suited for each species. Manual measurement of this growth is time-consuming and often imprecise, as it is typically performed along 4 to 8 radial directions on a cross-sectional disc. In recent years, automated algorithms and datasets have emerged to enhance accuracy and automate the delineation of annual rings in cross-sectional images.To address the scarcity of wood cross-section data, we introduce the UruDendro4 dataset—a collection of 102 image samples of Pinus taeda L., each manually annotated with annual growth rings. Unlike existing public datasets, UruDendro4 includes samples extracted at multiple heights along the stem, allowing for the volumetric modeling of annual growth using manually delineated rings. This dataset (images and annotations) allows the development of volumetric models for annual wood estimation based on cross-sectional imagery.Additionally, we provide a performance baseline for automatic ring detection on this dataset using state-of-the-art methods. The highest performance was achieved by the DeepCS-TRD method, with a mean Average Precision of 0.838, a mean Average Recall of 0.782, and an Adapted Rand Error score of 0.084. A series of ablation experiments were conducted to empirically validate the final parameter configuration. Furthermore, we empirically demonstrate that training a learning model including this dataset improves the model’s generalization in the tree-ring detection task.

title: Dynamics of the Director of a Nematic Liquid Crystal in a Conical Magnetic Field:model
authors: Stanislav O. Khotkin, Vitaly V. Chelnokov
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: This paper proposes a simple and efficient model of the dynamics of the orientation characteristics of a nematic liquid crystal in a conical magnetic field. The proposed model can serve as a methodological basis for creating new effective approaches to studying and control the physical properties of liquid crystals. Conditions that guarantee the observation of a synchronous mode of director motion are obtained. It is shown that the frequency range of measuring the rotational viscosity of a liquid crystal significantly expands under conical field.

title: Modern Strategies for Failure Analysis and Machinery Predictive Maintenance
authors: Yassen Gorbounov
abstract: Predictive maintenance has traditionally been applied to large-scale industrial machinery, but recent advances in edge computing and low-cost sensors make it feasible to extend these techniques to smaller machinery including household appliances, home and even hobbyist applications. This paper presents a machinery health-monitoring framework that integrates affordable MEMS accelerometer with a Raspberry Pi platform equipped with an AI HAT+ for on-device machine learning. The system collects vibration signals from small machines such as DC motors, fans, and white goods, and processes them using lightweight signal analysis and dedicated algorithms. Both classical features, such as RMS and FFT, and advanced methods, are candidates to capture time-and frequency-domain fault signatures. In the current phase, the framework and data acquisition components have been implemented on the Raspberry Pi with the AI HAT+. Python modules from a previous research have been ported for on-device signal processing. This implementation lays the groundwork for deploying lightweight neural networks using TensorFlow Lite to enable on-device fault classification.

title: A Falcon Signature Verification Accelerator Using Area-Efficient NTT Architecture With Simplified Barrett Modular Multiplier
authors: Hongran Hu, Yangyi Chu, Gaoming Du, Xiaolei Wang, Yukun Song, Duoli Zhang, Zhenmin Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Very Large Scale Integration (VLSI) Systems
abstract: Falcon is a lattice-based post-quantum digital-signature scheme standardized by U.S. National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST). As for its hardware implementation, signature verification is the critical operation, in which the polynomial multiplier and the hash generator are computationally intensive. Existing hardware implementations face an inherent resource–performance tradeoff in the multiplier, and the overall verification latency remains high. In this article, we present an accelerator for Falcon signature verification using area-efficient number-theoretic transform (NTT) architecture with simplified Barrett modular multiplier. The precomputed constant of Barrett modular-multiplication unit is adjusted from 21 845 to 21 840. This modification maintains computation correctness while lowering resource consumption and improving throughput, which serves as an efficient building block for NTT/inverse NTT (INTT) operations. Moreover, a fully pipelined, nonstored radix-2 multipath delay commutator (R2-MDC) architecture is adopted for the NTT/INTT, which effectively reduces the delay and achieves a more balanced resource–performance tradeoff. Both the polynomial multiplier and the hash generator are parallelized to improve performance. A complete Falcon-1024 signature verification accelerator is implemented on FPGA platform. Experimental results show that, for the two-stage NTT inside the multiplier, the proposed design attains the lowest area–time product (ATP) compared to state-of-the-art designs, and the ATP of the entire Falcon-1024 verification procedure is reduced by 50%.

title: Prototype-Based Modality-Specific Feature Distillation for Incomplete Multimodal Sentiment Analysis
authors: Aihua Zheng, Yongbo Wang, Jiaxiang Wang, Chenglong Li, Bing Yin
publish: IEEE Transactions on Emerging Topics in Computational Intelligence
abstract: Incomplete multimodal sentiment analysis is to recognize human emotional states by leveraging the incomplete multimodal information including text, audio, and visual data. Existing methods mainly focus on reconstructing from available modalities, while ignoring the specific information of missing modalities and the inconsistent distribution between original and recovered data. In this work, we propose a novel Prototype-based modality-specific feature Distillation Network called ProDNet, which can recover the specific information of missing modalities with more consistent distributions between original and recovered data. In particular, we design a category-specific prototype for each modality to store the modality-specific information, and reconstruct the missing modality by combining the invariant features from existing modalities with the prototype of the missing modality in a feature self-distillation manner. To obtain favorable invariant features, we design an invariant feature distillation strategy, in which the weight-gating mechanism is introduced to enhance invariant feature representation. Finally, to reduce distributional inconsistency, we design a distribution consistency distillation loss to enforce the consistent distribution of original and recovered data by considering the sample correlation between teacher and student networks. Extensive experiments on two benchmark datasets, CMU-MOSI and CMU-MOSEI, demonstrate the superior performance of the proposed method, particularly in scenarios with higher missing rates.

title: Anomaly Detection in Networked Bandits
authors: Xiaotong Cheng, Setareh Maghsudi
abstract:
The nodes’ interconnections on a social network often reflect their dependencies and information-sharing behaviors. Nevertheless, abnormal nodes, which significantly deviate from most of the network concerning patterns or behaviors, can lead to grave consequences. Therefore, it is imperative to design efficient online learning algorithms that robustly learn users’ preferences while simultaneously detecting anomalies.

We introduce a novel bandit algorithm to address this problem. Through network knowledge, the method characterizes the users’ preferences and residuals of feature information. By learning and analyzing these preferences and residuals, it develops a personalized recommendation strategy for each user and simultaneously detects anomalies. We rigorously prove an upper bound on the regret of the proposed algorithm and experimentally compare it with several state-of-the-art collaborative contextual bandit algorithms on both synthetic and real-world datasets.

title: Effect of Constraining a Limited Number of Slant Ionospheric Corrections in PPP and an Improved Partial Tight-Constraining Algorithm
authors: Jiahuan Hu, Yao Shi, Pan Li, Wu Chen, Long Tang, Feng Zhou, Xiaolong Mi, Sunil Bisnath
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: With external ionospheric corrections, precise point positioning solutions can be augmented with proper constraints, enabling fast convergence and high-precision positioning performance. However, there are two main issues in user algorithms. Firstly, the contribution of the number of applied ionospheric corrections on positioning performance is not clear to users. For instance, in low-cost sensors where computation resources are limited, applying too many corrections (e.g., tens of corrections) from server will possibly cause slow response. Secondly, the determination of constraining strength for corrections from different satellites remains challenging. Therefore, this paper evaluates the effect of the number of ionospheric corrections on positioning errors and convergence time, and proposes an improved tight-constraining algorithm for partial reliable corrections. Static and simulated kinematic positioning results confirm that the more corrections applied, the better the positioning performance. However, the positioning accuracy only has limited improvements when several corrections are already applied, especially in the north direction. The proposed method reduces static positioning root-mean-square errors by 43.4%, 26.9%, and 32.1% in the east, north, and up directions, respectively, compared to solutions without constraint. In simulated kinematic results, the convergence time is further shortened by 7.7%, 4.8%, and 2.5% for the east, north, and up directions, respectively, compared to cases where all corrections are applied.
