title: High-Precision RGB-NIR Vision-Tactile Sensor via Neural Inverse Rendering for Robotic Perception
authors: Yuankai Lin, Xiaofan Lu, Hua Yang
abstract: Fine-grained manipulation requires high-precision tactile perception, yet existing vision-based tactile sensors suffer from measurement artifacts and limited generalization due to the constrained channel capacity of conventional RGB cameras. To address these issues, this article introduces a multimodal vision-tactile sensor framework based on synchronized multicamera sensing. We further propose a self-calibrating multimodal fusion photometric stereoneural network, which not only reconstructs high-fidelity contact surface geometry but also incorporates an LED-based renderer to synthesize diverse tactile images under novel lighting conditions. A unified joint calibration method is also developed to simultaneously optimize geometric, optical, and normal force parameters, significantly simplifying sensor setup and improving measurement accuracy. Experimental validation shows that our sensor, GelSplitter, achieves a 28.2% reduction in surface normal error while producing cleaner reconstructions with fewer artifacts. The integrated renderer synthesizes high-quality tactile images with a PSNR of 30.22 dB, outperforming single-light source methods by 6.33 dB. The effectiveness of the proposed system is further demonstrated in three downstream tactile tasks: pose estimation, fingerprint recognition, and slip detection.

title: Contrastive Graph Modeling for Cross-Domain Few-Shot Medical Image Segmentation
authors: Yuntian Bo, Tao Zhou, Zechao Li, Haofeng Zhang, Ling Shao
abstract: Cross-domain few-shot medical image segmentation (CD-FSMIS) offers a promising and data-efficient solution for medical applications where annotations are severely scarce and multimodal analysis is required. However, existing methods typically filter out domain-specific information to improve generalization, which inadvertently limits cross-domain performance and degrades source-domain accuracy. To address this, we present Contrastive Graph Modeling (C-Graph), a framework that leverages the structural consistency of medical images as a reliable domain-transferable prior. We represent image features as graphs, with pixels as nodes and semantic affinities as edges. A Structural Prior Graph (SPG) layer is proposed to capture and transfer target-category node dependencies and enable global structure modeling through explicit node interactions. Building upon SPG layers, we introduce a Subgraph Matching Decoding (SMD) mechanism that exploits semantic relations among nodes to guide prediction. Furthermore, we design a Confusion-minimizing Node Contrast (CNC) loss to mitigate node ambiguity and sub-graph heterogeneity by contrastively enhancing node discriminability in the graph space. Our method significantly outperforms prior CD-FSMIS approaches across multiple cross-domain benchmarks, achieving state-of-the-art performance while simultaneously preserving strong segmentation accuracy on the source domain. Our code is available at https://github.com/primebo1/C-Graph.

title: Balancing Efficiency and Fairness: An Iterative Exchange Framework for Multi-UAV Cooperative Path Planning
authors: Hongzpng Li, Luwei Liao, Xiangguang Dai, Yuming Feng, Rong Feng, Shiqin Tang
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Trends in Computational Intelligence (NTCI)
abstract: Multi-UAV cooperative path planning (MUCPP) is a fundamental problem in multi-agent systems, aiming to generate collision-free trajectories for a team of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) to complete distributed tasks efficiently. A key challenge lies in achieving both efficiency, by minimizing total mission cost, and fairness, by balancing the workload among UAVs to avoid overburdening individual agents. This paper presents a novel Iterative Exchange Framework for MUCPP, balancing efficiency and fairness through iterative task exchanges and path refinements. The proposed framework formulates a composite objective that combines the total mission distance and the makespan, and iteratively improves the solution via local exchanges under feasibility and safety constraints. For each UAV, collision-free trajectories are generated using A $^{*}$ search over a terrainaware configuration space. Comprehensive experiments on multiple terrain datasets demonstrate that the proposed method consistently achieves superior trade-offs between total distance and makespan compared to existing baselines.

title: Estimation of Sentinel-1 Atmospheric Delays Using Cross-Seasonal Common-Master (CSCM) Interferogram Subsets
authors: Chaoying Zhao, Guangrong Li
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Tropospheric delays caused by the differences in pressure, temperature and humidity of observation between the master and slave images are one of the main errors affecting the accuracy of the deformation inversion of Synthetic Aperture Radar interferometry (InSAR) techniques. We propose a Cross-seasonal Common-master (CSCM) Interferograms Subsets method to accurately estimate the tropospheric delays of master and slave images. Firstly, the characteristic of the tropospheric delays being strong in summer and weak in winter is used to generate the cross-seasonal common-master interferograms subsets. Then, the tropospheric delays are estimated by modeling each subset. We validate the Sentinel-1A/B atmospheric delays correction in Sydney. The results show the RMSE between the InSAR deformation with atmospheric correction by our method and the GPS measurements is 7.6 mm, which is 49% lower than that before tropospheric correction, i.e. 14.7 mm. Therefore, the new method provides an accurate and efficient means for the tropospheric delay estimation of Sentinel-1 data, which can be applied to atmospheric water vapor inversion and high precision surface deformation monitoring.

title: Impact of Stability-Based Client Selection on Overhead Traffic in Federated Learning Systems
authors: Kukuh Nugroho, Hendrawan, Iskandar
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Telecommunication Systems, Services, and Applications (TSSA)
abstract: A distributed machine learning framework allows multiple clients to collaboratively train models without sending data away from the data-generating device. This approach, known as federated learning (FL), involves decentralized clients contributing to build their own local model with a shared global model. However, this framework inevitably generates significant data communication exchanges between clients and the central server, which can produce overhead traffic in the network and potentially degrade quality of service (QoS) and network efficiency. To alleviate this problem, we proposed client selection methods in federated learning, enabling the system to strategically involve only the most suitable clients in each training round. This study proposes a stability-based client selection method, in which clients are evaluated according to the consistency of their local training behaviour, ensuring that only stable participants are prioritized to build an updated global model. The experimental results demonstrate that applying this stability-based client selection method in the FL system achieves an average network efficiency improvement of 46.88%, indicating a substantial reduction in communication overhead and enhancing network quality by addressing potential bottlenecks.

title: Enhancing Dermatologic Image Classification via Advanced Hybrid Deep Learning Approach
authors: Tamara Korobkova, Oleg Golovnin
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: Recently, machine learning algorithms in computer vision have made significant contributions to the development of computer-assisted systems for the diagnosis and early detection of dangerous skin cancers. In this paper, we propose an advanced approach for classifying dermatologic images used in the diagnosis of skin diseases. Our approach involves three main steps: first, an image preprocessing stage removes artifacts from input data; second, region-of-interest segmentation employs the U-Net architecture; third, classification utilizes an ensemble model that combines the strengths of ResNet convolutional neural networks and the Vision Transformer architecture. Experiments were carried out on the widely recognized HAM10000 dataset. During these experiments, our proposed approach demonstrated exceptional performance, achieving an accuracy of 95.57%, a macro-averaged AUC-ROC score of 1.00, and a micro-averaged F1-score of 0.99. Importantly, it also achieved very high levels of both specificity (98.87%) and sensitivity (93.44%), making it particularly suitable for use in medical diagnostic settings. Visualizations generated by the Grad-CAM technique further confirmed the clinical interpretability of the model's predictions. These findings suggest substantial promise for the application of our approach in developing decision-support systems aimed at improving the diagnosis of skin diseases.

title: An Integrated Deep Learning Pipeline for Multi-Object Tracking and Interaction Analysis of Cetaceans in UAV Imagery
authors: Reinan Lopes Argolo, Paulo Eduardo Ambrósio, Bianca Machado Righi, Susana Marrero Iglesias
publish: 2025 15th IEEE International Conference on Pattern Recognition Systems (ICPRS)
abstract: The ethological study of cetaceans, such as hump-back whales (Megaptera novaeangliae), plays a vital role in marine conservation efforts. Traditionally, behavioral analyzes have relied on manual video inspection, which is time-consuming and limits scalability. The adoption of Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) has improved data collection through efficient and noninvasive aerial monitoring. However, this advancement has led to a substantial increase in the volume of video footage, intensifying the burden of manual review. To address this challenge, we propose a computer vision–based solution that integrates deep learning techniques for the automatic detection and tracking of whales on UAV footage. Using the YOLOv8 model for object detection and the DeepSORT algorithm for real-time multi-object tracking, our system successfully identified and followed humpback whales across varied video sequences. Visual evaluation of the results demonstrated consistent detection accuracy, maintaining spatial coherence even under varying lighting conditions and surface disturbances. The system’s ability to capture detailed movement patterns and behavioral sequences suggests strong potential for supporting qualitative behavioral assessments. This approach streamlines data processing and facilitates in-depth observation of whale behavior in natural settings, thereby contributing to improved conservation practices.

title: GDE-YOLO: A Lightweight YOLOv10-Based Framework for Classroom Behavior Detection on Embedded Devices
authors: Pengyu Gao, Guangfeng Guo, Baowei Liu, Zhixue Liu, Jiran Zhao, Xintian Zhang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Trustworthy Big Data and Artificial Intelligence (ICTBAI)
abstract: To address the practical needs for real-time student behavior detection in smart classroom scenarios, this paper proposes GDE-YOLO (Ghost-ECA-DMBC Enhanced YOLO), a lightweight object detection model oriented towards edge computing platforms. Based on YOLOv10-n, the model incorporates Ghost convolutional modules, Efficient Channel Attention (ECA) mechanisms, and an improved detection head (DMBC) to significantly reduce model parameters and computational complexity while maintaining high detection accuracy. The model was trained on a mixed dataset of 12 typical classroom behaviors and tested on the Jetson Orin Nano edge device. Experimental results demonstrate that GDE-YOLO, compared to YOLOv10-n, reduces parameter count by 40.6%, computational load by 41.7%, and model size by 39.3%, When deployed on the Jetson Orin Nano, it achieves an average inference speed improvement of approximately 5%. while preserving competitive accuracy. These improvements ensure smooth real-time detection with significantly lower resource consumption. The proposed GDE-YOLO model offers a practical and deployable solution for efficient behavior detection in low-power educational environments.

title: Real-Time V2V Communication for Collision Avoidance in AV Networks
authors: S Sivasubramanian, Nabiev Bosit Sobirovich, Zaeid Ajsan Salami, Sandeep Soni, S. Balambigai, Manzura Pirnazarova, Yogapriya J, M.O Pallavi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems and Pioneering Innovations in Robotics and Electric Mobility (INSPIRE)
abstract: The paper introduces a new Adaptive Decentralised Real-Time Vehicle-to-Vehicle (V2V) Communication Framework designed to enhance the efficiency of collision avoidance in autonomous vehicle (AV) networks. When AVs are found on more roads, fast and dependable communication between the vehicles is vital to avoid accidents and increase traffic safety. The framework introduces edge computing inside the vehicles, enabling them to process the data gathered by several sensors on the spot, thus cutting latency. Thanks to a blockchain-inspired decentralized protocol, all messages are authenticated and remain reliable without requiring central servers, thus increasing security. An AI-based collision forecasting system checks the collected sensor signals to predict collisions fast and take quick preemptive actions. It prioritizes the delivery of important messages and manages the device’s bandwidth by sending the signals only when needed. It also helps by switching available channels cleverly to prevent communication interruptions and overcrowding. Working together, models updates make the network better, and all data is kept confidential during this process. The results of the simulation explain that collision rates, time between messages, and network delays are reduced more than in current V2V systems. This approach makes it easy to avoid collisions in real time and offers good security, which also makes it simple for AVs to communicate with other vehicles on the roads. The suggested method is expected to make roads safer, increase traffic flow smoothness, and speed up the adoption of trustworthy autonomous vehicles.

title: Comparative Analysis of Multimodal Deep Learning Approaches for Skin Disease Classification
authors: Sherley Velenteena Andrade, Jeevan Lionel Joseph Pinto
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems and Pioneering Innovations in Robotics and Electric Mobility (INSPIRE)
abstract: Multimodal deep learning, which combines several data sources like dermoscopic pictures, clinical photographs, patient metadata, and textual health records, has become an essential tool for increasing diagnosis accuracy in the classification of skin diseases. This study presents a comprehensive comparison of 44 advanced research articles published between 2023 and 2025. The goal, deep learning architecture, input modalities, performance indicators, and workable deployment plan are all taken into consideration while evaluating each article. CNN variations (e.g., ResNet, DenseNet), Transformer-Based designs (e.g., ViT, Swin), and hybrid fusion frameworks (e.g., SkinIncept, HI-MViT) are among the models that are being compared. According to our studies, models that utilise both visual and non-visual data often perform better than their unimodal counterparts, improving classification accuracy by up to 12%. Furthermore, research using explainable artificial intelligence techniques (e.g., GradCAM, SHAP) and real-time systems (e.g., YOLOv8) shows improved usability and clinical relevance.

title: Economic Dispatch Optimization for 5 Bus Power System Optimizing Loss And Cost-Power Study
authors: Sandesh Acharya, Prakash Adhikari, Shubha Narayan Yadav
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: The paper presents the study of load flow analysis for the economic dispatch optimization for the 5- b u s system with and without considering the losses in the power system. It accounts for the input of the generator fuel costs, a quadratic function in $/hr, cost curve analysis, product of input-output hour curve (BTU/hr), and fuel-curve ($/BTU). Cost-curve is often a piecewise continuous function and the derivative of the cost- curve with respect to the power gives the incremental operating cost. Total load of the 5-bus system is 824.5 MW, allowing the generator units to have automatic generation control for optimizing the best economic dispatch. The 5-bus system was verified to study the system stability and minimizing the operating costs of the system. The research rigorously analyzes the allocation of power generation among multiple generating units with the objective of minimizing overall generation cost, while accounting for real system constraints and losses particularly focusing on cost-power study.

title: Residential AC Consumers Supplied by DC Renewable Electric Microgrids Research Study
authors: Mariana Dumitrescu
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Electrical and Electronics Engineering (ISEEE)
abstract: Global power specialists are very interested in the transition from the classic centralized system to multiple microgrids of power supply, which will form a decentralized system. Renewable power sources are increasingly involved in power systems. More important is their placement close to the consumers, for the residential ones, exactly in the consumer area. This paper approaches the DC power microgrids involved in supplying AC residential consumers as devices, power supply parameters, technical adaptability of the consumers to the DC voltage. Special build research system, involving hardware and software devices, helps to analyze residential consumers behavior when a DC microgrid is used for supplying. The paper is focused on the analysis methodology, which can be used on large scale whenever AC consumers are/will be involved and used for residential applications with DC renewable microgrids.

title: Enhanced Feature Based Methods for Histopathology Image Registration with ORB
authors: Bijoyeta Roy, Mousumi Gupta
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Computing and Communication Technologies (CONECCT)
abstract: Histopathology image registration is a critical process for accurate diagnosis and analysis in medical imaging. Feature-based methods, compared to intensity-based or transform-based techniques, are particularly effective in aligning histopathology images due to their robustness against variations in staining, lighting, and tissue deformation. These methods allow for precise comparison and interpretation of tissue samples, enhancing diagnostic accuracy. In this study, we employ the ORB (Oriented FAST and Rotated BRIEF) detector to generate key points and use the BRIEF (Binary Robust Independent Elementary Features) algorithm for feature matching. The ORB detector is advantageous due to its computational efficiency and invariance to rotation and scale, making it ideal for histopathological applications. To further enhance performance, adaptive thresholding is incorporated in ORB for improved feature detection in varying intensity regions. Additionally, RANSAC (Random Sample Consensus) is applied for robust outlier rejection, ensuring accurate alignment of histopathology images. This combination has demonstrated successful results in aligning histopathology images, ensuring high accuracy and consistency. The proposed method effectively addresses challenges posed by variations in tissue appearance, contributing to improved diagnostic precision and research in medical imaging.

title: Performance Evaluation of Wavelet and Adaptive Filters for ECG Denoising in the LabVIEW Environment
authors: Alexandra Nistor, George-Călin Serițan, Felix Constantin Adochiei, Florin-Ciprian Argatu, Bogdan-Adrian Enache
publish: 2025 14th International Symposium on Advanced Topics in Electrical Engineering (ATEE)
abstract: Electrocardiogram (ECG) signals are essential for diagnosing cardiovascular diseases, but they are frequently corrupted by baseline drift, muscular noise, and power-line interference, which hinder reliable feature detection. Conventional FIR, IIR, and notch filters are often insufficient because they distort waveform morphology or lack adaptability to different noise sources. In this work, ECG denoising was implemented in the LabVIEW environment by simulating noisy signals with the Biomedical Toolkit, applying wavelet filtering with several families, and adaptive filtering with LMS and RLS algorithms, followed by performance evaluation using signal-tonoise ratio (SNR). The results show that wavelet filters, particularly db5 and coif5, achieved the best performance with SNR around 14 dB, while LMS and RLS reached about 10-12 dB, confirming wavelet filtering as the most reliable approach under the tested conditions.

title: Coastal Sea Surface Temperature Retrieval for Amsr2 Using Machine Learning
authors: Haoming Song, Lanjie Zhang, Jingyi Liu
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Coastal sea surface temperature (SST) plays a crucial role in studying coastal upwelling currents and ocean atmosphere coupling. However, the accuracy of SST in coastal regions remains unsatisfactory due to radio frequency interference and land sea contamination. In this paper, an SST retrieval model in global coastal regions was developed based on a MLP-LGBM hybrid model using Advanced Microwave Scanning Radiometer2 observations. The results demonstrate that the MLP-LGBM hybrid model performs well in global coastal regions achieving a mean bias (MB) of 0.07°C, a root mean square error (RMSE) of 0.64°C, and a correlation (R) of 0.998. Using in situ SST Quality Monitor SST as a reference, the model shows significant improvement compared to AMSR2 L2 SST, with an MB of 0.07°C, an RMSE of 0.59°C, the R is 0.998. This study confirms the effectiveness of using machine learning approach to retrieve SST in global coastal regions. Additionally, compared to AMSR2 L2 SST, the coastal temperature retrieval model established in this study is capable of retrieving temperatures within 1 km of the coastline.

title: Dynamic Streetlights Adapt Energy Usage Based on Real-Time Traffic Flow
authors: Ashutosh Pandey, Neethu V. K, Zayd Balassem, A. S. Kannan, S. Goshteeswaran, B.C Shylesh, Dilli Ganesh V
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems and Pioneering Innovations in Robotics and Electric Mobility (INSPIRE)
abstract: The amount of energy used by standard streetlights in cities is a genuine concern, particularly when few cars are on the streets. Each light in these places works at maximum brightness, leading to energy waste and environmental harm. Sustainability in smart cities can be reached when suitable energy-efficient solutions are available for changing traffic demands. A system is discussed in this research that adjusts its light output according to the amount of traffic on the street in real time. The combination of IoT sensors, observing areas such as streets, and a central control system allows traffic conditions to decide the brightness of streetlights. A basic rule is used to control streetlight brightness: they are brightest when there is high traffic, dimmer if traffic is moderate, and either dim or off during low or no traffic. It saves power and guarantees everyone using the streets will feel securely illuminated. A simulation of the proposed system shows that energy usage can be reduced by as much as 70% when most people are not using the system, without endangering the public. If developed, this system is scalable, low in cost, and able to adapt, making it useful for urban regions hoping to save energy and maintain public safety. As a result, this system significantly reduces streetlighting’s effects on the environment and contributes to building more intelligent and greener cities.

title: Explanatory Machine Learning Predicts STEM Academic Performance: The Impact of Information Literacy and Past Performance
authors: Rong Rong, Mei Zhang
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Modern Education and Information Management (ICMEIM)
abstract: This study investigates the predictive role of interpretable machine learning models in analyzing how information literacy and historical academic performance influence STEM achievement. To address the limitations of traditional linear models in capturing nonlinear relationships and dynamic behavioral data, Support Vector Machines (SVM) and explainable AI (XAI) techniques (SHAP and LIME) were employed, with data from 153 Chilean engineering students. Results indicate that SVM performs superiorly in small-sample scenarios compared to benchmark models. XAI analysis reveals critical thresholds in key factors, while self-reported and observational information literacy metrics show divergent predictive efficacy across different STEM courses. These findings support the adoption of dual-assessment frameworks and curriculum-specific interventions, highlighting the value of transparent, data-driven decision-making in STEM education.

title: Intelligent Data Analysis for Prediction of Quality of Experience Based on Real-Time IP Network Metrics
authors: Aleksei Elokhov
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: This paper presents a novel approach for intelligent prediction of Quality of Experience (QoE) in IP networks through advanced data analysis of real-time network metrics. System-cognitive analysis methods implemented in the EIDOS-X++ analytical platform were applied to monitoring data from Software-Defined Wide Area Network (SD-WAN) devices, revealing causal relationships between network parameters (jitter, latency, packet loss, bandwidth) and user-perceived service quality. The developed INF3 model (Chi-square) achieved L1-measure accuracy of 0.927, demonstrating robust predictive capability. Automated SWOT analysis identified critical factors that enhance or impede QoE performance. The methodology can be integrated into existing network management infrastructure as an automated Decision Support System (DSS), enabling network operations engineers to perform continuous quality monitoring and proactive problem resolution.

title: GANHSS: A Generative Adversarial Network-Based Hospital Staff Scheduler
authors: Bibhasan Podder, Anurag Das, Soura Bose, Sattwik Sarkar, Ipsita Dalui, Sohinee Mondal
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Computing and Communication Technologies (CONECCT)
abstract: Hospital staff scheduling algorithms are difficult to design because of changing demands, employee preferences, and legal restrictions. A potential remedy is offered by Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs), which produce flexible timetables that maximize staff satisfaction and maximize resources because of its adaptability to real world complexities, efficient handling of nonlinear constraints, faster execution, robustness, ability to generate synthetic data based realistic schedule in case of limited historical data and most importantly ability to handle last minute schedule changes dynamically. This study presents a GANbased approach to hospital staff schedule generation that takes into account limitations including role-based requirements, legal compliance, and personal preferences. A generator that suggests schedules and a discriminator that evaluates their viability and quality are both components of the GAN architecture. These schedules are improved by iterative training, increasing their usefulness in practical settings. The GAN is useful in complicated healthcare scheduling situations because it uses previous patient load and staff data to dynamically adapt to hospital demands, improving scheduling accuracy, workload distribution, and response to unforeseen changes.

title: Hybrid Visual Feature Extraction for Goldfish Image Classification Using K-Nearest Neighbor
authors: Fitri Marisa, M. Ilham Setyo Wahyudi, Anastasia Lidya Maukar, Adriadi, Farida Yuliaty, Rina Novianty
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Telecommunication Systems, Services, and Applications (TSSA)
abstract: (KNN) algorithm based on the extraction of visual characteristic features such as color, shape, texture, and spatial frequency. The dataset consists of 1,500 images categorized into three classes: Oranda, Ryukin, and Ranchu. Feature extraction includes HSV color histograms, Hu Moments for shape, GLCM for statistical texture, and Gabor filters for directional texture analysis. Classification was evaluated using several training and testing data ratios, and the results showed improved accuracy, especially with the inclusion of Gabor features. Experimental findings indicate that integrating these four features enhances the performance of the KNN algorithm in the goldfish image classification task, achieving a peak accuracy of 90% with an 80:20 train-test split ratio.

title: Automated System For Image Analysis And Determination Of Chlorophyll Content In Corn Plant Leaves
authors: Svetoslav Petrov, Tsvetelina Georgieva, Stanislav Penchev, Plamen Daskalov
publish: 2025 International Conference on Big Data, Knowledge and Control Systems Engineering (BdKCSE)
abstract: The article presents an autmated system for image analysis and determination of chlorophyll content in corn plant leaves. The application of image analysis in determining the amount of chlorophyll contained in corn leaves is presented. An automated system to capture and process the obtained images has been developed. A graphical user interface for image processing and analysis is assembled and tested. Future research is aimed at developing mathematical and neural models for determining the amount of chlorophyll contained in the leaves of corn plants, which will indicate the phase of plant development, on which all fertilization and treatment activities depend.

title: A Physics-Based Algorithm for Retrieving Land Surface Temperature Under Liquid-Phase Clouds
authors: Xiao-Ning Song, Xin-Ming Zhu, Chuan Sun, Han Guo
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Acquiring land surface temperature (LST) at cloudy status is essential for the all-weather mapping of LST. In this paper, a physics-based LST retrieval algorithm was proposed to derive the LST under liquid-phase clouds with the simulated database. This algorithm is developed via the ratio of brightness temperature polarization difference for 18.7 and 23.8 GHz. The emissivity parameter (ratio of emissivity polarization difference for 18.7 and 23.8 GHz) is simulated using Advanced Integral Equation Model. The atmospheric downwelling radiation (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$T_{\mathrm{d} 18.7}, ~\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{d} 23.8}$</tex>) and transmittance (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\tau_{18.7}$</tex>, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\tau$</tex> 23.8) are estimated using the parameterized relations to cloud liquid water (CLW), mean temperature of cloud (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$T_{\mathrm{c}}$</tex>), and precipitable water vapor (PWV) in the Community Radiative Transfer Model. Results indicate that the effect of cloud layers on three atmospheric parameters at selected channels is non-negligible. The algorithm accuracy is 1.95 K when LST is above 280 K, and bias varies from 0.69 K to 5.38 K.

title: Co-simulation of Shortcircuit Current Measurement in LVDC Systems
authors: Daniel-Catalin Mitroi, Grigore Stamatescu, Radu Plămănescu, Mihaela Albu
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Electrical and Electronics Engineering (ISEEE)
abstract: Emerging low-voltage direct current (LVDC) micro-grids represent a compelling alternative for efficient renewable energy use in multiple residential and industrial scenarios. Typical concerns regarding safety of DC systems are currently being addressed through the sustained development and deployment of solid-state circuit breakers (SSCBs) and current limiter (CL) devices. Design of such elements requires suitable simulation approaches and tools for accurate understanding of short-circuit current behavior under multiple usage and parametrisation scenarios, in accordance to established norms and regulations. This paper presents a co-simulation approach to derive short-circuit current profiles in a typical off-grid home setting supplied by solar energy. The implementation has been carried out by integration of Simulink models with the TyphoonHIL environment for real-time simulation through the dedicated FMU/FMI interface. We report on the numerical results achieved and derive insights for improved protection of LVDC microgrids.

title: Hybrid Mean-Max Color Correction Algorithm with LAB Contrast Adjustment for Underwater Image Enhancement
authors: Ishani Barad, Arvind R. Yadav
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Computing and Communication Technologies (CONECCT)
abstract: Underwater imaging has various applications in fields such as marine life conservation, deep sea exploration, and defense. However, capturing clear images is challenging due to the scattering and absorption of light and water pollution, which leads to low contrast and a blue or green cast. These issues cause degradation in image quality which makes the analysis of underwater images more complicated. This paper presents a hybrid mean-max color correction algorithm with contrast enhancement, to enhance the quality of underwater images. The proposed method improves contrast and restores natural colors, thus addressing the common visual distortions caused by light degradation. The effectiveness of the algorithm has been demonstrated by enhancing the image quality of 16 different types of underwater images.

title: Analysis of FCS Model Predictive Control Strategy for Grid-Connected 7-Level Cascaded H-Bridge Multilevel Inverter
authors: Amina Alshekh, Chivon Choeung, Mehmet Ali Usta, Yahya Danayiyen
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Electrical and Electronics Engineering (ISEEE)
abstract: The role for Cascaded H-Bridge Multilevel Inverters (CHB-MLIs) is becoming increasingly critical for interfacing renewable sources with electrical grid. The integration into the grid requires high-quality power conversion and CHB-MLIs are particularly advantageous for this goal because of their modular structure and enhanced output quality. In addition, the employed control strategy in these inverters determines the overall performance and efficiency. This paper investigates a dedicated analysis of a Finite Control Set Model Predictive Control (FCS-MPC) for 7-level grid-connected CHB-MLI. The system, including the inverter and an LCL filter, is modeled in Simulink/MALTAB, and the evaluation of the performance is carried out by measuring the total harmonic distortion (THD) of the injected grid current and assessing its robustness under grid fluctuations. The analysis finds out that FCS-MPC shows a high efficiency, ability to select optimal switching states, integrate multiple control objectives, such as grid current tracking and DC-link voltage balancing, capacity to address system constraints and notable improvements in power quality. The results demonstrate the critical role of advanced control methods to maximize the performance of grid-connected CHB-MLIs in renewable energy systems.

title: DM-SCT: Side-Channel Trace Generation Via Attention-Enhanced Diffusion Model
authors: Yuxuan Meng, Baosheng Wang, Qianqian Xing, Xiaofeng Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Performance, Computing, and Communications Conference (IPCCC)
abstract: Deep Learning-based Side-Channel Analysis (DLSCA) has demonstrated its potent attack capability against cryptographic systems, enabling the extraction of secret information from leaked physical signal traces. Unfortunately, the availability of real traces for classifier training is often limited due to restricted data collection or protective countermeasures. The generation and enhancement of signal trace is crucial in practical DL-SCA analysis. Existing methods often struggle to accurately model the feature distribution of real traces, and their applicability to emerging post-quantum cryptographic (PQC) algorithms remains unexplored. In this paper, we propose DMSCT, an attention-enhanced diffusion model framework for side-channel trace generation. DM-SCT precisely models the feature distributions of real traces through a conditional injection mechanism and an enhanced attention mechanism. We evaluate DM-SCT across three PQC algorithms: NTRU, Saber, and Kyber, demonstrating its ability to faithfully replicate the leakage features of original side-channel traces. By integrating DM-SCT into DL-SCA, we validate its practical efficacy. Compared to training with real traces alone, DM-SCT improves the accuracy of recovering individual key coefficients by 0.62% to 1.6%. Furthermore, DM-SCT reduces the required number of real training traces by 20% to 25%, outperforming state-of-the-art trace generation methods.

title: On the Kuruklis Trinomial Difference Equation
authors: Pavel Shcherbakov, Dmitrii Ostrovskii, Sergei Parsegov
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: The subject of this paper is the family of linear difference equations widely used in the modeling of population dynamics. We analyze the nonasymptotic behavior of stable solutions of this equation for various initial conditions in the unit box, paying special attention to possible large deviations of solutions from the initial values at finite time instants, a phenomenon referred to as peak effect. We first identify the worst-case initial conditions yielding maximum deviation. Next, we consider a parameterized subfamily and prove two results on the properties of the roots of its characteristic polynomial and on computation of threshold peak-promoting values of the parameter of the family. Several special cases are analyzed and illustrative examples are provided.

title: Project-Based Robotics 4.0 Education Using Microcontrollers to Enhance Technical and Programming Competencies
authors: József Udvaros, Veronika Gabal’ová
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Symposium on Computational Intelligence and Informatics (CINTI)
abstract: The concept of Robotics 4.0 represents the integration of robotic technologies with digital innovations within the broader framework of Industry $\mathbf{4. 0}$. This paper analyzes the transition from traditional industrial robotics to intelligent, collaborative, and networked robotic systems, and examines their potential implementation in educational settings. Special attention is given to the integration of microcontrollers (Arduino, ESP32, Raspberry Pi Pico) and sensor modules in robotics education at secondary and higher education levels. The research section presents an experiment aimed at evaluating the effectiveness of project-based robotics education using microcontrollers, focusing on changes in students’ technical skills, programming competencies, and motivation. The results highlight the importance of hands-on learning in preparing graduates for modern industry requirements and provide recommendations for effectively linking industrial practice with pedagogical processes. The study, conducted at a Slovak secondary school, examined the impact of project-based robotics education using the Arduino platform on students’ technical and programming competencies as well as motivation ($\mathbf{N}=\mathbf{4 8}$). An eight-week intervention was implemented in a quasi-experimental design with pre- and posttests and a control group, employing a knowledge test, assessment rubric, and motivation questionnaire. Statistical analysis confirmed significant improvements across all evaluated areas in favor of the experimental group.

title: Real-Time Patient Data Exchange with Blockchain-Backed Consent Layers
authors: Ahmed Anwer Jaafa, Madhu Sahu, M. Jasmin, Mamadjanova Zukhra Bakhromjanovna, K. Karunambiga, E. Nirmala Devi, Shuhrat Sirojiddinov, Gangothri Sani
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems and Pioneering Innovations in Robotics and Electric Mobility (INSPIRE)
abstract: Sharing patient data safely and efficiently is still hard in the constantly changing world of digital healthcare because of worries about privacy, giving consent, and how different systems work together. This paper suggests using ChainMedX, which relies on blockchain technology to let patients, doctors, and other healthcare professionals exchange data in real time with dynamic consent consent management. ChainMedX uses permissions, smart contracts, and zero-knowledge proofs to let patients pick who can have access to their medical records, manage exactly what is shared, and specify the time period the sharing is needed, making sure those permissions cannot be altered. Being distributed across both cloud and edge servers, the patient-managed encrypted data vaults make active updates of medical records possible, complying with FHIR standards. Thanks to an AI-based consent suggestion module, patients receive useful advice that suits their needs and the current emergency situation. In addition, ChainMedX deals with urgent issues, such as fast access with easy ‘break-glass’ rules and complete tracking of every transaction, and makes it easier for healthcare services to interact with the wider health organization and verify insurance policies. According to the results, latency, security, and managing consent are all better in the new system than in systems that operate centrally or rely on blockchain. The research mentions that connecting blockchain, edge computing, and privacy-based cryptography can form a healthcare system that respects patient data privacy and makes healthcare cooperation speedy and secure. The goal of this framework is to help provide for data exchange between countries, while including new forms of digital health technology, all this aims to strengthen patient trust and the integrity of their medical data, along with providing better healthcare outcomes.

title: Improving the Accuracy of Temperature Measurement with Thermoresistive Sensors
authors: Tsanko Karadzhov, Dimitar Dichev, Iliya Zhelezarov, Borislav Georgiev, Dimcho Pulov, Krasimir Drumev
publish: 2025 XXXV International Scientific Symposium Metrology and Metrology Assurance (MMA)
abstract: This paper discusses methods for improving the accuracy of temperature measurements with thermistor sensors. Thermistors are widely used in various industrial and domestic applications due to their high sensitivity. However, their nonlinear characteristics, hysteresis, and the influence of parasitic factors such as noise and others can lead to significant measurement errors. The article analyzes various calibration methods, the use of precise analog and digital signal processing circuits. A temperature measurement system with a thermistor sensor based on the LabVIEW software product has been developed, on which the methods for reducing the error in temperature measurement are applied. The results show that the application of combined hardware and software corrections can improve the accuracy of measurement with thermistor sensors to a level comparable to that of more expensive temperature measurement sensors.

title: Analysis of The Effect of Distance-Based Clustering on Ensemble Model Performance for Cellular Signal Prediction in Urban Areas
authors: Fikry Adam, Iskandar, Hajiar Yuliana
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Telecommunication Systems, Services, and Applications (TSSA)
abstract: Accurate cellular network coverage prediction presents a significant challenge in complex urban areas. This research provides a comprehensive analysis of the influence of distance-based clustering on the performance of Ensemble Learning models for cellular signal prediction. The methodology involved collecting drive test and operator data, followed by data preprocessing and feature engineering. The data was then clustered by distance using Quantile Binning and Fixed Interval methods. Various ensemble models were evaluated across three modeling scenarios: a specific model per cluster, a global model (baseline), and a global model with an added cluster feature. The results consistently demonstrate that the global model (baseline) approach delivered the most accurate and robust performance, with the Stacking model achieving the best results (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> = 0.80). The initial hypothesis, which stated that prediction error would increase with distance, was definitively rejected. In-depth analysis revealed that the error peaked at mid-range distances (100-250 meters), attributed to the high volatility of the actual signal in complex local environments like urban canyons. This finding proves that unmodeled local environmental factors have a more dominant influence on prediction difficulty than signal attenuation due to distance alone, offering the insight that more detailed geospatial features are needed to improve model accuracy in the future.

title: Generative Markov Chain Model Development for Guitar Melodies Creation
authors: Snezhana G. Pleshkova, Konstantin Kostov
abstract: This study proposes a generative Markov Chain model for creating guitar melodies. The proposed model generates various transition matrices for the Markov chain using multiple chord progressions in different genres. When analyzing the various transition states, separate transition matrices are created for each genre, each with an N-chord sequence used as a context. The purpose of the model is to generate stylistically consistent and accurate guitar chord progressions across various genres for creating guitar melodies.

title:
Compact Laser with Composite Ceramic YAG: Nd
                    <sup>3+</sup>
                    / YAG: Cr
                    <sup>4+</sup>
                    Element for LiDAR Applications
authors: Mikhail Ershkov, Alexander Shepelev, Sergei Solokhin, Sergei Smetanin
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: The results of experimental studies of compact laser oscillation with a composite ceramic YAG: Nd<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3+</sup> / YAG: Cr<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">4+</sup>element are presented. It was found that with an average pumping power of 0.5 W at a wavelength of 0.808 µm, the average single-mode oscillation power at a wavelength of 1.064 µm reaches 125 mW with a slope efficiency of 36.9 % and an overall efficiency of 30.2 %. The pulse energy was 18.8 µJ with a pulse duration of about 8 ns corresponding to a peak power of 2.5 kW. At maximum pumping power the divergence was less than 9 mrad.

title: A Data-Driven Framework for Remaining Useful Life Prediction of Main Power Transformers Using TPE-Optimized CatBoost
authors: Weiteng Lin, Hailong Jiang, Bao Wen, Aihui Wen, Jin Xu
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Trends in Computational Intelligence (NTCI)
abstract: Accurate prediction of the Remaining Useful Life (RUL) of main power transformers is essential for “ptimizing maintenance and enhancing grid reliability. However, conventional methods often suffer from data sparsity and inconsistent data quality. This paper introduces a comprehensive data-driven framework that integrates multi-source heterogeneous data—including asset registers, historical defect records, dissolved gas analysis (DGA), and, verload histories—to better characterize equipment aging. A systematic preprocessing pipeline is applied to improve data quality, incorporating advanced text normalization for categorical features. Among several state-of-the-art machine learning models evaluated, CatBoost demonstrated superior performance. Its hyperparameters were optimized using the Tree-structured Parzen Estimator (TPE) to further improve predictive accuracy and robustness. Validated on a real-world utility dataset, the proposed TPE-CatBoost model achieves a Mean Absolute Error (MAE) of 1.90 years in RUL prediction, confirming its effectiveness and practical value for proactive transformer asset management.

title: TOPKPHM:Periodic Patterns Mining of Top-K High Utility Itemsets
authors: Xintian Zhang, Baowei Liu, Jing Chen, Shengyi Yang, Zhixue Liu, Zhongkai Gu, Shun Xu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Trustworthy Big Data and Artificial Intelligence (ICTBAI)
abstract: The goal of periodic high-utility itemsets mining (PHUIM) is to uncover item combinations with high utility over recurring intervals based on minimum utility constraints. Traditional periodic high utility itemsets mining (PHUIM) algorithms rely on preset thresholds, which are difficult to choose without prior data knowledge. This work presents Top-K periodic high utility itemsets mining (TOPKPHM), a Top-K approach that addresses threshold specification by dynamically maintaining the utility value at the K-th rank position. TOPKPHM employs the Estimated Utility & Support Co-Occurrence Structure (EUSCS) for unified utility and support management. An enhanced utility-list structure integrates periodicity constraints directly, eliminating separate data structure overhead. Extensive experiments on four real-world datasets show TOPKPHM significantly outperforms state-of-the-art algorithms, achieving execution time reductions of multiple times compared to traditional methods on the chess dataset while maintaining consistent memory efficiency. This work advances constraint-based pattern mining theory and provides practical solutions for large-scale temporal data analysis.

title: Adaptive ESP-NOW Switching between Direct and Relay Paths Using RSSI-Based Beacon Monitoring
authors: Ivan Bozhilov, Milen H. Todorov, Boyanka Nikolova
abstract: This work presents a new approach for adaptive communication using ESP-NOW on ESP32 microcontrollers. In this system data transmission dynamically switches between direct and relay paths based on Received Signal Strength Indicator (RSSI). Dedicated beacon nodes broadcast periodically, and a beacon receiver compares their RSSI values to instruct the client node to select the optimal route. The performed experimental evaluation shows that this architecture maintains reliable audio data streaming in conditions where frequent path switching is necessary and also extends communication range with minimal latency overhead.

title: Application of the Phase Coordinate Method for Mathematical Modeling of 0.4 Kv Branched Rural Electrical Networks
authors: Alexander Vinogradov, Igor Golikov
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: The article discusses the application of the phase coordinate method for mathematical modeling of 0.4 kV branched electrical networks. A mathematical model based on the phase coordinate method has been developed to assess the changes in voltage deviations at various nodes of a branched electrical network. Unlike traditional approaches, the calculation is performed from the beginning of the power line, allowing for accurate determination of the distribution of voltages and currents throughout the branched section. This is particularly important for validating the effectiveness of design solutions during the construction or renovation of networks and ensuring stable power supply to consumers. The article also provides an example of a practical calculation of 0.4 kV branched electrical networks using the proposed method, illustrating its advantages and possibilities for engineering analysis.

title: A Performance Evaluation of A* and Dijkstra Algorithms with Visual-Based Goal Selection
authors: Tuğba Fıçııcı, Erdal Alimovski, Gökhan Erdemir
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Symposium on Computational Intelligence and Informatics (CINTI)
abstract: Successful operation of autonomous robots in complex environments require both reliable perception and efficient path planing. Reliable perception provide the foundation of scene understanding, which enables robots to understand their environment correctly and operate effectively. This study focuses on two main objectives: generation of a spatial map of the environment and extract the coordinates of bussinesses using LiDAR and visual perception and evaluation-comparison the performance of A* and Dijkstra path planning algorithms based on these perception-driven destination points. As the part of visual perception pipeline, we perform text detection and recognition where the coordinates of bussinesses were extracted. These extracted coordinates then are used as destination points for path planning algorithms. The experiments were conducted in the Gazebo simulation environment using a TurtleBot3 Waffle robot platform. The performance of path planning algorithms is evaluated based on following metrics; distance to the target, time to reach the destination, energy consumption, CPU load, and RAM usage. The experimental results shows that A* outperforms Dijkstra algorithm in terms of shorter travel time, lower energy consumption and CPU usage.

title: Research and Practice of a Blended Teaching Mode for Core Courses in Air Traffic Management
authors: Qunting Yang, Xiangbo Song, Jian Zhang, Yongxin Liu
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Modern Education and Information Management (ICMEIM)
abstract: To address the new challenges posed by the rapid development of air traffic management technology on the cultivation of air traffic controllers, and to resolve the core contradiction between limited class hours and increasing competency requirements in traditional teaching modes, this study implemented a reform of the blended teaching mode for core courses in the Air Traffic Management major. Based on Bloom's Taxonomy and CBE/CBT concepts, we adopted a “4C” teaching philosophy centered on Competency, incorporating Constructivism, Cultivation and Conduction to the teaching reform of core courses in the Air Traffic Management major. Utilizing the independently developed TULIP smart learning platform, which offers multiple categories of learning resources and virtual simulation training tasks, we designed a teaching implementation plan featuring “online task-driven independent learning + offline targeted deepening and expansion”. This model was practiced in courses such as Procedural Control. The results indicate that this mode significantly saves teaching time in classroom while effectively enhancing students' knowledge application ability and practical skills, providing a new referable path for teaching reform in the ATM major.

title: Machine Learning in Telecommunications: Literature Review by Field of Application
authors: Marija Konjević
abstract: Machine learning (ML) has great potential for application in various areas of telecommunications. This paper provides an overview of selected literature addressing the application of ML by areas: network management and optimization, prediction and analytics, security and threat detection, signal and data processing, resource allocation and management, mobility management, network planning and design, edge and cloud intelligence, application in next-generation services (5G/6G). The study aims to identify research trends and gaps relevant to regulatory practice in telecommunications.

title: A Prior Feature-Injected Cross-Attention Auto-Encoder for Land Cover Segmentation Using Optical and SAR Images
authors: Qian Guo, Xinyu Liu, Sijia Lu, Hui Bi
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Compared to traditional single-sensor data-based techniques, multi-source data provides complementary information about land cover targets, making it a hot research direction for improving the segmentation performance of land cover. However, multi-source data-based segmentation faces significant challenges due to the domain shifts in heterogeneous data, substantial sensitivity differences, imbalanced class distributions, and the limited availability of well-matched heterogeneous data samples. Therefore, A Prior Feature-injected Cross-Attention auto-Encoder(PF-CAE) is proposed using optical and SAR Images. First, an unsupervised prior feature injection module is designed to reduce the reliance on training data. Specifically, it utilizes maximum-based texture features, and magnitude-based strong scattering features extracted from optical and SAR images, respectively, as prior constraint features, emphasizing the strengths of heterogeneous data in segmenting different land cover types. Second, a transformer-based cross-attention feature module is introduced, which facilitates the extraction and learning of semantically consistent features while suppressing interference from redundant or irrelevant unique features. Finally, a class-weighted cross-entropy loss function is developed to address the imbalanced class distributions. Experimental results on the WHU-OPT-SAR dataset demonstrate the effectiveness and superiority of the proposed PF-CAE, achieving an average improvement of 3.5 % in the Kappa compared to other state-of-the-art algorithms.

title: Research on Evaluation Model of Internationalization Level of Scientific Research Institutions Based on BP Neural Networks
authors: Mingjun Zhang
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Modern Education and Information Management (ICMEIM)
abstract: In order to improve the scientificity and objectivity of the evaluation of scientific research institutions' internationalization, this research constructs an evaluation index system based on system theory, which covers talent input, international exchange activities and scientific research achievements, and proposes an improved BP neural network evaluation model. This model provides an intelligent tool for the evaluation of the internationalization level of scientific research institutions. The results show that it can effectively evaluate scientific research institutions. It not only has application value, but also has practical significance for improving the education evaluation system.

title: Corporate Production Control with Reinforcement Learning
authors: Vladimir Tsyganov
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: The article analyzes the problems and methods of research, development, and implementation of control theory and machine learning in industrial corporation. A model of organization of corporate production is built and studied, at the top level of which is the Principal, at the middle - the Representative and at the bottom — the Agent. The interaction between the Principal and the Representative was studied, and the features of their strategic behavior were identified. An optimal mechanism of control of the Representative on the part of the Principal, aimed at revealing the production potential, is proposed. The nature of the interaction between the Representative and the Agent and their strategic behavior is determined. The procedures of reinforcement learning of the Representative and motivation of the Agent are considered. An optimal mechanism of control of the Agent on the part of the Representative is developed. Based on the obtained results, a comprehensive mechanism for corporate management has been formed, which motivates active elements of an industrial corporation to increase production. The obtained results are applied in the service management system of Russian Railways corporation.

title: Industrial Computer Networks as a Design Object Using Fuzzy Models
authors: Margarita Yashchuk, Roman Makaruk
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: In the context of modern automated production control systems, the predominant use of industrial computer networks presents a complex challenge for network administrators. The article analyzes industrial computer networks as a design object, including: an analysis of key network characteristics considering the specifics of industrial facilities, formalization of the process for analyzing network parameters and generating recommendations, the functional structure of a software suite, and a justified choice of a fuzzy inference algorithm for processing qualitative indicators. The developed software suite will account for data incompleteness, adapt to changes in network topology, and provide engineers with interpretable results for making design decisions.

title: A Flexible Method for Backing Up and Migrating MySQL Users "MySQLUserFlex"
authors: Dimitar T. Todorov
publish: 2025 International Conference on Big Data, Knowledge and Control Systems Engineering (BdKCSE)
abstract: Migrating MySQL user accounts across server versions is challenging due to structural and functional changes in system tables and privilege management. Versions 5.6, 5.7, and 8.0+ differ in table schemas and supported privileges, with some removed or redefined. New authentication mechanisms, such as caching_sha2_password, and JSON-based attributes further complicate backup and restore. This paper presents MySQLUserFlex, a flexible script that extracts, filters, and generates SQL scripts fully compatible with the target version. It removes unsupported privileges, adapts CREATE USER and GRANT syntax, and handles system accounts and plugin-based authentication. MySQLUserFlex works in both standalone and clustered environments (e.g., MySQL NDB Cluster), providing reliable migration with minimal manual effort and enabling seamless transfer of user accounts across heterogeneous infrastructures.

title: Linearity Enhancement Method for CMOS Phase Interpolators In High-Speed SerDes
authors: Artur Mkhitaryan, Lyudvig Hakobyan, Albert Gevorgyan, Elen Piliposyan
abstract: Modern high-speed SerDes and clock/data recovery (CDR) systems heavily rely on phase interpolators (PI) to generate accurate clocks for timing critical paths. As data rates continue to scale, achieving linear code-to-phase transfer becomes increasingly difficult due to device nonidealities, shrinking supply voltages, and tighter jitter budgets. Nonlinearity in the interpolator directly degrades timing accuracy, leading to higher bit-error rates (BER). This work explores methods to improve interpolator linearity in CMOS inverter-based mixer architectures. The three methods are: digital predisposition, an ac-coupled feedback inverter at the input, and reduced supply operation of the mixer stage. Simulation results show that the combination of these methods effectively flattens the code-to-phrase characteristics and reduces integral nonlinearity. Trade-offs are added circuit complexity, area and jitter. The results demonstrate that with modest design, the proposed methods provide a practical way toward more accurate PIs in advanced SerDes and CDR applications.

title: Mass Transfer Models for Steam Methane Reforming
authors: Igor Dmitrievich Karpilov, Ravil Mansurovich Mustafin, Dmitry Mikhailovich Bragin, Andrey Igorevich Popov, Sofya Alekseevna Zinina, Anton Vladimirovich Eremin
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: The diffusion mass transfer governs the species motion inside the porous catalyst particle. It is important to correctly choose the diffusion model to predict the reaction behavior in packed bed reactors. This article explores the applicability of four diffusion models to the reaction CFD modelling inside the packed bed reactor. The models considered are: constant diffusion coefficient, kinetic theory, Lewis number and Bosanquet approximation. The numerical values were acquired for a wide range of operating pressure and residence time. The CFD results indicate that the Kinetic theory models overpredicts the CH<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">4</inf> conversion by 66% on average. The Constant model underpredicts the results by 38% on average. The Bosanquet approximation and Lewis number values were quite close for all cases considered. This implies that Lewis number model may be used for CFD model simplification.

title: A Cross-Paradigm Evaluation of SLAM Algorithms for Autonomous Driving on the KITTI Dataset
authors: Péter Rózsás, László Schäffer, Zoltán Kincses, Szilveszter Pletl
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Symposium on Computational Intelligence and Informatics (CINTI)
abstract: Simultaneous Localization and Mapping (SLAM) is a cornerstone technology for autonomous systems, particularly in autonomous driving. Although numerous studies benchmark SLAM algorithms, a significant gap exists in the literature regarding direct, cross-paradigm comparisons, evaluating systems based on disparate sensor modalities under identical conditions on public datasets. This paper addresses this gap by presenting a comprehensive qualitative and quantitative evaluation of several state-of-the-art SLAM algorithms. The EKF, MSCKF, OKVIS, ORB-SLAM3, F-LOAM and LVI-SAM algorithms are qualitatively compared, but only the last four algorithms were evaluated using the publicly available KITTI (Karlsruhe Institute of Technology and Toyota Technological Institute) dataset. The findings indicate that ORB-SLAM3 provides the highest accuracy in both position and orientation estimation on the chosen KITTI sequences. The results highlight a critical trade-off between the high precision of visual-based methods in suitable environments and the increased robustness offered by multi-sensor fusion systems.

title: Integration of a Collaborative Robot with PLC and HMI for an Automated Street Lamp Assembly Line
authors: Kamen Hristov, Daniel Dinkov
abstract: This paper presents the integration of a FANUC CRX-10iA/L collaborative robot with a Siemens PLC and WinCC HMI for an automated street lamp assembly line. The system enables real-time coordination between robotic and peripheral operations through a deterministic Modbus/TCP network. The PLC manages process sequencing and interlocks, while the HMI provides intuitive visualization, manual control, and alarm diagnostics. Experimental results demonstrated efficient communication, smooth synchronization, and improved reliability. The integration reduced the assembly cycle time by 31%, decreased downtime by 35%, and shortened operator response time by 43% compared to the pre-integration setup. The proposed control architecture offers a flexible and scalable solution for Industry 4.0 applications, combining collaborative robotics, programmable control, and user-centered interfaces to enhance productivity and safety in modern manufacturing.

title: Power module packaging using 3D printed ceramics substrate
authors: Emmanuel Marcault, Loïc Teisserenc, Manon Porlan, Marie Beaujard, Lucile Mage, Régis Delsol
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th Workshop on Wide Bandgap Power Devices and Applications (WiPDA)
abstract: The use of wide bandgap devices such as GaN (gallium nitride) in electronic circuits requires a reduction in parasitic elements [1] - [2]. In addition, the miniaturisation of power modules leads to a significant increase in power density and temperature [3]. Ceramics such as Al2O3 or AlN are promising materials for cooling [4] - [5], thanks to their remarkable thermal properties (notably their high thermal conductivity, approximately 30 W/m.K and 180 W/m.K respectively) and their electrical insulation capacity. The aim of this work is to take advantage of the design flexibility offered by 3D printing to reduce parasitic elements and optimise thermal management.

title: Cross-Platform Evaluation of Visual Localization Models: Benchmarking CPU, GPU, Jetson, and FPGA Implementations
authors: Vazgen Melikyan, Tigran Khachatryan, Mushegh Grigoryan, Eduard Harutyunyan, Arthur Mkhitaryan, Sargis Azizbekyan, Vardan Hovhannisyan
abstract: This paper presents a comprehensive comparative study of the deployment and performance of machine learning-based visual localization systems across various hardware platforms: CPU, GPU, NVIDIA Jetson, and FPGA. Using a dual-modality (RGB-IR) object detection framework based on the YOLO architecture, each platform’s suitability is assesed for real-time inference in terms of latency, throughput, power consumption, model complexity, and ease of deployment. The analysis highlights practical implications of deploying AI systems on edge and embedded platforms, with an emphasis on optimizing resource-constrained applications. The findings offer clear recommendations for selecting hardware platforms tailored to specific operational requirements. Furthermore, underscores the importance of hardware-aware model design, quantization, and efficient memory usage in enabling scalable and deployable visual intelligence. The work contributes in deploying deep learning models in production environments by offering practical, hardware-specific deployment insights and performance trade-offs.

title: Indian Sign Language Recognition System Using Machine Language
authors: Y R Thulasi Prasad
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Computing and Communication Technologies (CONECCT)
abstract: This paper presents a machine learning-based system designed to recognize Indian Sign Language (ISL) gestures and convert them into text, enabling effective communication for individuals with hearing and speech impairments. The proposed approach utilizes computer vision techniques and a standard webcam for gesture recognition, eliminating the need for specialized external sensors. A deep learning model is trained on a diverse ISL dataset to achieve real-time recognition with high accuracy. The system is evaluated through extensive testing, demonstrating its ability to accurately interpret various ISL signs. By offering a cost-effective and accessible solution, this work promotes inclusivity and enhances communication for the Deaf community. Future improvements will focus on expanding gesture coverage, enhancing model robustness, and integrating multilingual capabilities to support a wider user base.

title: IoT-Enabled Smart Security Surveillance System for Farmland and Livestock Monitoring Using Computer Vision
authors: Nisha Varghese, Shafi Shereef
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Computing and Communication Technologies (CONECCT)
abstract: Agriculture is the main source of income of every country and agriculture plays a critical role in sustaining human civilization by providing food, fuel, and other essential resources. Even though, the conflict between farmers and wildlife remains a significant challenge even today. It is essential to arrange the protection of fields and farms by deterring wild animals and predators without making harm to the wildlife. This study proposes a framework that can detect and classify animals or intruders or any natural calamities. The novelty of the study is deterring the wild animals using innocuous devices and chemical components instead of the harmful electric fences and other methods. Based on the classification it will take preventive measures and will send an alert to the Farmer. The preventive measures are ensuring that will not make any harm to the wild animals. The framework incorporated four major components PIR (Passive Infrared) Sensor, Raspberry Pi Camera, Scarecrow and GSM (Global System for Mobile Communications) Module. PIR Sensor detects an object, Raspberry Pi Camera captures the images and images classify the specific object, later based on the type of the animal the scare tactics will be applied by the scarecrow and if any unusual incident is happening like the presence of an intruder, fire or tornado the alert will send to the Farmer with the help of a GSM Module.

title: Ring Interconnection Methods and Algorithms: Case study on Sumatra Island Topology in NDN Network
authors: Syaiful Ahdan, Dzata Farahiyah, Ade Nurhayati, Adi Sucipto, Nana Rachmana Syambas
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Telecommunication Systems, Services, and Applications (TSSA)
abstract: A network that is interconnected for efficient computing and communication is made up of hardware and software elements. Computer systems, memory modules, processors, and processes are some examples of these entities. The design and deployment of communication networks depend heavily on interconnection networks. The primary challenge with many network design issues is that cost and inherent technical limitations limit the maximum node degree. In this work, we used the optimum flow approach, utilizing traffic and distance data to simulate the best interconnection planning for a section of Sumatra's island divided into multiple clusters. With the use of our suggested system, we developed an optimum flow algorithm for the Sumatra region that can automatically select the best interconnection, resulting in the optimal interconnection in each cluster.

title: Range super-resolution imaging based on TSVD dimensionality reduction combined with FISTA
authors: Zhimeng Hu, Weixin Li, Dong Wang, Dandan Wang, Lei Yang
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Trends in Computational Intelligence (NTCI)
abstract: The Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSSR) Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) is widely used in target detection. However, its low signal power and narrow bandwidth directly lead to low radar imaging resolution and significant noise impact. Because of the low resolution of GNSS-R SAR, high sampling rate is required during sampling. This leads to the large size of the imaging matrix, which affects the imaging speed. And low rank leads to the ill-posedness of its observation matrix. Therefore, in order to improve its imaging speed and alleviate its ill-posedness, we propose a fast range super-resolution imaging based on TSVD dimensionality reduction combined with FISTA. In the proposed method, the matrix dimension reduction is carried out to reduce the amount of data processing and accelerate the speed of the algorithm. Since the TSVD technique alleviates the ill-posedness of the measurement matrix, the L1 norm constraint is introduced to construct the objective function by using the sparse characteristics of the target from the regularization. Finally, the approximate solution is found by solving the objective function with the fast iterative threshold shrinkage method of adaptive step size. The simulation results show that this method not only improves the resolution accuracy of GNSS-R SAR, but also greatly accelerates the speed of the fast iterative threshold shrinkage method.

title: Cybersecurity Concerns of Older Irish Adults: A Comparison Across High, Medium and Low Tech Usage
authors: Michelle O’Keeffe, Jacob Camilleri, Ashley Sheil, Sanchari Das, Melanie Gruben, Moya Cronin, Miriam Curtin, Aoife Long, Hazel Murray
abstract: Older adults in Ireland face critical cybersecurity challenges that impact their digital security posture, risk perception, and online engagement. Through a qualitative analysis of semi-structured interviews with 77 participants aged 60 and above, we identify key barriers, including cybersecurity knowledge gaps, usability challenges with authentication mechanisms, and a lack of accessible security support. Participants report concerns about online fraud, privacy risks, and the overwhelming nature of security advice, which often results in digital disengagement. By categorizing participants by technology usage–low, medium, and high, we uncover distinct cybersecurity behaviors. Greater technology use is often accompanied by increased awareness of cyber threats; however, this does not necessarily translate into secure practices, as many continue to struggle with two-factor authentication (2FA) and secure password management. Medium-usage participants exhibit high anxiety over scams and rely on family for security support, while low-usage individuals, though less exposed to threats, remain at risk due to a lack of foundational digital skills and reliance on avoidance-based security strategies. Our findings highlight the urgent need for targeted cybersecurity education, simplified authentication systems, and age-appropriate security interventions to enhance digital confidence, cyber resilience, and online inclusion among older adults, ensuring their secure and equitable participation in an increasingly digital society.
