title: MultiSiFer: Detecting Multiple-Speaker Fake Voice Without Speaker-Irrelative Features
authors: Xin Liu, Xuan Hai, Ziyao Yu, Zihao Zhang, Qingyuan Fei, Qinguo Zhou
abstract: Voice synthesis technologies have advanced rapidly, raising serious concerns about content security and trust. While many fake voice detectors achieve strong performance in controlled settings, they often overfit to speaker-irrelative features (SiFs), exhibit poor robustness, and fail in multi-speaker scenarios. To address these limitations, we propose MultiSiFer, a novel fake voice detector grounded in a new design philosophy: rather than merely distinguishing synthetic from human voices, it explicitly prioritizes learning essential human voice characteristics. MultiSiFer leverages a pre-trained speech representation model to enhance this learning and is the first detector trained on a newly curated multi-speaker fake voice dataset, enabling effective generalization across speakers. Experiments show that MultiSiFer outperforms existing methods in both standard and multi-speaker settings, achieving 10.84% average equal error rate (EER).

title: Large Language Model-Driven Closed-Loop UAV Operation with Semantic Observations
authors: Wenhao Wang, Yanyan Li, Long Jiao, Jiawei Yuan
abstract: Recent advances in Large Language Models (LLMs) have revolutionized mobile robots, including unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs), enabling their intelligent operation within Internet of Things (IoT) ecosystems. However, LLMs still face challenges from logical reasoning and complex decision-making, leading to concerns about the reliability of LLM-driven UAV operations in IoT applications. In this paper, we propose a closed-loop LLM-driven UAV operation code generation framework that enables reliable UAV operations powered by effective feedback and refinement using two LLM modules, i.e., a Code Generator and an Evaluator. Our framework transforms numerical state observations from UAV operations into semantic trajectory descriptions to enhance the evaluator LLM’s understanding of UAV dynamics for precise feedback generation. Our framework also enables a simulation-based refinement process, and hence eliminates the risks to physical UAVs caused by incorrect code execution during the refinement. Extensive experiments on UAV control tasks with different complexities are conducted. The experimental results show that our framework can achieve reliable UAV operations using LLMs, which significantly outperforms baseline methods in terms of success rate and completeness with the increase of task complexity.

title: Interference Mitigation in One-Way Channel Reconstruction for Robust Phase-Based Ranging
authors: Grega Morano, Tomaž Javornik, Aleš Simončič, Aleš Švigelj, Andrej Hrovat
abstract: Under the Integrated Sensing and Communication (ISAC) paradigm, wireless networks are evolving into multifunctional platforms that seamlessly combine data transmission with high-precision ranging for applications such as indoor navigation, asset tracking, and context-aware Internet of Things (IoT). The Multi-Carrier Phase Difference (MCPD) method has emerged as an effective technique for enabling localization in narrowband communication systems by estimating the channel frequency response (CFR) used for distance estimation. Converting the two-way CFR (TWCFR) into a one-way CFR (OWCFR) provides a physically consistent representation of the propagation channel and thus improves the ranging performance. However, existing channel reconstruction (CR) methods rely on noise-sensitive phase unwrapping which degrades in the presence of noise and interference, common in dense IoT deployments and crowded frequency bands. To address these limitations, we propose a noise-resistant OWCFR reconstruction algorithm that utilizes a peak-driven adaptive windowing strategy to generate a reference TWCFR for reliable square-root branch selection and incorporates a delay alignment correction to restore the maximum unambiguous range. Simulation and experimental results using IEEE 802.15.4 time-slotted channel hopping (TSCH) compliant devices demonstrate that the proposed method achieves robust and accurate distance estimation in more than 99.8% of interference scenarios.

title: Latency Optimization in Hybrid Memory System for GNNs
authors: Zhaoyang Zeng, Yujuan Tan, Wei Chen, Jiali Li, Zhuoxin Bai, Ao Ren, Duo Liu, Xianzhang Chen
abstract: Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) require high-capacity, low-latency memory systems to process large graphs. A hierarchical hybrid memory architecture combining high-capacity Non-Volatile Memory (NVM) and low-latency DRAM offers a promising solution. However, the inherent sparsity of graph data results in poor locality for GNN memory requests, leading to low DRAM cache hit rates and numerous misses, which significantly impairs the hybrid memory system’s performance. A critical issue is that DRAM misses in serial access mode incur substantial latency. While parallel access mode can mitigate this for misses, it introduces long-tail latency and wastes bandwidth for DRAM hits. In this paper, we focus on addressing these issues from two aspects: increasing the cache hit rate and decreasing the miss latency. We mainly propose two predictors: a future data access predictor that enables accurate prefetching to DRAM, thereby improving cache hit rates, and a data location predictor that determines whether data resides in DRAM or NVM, optimizing the choice between serial and parallel access modes to reduce miss latency. By integrating these predictors, we achieve efficient data access in both DRAM and NVM. Our experiments show a 49.5% reduction in memory delay and a 38.1% increase in memory bandwidth utilization compared to baseline.

title: K-Band High-Power Rectification With GaAs E-pHEMT Gated Anode Diodes
authors: Yuya Hirose, Naoya Kakutani, Fumiya Komatsu, Naoki Sakai, Masaomi Tsuru, Kenji Itoh
abstract: In this paper, K-band high-power rectification and its efficiency are discussed in theoretical and experimental approaches. A gated anode diodes (GAD) configured with a gallium arsenide (GaAs) enhancement-mode pseudomorphic high-electron-mobility-transistor (E-pHEMT) is focused as a rectifier diode. The GaAs E-pHEMT GAD is characterized to formulate its rectification efficiency. In K-band rectification at an input power of 100 mW or less, it is analytically clarified that the 0.18 μm GaAs E-pHEMT GAD, manufactured using a standard GaAs process, exhibited a rectification efficiency within 2% of that of the commercially available GaAs Schottky barrier diode (SBD) (MACOM MA4E1317) widely used in millimeter wave systems. For the K-band 1 W rectifier MMIC demonstrated in this paper, multi-stage series-connected GaAs E-pHEMT GADs with a wider gate width are used to achieve high-power rectification with high efficiency. For the prototyped K-band 1 W rectifier MMIC, the gate width and the stage number of the series-connected GADs are optimized and a rectification efficiency of 64% at 26.5 GHz is achieved. This is the highest value reported for 50 Ω matched watt-class rectifiers. The results confirm that the proposed design approach with the GaAs E-pHEMT GAD is effective for high-power rectification in the K-band.

title: Selective disclosure approaches in Self-Sovereign Identity: an experimental comparison
authors: Andrea De Salve, Andrea Lisi, Maurizio Cascino, Paolo Mori, Laura Ricci
abstract: The Self-Sovereign Identity (SSI) paradigm empowers individuals to manage their own credentials by storing them in digital wallets under their full control. In SSI, a credential embeds a list of claims representing personal attributes of the holder, and it is digitally signed by the issuer. When requested, the holder submits some of their credentials to a verifier to prove some of their attributes (e.g., being of legal age). However, to protect their privacy, the holder might want to disclose to the verifier only a subset of the claims embedded in each of the credentials they share, thus requiring a mechanism for hiding the other claims without invalidating the digital signatures of the credentials. This paper surveys the approaches enabling a subject to disclose only selected claims from a signed credential, known as Selective Disclosure. These approaches define the protocol the issuer should follow to construct the credentials, and the holder should follow to disclose only the claims they wish. We examined five approaches, based on: atomic credentials, hashing, encryption, hash trees, and signature, and we compare them from both a qualitative and quantitative point of view. In order to perform an unbiased quantitative evaluation, we developed a reference implementation for each approach and we assessed their performance in executing the same SSI operations on the same credentials. In particular, we measured the time required to create and verify credentials and presentations, as well as the size they take, varying both the number of claims in the credentials and the percentage of disclosed ones in the presentations. The proposed qualitative and experimental comparison is meant to support application designers in understanding which of the available selective disclosure approach is more convenient for their application scenarios.

title: A Novel Rat Robot: Multi Degree of Freedom Motion Control_supp4-3648651.mp4
authors: le zhang
abstract: Objective: The development of brain-computer interface (BCI) technology has enabled animals to execute movements in accordance with human intent. The rat robot represents a novel robotic system based on BCI technology. However, due to limitations in electrode fabrication techniques and the use of simplistic control strategies, current rat robots are restricted to limited movement patterns, which hinder their applicability in real-world scenarios. To address these challenges, we have developed a portable wireless neural stimulator and a novel 3D integrated stimulating electrode. By refining the locomotion control strategy, we aim to achieve complex, high-degree-of-freedom movement in rat robot systems. Methods: 3D integrated electrodes were implanted into the rats' head, with no reward-based training required. By utilizing a wearable wireless stimulation backpack to connect the electrodes and deliver electrical stimulation to multiple brain regions, thereby enabling the rat to perform forward movement, turning, and stopping behaviors. Results: The experimental results demonstrate that under optimized stimulation parameters, the forward speed of the rat robot can be controlled to achieve 31.06 ± 1.21 m/min, the turning angle can reach up to 150 ± 1.22°, and the stopping duration can be flexibly adjusted. Furthermore, we presented a practical scenario in which the rat robot successfully executed a predefined navigation task in a real-world environment, thereby validating its high degree of movement flexibility and control precision. Conclusion: This study achieved high-degree-of-freedom motion control of rat robots without the need for reward-based training, which was previously unattainable. Significance: This research establishes a crucial foundation and provides valuable technical references for the application of animal robots in fields such as information reconnaissance and wreckage search and rescue operations.

title: An Arbitrary Register Grouping Scheme for RISC-V Vector Extension: Compilation Support and Hardware Implementation
authors: Limin Jiang, Siyi Xu, Yintao Liu, Yihao Shen, Yi Shi, Shan Cao, Zhiyuan Jiang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computer-Aided Design of Integrated Circuits and Systems
abstract: Vector instruction set architectures (ISAs) play a critical role in accelerating data-parallel computation, yet mainstream designs—such as the RISC-V “V” Vector Extension (RVV) – still rely on rigid, power-of-two register grouping strategies. These limitations hinder performance when handling ultra-long vectors or non-uniform workloads, as they require extensive strip-mining and careful low-level tuning to maintain efficiency. To overcome these bottlenecks, we propose Zoozve, a flexible, strip-mining-free extension to the RISC-V vector ISA. Zoozve introduces an arbitrary register grouping mechanism that enables more precise register utilization and eliminates the need for data slicing across multiple loop iterations. This work presents a full-stack realization of Zoozve, including (1) a hardware-compatible ISA with support for flexible vector lengths and asymmetric instructions, (2) a compiler backend based on LLVM that performs intrinsic splitting, register allocation with live-interval modification, and instruction coalescing, and (3) a hardware proof-of-concept implementation that integrates hazard detection and a register-level element exchange engine. Experimental evaluation using instruction-level simulation shows that Zoozve achieves up to 344.44× speedup in fast Fourier transform (FFT), 76× in dot product, 58.92× in axpy, and 20.41× in 2D convolution compared to RVV, primarily by eliminating strip-mining and improving register reuse. Register transfer level (RTL) synthesis in a 40 nm process shows that Zoozve’s additional hardware logic incurs only 9% area overhead, confirming its feasibility for real-world deployment. Together, these results demonstrate Zoozve’s potential as a scalable and efficient vector processing solution for high-performance computing, machine learning, and signal processing.

title: Online Monitoring Method for Gate Oxide Degradation in SiC MOSFETs Based on Turn-on Current Rise Time
authors: Zhuang Li, Jiadi Li, Junyu Wang, Rui Yang, Yumeng Cai, Peng Sun, Xuebao Li, Zhibin Zhao, Xu Cheng
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th Workshop on Wide Bandgap Power Devices and Applications (WiPDA)
abstract: Gate oxide degradation is a critical reliability issue that limits the widespread application of SiC MOSFETs. Online monitoring of gate oxide degradation significantly enhances device operational reliability. This paper proposes an online method for monitoring gate oxide degradation in SiC MOSFETs using turn-on current rise time. Firstly, the influence of gate oxide degradation on turn-on current rise time is investigated through theoretical modeling. Secondly, the effectiveness of analytical analysis is validated via experiments. Moreover, it is demonstrated that the package degradation does not affect turn-on current rise time. Thirdly, an operational monitor circuit of turn-on current rise time is designed, and the feasibility of this monitoring approach to detect the variation in turn-on current rise time is validated through simulation. This non-invasive method offers strong real-time capability, providing an effective approach for online SiC MOSFETs health assessment and system reliability prediction.

title: Agricultural Waste to Biofuel: Transforming Crop Residue into Next-Generation Aviation Fuel
authors: Shyam Maurya, V. Mangaiyarkarasi, Bakhriddinov Makhamadali Madaminjonugli, Hasssan MuhamedAle, E. Arunkumar, Guma Ali, Navruzbek Rakhimov, Chinmai Shetty
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems and Pioneering Innovations in Robotics and Electric Mobility (INSPIRE)
abstract: The rapid expansion of international aviation has significantly contributed to greenhouse gas emissions. The existing type of jet fuel consumes a considerable amount of crude oil, which has compounded the demand. As a result, the industry accounts for a carbon footprint that reduces the pressure on alternative energy sources with lower carbon emissions. Agricultural waste comprises straw, husks, and stalks, which denotes one such available lignocellulosic feedstock that is not exhaustively utilised to offer a solution to environmental and economic dilemmas in the aviation energy production. The given research paper proposes an integrated solution to transform agricultural waste materials into high-energy-density biofuels, which can be utilised in the aviation industry through a two-stage biochemical and thermochemical treatment, followed by subsequent fuel upgrading to produce a high-quality product. Pre-treatment options, which were attempted on a lab scale, included steam explosion, dilute acid hydrolysis, enzyme saccharification, fermentation, pyrolysis, and Fischer-Tropsch catalytic upgrading. The parameters of the process conditions were optimised to achieve a high yield and minimise energy consumption. Results were statistically analysed to ensure reproducibility, and fuel properties were compared to ASTM D7566 standards to verify that they conformed to conventional jet fuel specifications. The results show that biofuels produced from agricultural waste have an energy density similar to that of Jet A fuel, with notable reductions in carbon and particulate emissions, making them a viable option for mitigating greenhouse gas emissions caused by aviation. The techno-economic analysis also demonstrates the viability of large-scale implementation, based on the availability of feedstock, process effectiveness, and compliance with regulations. The practice is also compatible with the principles of the circular economy, which emphasises the value of agricultural residues, agrarian economies, and sustainable waste management. Moreover, it is possible to optimise it with AI, emulate the use of blockchains to track feedstock, and adopt the concept of hybrid biofuel-electric to make the future of biofuel work more efficiently and easily tracked. Comprehensively, the paper demonstrates that agricultural waste can be a feasible and sustainable aviation biofeedstock of the next generation, as it can help minimise carbon footprints, make biofuels economically viable, and promote the current trend of carbon-neutral aircraft in the global community.

title: Adaptive Security Operations Center
authors: D R Janardhana, M Tejas, Vamshi Rayala, Jayapadmini Kanchan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Computing and Communication Technologies (CONECCT)
abstract: Security Operations Centers (SOCs) play a vital role in automating threat detection, enhancing incident response, and streamlining workflows. However, traditional SOCs often struggle to efficiently manage dynamic workloads and fluctuating network traffic. This research presents an Adaptive Security Operations Center (ASOC) that leverages rule-based mechanisms to optimize resource utilization and traffic analysis in real time. The ASOC adjusts its operations based on workload conditions: during low activity, it minimizes resource usage by performing autonomous analysis, reducing the need for human intervention, while under high-load conditions, it dynamically allocates additional resources and partially processes data to assist analysts. This adaptive approach ensures scalability, enhances operational efficiency, and balances computational and human resources, offering a more agile and effective solution to modern cybersecurity challenges.

title: Reservoir Modeling of Well-Seismic Fusion based on Lightweight Generative Adversarial Network
authors: Xu Yang, Shaoqun Dong, Tao Xu, Fuyu Zhang, Leting Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Trends in Computational Intelligence (NTCI)
abstract: Reservoir modeling technology based on well logs and seismic is the key to underground reservoir characterization, which determines the development plan and well pattern deployment. In recent years, generative adversarial network (GAN) has emerged as a research hotspot in reservoir modeling. Aiming at the challenges associated with traditional GAN-based reservoir modeling algorithms, such as excessive parameters, high computational demands, significant memory usage, and substantial resource consumption, a lightweight well and seismic fusion reservoir modeling network (LightGAN) is proposed. The network employs shallow convolutional neural networks combined with Wasserstein distances to achieve fast and accurate modeling. In order to verify the effectiveness of the improved method, sedimentary facies data are used for experimental detection. The results show that LightGAN improves accuracy by more than $6 \%$ relative to the conditional deep convolutional generative adversarial network (CDCGAN) and shows incremental improvement over the state-of-the-art Generative facial prior GAN (GFPGAN). As training parameters increase, LightGAN’s performance gradually stabilizes, resulting in an enhancement in accuracy of over $\mathbf{3 . 5 \%}$.

title: Riesz Wavelets Toolbox for Differential SAR Interferograms Despeckling
authors: Yassine Tounsi, Jamila Fathi, Imad Hamdi, Abdelkrim Nassim
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Phase extraction in Differential Synthetic Aperture Radar (DInSAR) is a crucial tool for detecting ground deformation changes at a subcentimeter level. The processing of the evaluated phase map occurs through two significant and consecutive steps: phase denoising and phase unwrapping. We focus on the initial step and propose utilizing the discrete Riesz wavelets transform to mitigate residual speckle noise from the generated DInSAR phase map. The effectiveness of the proposed method is assessed using three important criteria: peak-to-signal-noise ratio (PSNR), the quality index Q, and the edge preservation index. The obtained metric values demonstrate that this technique can enhance both PSNR and Q compared to other well-known methods.

title: A Single Signal Conversion Terminal as a Means of Improving the Accuracy and Reliability of PLC Systems
authors: E.S. Duvanov, A.F. Pashchenko, R.V. Batishchev, A.V. Piatykh, M.I. Kopaev
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: The article considers the disadvantages of the traditional multi-stage signal transmission scheme from sensors to programmable logic controllers (PLC) in industrial automation systems. The concept of a single conversion terminal integrating the functions of all intermediate devices is substantiated. A comparative analysis was carried out, which showed an increase in the accuracy, reliability and cost-effectiveness of the proposed solution.

title: Deep Neuro-Fuzzy Systems: Integration, Challenges, and Future Directions
authors: Chao Xi, Jiale Liu, Zhiqiang Wei, Silong Qin, Zhicheng Wang, Zizhu Fan
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Trends in Computational Intelligence (NTCI)
abstract: Due to the black-box nature of deep learning, its application in critical domains has been limited, highlighting the growing demand for transparent and interpretable AI models. Deep neuro-fuzzy systems (DNFSs) combine the powerful feature extraction capabilities of deep neural networks with the interpretability of fuzzy systems, making them a promising area of research. This paper provides a review of key research in DNFSs from 2020 to 2025, focusing on model structures, optimization methods, and approaches to achieving interpretability. Unlike previous reviews, we particularly emphasize the integration of Transformer networks with fuzzy systems, an area that has gained significant attention. The review also addresses challenges in DNFS development, such as computational complexity, rule explosion, and domain generalization, and outlines future research directions to optimize these systems for broader applications.

title:
Humidity Sensing Performance of MoO
                    <sub>3</sub>
                    /ZnO Heterostructure Based on First-principles Calculation
authors: Lina Zhou, Zuozhe Ding, Gongao Jiao, Xingyan Shao, Dongzhi Zhang
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Trends in Computational Intelligence (NTCI)
abstract: Relative humidity is one of the core parameters in environmental monitoring, with measurement needs pervasive across multiple critical domains including agricultural production, petrochemical industries, aerospace, and even health monitoring. However, despite the widespread use and urgent demand for humidity sensors, a fundamental challenge persists: the underlying sensing mechanisms, particularly at atomic and molecular levels, often remain inadequately understood. This lack of mechanistic clarity hampers the rational design of nextgeneration sensors with enhanced sensitivity, selectivity, stability, and response speed. In this study, a molybdenum trioxide/zinc oxide $\left(\mathrm{MoO}_{3} / \mathrm{ZnO}\right)$ heterostructure was constructed and first-principles calculations were employed to conduct an in-depth investigation, at the atomic and electronic scales, into interfacial charge transfer at the $\mathrm{MoO}_{3} / \mathrm{ZnO}$ heterojunction and its adsorption characteristics toward water molecules. The results demonstrated that the adsorption energy (-1.395 eV) and charge transfer (0.083 e) of the $\mathrm{MoO}_{3} / \mathrm{ZnO}$ composite material with water molecules are higher than those of the pure MoO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf> and pure ZnO structures, indicating a stronger and more stable adsorption interactions between the $\mathrm{MoO}_{3} / \mathrm{ZnO}$ composite and H<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>O molecules. Consequently, constructing the $\mathrm{MoO}_{3} / \mathrm{ZnO}$ heterostructure effectively enhances the adsorption of water molecules by the humidity-sensitive material, thereby improving its humidity sensing properties.

title: Semantic Segmentation in Natural Environments: An Analysis of Deep Learning Techniques
authors: Jahid Hasan Rony, Abdullah Al Shafi, Razib Hayat Khan, M. M. Mahbubul Syeed, Mohammad Faisal Uddin
publish: 2025 IEEE International Performance, Computing, and Communications Conference (IPCCC)
abstract: Semantic segmentation in complex natural environments remains a challenging task due to diverse object appearances, background clutter, and class imbalance. This study evaluates state-of-the-art segmentation models, categorized into UNet-based, encoder-decoder, and transformer-based architectures, using a dataset focused on aquatic plant segmentation in a natural environment. The model is evaluated using Dice coefficient, F1 score, IoU and overall accuracy, along with computational complexity measured by parameter count and GFLOPs. Results indicate that backbone-enhanced models outperform base configurations by providing deeper and more robust feature representations. Then, explainable AI (XAI) techniques are used to evaluate the model attention and ensure the precise focus of the network on ecologically meaningful regions. These insights not only highlight the importance of architectural depth and input diversity but also demonstrate how XAI can support iterative model refinement. As a result of these combined efforts, segmentation performance is improved from a baseline dice coefficient and accuracy of 50.76 and 85.07 % to a maximum 75.57 and 94.94 % respectively. This comprehensive analysis provides valuable insights of selecting suitable models in resource-constrained environments and advances the development of robust segmentation systems.

title: ORAN Driven Network Slicing in 5G
authors: Adil Mulimani, Shreeniwas R. Kolagal, Vishal R. Patil, Vineet S. Hiremani, Meenaxi M. Raikar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems and Pioneering Innovations in Robotics and Electric Mobility (INSPIRE)
abstract: The growing demand for differentiated services in 5G networks has led to the adoption of network slicing to support heterogeneous use cases such as enhanced Mobile Broadband (eMBB) and massive Machine-Type Communications (mMTC). Traditional RAN architectures fall short in delivering isolated and service-specific performance. In this work, we present a proof-of-concept ORAN-aligned 5G slicing testbed built entirely using open-source components. The system integrates Open5GS as the 5G Core and UERANSIM for emulating gNB and UE behavior. Two static slices—eMBB and mMTC—are configured using distinct DNNs and dedicated UPF instances to enforce service-level isolation. Performance validation is conducted using iperf3-driven TCP and UDP traffic for the eMBB slice, achieving stable throughput over 50 Mbps in both uplink and downlink. The mMTC slice is simulated using synthetic telemetry-style traffic to reflect low-data-rate IoT scenarios. Prometheus and Grafana are integrated for end-to-end observability, enabling slice-specific metric collection and anomaly detection. Our modular, containerized design enables reproducibility and provides a foundation for future enhancements, including dynamic slicing and AI-driven RAN optimization.

title: Semantically Enhanced Satellite Image Querying: A Knowledge Graph-Driven Agent Based System
authors: Aaryan Shetty, Sai Anitej Amara, Chetana Mital, Ashvin Bhat, S Natarajan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Computing and Communication Technologies (CONECCT)
abstract: The interpretation of Remote Sensing (RS) imagery remains a challenge due to the complexity of extracting meaningful insights from large-scale geospatial data. In this work, we propose an agentic Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) system that enables interactive querying of a semantic knowledge graph-driven repository of annotated satellite images. We create a knowledge graph (KG) using OpenStreetMap (OSM) data, which is used to enhance our satellite imagery with semantic context. This is achieved by linking extracted geometric features (polygons) from satellite imagery to their corresponding entities in the knowledge graph, enabling precise localization and visual annotation of queried features. This satellite imagery builds our repository, which allows users to retrieve both textual responses and annotated images based on natural language queries. Our system effectively enhances the usability, accessibility, and contextual understanding of low resolution satellite imagery by transforming raw geospatial data into structured and retrievable information. Experimental results on satellite imagery of Bangalore demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in retrieving and visualizing geographic information

title: Application of Neural Networks to Generate Production Rules for Traffic Flow Control
authors: Galina Borovkova, Svetlana Galkina, Vladimir Klyavin, Anatoly Pogodaev, Anton Sysoev
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: In the modern world, traffic flow control has become an increasingly relevant task, as the growing number of vehicles leads to increased congestion and reduced road traffic efficiency. Traditional control methods, based on fixed rules and signals, often fail to cope with the dynamics of traffic flows. In recent years, neural networks have shown significant potential in solving such problems due to their ability to process large volumes of data and identify complex patterns [1]. This study aims to develop and apply neural network models to generate production rules for traffic flow control systems, to improve the efficiency and resilience of transport systems. The proposed methodology involves using a neural network model to predict key indicators, such as capacity, while considering various factors that influence transport network elements. The model is then used to form consistent rules for the inference system by analyzing the model’s weights and applying an algorithm to evaluate factor significance.

title: Improvised SAR Time Series Algorithm for Nisar High Resolution Soil Moisture Product Over Indian Tropical Region
authors: Dharmendra Kr. Pandey, Prashant Kr. Srivastava, Rucha Dave, Praveen Kr. Gupta, Rashmi Sharma
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: This study developed a novel SAR Time Series algorithm as modified & improvised change detection model using time series of Sentinel-1 C-band SAR data to estimate field scale <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(100 ~\mathrm{m})$</tex> soil moisture for agriculture applications for the upcoming NASA-ISRO SAR (NISAR) mission. SAR Time Series (STS) based high resolution soil moisture algorithm is developed as modified change detection model using time series of Sentinel-1 C-band SAR data to estimate field scale (100 m) soil moisture for agriculture applications. This algorithm doesn't depend on any field data for any parameterization. It is extensively tested and validated over soil moisture stations for performance evaluation. It is observed that STS algorithm outperformed the traditional change detection model approach and shows significant improvement in all standard statistical performance metrics. Overall, proposed STS algorithm demonstrated the potential for soil moisture retrieval using NISAR data at 100 with required accuracy, in order to meet the agricultural application requirements.

title: LUOJIA-VG: A New Dataset for Complex Scene Understanding in Remote Sensing Visual Reasoning
authors: Ke She, Mi Zhang, Qingyu Liu, Yuanxin Zhao, Bingnan Yang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Visual grounding (VG) has become a critical task for geospatial understanding, with its core focus on accurately locating objects in remote sensing images based on referring expressions. However, existing VG datasets primarily focus on standard object recognition or semantic segmentation, often neglecting the interplay between visual content and semantic context. To address this issue, we propose a new task, Visual Reasoning for Remote Sensing Images, which requires models not only to localize objects but also to infer complex scene relationships and semantic connections. To support this task, we introduce LuoJia-VG dataset containing 40,903 image-referring expression-scene knowledge triplets. This dataset incorporates abundant scene knowledge on object relationships, functions, and potential activities, facilitating a deeper understanding of spatial and contextual dependencies in complex remote sensing images. By extending visual grounding task to visual reasoning, LuoJiaVG enables models to tackle more complex reasoning tasks, ultimately enhancing the understanding of semantic contexts in remote sensing scenes and supporting a broader range of geospatial applications. Furthermore, we conduct extensive experiments on this dataset and establish a benchmark to facilitate future research in this task.

title: Design of Digital Beam Steering Network with Early Verification for Active Phased Array Radars
authors: Taniza Roy, Abhinandan Sarkar, Shreeshail, Jayabrata Chakrabarty, M Sheik Althaf
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Computing and Communication Technologies (CONECCT)
abstract: Modern phased array radars are equipped with large number of phase shifters along with antenna elements in the front end of the system to accomplish beam steering. Beam steering directs the main lobe of a radiation pattern by adjusting the relative phases of these phase shifters of the antenna elements. The work puts forward design of a hierarchical digital beam steering network with programmable controllers at each level responsible for computation of the beam parameters such as phase and amplitude values for each radiating element of the radar for beam steering requirements in different modes of operation of radar. The design is also responsible for the beam synchronization with respect to the other subsystems of the radar and preparation of multiple control messages per burst to be sent to other subsystems for synchronised operation of the radar. In this work development and verification of the design are conducted concurrently and integrated throughout the design process enabling early verification of the design with respect to requirements. A structured design implementation is followed comprising of stages of requirements capture, conceptual design, detailed design followed by test plans with traceability matrix and rigorous testing which improves development efficiency and minimizes time spent on testing. The designed system has the capability of automatic remote update of software & firmware of the system.

title: Computing the Detent Torque of A Hybrid Stepper Motor using FEM
authors: Teodor-Ionuț Ichim, Ovidiu Craiu
publish: 2025 14th International Symposium on Advanced Topics in Electrical Engineering (ATEE)
abstract: The numerical modeling of hybrid stepper motors (HSMs) using the Finite Element Method (FEM) is challenging due to the complex magnetic field distribution and their very small air gap. Accurate computation requires three-dimensional FEM models with extremely fine meshes, resulting in a very large number of unknowns and demanding high-performance computing resources. This study investigates the detent torque computation of a two-phase hybrid stepper motor with a doublestack rotor configuration. Two different FEM formulations based on magnetic vector potential and magnetic scalar potential, and four meshes with increased density were used in the process.

title: SWOT Multitemporal River Analysis
authors: Brent Williams
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: The Surface Water and Ocean Topography (SWOT) Mission produces simultaneous estimates of river elevation, and extent for reaches and nodes defined by the SWOT River Database (SWORD). These measurements can be stacked up over time to produce valuable information of the mean river flow as well as the variation around the mean, the spatial correlation structure, and the correlations between elevation and extent for each river measured by SWOT. This paper develops the methodology and explores the nuances of estimating the elevation and width profiles, as well as the variation at each node along a river from SWOT data. Spectral estimation of the deviation from the typical flow is also considered as well as height/width correlation estimation. Estimates of dark water occurrence rates that affect the measurability of the surface water from SWOT are also considered. A Bayes approach is also developed to apply the multitemporal information as prior information to reproduce the single-pass river node estimates with lower noise, while correcting corrupted and flagged measurements.

title: On the Use of AI in Signal Processing Programming Applications at the Master of Science Level
authors: Constantin George Druga, Gabriel Sirbu, Dorel Aiordachioaie
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Electrical and Electronics Engineering (ISEEE)
abstract: The paper presents the results of an analysis related to the use of AI tools in running signal processing courses and applications, at the Master of Science level, where high-level programming languages such as MATLAB /Octave/ Python are involved. Three AI tools were selected: ChatGPT (OpenAI), Microsoft Copilot, and Google Gemini. As a case study, three signal processing applications are considered where a programming task is involved. These are related to signal generation, function computation, and signal filtering. The solutions of AI tools are presented, analyzed, and compared with an in-house one, from the accuracy, clarity, and compactness criteria. The preliminary conclusion shows that all AI tools provide good solutions related to the considered signal processing tasks. The major concern is the choice of the parameters of the simulations when the experience and knowledge of the end user are dominant. The aspects discussed in this paper indicate the paths that should be followed when programming languages are involved for engineering applications, like signal processing. The aspects considered have a major impact on the educational process, where generative AI seems to dominate and dramatically change the paradigm of education, in general.

title: Sybil Detection in V2X: From On-vehicle Features to RSU Graph Reasoning
authors: Ivan O. Ivanov, Ventsislav Nikolov
abstract: This study presents a novel multi-stage algorithm for detecting and mitigating Sybil attacks in vehicle-to-everything (V2X) communications, enhancing the security and reliability of Intelligent Transport Systems. By combining lightweight on-vehicle filtering with infrastructure-assisted temporal and graph-based analysis, the algorithm ensures adaptive risk evaluation under diverse traffic scenarios. Simulation results confirm high detection accuracy, low false positives, and scalable performance, demonstrating the algorithm’s potential for real-world deployment.

title: Delay Dynamics of BCD to 7-Segment Converters: A Comparative Study of Single vs. Dual Stage CMOS Architectures
authors: Pradyumn S Joshi, Prakhar Singh, Parikshith Shetty, Sanyukta Chandrabhan Chavan, Arjun Sunil Rao, Basavaraj S Sannakashappanavar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems and Pioneering Innovations in Robotics and Electric Mobility (INSPIRE)
abstract: This research work is on study of propagation delay of binary coded decimal (BCD) to 7-segment converter circuit. Two architectures of BCD to 7-segment circuits are designed, one is single stage, and the other is dual stage circuits. Single stage circuit is implemented using static CMOS logic while the dual stage circuit is designed using AND OR logic arrays. BCD to 7-segment converter with four BCD inputs and seven output corresponding to segments a through g are implemented in Cadence Virtuoso simulation tool using gpdk090 with both the architectures. The propagation delay of all seven segments is determined for both the architectures. The output segments a through g for a single stage BCD to 7-segment converter circuit produced a propagation delay of 91.8 ps, 1036.4 ps, 80.69 ps, 95.86 ps, 1158.5 ps, 72.5 ps, and 83.3 ps, respectively. Similarly, the output segments a through g for dual stage BCD to 7-segment converter circuit produced a propagation delay of 92.93 ps, 399.5 ps, 80.68 ps, 102.6 ps, 266.5 ps, 90.83 ps, and 101.1 ps, respectively. Depending on the type of architecture it is found that the output segments a, d, f, and g of single stage converter circuit performed faster with lesser propagation delay as compared to its dual stage version. On the other hand, the output segments b, c, and e of the dual stage have the least propagation delay compared to its corresponding single stage circuit. Our results show the application of respective architectures for high-speed applications in digital VLSI displays and other circuits.

title: A Comparative Study of Energy Loss in Glass and Polymer Insulators: Influence of Environmental Conditions and Insulator Aging
authors: Shereen Gath, Dmitry Titov
publish: 2025 14th International Symposium on Advanced Topics in Electrical Engineering (ATEE)
abstract: Leakage current (LC) along high-voltage insulator surfaces is a factor contributing to energy loss, particularly under polluted and humid environmental conditions. This study compares the two most commonly used materials in overhead transmission lines (OHTLs), glass and polymer insulators, in terms of energy losses due to LC. Sensors installed on OHTLs were used to monitor LC and weather parameters in real-time at two stations, both located near highway roads, which are exposed to similar environmental conditions. Each insulator string consisted of one insulator per string at the first station and seven insulators per string at the second station. Energy losses were evaluated across all three phases for both materials. The results demonstrate that polymer insulators exhibit significantly lower energy losses compared to glass insulators under similar environmental conditions. On average, polymer insulators reduced energy loss by approximately 81 % compared to glass insulators. Additionally, the form factor calculated was higher for polymer insulators <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(26.04)$</tex> compared to glass insulators <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(4.78)$</tex>, indicating better insulation. Furthermore, high humidity and precipitation were found to cause more pronounced increases in LC for glass insulators, likely due to their hydrophilic surface properties making polymer insulators a more efficient option for minimizing energy loss in such environments.

title: A Proposed Dual-Band Low-Noise Amplifier With Tunable Gain and SNDR Characteristics
authors: Utkarsh Singh, Sateesh Kourav, Riyaz Ahmad, Kavindra Kandpal, Prasanna Kumar Misra
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Computing and Communication Technologies (CONECCT)
abstract: In this paper, the physical design process of the dualband receiver frontend is presented, which includes the dualband low-noise amplifier (LNA), Gilbert cell mixer, and low-pass filter for joint communication purposes with Sub GHz Long Range (LoRa) and Bluetooth applications. The challenges and integration in the layout design for the blocks are addressed. The integration and isolation issues are discussed. The prelayout and post-layout simulation results are compared and presented. A method is proposed to minimize the gap between the schematic simulation results and the post-layout simulation results after integration by using 180 nm CMOS technology. After optimization, the dual-band LNA delivers a power gain of $35.2 \mathrm{~dB} / 47.2 \mathrm{~dB}$ and a noise figure of $2 \mathrm{~dB} / 1.9 \mathrm{~dB}$ while consuming a power of $37.2 \mathrm{~mW} / 37 \mathrm{~mW}$ for LoRa/BLE. The tunability property of power gain is validated for the dual-band LNA for practical use. This method can be extended for the use of all kinds of receiver architecture, like low-IF, superheterodyne, and direct conversion receivers with all practical RF frequency bands.

title: Modern Day LLMs : A GOLDMINE or a LANDMINE ?
authors: Amogh R S, A R Muthudhanush, Shwetha M D
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems and Pioneering Innovations in Robotics and Electric Mobility (INSPIRE)
abstract: This paper presents a systematic analysis of Indirect Prompt Injection (IPI) attacks on Large Language Models (LLMs), examining their dual role as enablers of advanced AI applications and as sources of significant security risk. The study addresses three core research objectives: (1) identifying adversarial techniques that enable effective IPI execution, (2) comparing vulnerabilities across leading LLM architectures, and (3) evaluating the efficacy of existing mitigation strategies. Through empirical testing of Blackbox AI 3.1.6, ChatGPT 3.5, and Gemini 2.0, we find that multi-turn escalation, privilege manipulation, and role-conditioning consistently bypass baseline safety defenses. Our results reveal critical weaknesses in refusal consistency and context-aware filtering. To address these issues, we propose a structured evaluation framework for benchmarking model resilience and outline mitigation pathways with direct deployment relevance, contributing to adversarial robustness research and safer LLM design.

title: EEMamba: A Hardware-Aware Energy-Efficient State-Space Model for Eurosat Classification
authors: Maneet Chatterjee, Anuvab Sen, Subhabrata Roy
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: The increasing dimensionality and spectral bandwidth of satellite imagery pose serious challenges to image classification based on remote sensing. Conventional techniques like transformers and convolutional neural networks (CNNs) have been used in the past for image classification, however, they frequently demand high computational costs and have trouble accurately simulating spatiotemporal dependencies. Using the EuroSAT dataset we present EEMamba a novel framework created especially for satellite image classification using State Space Models (SSMs). These problems are resolved by EEMambas integration of SSMs which enable effective latent pattern extraction in multispectral data while preserving a lightweight architecture. This method improves classification accuracy while also lessening the computational load. A significant benefit of our framework is its capacity to maximize feature extraction by utilizing multispectral bands guaranteeing robustness against noise and resolution fluctuations. To measure EEMambas computational efficiency we perform a thorough analysis of floating-point operations per second (FLOPs) and performance enhancements. Large Earth observation datasets are among the real-time geospatial analysis applications that our framework can handle. We prove how EEMamba is a shining example of how state-space dynamics can revolutionize the analysis of geospatial images thus paving the way for future research that employs state-of-the-art machine learning techniques to address the evolving challenges in remote sensing image classification.

title: An Adaptive RBF Neural Network with Structural Evolution for Predicting Supply-Demand Relationship of Human Resource
authors: Suling Jiang, Guanghui Yuan, Weijiang Chen, Gongming Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Trends in Computational Intelligence (NTCI)
abstract: Predicting the supply-demand relationship of human resource is one of the important tasks in employment and livelihood. However, the existing prediction models do not perform well due to their poor self-adaptive abilities. In this paper, we propose an adaptive RBF neural network (ARBFNN-SE) with structural evolution for predicting supply-demand relationship of human resource. First, a deformable kernel function is designed for RBFNN. Second, a diffeomorphism change is proposed to transform the deformable kernel function into a new function that involves in the gradient information. Third, a structural evolution is designed based on the transformed kernel function. Finally, we demonstrate the advantages of the proposed ARBFNN-SE by modeling and predicting the supply-demand relationship of human resource.

title: Modeling passenger boarding in a microscopic simulation model of public transport
authors: Andrea Galadíková, Peter Jankovič
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Symposium on Computational Intelligence and Informatics (CINTI)
abstract: Simulation models of public transportation systems are powerful tools for analyzing and optimizing transit networks. They help identify potential bottlenecks and evaluate alternative solutions in a cost-effective and time-efficient manner. To ensure high accuracy, these models must integrate vehicle dynamics, road network characteristics, schedules, and the complex aspects of passenger behavior. Modeling passenger behavior presents unique challenges and requires a careful balance between simulation detail and model complexity. A critical component of this process is modeling passenger boarding and alighting, which directly influences system performance. Factors such as boarding speed, collision avoidance, crowd density, and station-specific features significantly affect dwell times at stops and the overall system efficiency. These variables are essential for generating precise estimates of travel times, operational costs, and service reliability. This paper introduces a comprehensive approach to modeling passenger boarding, incorporating realistic assumptions and behavioral patterns to enhance simulation accuracy. The proposed model is validated using simulations of Žilina’s public transport system, demonstrating its capability to capture complex interactions and deliver actionable insights. The model was also compared to existing estimates of group boarding times. By integrating these detailed modeling techniques, this study supports more informed decisions in urban transportation planning and enhances passenger satisfaction.

title: Impulsive Noise Reduction using Microphone Systems with Directional Patterns and Real-Space Sound Source Estimation by Separation and Localization
authors: Chiharu Okuma, Kanta Kobayashi, Manabu Shimakawa, Takaaki Ishibashi
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Symposium on Computational Intelligence and Informatics (CINTI)
abstract: This study proposes a speech extraction method that achieves both directional control and impulsive noise reduction using a variable-directional microphone system, and confirms its effectiveness through kurtosis-based processing. Furthermore, the performance of direction estimation combining sound source separation methods (ILRMA and ILRMA+Dereverb) with a localization method (MUSIC) was evaluated in a virtual environment. Experimental results showed that ILRMA performs well in anechoic conditions, while ILRMA+Dereverb maintains stable performance in reverberant environments. The MUSIC demonstrated high accuracy in anechoic conditions but was susceptible to degradation under reverberant conditions, particularly when used in conjunction with ILRMA+Dereverb. Future challenges include the development of new methods that integrate separation and localization, and the improvement of practicality through evaluation in real-space environments.

title: Challenges in the Design of Compact Control Cable Harnesses Optimized for Performance for Long Range Radars Operating In Naval Environment
authors: Abhinandan Sarkar, Shiva S Rai, Rakesh Kumar Verma, Jayabrata Chakrabarty, Shashi Kant, M Sheik Althaf
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Computing and Communication Technologies (CONECCT)
abstract: Long Range and Very Long Range Radars with large Aperture Antennas require thousands of Transmit Receive (T/R Modules) to detect and track targets at long ranges. These T/R modules are commanded through multiple LRUs arranged in multiple levels of hierarchy. The interconnection between these LRUs across all the levels of hierarchy starting from source till destination is quite complex because of the sheer high numbers and many other factors like closed the operating environment, narrow space available for routing, small volume for installation etc. Thus designing, routing and managing thousands of such cables becomes quite a daunting task. This paper presents the challenges in the designing of the control cables optimized for minimum cable diameter and bending radius through iterative designs thereby enabling efficient routing of the cables through narrow ducts. At the same time, it is ensured that stringent performance criterion is met from each of these control cable. Because the operating environment is closed, it is also mandated to comply to Low Smoke Zero Halogen emissions from each cable in case of fire, which in turn is a contradictory requirement for achieving minimum cable diameter. This paper presents the various optimization techniques and best practices involved in the design and realization of different types of control cables. The cables are successfully realized, tested, performance evaluated and finally deployed in the array.

title: Generalized Cheeger Cut Clustering Model Using P-Laplace with Its Two Solutions
authors: Bowen Liu, Zhongtao Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Trends in Computational Intelligence (NTCI)
abstract: Cheeger cut model is an important clustering model using variational method and graph theory, and it has a good performance for clustering problem, but solving Cheeger cut model is an NP hard problem. Based on Cheeger cut model, a P-Laplace Cheeger cut model was proposed. Cheeger cut model is a special case of P-Laplace Cheeger cut. P-Laplace Cheeger cut model is still an NP hard problem, and we propose a Split Bregman algorithm and an ADMM algorithm to solve this problem. The Split Bregman algorithm and ADMM algorithm convert the optimization problem with constraints into the optimization problem without constraints by introducing auxiliary variables. Multiplier parameters of the constraints are optimized by using an iterative method. In order to avoid the influence of the indifferentiable problem, soft threshold formula is used to compute the formula containing L1 norm. Experiments show that the Split Bregman algorithm and ADMM algorithm can solve the $\mathbf{P}$-Laplace Cheeger cut model, and the proposed P-Laplace Cheeger cut model can correctly cluster the datasets containing non-spherical clusters. Meanwhile, it has better results than the most important graph clustering algorithm on the real data sets.

title: Structurization of Unstructured Data by using Triplet Extraction and Text Refinement
authors: Nagesh H R, Ravinarayanan B, Prakhyath Rai
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems and Pioneering Innovations in Robotics and Electric Mobility (INSPIRE)
abstract: In today’s data-driven world, structuring unstructured data is crucial for efficient analysis and meaningful insights. This paper focuses on transforming unstructured text documents into a structured format using advanced natural language processing techniques. We address challenges such as noise reduction, synonym replacement, and semantic mapping through triplet extraction. By leveraging tools like spaCy and Coreferee, we refine sentences by resolving coreferences, lemmatizing tokens, and identifying subject-verb-object relationships. The structured data is integrated into a graph database for enhanced querying and visualization. Our approach aims to streamline information retrieval and analysis, demonstrating significant improvements in data accessibility and usability. This paper focuses on converting raw text data into structured formats, thereby enabling better data accessibility, efficient querying, and insightful visualization.

title: TemporalFormer: Enhanced EfficientFormer for Real-Time Deepfake Detection on Edge Devices
authors: Aarif Zafar, Kartik Singh, Udit Manav, Rajesh Kumar Panda, Nikhil Sahni, Renju Chirakarotu Nair
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Computing and Communication Technologies (CONECCT)
abstract: The rapid proliferation of deepfake videos, forged multimedia, tampered contents across social media and other communication platforms poses significant challenges to digital security and information authenticity, necessitating effective detection mechanisms, particularly on mobile platforms. Deepfake videos increasingly undermine digital trust, but most detection methods depend on resource-heavy cloud systems, unsuitable for real-time use on edge devices. We present TemporalFormer, an enhanced EfficientFormerV2 model, optimized for fast and accurate deepfake detection directly on mobile and edge platforms. TemporalFormer analyzes video streams by extracting 30 equidistant frames from a 6 -second window by capturing a frame from live screen at 200 ms intervals and processing a batch of 30 frames in single prediction. This enables real-time processing of dynamic content like video calls, social media feeds, and video conferences. This lightweight framework integrates EfficientFormerV2’s feature extraction with positional encoding and a 1D CNN layer to model temporal dependencies, achieving an inference time of 20 ms per batch. Trained and tested on Celeb-df(v2), TemporalFormer attains an accuracy of $93.2 \%$ and an AUC of 0.90, while demonstrating robust generalization with an AUC of 0.87 on the FaceForensics++ dataset during crosscorpora analysis, surpassing baselines such as Xception and EfficientNet-B0 in both performance and efficiency. By offering a scalable, offline solution, TemporalFormer enables robust, ondevice video forensics for resource-constrained environments.

title: STG-foF2: Spatio-Temporal Graph Networks for foF2 Prediction in High-Frequency Communication
authors: Dandan Che, Ying Li, Yi Gong
publish: 2025 IEEE International Performance, Computing, and Communications Conference (IPCCC)
abstract: High-frequency (HF) communication is known as a pivotal task in military operations, disaster relief efforts and global broadcasting by virtue of its unique advantages of long-distance reach, non-relay capabilities and flexible deployment. Accurate forecasting of foF2 values is critical for optimizing HF communication technologies. However, the complex, nonlinear and dynamic nature of ionospheric variations caused by solar activity and atmospheric conditions makes it a huge challenge. International reference ionosphere relies on semi-empirical formulas with substantial prediction errors, while some data-driven variants focus mainly on time series predictions derived from individual stations, thus ignoring the inter-station correlations that are closely related to the model accuracy and effectiveness. In this paper, we propose a novel deep learning approach based on spatio-temporal graph convolutional networks (STG-foF2) to address the above issues of ionospheric forecasting in the context of HF communication, which leverages a cascade structure of graph convolutional layers and long short-term memory layers to extract the intricate patterns and connections across diverse geographical locations and temporal intervals. Extensive experiments on Global ionospheric radio observatory datasets verify the superior performance in terms of accuracy and time complexity of the proposed STG-foF2 over the existing benchmarks under different geomagnetic activity states.

title: Energy-Aware A* Path Planning for Indoor Automated Guided Vehicles
authors: Bogdan-Adrian Enache, Sorin-Dan Grigorescu, Felix Constantin Adochiei, Florin Ciprian Argatu, George Calin Seritan, Cosmin Karl Banica
publish: 2025 14th International Symposium on Advanced Topics in Electrical Engineering (ATEE)
abstract: This paper presents an energy-aware path planner for indoor autonomous guided vehicles, that maintains A*'s transparency while substituting geometric edge costs with laboratory-calibrated energy terms for rolling resistance, turn severity, near-wall operation and stop-go events. Implemented in RVC3-Python and evaluated across four scenarios of increasing complexity, the proposed algorithm delivers smoother, clearancepreserving routes and reduces total energy with only marginal path-length changes. The approach stands as a deployable, physically grounded solution for battery-constrained indoor robots.

title: Physics-Informed LS-SVM: A Hybrid Approach for AI-Driven Financial Modelling
authors: Bhubaneswari Mishra, Snehashish Chakraverty
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Computing and Communication Technologies (CONECCT)
abstract: Integrating domain knowledge into machine learning models enhances both predictive accuracy and theoretical consistency, particularly for problems governed by differential equations. While traditional machine learning (ML) techniques provide flexible data-driven approximations, they often disregard underlying physical constraints, leading to reduced generalizability. Embedding governing equations within learning frameworks has shown promise in scientific computing but remains underexplored in financial modelling. This work formulates a Physics-Informed Least Squares Support Vector Machine (PI-LS-SVM), incorporating differential equation constraints within the Least Square Support Vector Machine (LS-SVM) framework to improve function approximation under physical constraints. To validate its effectiveness, PI-LS-SVM is applied to solving the Black-Scholes partial differential equation (BS PDE), a fundamental model in option pricing. The method is trained using real-world data and benchmarked against standard SVM and LS-SVM models. Empirical results demonstrate that PI-LS-SVM achieves higher accuracy, reduced pricing errors, and improved robustness against market fluctuations, outperforming conventional machine learning approaches. The integration of physicsbased constraints enhances model stability and interpretability, reinforcing the broader applicability of physics-informed learning in constrained optimization problems. By bridging computational intelligence with structured modelling, this study highlights PI-LS-SVM as a generalizable framework for solving physicsinformed machine learning problems, with applications extending beyond finance into AI-driven modelling and engineering systems.

title: The Prospects of the Political and Financial System Caused by Innovations in Technology
authors: Radoslav Kardzhiev
abstract: The article summarizes trends and cases from the last five years pertaining to the adoption of block chain technology in public government, the financial industry, and associated infrastructures (voting, energy, supply chains, and identities). Examples of economic sectors where the application of block chain technology has been successful are presented. It makes a distinction between centrally issued digital currencies and decentralized crypto-assets, examines the sustainability and energy efficiency of public block chain, and considers the suitability of immutable registries for official data and election procedures. It provides guidelines for creating a financial-monetary equivalent that would associate physical assets and energy with a distributed ledger value unit. The conclusion is that while block chain is still being institutionalized in certain sectors (traceability, settlement), its usage in politics (voting, identification) remains pilot-stage and context-dependent.

title: Analysis and Redesign Using the User-Centered Design Method and Usability Scale to Optimize the Use of the Whoosh Application
authors: Heri Purwanto, Rudy Sofian, Fahmi Reza Ferdiansyah, Mochamad Alif Fauzan, Khaerul Manaf, Edi Andriansyah
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Telecommunication Systems, Services, and Applications (TSSA)
abstract: Transportation plays a crucial role in supporting economic growth and the development of a country. An initial assessment of the Whoosh application using the System Usability Scale (SUS) method with 102 respondents yielded a score of 34, which falls into Grade D with a "Poor" category, an acceptance level of "Not Acceptable", and a Net Promoter Score (NPS) classification of "Detractor". The redesign process of the application adopted the User Centered Design (UCD) principles, involving continuous iteration and evaluation to ensure the final product meets user needs. SUS is an essential tool for measuring product usability, allowing for the identification of improvement areas. After the redesign, the questionnaire results showed a SUS score increase to 81, which falls into Grade B, with a "Good" category, an acceptance level of "Acceptable", and the NPS classification improved to "Promoter".The UI/UX improvements in the Whoosh application demonstrate the effectiveness of a user-centered design approach, resulting in better usability and user acceptance, and making a positive to the development of a more satisfying user experience. title: Analysis of Modern Technologies and Approaches for Automatic Processing Cardiological Data
authors: Omar Yahya, Vladimir Vitalievich Alekseev
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: This paper presents a comprehensive analysis of current technologies and methodologies for processing electrocardiographic data, particularly for automatic analysis in cardiovascular disease diagnosis. It focuses on addressing uncertainties inherent in clinical cardiac monitoring by systematically reviewing modern signal processing techniques, neural network architectures, and diagnostic support systems, and evaluating their effectiveness in arrhythmia detection and classification. Through a comparative analysis of traditional machine learning approaches versus deep learning architectures, the research identifies critical limitations in existing systems, including architectural complexity, interpretability constraints, and uncertainty management. Our analysis reveals that while current deep learning models achieve classification accuracies ranging from 83-98%, they often sacrifice computational efficiency and clinical interpretability. We propose a framework for evaluating ECG processing systems that balances accuracy, computational complexity, and clinical applicability. The findings show that one-dimensional convolutional neural networks offer the best trade-offs between performance (91-93% accuracy) and practical deployment constraints, particularly in rural areas where access to healthcare and the availability of expert cardiologists are limited. This comprehensive review offers essential insights into developing next-generation cardiac diagnostic systems that effectively manage uncertainty while supporting clinical relevance.

title: A Study on Chromaticity Modulation Combining Discrete Cosine Transform in Digital Signage and Image Sensor-based Visible Light Communication
authors: Katsumasa Noritake, Kentaro Kobayashi
abstract: Digital signage is expected to provide not only visual information, but also data information by visible light communication through an image sensor of mobile devices. Images on which data signals are superimposed are displayed on the digital signage and captured by the image sensor for communication. In order to avoid degrading visual quality, it is necessary to enable communication even with weak signal intensity. In this study, in addition to using chromaticity components that are difficult for humans to recognize the superimposed data signal, we aim to improve the communication quality by using discrete cosine transformation (DCT) to superimpose the data signal in the low-frequency region, which is less susceptible to signal loss even when captured from a long distance.

title: A Muliti-Objective Coal Blending Optimizaiton Method Based on Coke Quality Prediction
authors: Sisi Li, Jing An, Liang Zhao, Qi Kang
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Trends in Computational Intelligence (NTCI)
abstract: Coal blending optimization is critical in intelligent coke production, but independent prediction and optimization models limit simultaneous cost and quality improvement. This study proposes an integrated approach combining coke quality prediction and multi-objective optimization. A Dual-Branch Feature Fusion Network (DBFFNet) is developed to enhance prediction accuracy of multiple coke quality indicators by fusing industrial coal properties and maceral petrographic characteristics. The prediction model is embedded into an improved Nondominated Sorting Genetic Algorithm II (NSGA-II) optimization framework, which incorporates an adaptive constraint relaxation factor, an infeasible solution ranking strategy based on a weighted objective function, and optimized genetic operators to enhance convergence and solution diversity. Experimental results show that DBFFNet outperforms comparison models in prediction accuracy, and the improved NSGA-II generates uniformly distributed, well-converged Pareto fronts, demonstrating the method’s practical value.

title: Verifiable Credential-Based Access Control for Interoperable Crowdsourced Drone Services
authors: Junaid Akram, Awais Akram, Ali Anaissi, Rutvij H. Jhaveri, Ali Kashif Bashir, Maryam M. Al Dabel
abstract: The rapid evolution of consumer electronics, especially through immersive embedded cyber-physical systems, has intensified the complexity of access control in decentralized environments such as the Internet of Drone Things (IoDT). In critical applications like crowdsourced drone services for bushfire management, ensuring secure, privacy-preserving, and interoperable data sharing among multiple stakeholders remains a major challenge. Existing blockchain-based or traditional access control methods often impose significant communication overhead, scalability bottlenecks, and privacy risks due to centralized or publicly auditable structures. This paper introduces a novel access management architecture that leverages Verifiable Credentials (VCs), which, unlike blockchain approaches, enable decentralized, fine-grained, and revocable authorizations without exposing sensitive information or incurring heavy computational costs. By integrating a cloud-based VC wallet, our system abstracts credential handling away from client applications, thereby enhancing interoperability and enabling seamless, standards-compliant collaboration among diverse drone operators and bushfire management authorities. The result is a framework that not only ensures robust data integrity and privacy but also delivers agile, efficient management of access rights, directly addressing the unique security and usability demands of immersive IoDT environments.

title: Investigating Mortality: From Basic Science to Information Technology Tools and Applications : Plenary Talk
authors: Tamás Ferenci
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Symposium on Computational Intelligence and Informatics (CINTI)
abstract: Investigating the temporal and spatial patterns of the indicators of mortality is a crucial area in epidemiology. One particular concept, excess mortality gained widespread attention and was often both used and misused in scientific discussions and public debates during the coronavirus pandemic. In this talk, I will present work conducted in Hungary under my supervision to estimate excess mortality during the pandemic and I will explore the related challenges. I will outline the foundational research aimed at identifying the optimal theoretical methods, and I will demonstrate their practical applications. In particular, I will introduce the pipeline developed for the comprehensive calculation and reporting of excess mortality, as well as its long-term use in ongoing mortality monitoring.

title: Large-Language-Model-Aided Assistive Robot for Single-Operator Bimanual Teleoperation: Introduction and Validation of a Flexible Assistance System
authors: Haolin Fei, Songlin Ma, Guanglong Du, Elmira Yadollahi, Hak-Keung Lam, Angela Faragasso, Allahyar Montazeri, Ziwei Wang
abstract: Bimanual teleoperation tasks are highly demanding for human operators, requiring the simultaneous control of two robotic arms while managing complex coordination and cognitive load. Current approaches to this challenge often rely on rigid control schemes or task-specific automations that do not adapt well to dynamic environments or varied operator needs. This article presents a novel large language model (LLM)-aided bimanual teleoperation assistant (BTLA) that helps operators control dual-arm robots through an intuitive voice command interface and variable autonomy. The BTLA system enables a hybrid control paradigm by combining natural language interaction for an assistive robot arm with direct teleoperation of the dominant robotic arm. Our system implements six core manipulation skills with varying autonomy, ranging from direct mirroring to autonomous object manipulation. The BTLA leverages the LLM to interpret natural language commands and select an appropriate assistance mode based on task requirements and operator preferences. Experimental validation on bimanual object manipulation tasks demonstrates that the BTLA system yields a 240.8% increase in success rate over solo teleoperation and a 69.9% increase over dyadic teleoperation, while significantly reducing operator mental workload. In addition, we validate our approach on a physical dual-arm UR3e robot system, achieving a 90% success rate on challenging soft bottle handling and box transportation tasks.

title: AFGLFF-YOLO: Adaptive Frequency Global-Local Feature Fusion Model on YOLO for Remote Sensing Object Detection
authors: Junpeng Wu, Xinguang Tao, Pan Gao
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Remote sensing images pose significant challenges for object detection due to their high resolution, complex backgrounds, large scale variations, and dense distribution of small targets. To address these issues, we propose an improved remote sensing object detection model based on YOLOv8, named Adaptive Frequency Global-Local Feature Fusion Model on YOLO (AFGLFF-YOLO). This model is optimized in two aspects: frequency domain feature preservation and cross-scale information construction. Firstly, an Adaptive Frequency Wavelet Downsample (AFWD) module is designed to effectively retain structural high-frequency details during the downsample phase. Secondly, in the feature extraction phase, a dual-channel structure combining frequency-response Wavelet-Guided Vision GNN-CNN (WGVGC) is introduced. Its fundamental module is the Vision GNN-CNN (VGC), where graph convolution and depthwise separable convolution collaboratively enhance the complementarity of global and local features. Furthermore, to mitigate the interference between high- and low-frequency features within the same feature space, a frequency guidance mechanism derived from wavelet decomposition is introduced. This mechanism employs the Daubechies4 (DB4) wavelet and Haar wavelet for feature frequency differentiation. Subsequently, the Global Low-Frequency Enhancement Fusion Module (GLFM) and Edge-Aware High-Frequency Enhancement Fusion Module (EHFM) are designed to achieve complementary enhancement of cross-frequency domain features through adaptive frequency fusion. Finally, experimental results on four public remote sensing object detection datasets, NWPU VHR-10, RSOD, DIOR and RS-STOD, demonstrate that AFGLFF-YOLO achieves mAP@50 of 95.6%, 97.6%, 79.6% and 83.1%, respectively, marking a significant improvement over the original YOLOv8 model. These experimental results validate the detection accuracy, feature representation capability, and robustness of the proposed method in complex remote sensing scenarios, highlighting the effectiveness of global-local fusion and frequency domain feature enhancement.
