title: A Fuzzy RL-Based Energy Management Strategy for Battery/Supercapacitor Hybrid Energy Storage System with Road Condition Recognition
authors: Rui Pan, Junjie Li, Duo Yang, Yu Yan
abstract: Energy management strategy (EMS) has a significant impact on the lithium-ion battery/supercapacitor combined hybrid energy storage systems (HESS) of electric vehicles. However, existing strategies often suffer from inefficient energy allocation and poor dynamic response. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a fuzzy reinforcement learning (RL)-based EMS to optimize the efficiency of HESS. Firstly, key road features are extracted from vehicle operation data using a sliding window, and then principal component analysis and an optimized K-nearest neighbors’ algorithm are used for feature dimensionality reduction and clustering, which can enable more precise feature classification under various road conditions. Secondly, a dueling double deep fuzzy Q-network (D3FQN) framework is proposed for real-time power allocation optimization. By combining the uncertainty handling capability of the fuzzy inference system with the efficient learning ability of the dueling architecture, the real-time adaptively decision-making ability of HESS can be enhanced under complex road conditions. Additionally, an adaptive reward function is designed to dynamically adjust the allocation strategy according to real-time road conditions, power demand, and battery status. Finally, the physical and comparative experiments are conducted, and the results validated the strong dynamic adaptability and efficient energy allocation of the proposed strategy across various road conditions.

title: Supervisory multi switching data driven control theory and application
authors: Hong Wangjian, Cao Lei
abstract: Due to the varying circumstances, thus resulting in frequently changed system plant, the controller must also varies with time increases. This paper proposes supervisory multi switching data driven control strategy from both theoretical analysis and practical application. Specifically, multi switching control strategy and data driven control are combined together to achieve the dual goals, i.e. multi models selection and multi controllers selection, while determining the appropriate model and active controller through two optimization criterions. Firstly, the detailed academic theories center around data driven identification, multidimensional Taylor network structure, data driven switching controller for model tracking or mismatch and guaranteed optimal analysis, corresponding to switching models selection, switching controllers selection and optimal switching logic respectively. Secondly, the theoretical results are supported by automatic takeoff and landing of unmanned helicopter, as the entire automatic takeoff and landing are separated into five continuous subprocess. To better understanding the control principle for automatic takeoff and landing process, three different subjects are analyzed in constraint analysis, automatic takeoff control and landing control, leading to devise each controller for each subprocess by supervisory multi switching control, and constructing one supervisor mechanism to achieve the switching logic. Finally, one practical platform is shown to prove our theoretical analysis. Generally, roughly speaking, our paper introduces data driven idea into switching control to form an innovative multi switching data driven control, i.e, switching model identification and switching tracking control, while covering identification, control, optimization and application etc.

title: Bridging the Semantic Gap in Computational Color Design: A Neurocognitively Validated Framework_supp3-3648792.docx
authors: Lin Li
abstract: Against the backdrop of the AIGC wave reshaping the creative design landscape, color design is rapidly transitioning from intuition-driven to data-intelligence. However, a critical "semantic gap" persists between abstract human intentions and controllable parameters of generative tools. To address this challenge, this study proposes and neurocognitively validates a computational framework for semantic color design, grounded in the Chinese linguistic context. The framework integrates two core modules: 1) Semantic Deconstruction, which constructs a multidimensional color-semantic lexicon from Chinese multisource texts using natural language processing and 2) Parametric Mapping, which establishes a controllable model to map structured semantics to quantitative color parameters in the perceptually uniform CIELAB space. Critically, we employed event-related potentials to validate the framework’s semantic accuracy in this cultural context. Neuroscientific evidence has confirmed that colors generated by our framework elicit cognitive responses consistent with target semantics; the N400 effect was statistically equivalent to that of a highly congruent baseline (equivalence test, p < 0.01). The study further revealed a hierarchical contribution of color attributes to semantic conveyance: hue played a decisive role, followed by brightness, whereas the influence of saturation was limited. The proposed framework not only offers a scientific paradigm for bridging the semantic gap in color design but also provides a computational blueprint for next-generation AIGC tools, enabling them to move beyond randomness toward precise, controllable, and semantically meaningful color generation.

title: The Artificial Intelligence Cognitive Examination: A Survey on the Evolution of Multimodal Evaluation from Recognition to Reasoning
authors: Mayank Ravishankara, Varindra V. Persad Maharaj
abstract: This survey paper chronicles the evolution of evaluation in multimodal artificial intelligence (AI), framing it as a progression of increasingly sophisticated "cognitive examinations." We argue that the field is undergoing a paradigm shift, moving from simple recognition tasks that test "what" a model sees, to complex reasoning benchmarks that probe "why" and "how" it understands. This evolution is driven by the saturation of older benchmarks, where high performance often masks fundamental weaknesses. We chart the journey from the foundational "knowledge tests" of the ImageNet era to the "applied logic and comprehension" exams such as GQA and Visual Commonsense Reasoning (VCR), which were designed specifically to diagnose systemic flaws such as shortcut learning and failures in compositional generalization. We then survey the current frontier of "expert-level integration" benchmarks (e.g., MMBench, SEED-Bench, MMMU) designed for today’s powerful multimodal large language models (MLLMs). Next, we explore the uncharted territories of evaluating abstract, creative, and social intelligence. We also discuss the emerging "Post-2025" landscape, where rapid saturation of reasoning benchmarks by models like Gemini 3 Pro necessitates a shift toward "living" adversarial evaluations. We conclude that the narrative of AI evaluation is not merely a history of datasets, but a continuous, adversarial process of designing better examinations that, in turn, redefine our goals for creating truly intelligent systems.

title: Multi-Source Remote Sensing Data Fusion for Aboveground Biomass Estimation in Tropical Forests: Recent Advances, Challenges, and Future Trends
authors: Qiaona Meng, Yu-Beng Leau, Jinmei Shi, Jinghe Zhou
abstract: Accurate estimation of aboveground biomass (AGB) in tropical forests is critical for global carbon cycle research and climate policies such as REDD+, but single remote sensing sources face limitations: optical sensors suffer from saturation and cloud interference, SAR has saturation and terrain-induced distortions, and lidar (e.g., GEDI) provides high-precision vertical structures but sparse coverage. Multi-source data fusion - including data-level, feature-level, decision-level fusion, and spatio-temporal scaling - leverages the complementary strengths of optical, SAR, and LiDAR data to mitigate these issues, machine learning (e.g., RF, XGBoost) and deep learning (e.g., CNN, Transformer) to improve performance, and hybrid models to balance learning ability and robustness. Key challenges including data heterogeneity, geometric/radiometric inconsistencies, saturation in dense forests, cloud-induced optical data loss, and sparse GEDI footprints are addressed through validation frameworks (involving forest maps, NFI, airborne LiDAR) and uncertainty quantification methods (e.g., spatial cross-validation, Monte Carlo simulations). Regional case studies (Amazon, Congo Basin, Southeast Asia) show optimal strategies for specific environments, while future directions focus on collaborative GEDI with P-band SAR, dynamic monitoring through temporal fusion, physical based deep learning, federated/transfer learning, interpretable AI, and standardized REDD+ protocols. Based on a systematic review of AGB estimation studies in tropical forests in the past five years, this paper summarizes the development progress of multi-source remote sensing data fusion and advanced algorithms, identifies the existing technical bottlenecks, and proposes a future-oriented comprehensive optimization framework to improve the accuracy and robustness of AGB estimation.

title: Integrated Constrained Manifold Optimization for Wideband OFDM-DFRC Hybrid Beamforming
authors: Dongxu An, Jinfeng Hu, Yiran Zhang, Kai Zhong, Xin Tai, Yongfeng Zuo, Huiyong Li, Fulvio Gini, Maria Sabrina Greco
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: Hybrid beamforming (HBF) offers a cost effective solution for multiple-input multiple-output dual-functional radar-communication (MIMO-DFRC) systems by reducing hardware complexity and power consumption. While narrowband HBF has been widely studied, wideband HBF design, particularly for transceiver-side hybrid architectures, remains rather underexplored. Existing HBF methods for wideband MIMO-DFRC systems typically adopt a sequential optimization (SO) framework based on the consensus alternating direction method of multipliers (CADMM), assuming a fully digital receiver architecture during the initial optimization stage. This assumption restricts the design flexibility and limits the achievable spectral efficiency (SE) on the communication side. To this end, an integrated constrained manifold optimization (ICMO) framework is proposed. The ICMO method embeds the transmit and receive HBF matrices, subject to constant modulus (CM) and transmit power per subcarrier, into an integrated variable and projects them onto an ICM-space for joint optimization. This transforms the original constrained problem into an unconstrained manifold optimization problem. Subsequently, a parallel simplified quasi-Newton (PSQN) method is developed to optimize the integrated variable within the ICMO framework, ultimately yielding the transmit and receive HBF coding matrices. Simulation results under a Pareto behavior analysis show that the proposed method dominates the CADMM baseline across the SSME and SE frontier, achieving up to <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$40\%$</tex-math></inline-formula> higher SE at comparable SSME and about 4.4 dB lower sidelobe levels, thereby enabling spectrum efficient and low sidelobe DFRC design.

title: Position-aware Differential Denoising Transformer for Semantic Segmentation of Remote Sensing Images
authors: Xin Li, Chengyi Shi, Nan Xu, Yuanchao Su, André Kaup, Daofang Liu, Xing Li
publish: IEEE Geoscience and Remote Sensing Letters
abstract: Semantic segmentation of high-resolution remote sensing images (HRRSIs) is essential for various geospatial applications. While recent transformer-based models demonstrate promising global modeling capabilities, they are susceptible to attention noise—particularly in cluttered or noisy scenes—leading to degraded segmentation quality. This challenge is amplified in HRRSIs, where spatially heterogeneous noise and ambiguous object boundaries are prevalent. To address this problem, we propose PDDFormer, a Position-aware Differential Denoising Transformer tailored for semantic segmentation of HRRSIs. Central to our design is the Spatially Gated Differential Attention (SGDA), which adaptively modulates denoising strength across spatial positions using a learnable gate. Unlike prior differential attention models, SGDA introduces position-aware denoising that dynamically adjusts attention suppression at each token, guided by spatial semantics. This allows PDDFormer to suppress redundant background responses while preserving critical structural semantics. Extensive experiments on two public benchmarks, ISPRS Potsdam and LoveDA, demonstrate that PDDFormer consistently outperforms state-of-the-art methods in both accuracy and boundary preservation. Moreover, PDDFormer achieves favorable performance-efficiency trade-offs, making it practical for large-scale geospatial analysis. Visualizations further confirm the model’s ability to generate cleaner, more coherent segmentation maps, validating the effectiveness of our spatially adaptive denoising strategy.

title: Analyzing Spatio-Temporal Alterations in the Coastal Areas of Funafuti, Tuvalu
authors: Sree Juwel Kumar Chowdhury, Chan-Su Yang, Sachindra Singh
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Island nations are particularly vulnerable to dynamic coastal changes influenced by both natural and human factors and, specifically, coastline; the intersection between land and water, and its changes over a time period reflect the evolutionary information about the resources and ecosystem of the coastal region [1]. To acquire essential information on the intensity of changes, extracting coastline, particularly for the island countries, is crucial. Remotely sensed satellite imagery is considered an important data source for continuously monitoring the coastal area and its alterations. It has opened an effective way to conduct research work as it provides frequent data with a large coverage [2]. Consequently, the detection and extraction processes of coastlines from different medium and high-resolution satellite images have been developed [3]. Therefore, automatic extraction techniques, including edge detection, band thresholding [4], and classification approach [5], have been applied in satellite images to acquire coastline information within a short period of time. However, to extract the coastline of a small atoll island, using a specific coastline extraction method becomes challenging due to the complex and distinct coastal features. Therefore, an automatic method combining segmentation and thresholding is proposed to normalized difference vegetation index (NDVI) images to delineate the coastline from the satellite image. Funafuti Atoll, an archipelago of small, scattered islets with unique features, was selected as the study region for extracting the coastline and analyzing the recent coastal alterations. Sentinel-2 satellite imagery, digital elevation model (DEM) data, and sea level information were utilized to extract coastline and analyze coastal alterations. At first, resampling was performed to convert the required bands into the same resolution (10 m). Then, NDVI was calculated in the resampled images because it enhances the contrast between the land and water, which is regarded as a crucial part of the coastline extraction process. Afterwards, superpixel segmentation method was applied to segment the image into smaller area, and then, segmented areas of target islet regions were linked to NDVI values. To account for the unique features of each islet, adaptive thresholding was utilized to differentiate between land and water accurately, enabling the extraction of coastlines from 2019 to 2023. Subsequently, sea level data corresponding to the image acquisition periods was incorporated to adjust the DEM for each year. This adjustment involves adding or subtracting sea level values to reflect temporal variations accurately. The adjusted DEMs and extracted coastlines were then overlaid to identify spatial shifts, highlighting areas of erosion or accretion. To quantify these changes, the land area lost or gained was analyzed, and the elevation differences between adjusted DEMs were used to estimate the volume of material displaced. The estimated volume was calculated by multiplying elevation changes by pixel area, providing insights into the scale of erosion or accretion over time. The study depicts that the length of the coastline decreased by approximately 0.27 %, and the vegetation area decreased by approximately 3.52 %. Most of the alterations happened in the eastern part of Funafuti, which were caused by human intervention and tropical cyclones.

title: Digital Modernization of a Wire Straightening and Cutting Machine in Compliance with Industry 4.0 Principles
authors: Ivan Kirilov Stoyanov, Docho Tsankov Tsankov
abstract: This paper presents the Industry 4.0 digital retrofit of a WMW UDARA 6.3 wire straightening and cutting machine, originally manufactured in 1968. The retrofit introduces a modern control system comprising a PLC, frequency converter, servo drive, and HMI visualization, while preserving the mechanical structure. The methodology includes process analysis, identification of critical parameters, and calibration of control logic. Results demonstrate significant improvements in productivity, reliability, maintenance time, and integration with digital production environments. The study fills a research gap in the retrofitting of specialized wire processing machines and highlights the practical application of low-invasive digital modernization for legacy equipment

title: DichroGAN: Towards Restoration of in-Air Colours of Seafloor from Satellite Imagery
authors: Salma González-Sabbagh, Antonio Robles-Kelly, Shang Gao
publish: 2025 International Conference on Digital Image Computing: Techniques and Applications (DICTA)
abstract: Recovering the in-air colours of seafloor from satellite imagery is a challenging task due to the exponential attenuation of light with depth in the water column. In this study, we present DichroGAN, a conditional generative adversarial network (cGAN) designed for this purpose. DichroGAN employs a two-steps simultaneous training: first, two generators utilise a hyperspectral image cube to estimate diffuse and specular reflections, thereby obtaining atmospheric scene radiance. Next, a third generator receives as input the generated scene radiance containing the features of each spectral band, while a fourth generator estimates the underwater light transmission. These generators work together to remove the effects of light absorption and scattering, restoring the in-air colours of seafloor based on the underwater image formation equation. DichroGAN is trained on a compact dataset derived from PRISMA satellite imagery, comprising RGB images paired with their corresponding spectral bands and masks. Extensive experiments on both satellite and underwater datasets demonstrate that DichroGAN achieves competitive performance compared to state-of-the-art underwater restoration techniques.

title: Speeding up KNN-WH for Origin–Destination Travel Time Estimation
authors: Sofía Alvarez, Sebastián Moreno, Alfonso Tobar-Arancibia, Wilfredo Yushimito
publish: 2025 15th IEEE International Conference on Pattern Recognition Systems (ICPRS)
abstract: Origin-destination (O-D) travel time estimation is among the most important problems studied in transportation. It focuses on determining accurate travel time from a specific origin point to a destination point. Given the development of new technologies such as GPS and mobile applications, this data can be easily gathered, improving the estimation of the O-D travel time and enabling prediction in almost real-time. Currently, one of the simplest and newest algorithms is the $KNN - \bar WH$ model, an improvement of the K-Nearest Neighbors method with Haversine distance and a correction factor. Unfortunately, the direct application of this method can take over 50 minutes to predict a new set of 70,000 data points. This paper proposes $k - KNN - \bar WH$, a new two-step framework that clusters the data using k-means and then applies $KNN - \bar WH$ on the corresponding cluster. The empirical results show a minimal impact on the MAPE performance (1.5%) while reducing the time estimation process from approximately 50 to 20 minutes.

title: Unsupervised Indoor Relative Positioning and Group Proximity Prediction Based on CIR Graph Convolutional Network and MDS Embedding
authors: Kaiqing Zhang, Xuemin Hong, Ao Peng
publish: 2025 IEEE International Performance, Computing, and Communications Conference (IPCCC)
abstract: Accurate modeling of proximity relationships between individuals and groups in urban spaces is critical for public safety alerts, emergency evacuation planning, commercial flow analysis, and urban planning optimization. Existing indoor localization techniques-including TOA/TDOA/AoA geometry-based methods, visual SLAM, inertial navigation (PDR), and RSSI/UWB fingerprinting-achieve high accuracy in static environments but rely heavily on large-scale manual labeling, strict clock synchronization, or dense anchor deployment, and struggle to accommodate both trajectory continuity and dynamic environmental changes. To address these limitations, we propose a dual-modal deep learning framework based on Graph Convolutional Networks and Multidimensional Scaling embedding. First, channel feature similarities are computed from CIR sequences sampled continuously by mobile terminals, and an attentionenhanced proximity graph is constructed. Then, the graph adjacency matrix is fed into the MDS algorithm to recover the relative low-dimensional layout of observation points, enabling robust reconstruction of crowd density and flow topology. To mitigate class imbalance and manage positive and negative pair ratios both within and across trajectories, we introduce a spatiotemporal pair generation strategy and employ a weighted binary crossentropy loss during training. Simulation results demonstrate that under sparse sampling and dynamic conditions, our method significantly outperforms traditional thresholding and existing unsupervised baselines in both precision and recall, and approaches the performance of supervised methods under moderate label noise. This framework offers an efficient, annotation-free solution for indoor crowd density estimation and flow analysis.

title: Optimization of Waste Collection Points in Collective Housing Areas
authors: Anna Biceková, Martin Sarnovský, Frantiśek Babic, Pavol Petrović, Roman Rigó, Patrik Brecka
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Symposium on Computational Intelligence and Informatics (CINTI)
abstract: The paper focuses on the optimization of municipal waste collection points in urban housing areas, representing a partial task within the broader context of urban waste management. At first, we outline typical challenge and current trends in this domain. We continue with a review of theoretical approaches applicable to similar spatial optimization problems along with an analysis of the specific requirements arising from the domain. Key decision-making factors are identified, and their availability in real-world datasets is assessed. Based on data from a selected urban area, we designed and generated suitable optimization models for experimental verification (TRL3). The research results were compared with a parallel optimization process independently conducted by the cooperated city, using only basic input and map data. Particular attention was paid to the number and nature of external factors considered by the city when deciding to cancel or merge waste collection points. Finally, we evaluated the practical applicability of the selected methods and identifies key factors for relevant city’s decision-making processes to improve efficiency and resident satisfaction.

title: AI-Powered Augmented Reality (AR) Approach for Real-Time Wound Healing Visualization and Infection Risk Prediction
authors: Kiran Poojary, Anushree Raj, K. Annapoorneshwari Shetty, Khadersab Adamsab
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems and Pioneering Innovations in Robotics and Electric Mobility (INSPIRE)
abstract: Managing wounds is a critical aspect of healthcare, particularly for patients whose injuries heal slowly or become chronic. Conventional assessments typically depend on visual inspection by clinicians, a process that is often inconsistent, subjective, and time-intensive. In this work, we introduce a browser-based platform that merges a U-Net deep learning network with Augmented Reality (AR) to deliver live wound segmentation and infection risk indication through a standard camera feed. The system was trained on a diverse set of wound images covering different categories such as diabetic ulcers, surgical incisions, and burns, and included variations in skin tones and lighting to ensure wider applicability. Experimental evaluation shows that the U-Net achieved high accuracy (Dice = 0.91, IoU = 0.87, sensitivity = 0.89, specificity = 0.93), exceeding the performance of conventional CNN models by about 12%. The AR module overlays wound contours and potential risk regions directly on the real-time stream, offering clear and immediate visual cues to both patients and medical staff. This solution provides a step toward earlier infection detection, improved remote monitoring, and reduced clinical workload, while also being accessible without specialized equipment.

title: Prospects for Quantum Computing in Onboard Computer Systems for Robotics
authors: Nikita Bocharov
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: This paper evaluates the prospects for applying quantum computing to the onboard computing systems of robots amid rapidly growing computational demands that strain conventional scaling and parallelism. We outline robot-specific requirements—performance, real-time guarantees, size-weight-power (SWaP), and reliability—and survey quantum algorithms relevant to core workloads, including combinatorial optimization (e.g., Grover, variational methods), selected linear-algebra subroutines (e.g., HHL), spectral transforms, and elements of quantum machine learning. A modeling frame-work is described for benchmarking these methods against classical baselines and for integrating quantum simulation into existing toolchains.Results indicate promising acceleration for search/optimization and certain perception and estimation subroutines, while end-to-end gains depend critically on state preparation, oracle construction, error rates, and measurement overhead. Given current hardware and SWaP constraints, immediate onboard deployment is unrealistic; instead, we propose a staged path: near-term offboard/cloud assistance for pre- and post-processing, medium-term hybrid classical–quantum pipelines, and longer-term integration of compact quantum coprocessors as devices mature. The paper concludes with practical guidance on workload selection and evaluation criteria for robots.

title: Efficient Multilingual Translation of Native Indian Languages in GenAI based Product Offer Platform
authors: Shiv Anand Awasthi, Disha Kumar, Anouska Jhunjhunwala, Karthik Manikantan Padmanabhan, Vaishnavi Moorthy, Gomathi Sengodan, Sundar Srinivasan, Praveen George, Ankit Pandey, M Pushpalatha
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Computing and Communication Technologies (CONECCT)
abstract: Generative Artificial Intelligence is revolutionizing economies, bridging gaps with advanced deep learning and natural language processing techniques. In India there are 22 scheduled languages. Top Large language models such as Chat-GPT supports only limited languages. On the other-hand AI4Bharat shows highly efficient Multilingual translation benchmarks. However, in prompt engineering, using LLM alone as a translator often leads to hallucinated outputs lacking context, defaulting to the most common meaning of words and producing extremely bookish language. Fine-tuning the LLM models to support all the languages is costly. This work explores the challenges in machine translation of native languages when using prompt engineering as well as the transformative role of an LLM with the AI4Bharat transformer as a sophisticated language interface, enabling seamless communication across Indic languages with remarkable translation quality. In this study, the performance of AI4Bharat transformers is evaluated using Samsung consumer electronics offers dataset. The proposed translation pipeline integrates IndicTrans2 and Mistral models to benchmark the translation accuracy. By selecting evaluation metrics that focus on translation quality and contextual accuracy, the limitations are addressed. Leveraging RAG Framework with Mistral and IndicTrans2, the approach enhances translation performance for sector-specific offers, demonstrating the effectiveness of specialized LLM prompts and transformers in improving multilingual translations. This research highlights the potential to advance linguistic interfaces and foster cross-cultural communication, reshaping the way translation across diverse linguistic communities is perceived and achieved.

title: Machine Learning in Employment Research Considering Methods and Applications in Job Quality and Algorithmic Management
authors: N. Kalganov, B. Sabdenaliyev, A. Igenbayev, M. Kozhanov, A. Mosavi, C. Mako, I. Kazizat, A. Shakhatova
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Symposium on Computational Intelligence and Informatics (CINTI)
abstract: This review looks at the implementation of artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML) into Employment research. Based upon an extensive search of literature, the study aims to illustrate the main themes of algorithmic management, platform labor, and occupational safety. An initial search concerning publications between 2014 and 2024 followed an in-depth screening procedure. This review proposes a taxonomy of AI in employment research and demonstrates its role in modeling the employment quality and organizational productivity as well as the occupational safety. The results highlight the essential aspects of AI on the nature of work. The research contributes to the understanding of the impact of ML on employees and organizations.

title: Synthetic Data for Infertility Research: A Literature Review
authors: Rozália Szatmáry, Kornélia Sára Szatmáry, Fei-Yue Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Symposium on Computational Intelligence and Informatics (CINTI)
abstract: Infertility presents a pressing clinical and societal challenge, yet its study is constrained by the scarcity of representative data. Public health datasets such as NHANES contain rich physiological, behavioural, and demographic features but are limited by severe class imbalance, with infertile cases representing only a small minority. This imbalance reduces the sensitivity and generalizability of machine learning models applied to infertility prediction. Traditional rebalancing strategies, such as oversampling, are insufficient for capturing the complex hormonal, psychosocial, and environmental interactions underlying infertility. This paper reviews advances in synthetic data generation as a means to address these limitations. Generative adversarial networks (GANs) and variational autoencoders (VAEs) offer statistical realism and coverage, while large language models (LLMs) introduce the possibility of embedding domain knowledge and clinical constraints directly into synthetic case creation. These approaches promise to enrich minority-class representation, enhance predictive robustness, and improve fairness in reproductive health modelling. At the same time, they raise new challenges of validation, transparency, and ethical oversight. By synthesizing insights across existing methods, this review highlights infertility as a critical test case for generative $\mathbf{A I}$ and argues that progress depends not only on technical innovation but also on developing trustworthy frameworks for clinical deployment.

title: Model Predictive Planning and Control for Naturalistic Automated Driving
authors: Gergo Igneczi, Erno Horvath, Krisztian Nyilas
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Symposium on Computational Intelligence and Informatics (CINTI)
abstract: The evolution of Advanced Driver Assistance Systems (ADAS) has reached a stage of maturity where the social acceptance of these systems is becoming as important as coping with technical challenges. Most users complain that ADAS functions behave unnaturally, and they feel anxious because the driving system behaves in a way that is far from what the user prefers. One of the most controversial ADAS functions is Lane Keeping Assistance (LKA). This system detects the edge of the lane and drives the car actively by intervening on the steering wheel. Most available lane keeping follows the center of the lane, while the vehicle controller oscillates and often deviates from this line. Most people find this operation disturbing and unreliable. In our work, we propose a comprehensive Model Predictive Planner and Control that preserves the basic concept of how human drivers drive: they instinctively create the combined representation of the environment and the vehicle, and predictevely plan their action trajectory (i.e., steering angle). This method does not divide the driving task into planning and control, thereby improving tunability. On the other hand, the method provides direct relation to vehicle dynamics and high-level policies, and therefore it can be validated easier than end-to-end trained functions, such as neural networks. The initial algorithm is implemented in MATLAB and validated via simulation. title: Real-Time, In Situ Measurements for the Dynamic Testing of a Road Bridge
authors: Radu Iuliu Cruciat, Cristian Lucian Ghindea, Andrei Gheorghe Pricopie, Ionut Radu Racanel
publish: 2025 14th International Symposium on Advanced Topics in Electrical Engineering (ATEE)
abstract: Bridge structures play a critical socio-economic role, as a part of the national or regional transport infrastructure, necessitating rigorous performance evaluations prior to final acceptance and commissioning. Such evaluations commonly involve both static and dynamic regime testing using controlled trial loads. This study presents the methodology and instrumentation implemented for the dynamic testing of a road bridge with reinforced concrete deck. The measurement system, comprising calibrated sensors and data acquisition units, enabled real-time monitoring of structural response under test loads. Procedures for signal processing, data analysis and extraction of key dynamic parameters are described, alongside the criteria applied for interpreting the experimental results. To complement the experimental analysis, a finite element model of the bridge was developed, providing a numerical framework for validation and correlation of the measured dynamic behavior. The integrated approach allows for a comprehensive assessment of the bridge's structural performance and ensures reliability in operational conditions.

title: Further Evidence for the Organizing Role of the Plasmapause in the Nightside Distribution of Pc1/EMIC Waves
authors: Tamás Bozóki, Balázs Heilig
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Symposium on Computational Intelligence and Informatics (CINTI)
abstract: In a recently published paper, we investigated the spatial distribution of Pc1/EMIC waves in the topside ionosphere based on the high-frequency (HF) magnetometer measurements of the ESA Swarm A satellite, and showed that the appearance of these waves closely follows the variations in the plasmapause (PP) location. In the present contribution, we complement our results by incorporating Swarm B and C data into the analysis, as well as data from the year 2024, which included several geomagnetically active periods, such as the much studied Mother’s Day superstorm in May 2024. Hereby, we could increase the robustness and reliability of our earlier results, especially with regard to higher levels of geomagnetic activity.

title: Remote Sensing Image Generation from Text Disription Using Difussion Transformer
authors: Haoming Qin, Junpeng Zhang, Jie Feng, Weitong Zhang, Jue Zhang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Text-generated images have a wide range of applications in the field of remote sensing. Previous work on remote sensing image generation was mainly based on GAN, whereas the excellent performance of the Diffusion model has remained unexplored. In this work, we present RS-DiT, a novel Diffusion Transformer for generating remote sensing images conditioned on text discriptions. The main idea of RS-DIT is to predict the noise to be removed through conditional information in the input noise image, and generate remote sensing images that meet specific needs through diffusion. We use the semantic differences between remote sensing images of different categories and the text description information of a single image as conditional input, so that the generated images can achieve good results in semantic generalization and accurate description. In order to evaluate the difference between our model and previous GAN and transformer-based methods, we used zero-shot classification, FID, Inception, and clip score to evaluate the authenticity, diversity, and semantic relevance of the generated images. Experimental results demontrate that our method achieves SOTA performance.

title: The Technology for Designing a Logical Database Schema to Support a Business Process Using the EPC Diagram
authors: V.P. Khranilov, P.V. Misevich, P.S. Kulyasov, E.N. Pankratova
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: The technology for developing the DB schema for supporting a business process is described in this paper. The business process is described by the EPC diagram. A modification of the standard EPC diagram is developed in the article. The elements of the EPC diagram are assigned associative relationships to the values of various measures functions and the elements of the situational description (frames). The technology is based on a database logic diagram template. The template is the structure of the snowflake database. The technology is based on adapting the template to the EPC diagram. The technology maps the business process model into the system of the tables of the template. There is an example for illustrating the process of developing a logical database schema to support a business process in the paper.

title: PSRR Improvement Technique for Super Source Follower Based Voltage Regulators
authors: Vahan Sahakyan, Mariam Bagratunyan, Armen Khalilyan
abstract: The article presents a new technique for improving the PSRR in a voltage regulator with a PMOS output transistor. The voltage regulator with a PMOS output transistor was designed to support a 2-mA active load. The technique is relevant for modern 14nm and below technology nodes. SPICE analysis performed over the designed circuit showed a worst-case PSRR value as of -35 dB at lower frequencies at wide temperature ranges of -40°C…125°C and supply voltages up to 0.994 V considering the process deviation within ± 4.5 Sigma. Voltage overshoot protection circuit was also developed to ensure safe operation of core devices in various operation modes.

title: Block Ballot: Universal Verifiability in e-Voting System
authors: Teguh Nurhadi Suharsono, Renandh Alifian Putra Teguh, Gunawan Gunawan, Slamet Risnanto, Sofiani Nalwin Nurbani, Rosadi Rosadi
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Telecommunication Systems, Services, and Applications (TSSA)
abstract: Electronic voting (e-voting) is a digital system designed to facilitate both the casting and tabulation of votes in an election. Furthermore, it has been a major focus of research in cryptography over the past few decades. The proposed technique for implementing Universal Verifiability in the e-voting system for this research is the Block Ballot method. The Block Ballot method is effective for handling voting requests in electronic voting environments. The system treats every voter’s choice as an exchange that gets aggregated into a poll box, allowing the tally of votes to be monitored through the Block Ballot structure. Anyone can agree on the final count thanks to the Block Ballot’s audit trail, which allows the total number of votes to be confirmed by verifying that no data was altered, removed, or improperly introduced into the block. Based on several simulations, the block ballot method has been successfully used for the purposes of universal verifiability at the e-voting stage. The block ballot method in this study produced a universal verifiability degree of 1, which shows that the block ballot has reached the best universal verifiability degree value compared to other methods.

title: Evaluation of Impact of PID-controlled Mobility on Control Quality in CSMA/CA-based Coverage Control
authors: Taiyo Hanamura, Kentaro Kobayashi
abstract: Decentralized autonomous control with multiple agents, where each agent cooperates based on local information, has attracted attention. Among such methods, coverage control has promising applications in tasks such as surveillance, exploration, and environmental sensing. However, in coverage control using CSMA/CA, degraded control quality due to communication collisions is a problem. To address this issue, information transfer methods, where each agent transfers the received position information to its neighbors, have been proposed. In previous studies, evaluations assumed agents moved using a uniform linear motion model. In environments where position observation is noisy, the convergence tends to degrade. This paper introduces a PID control model for agent motion in coverage control with information transfer. We compare its control quality to that of the uniform linear motion model, and clarify the influence of PID gains on control quality.
