title: MRGAgents: A Multi-Agent Framework for Improved Medical Report Generation with Med-LVLMs
authors: Pengyu Wang, Shuchang Ye, Usman Naseem, Jinman Kim
publish: 2025 International Conference on Digital Image Computing: Techniques and Applications (DICTA)
abstract: Medical Large Vision-Language Models (MedLVLMs) have been widely adopted for medical report generation. Despite Med-LVLMs producing state-of-the-art performance, they exhibit a bias toward predicting findings as normal, leading to reports that overlook critical abnormalities. Furthermore, these models often fail to provide comprehensive descriptions of radiologically relevant regions necessary for accurate diagnosis. To address these challenges, we propose Medical Report Generation Agents (MRGAgents), a novel multi-agent framework that fine-tunes specialized agents for different disease categories. By curating subsets of the IU X-ray and MIMICCXR datasets to train disease-specific agents, our MRGAgents generates reports that effectively balance normal and abnormal findings while ensuring a comprehensive description of clinically relevant regions. Our experiments demonstrate that MRGAgents outperformed the state-of-the-art counterparts, improving both report comprehensiveness and diagnostic utility.

title: Federated Learning using Cloud Platform for Secure, Scalable AI Training
authors: Kakumani Akshar, P. Sathish
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems and Pioneering Innovations in Robotics and Electric Mobility (INSPIRE)
abstract: As artificial intelligence (AI) systems continue to grow in complexity and data requirements, federated learning (FL) has emerged as a practical alternative to centralized model training by preserving data locality. In this paper, we present a federated learning framework that integrates cloud-native services specifically from Amazon Web Services (AWS) to support secure, scalable, and interoperable training across client environments. This approach utilizes serverless components such as AWS Lambda, SageMaker, and Step Functions for orchestration, and we introduce a federated API standard designed to coordinate training across multiple cloud providers. This paper address key challenges such as client heterogeneity, non-IID data distributions, and cross-cloud synchronization. Initial architectural validation and experimental planning suggest that this framework can efficiently scale FL workloads without vendor lock-in. We anticipate that this federated API design can simplify multi-cloud collaborations and accelerate privacy-preserving AI development in critical sectors like healthcare, finance, and industrial IoT.

title: Comparison of Deep Learning Models with and without Image Annotations on Dragon Fruit
authors: Pranali Kosamkar, Srishti Bachchan, Soha Arora
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Computing and Communication Technologies (CONECCT)
abstract: To explore and study the integration of deep learning algorithms with image annotation and without image annotation into the field of farming, we have used three deep learning algorithms - VGG16, ResNet50 and YOLOv5.VGG16 is applied on unannotated images while YOLOv5 is applied on annotated images. ResNet50 is applied on both annotated and unannotated images to compare how the performance of the model changes when annotations are added to the images. For this purpose, we have taken the dataset from Roboflow consisting of 3461 dragon fruit images. We extracted an unannotated dragon fruit image dataset from Roboflow platform and added annotations to it. Among the deep learning models on annotated images, ResNet50 obtained the highest accuracy of 97.30% while YOLOv5 achieved an accuracy of 95.40%. On the other hand on unannotated images VGG 16 obtained the highest accuracy of 91.10% leaving behind ResNet50 with the accuracy of 63.13%. Deep learning algorithms with image annotation and without image annotation into the field of farming experiment only done for dragon fruit images. In agriculture domain image annotation is used for various tasks like crop detection, crop health monitoring, and livestock management etc. Image annotation is the image labeling technique. This technique is more specific to recognize the different objects to machines using artificial Intelligence algorithms. Computer vision based AI systems are trained with annotated images which help the agriculture field be more productive and proficient in various tasks.

title: On the Hidden Costs of Fairness in Byzantine-Robust Decentralized Federated Learning Under Data Heterogeneity
authors: Opeyemi Ajibuwa, Olusola T. Odeyomi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Performance, Computing, and Communications Conference (IPCCC)
abstract: Byzantine-robust aggregation methods secure decentralized federated learning (DFL) against malicious clients, yet their fairness effects remain poorly understood. We present the first systematic study of how such defenses impact group fairness in DFL, evaluating six state-of-the-art methods across three vision datasets under varied attacks and graph topologies. Our results show all robust methods consistently degrade fairness relative to weighted averaging, even without attacks, with degradation worsening under sophisticated attacks like ALIE and DISSENSUS. However, not all defenses degrade fairness equally. We identify the root cause as a fundamental misalignment between outlier-detection mechanisms and fairness objectives, where defenses treat statistical deviation as adversarial, inadvertently penalizing minority client updates. These findings have critical implications for DFL deployment in fairness-sensitive domains, underscoring the need for fairness-aware Byzantine defenses that can distinguish between malicious and underrepresented statistical patterns.

title: An Integrating Physical with Convolutional Neural Networks for Enhancing Soil Moisture Retrieval
authors: Xiangjin Meng, Yingbao Yang, Qing Zhu
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: This research presents an innovative approach to soil moisture estimation by integrating physical model with the deep learning techniques, named PCNN, utilizing SMAP satellite data. The study involves a comprehensive test and verification analysis across two dense ground networks (AMR and FLUXNET- AMERIFLUX) and two sparse networks (SCAN and USCRN). The results show that a finer level of prediction accuracy in new PCNN model than simple CNN model. This enhancement suggests the physic model's increased effectiveness in a broader, more diverse dataset. This study demonstrates that integrating physical information into conventional deep learning methods significantly enhances soil moisture estimation accuracy. The enhanced models not only provide more accurate and reliable data but also offer valuable insights into the variability and dynamics of soil moisture across different landscapes and climatic conditions. The success of these models opens avenues for future research and potential applications in agricultural planning, climate modeling, and water resource management.

title: Development and Testing of Modeling Software for Pair Potentials of Particle Interactions: the Lennard-Jones Potential and the Morse Potential
authors: Alexander S. Semenov, Mariya N. Semenova, Yuriy V. Bebikhov, Ilya A. Yakushev
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: This paper considers the development of software for the modeling and selection of particle interaction potential in the crystal lattice of metals. This research is made relevant by the need for an adequate description of atomic interaction in computer models of structures, properties, and behavior of metals. There are multiple models of interaction potentials, and their selection for a specific metal system is a complex problem. The purpose of this research is to develop a software package that can automate the calculation, modeling, and selection of the interaction potential of particles in the crystal lattices of metals. This research work provided the following results: the theoretical bases of atomic interactions in crystal lattices of metals have been described; the existing particle interaction pair potential and their applicability for the modeling of metal crystal properties have been analyzed; an algorithm and software have been developed to calculate and visualize interaction potentials between particles in crystal lattices of metals. The developed software supports parameter selection and adjustment for various interaction potentials.

authors: Laura Enache, Mihaela Draghici, Florin Ciuprina
publish: 2025 14th International Symposium on Advanced Topics in Electrical Engineering (ATEE)
abstract: This work investigates the influence of thermal treatment at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 0}^{\boldsymbol{\circ}} \mathbf{C}$</tex> for 84 days on the dielectric behavior of a nanocomposite made of poly(vinylidene fluoride) (PVDF) and nano-alumina <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\left(\text{Al}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}\right)$</tex>. The results obtained by dielectric spectroscopy at different temperatures show significantly improved performances of the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{PVDF}-\text{Al}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}$</tex> nanocomposites as compared to neat PVDF during the thermal treatment procedure.

title: Powertrain Definition and Energy Consumption Analysis for a Solar Electric Vehicle Using Permanent Magnet Synchronous Motors
authors: Liviu Popescu, Dănuț Marinescu, Ștefan Gamberea
publish: 2025 14th International Symposium on Advanced Topics in Electrical Engineering (ATEE)
abstract: The challenges for Solar Electric Vehicles (SEV) are ongoing, with various studies focusing on the subject. In this context, the present paper analyzes an electric powertrain solution for a small SEV, including the onboard generation of electric energy using solar panels. The investigation begins with vehicle data. An analytical method is employed to define a speed profile for a given physical testing circuit utilizing a multi-motor powertrain based on Permanent Magnet Synchronous Motors (PMSM), resulting in the first calculation of energy consumption. The onboard energy production is investigated by simulation. Additionally, the simulation is used to verify that the PMSM powertrain enables the vehicle to adhere to the requested speed profile and to assess the electric energy consumption.

title: Optimization Method of Multi-Threshold Digital Standard Libraries
authors: Vazgen Melikyan, Sahakanush Terteryan
abstract: It is known that today power consumption in ICs has reached unprecedented values. For this reason, low-power design methods are used in integrated circuits, of which the well-known and effective method is the Multiple Threshold Voltage Design Method. Further increase in the method efficiency is closely related to the number of digital standard cell library types used, which differ in V<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">th</inf>s. Usually, this number is fixed in libraries, which reduces the efficiency of design. A method based on the use of ML is proposed, which allows to correctly select the number of libraries' V<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">th</inf>s for each specific circuit and design requirements. The method is tested on a Schmitt trigger, as a result of which power consumption is improved by ~25% at the expense of area loss of ~1,25%.

title: Research on Automatic Annotation of Content Difficulty in “Principles of Communication” Teaching Videos Based on Multimodal Behavior Analysis
authors: Changzhi Wei, Yinuo Cheng, Dongjin Xin, Weixin Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Trends in Computational Intelligence (NTCI)
abstract: To address the issues of strong subjectivity, coarse granularity, and delayed feedback in current curriculum content difficulty evaluation, this paper proposes a computer vision-based teaching video analysis framework, aiming to realize automatic annotation of teaching content difficulty by quantifying students’ classroom behaviors. Taking Principles of Communication teaching videos as the research object, the framework uses YOLOv8 to calculate group indicators (e.g., students’ up-looking rate, listening rate), adopts deep learning to identify micro-expressions (capturing individual cognitive changes), and constructs a Transformer-based temporal feature fusion network to integrate multimodal behavioral data. Its core innovation lies in mapping fine-grained temporal behavioral patterns to difficulty levels, enabling the framework to distinguish students’ group cognitive states corresponding to teaching segments and map them to “easy”, “medium”, “difficult” levels. Results show the automatically annotated difficulty has a significant statistical correlation with students’ after-class questionnaires and expert evaluations (Spearman’s coefficient $\mathbf{\gt 0 . 7}$). This research provides a new technical means for objective, efficient teaching quality monitoring and a reliable empirical basis for personalized teaching improvement and teachers’ professional development.

title: Agentic AI Frameworks Under the Microscope: What Works, What Doesn’t
authors: Karthik Vaidhyanathan, Davide Taibi
abstract: AI agents are rapidly transforming the software engineering landscape, supported by a wave of new frameworks. Our review of the 10 most representative general-purpose agentic AI frameworks reveals a maturing but fragmented landscape. While some frameworks provide enterprise-ready capabilities, most remain immature, with limited memory models, basic reasoning, and uneven ecosystem support. Significant improvements are needed before these frameworks can enable reliable and large-scale adoption in practice.—Davide Taibi

title: Boosting Multi-Modal CoT Reasoning with Majority Vote and Fine-Grained Verification
authors: Jiacheng Cai
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Data Mining (ICDM)
abstract: Chain-of-thought (CoT) reasoning with purely textual data has achieved notable progress, yet extending such reasoning to multimodal tasks that integrate both images and text presents significant challenges. Existing approaches, such as large-scale fine-tuning and context-based learning, often demand vast annotated data and computational resources, while still exhibiting randomness and hallucination in single-step inference. Although prior work in multimodal classification has demonstrated the value of combining visual and textual features, the need for structured and reliable reasoning across different modalities remains underexplored. To address these issues, we propose VeriCoT, a framework that integrates majority voting with fine-grained verification of differences, thereby enhancing the robustness and precision of multimodal reasoning. By modeling multiple reasoning chains and systematically contrasting their outputs, VeriCoT mitigates errors arising from isolated predictions and improves overall reliability. Experiments on the ScienceQA and MathVista benchmarks show that VeriCoT consistently outperforms baseline models by reducing inference errors and increasing accuracy, particularly in tasks that require complex reasoning over textual and visual information. In particular, applying VeriCoT to the Gemini model raises its accuracy from 87% to 89.6% on MathVista and from 93.4% to 94.8% on ScienceQA. These results highlight the importance of diversity in reasoning processes and underscore verification as a critical step in advancing multimodal CoT methods.

title: AI in the workplace from the perspective of Generations X, Y, and Z - a literature review
authors: Szilárd Berke
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Symposium on Computational Intelligence and Informatics (CINTI)
abstract: The Industry 5.0 revolution and the rapid spread of generative artificial intelligence (AI) in the labor market present unprecedented organizational-, managerial-, and employee challenges. This study provides an integrative literature review of AI applications in workplace practices and employee attitudes, with particular focus on generational differences among Generation $X, Y$ and Z. For the time being, academic researchers have barely analyzed generational differences at work, in relation to AI, and when they have, the target group consists only of university students. Based on the results, it appears that research is still in its very early stages, and university students are currently the primary focus of academic research, presumably because they are easier to involve. There is already more generalist research, in which case the research sample population is general and does not analyze the extent to which the behavior of each generation is similar or different in relation to the factors examined. However, it is clear that Generation Z receives special attention, even though Generations Y and X are likely to face more challenges in terms of technological change and AI acceptance, as they have different psychometric and habitus characteristics than the members of Generation Z, who are “overpowered” and proficient in new technologies. Even though successful AI transformation from a managerial perspective is not only a technological but a human-strategic issue: mobilizing synergies between generations and creating an inclusive organizational culture is essential for ensuring long-term competitive advantage and better employee well-being. In sum, there is a significant market gap that has yet to be filled, so further research on this topic is warranted.

title: Disrupting the Critical 10 Seconds: An Optimization Framework for Lineup Changes and Strategy Shifts in Ice Hockey
authors: Attila Biró, Levente Kovács, László Szilágyi
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Symposium on Computational Intelligence and Informatics (CINTI)
abstract: Turnovers in ice hockey create a short-lived but highly critical window of vulnerability, where the probability of conceding a goal increases sharply within the first 10 seconds. This paper develops a rigorous mathematical optimization framework to determine how and when a team should apply a tactical strategy switch and/or lineup adjustment to minimize goal concession risk in this window. The proposed approach formalizes the game state as a hybrid system with discrete modes representing strategy-lineup pairs and continuous dynamics describing player motion and puck transitions. Switching decisions are constrained by substitution latencies, bench geometry, and coverage feasibility, and are evaluated through a multi-objective cost functional balancing hazard reduction, player effort, and switching penalties. Novel contributions include (1) a criticality index for early-warning detection of high-risk states, (2) latencyaware substitution models that capture transient substitution risks, and (3) receding-horizon optimization policies for operational deployment. Simulation-based analysis demonstrates how micro-substitutions and role-specific strategy shifts can reduce concession hazard without violating feasibility constraints. The results provide a mathematically grounded decision-support framework for coaches and analysts, bridging applied mathematics, informatics, and performance sports to improve defensive resilience in high-tempo, turnover-driven scenarios.

title: Downscaling Long-Term Sub-National Grain Yields into Field-Scale Equivalents
authors: Javier Navarro, Jonathan Richetti
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Since 2009 there have been a number of papers published on the topic of yield gap internationally. The first yield gap case study in Australia was published in 2012 and led to a range of crop-specific Australian yield gap assessments (see https://yieldgapaustralia.com.au) as well as assessments of yield gap of crop rotations. An important limitation of previous efforts in this space has been our reliance on sub-national level crop production statistics from the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) to infer crop yields achieved by farmers. Industry experts commonly argue that these yield values are significantly lower than field-scale yields and hence contribute to overestimating the Yield Gap. Here we present a method to downscale regional wheat, barley and canola yields into <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.1 ~\text{km}^{2}$</tex> pixels using long term NDVI and EVI signals, and our efforts to ensure these downscaled values are representative of field-scale yields and therefore useful in situations where field-scale yields are not available. Our work is the first to investigate these concerns around sub-national yield statistics and to provide a way to make them more useful for applications relying on real-world estimates of productivity such as Yield Gap assessment and diagnosing.

title: Self-Correcting Inference for Land Cover Mapping via Test-Time Domain Adaptation
authors: Mohammed El Amin Larabi, Meziane Iftene
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: This paper introduces a fully unsupervised testtime adaptation (TTA) strategy for robust deployment of autonomous systems in land cover mapping, addressing the challenge of domain shifts without relying on labeled target data. The proposed approach leverages entropy minimization and feature modulation to enable models to autonomously adapt to unseen target domains, characterized by variations in environmental factors, sensor properties, or data distributions. By generating and refining pseudo-labels during inference, the system achieves self-correcting capabilities, enhancing its autonomy and reducing reliance on human intervention. This is particularly valuable in resource-scarce regions, where acquiring labeled data is costly and time-consuming, yet accurate land cover maps are crucial for environmental monitoring, agricultural management, and urban planning. The method is validated using Sentinel-2 imagery, demonstrating an average accuracy improvement of 9.3 % across diverse regions in Algeria. This scalable solution not only improves model robustness but also addresses socio-economic needs by enabling large-scale, cost-effective land cover mapping in underresourced areas. From an Earth observation perspective, this work is novel as it extends TTA to complex remote sensing applications, offering a fully unsupervised framework that operates without source or target labels. By combining entropy minimization, pseudo-label refinement, and feature modulation, the approach sets a new standard for autonomous systems in remote sensing, ensuring consistent performance in dynamic environments and contributing to sustainable development goals.

title: SoC Implementation of Wildfire Infrared Monitoring and Early Detection System
authors: Shalmon Hermesh, Shahnam Mirzaei
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: This paper details the design and implementation of a wildfire infrared monitoring and early detection system (WIMEDS) on reconfigurable hardware. The proposed system aims to enhance the monitoring and detection of fires, with a particular focus on wildfires. Due to the complex nature of wildfire detection and classification, RGB imaging can be challenging. In contrast, infrared (IR) imaging simplifies this process, as fire captured by an IR camera displays a distinct pattern. This allows for more effective monitoring, detection, processing, and authentication of the images. The system is comprised of four primary components: image capture, software/hardware interface, image processing engine, and alarm module. The hardware module was implemented using the Vivado HLS Design Suite and targeted to the ZYNQ XC7Z020 SoC platform. The design efficiently utilizes FPGA resources, consuming less than 12% of Slice LUTs, 2% of memory LUTs, 5% of Slice registers, 8% of DSP blocks, and 4% of block RAMs. Implementation results demonstrate the system's inherent flame detection capabilities, effectively distinguishing hot flames from the surrounding environment.

title: Multispectral to Hyperspectral Using Pretrained Foundational Model
authors: Ruben Gonzalez, Conrad M Albrecht, Nassim Ait Ali Braham, Devyani Lambhate, Joao Lucas De Sousa Almeida, Paolo Fraccaro, Benedikt Blumenstiel, Thomas Brunschwiler, Ranjini Bangalore
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Hyperspectral imaging provides detailed spectral information, offering significant potential for monitoring greenhouse gases like <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{CH}_{4}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{NO}_{2}$</tex>. However, its application is constrained by limited spatial coverage and infrequent revisit times. In contrast, multispectral imaging delivers broader spatial and temporal coverage but lacks the spectral granularity required for precise GHG detection. To address these challenges, this study proposes Spectral and Spatial-Spectral transformer models that reconstructs hyperspectral data from multispectral inputs. The models in this paper are pretrained on EnMAP and EMIT datasets and fine-tuned on spatiotemporally aligned (Sentinel-2, EnMAP) and (HLS-S30, EMIT) image pairs respectively. Our model has the potential to enhance atmospheric monitoring by combining the strengths of hyperspectral and multispectral imaging systems.

title:
Multi L

                    -DTCCA: Multimodal Emotion Recognition Method Based on L
                    <sub>0</sub>
                    -Sparse Deep Tensor Canonical Correlation Analysis
authors: Yadi Wang, Jiahao Zhang, Tengfei Zhou, Xiaoding Guo, Hangjun Che, Yang Cheng, Xiaohui Zhou
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Trends in Computational Intelligence (NTCI)
abstract: With the continuous advancement of affective computing and human-computer interaction technologies, multimodal emotion recognition (MER) has gradually become a research hotspot due to its superior ability to understand human emotions. By integrating information from multiple modalities such as text, images, and audio, it enables a more comprehensive perception and recognition of emotions from multiple dimensions. To address the limitations of current multimodal feature selection methods in terms of accuracy and correlation modeling, this paper proposes a novel method called Multi $L_{0}$ Deep Tensor Canonical Correlation Analysis (Multi $L_{0}$-DTCCA), which combines sparse feature selection with nonlinear correlation learning for multimodal emotion recognition. Specifically, the method employs the $l_{0}$ norms to select features within each modality, effectively eliminating redundant information, and leverages Deep Tensor Canonical Correlation Analysis (DTCCA) to enhance the nonlinear correlations across modalities, thereby improving the quality of the fused representation. Experimental results demonstrate that Multi $L_{0}$-DTCCA significantly outperforms several mainstream correlation analysis-based methods in terms of classification accuracy and result stability, verifying its effectiveness in multimodal feature selection and emotion recognition tasks.

title: Study on the Accurate Identification and Guidance Model of Ideological and Political Education Based on Eventual Graph
authors: Shaowen Ran, Chengyin Liu
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Modern Education and Information Management (ICMEIM)
abstract: To address the prevalent issues of ambiguous identification of students' ideological states and the lack of targeted guidance strategies in current ideological and political education, this paper proposes a Precision Identification and Guidance Model for Ideological and Political Education based on an Event-Reasoning Graph (PIGM-ERG). The model first employs deep learning methods to extract key events and their causal relationships from unstructured text data generated by students on platforms such as university BBS forums, social media groups and online games. This process constructs individual event-reasoning graphs that reflect the evolutionary paths of students' ideological dynamics. Subsequently, leveraging the structural features of the graph, a quantitative assessment algorithm for ideological states is designed to achieve precise identification of potential ideological issues. Finally, the paper introduces a guidance strategy generation framework based on graph path planning, aiming to provide educators with personalized and executable intervention strategies. Experimental results on a dedicated dataset show that, compared to several baseline models including powerful pre-trained language models, the PIGM-ERG model demonstrates significant improvements in accuracy, recall, and F1-score for identifying ideological problems. Furthermore, case studies and expert evaluations have validated the model's interpretability and the reasonableness of the generated guidance strategies, proving the application potential of event-reasoning graphs in profoundly understanding and guiding student ideological dynamics.

title: Correction of the Drive Joints Position Target Based on the Jacobi Matrix When Controlling a Parallel Robot
authors: Sergey Khalapyan, Aleksandr Anpilov
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: The paper considers the problem of positioning errors when controlling a robot with a parallel structure, and suggests a way to solve it. It is shown that a significant reduction in positioning steady-state errors can be achieved by correcting the position assignments of the drive hinges based on the use of a matrix of partial derivatives.

title: Systematic Discrepancies Between COSMIC-2 and Nicosia Digisonde Electron Densities Below the F2 Peak
authors: Mefe Moses, Haris Haralambous, Krishnendu Sekhar Paul
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: This study investigates the systematic discrepancies between electron density profiles obtained from COSMIC-2 radio occultation and the Nicosia Digisonde, focusing on the bottomside ionosphere below the F2 peak height. Using data from 2020 to 2022 co-located COSMIC-2 and manually scaled Digisonde measurements were compared to evaluate the relative percentage differences and error trends across altitude, diurnal, and seasonal variations. Results show that COSMIC-2 exhibits strong agreement near the F2 peak, with discrepancies increasing below 100 km due to overestimations during daytime and underestimations at night. Seasonal analysis reveals improved agreement during winter, while summer shows significant discrepancies driven by heightened ionospheric activity. The findings highlight COSMIC-2's limitations in resolving lower-altitude electron density structures and emphasize the need for refined retrieval algorithms.

title: Factors influencing subsidiary role development
authors: Csilla Hegyi, István Szabó
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Symposium on Computational Intelligence and Informatics (CINTI)

title: Integrating DeepSeek API in Designing Krisna.ai as Artificial Intelligence Chat Assistant
authors: Edi Supriyadi, Ahsani Takwim, Dedi Rosadi, Raden M Adrian, Hanny Rahayu, Bambang Susanto
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Telecommunication Systems, Services, and Applications (TSSA)
abstract: Krisna.ai is a web-based tool embedded in Sketchbook. This study describes the design, development, and evaluation of Krisna.ai. The system contains two main modules an Automatic Dialogue Function, based on a decision-tree approach to provide context-sensitive teaching replies, and an Automatic Questionnaire Function that allows structured reflection and formative assessment. Krisna.ai uses the DeepSeek API to enable interactive discussions between students and academics. It doesn’t compromise privacy since the AI is different from the one used by the faculty. Two experiments were done with 26 college students. The first evaluation studied the fluency, clarity and pedagogical worth of solution proposed by AI to open-ended academic questions. The second study evaluated engagement, understanding, and user choice between a chatbot-supported learning help and a static, manual question. Krisna.ai understands learner intention accurately, enhances user engagement, and allows learners to study in a systematic manner. Krisna.ai can help with the AI-empowered adaptive learning platform for education.

title: Weight-Aware Deep Reinforcement Learning for Multi-Depot Home Healthcare Routing Optimization
authors: Yongqi Liu, Ying Li, Jie Tian, Hui Liu, Xiaoxu Zhang, Huizhi Liu
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Trends in Computational Intelligence (NTCI)
abstract: Home healthcare service routing optimization has become a critical issue in modern healthcare systems as the demand for efficient and patient-centered care continues to grow. This problem involves designing optimal visitation routes for healthcare staff under multiple operational constraints, with the dual objectives of minimizing service costs and maximizing patient satisfaction. However, most existing deep reinforcement learning (DRL) approaches primarily address single-objective problems and often struggle to balance conflicting goals in multi-objective scenarios. To overcome this limitation, this paper proposes a Weight-Aware Deep Reinforcement Learning (WADRL) framework for multi-depot home healthcare routing optimization. The proposed approach integrates a Transformer-based pointer network with a weight-aware modulation mechanism, enabling adaptive policy learning under varying optimization preferences. Furthermore, an Adaptive Large Neighborhood Search (ALNS) procedure is incorporated to refine DRL-generated solutions, enhancing both the quality and diversity of the Pareto front. Experimental evaluations on extended benchmark datasets demonstrate that the WADRL framework significantly outperforms classical multi-objective optimization algorithms, including NSGA-II, SPEA2, and MOEA/D, in terms of solution quality, convergence, and robustness, highlighting its potential for practical deployment in intelligent home healthcare scheduling systems.

title: Using Vertically Oriented Nanotubes to Form a Catalytic Layer for a Solid Oxide Fuel
authors: Alexey Platenkin, Vladimir Chernyshov
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: The article is devoted to the urgent problem of improving the technical characteristics of solid oxide fuel cells (SOFC). An approach is proposed, which consists in forming a catalytic layer on the electrodes of the SOFC in the form of vertically alignment of carbon nanotubes (CNT), followed by uniform spraying of the catalyst material onto their surface. The created structure of the catalytic layer significantly increases the active surface area of the catalyst, which significantly accelerates electrochemical processes at the three-phase boundary (TPB) of the reaction zone in the SOFC, and this, as a result, significantly increases the power and service life of the created SOFC. The paper proposes a method and an automated system for monitoring and controlling the creation of a catalytic layer on SOFC electrodes, which includes the process of forming a layer of vertically arranged nanotubes on SOFC electrodes, followed by spraying a catalyst layer on their surface.

title: Comparison of GUM and Monte Carlo Methods for Evaluation the Measurements Uncertainty of DC Voltage, DC Magnetic Flux Density and Dc Resistance
authors: Radoslav Marinov
publish: 2025 XXXV International Scientific Symposium Metrology and Metrology Assurance (MMA)
abstract: This paper presents a comprehensive comparison of the results obtained using the standard method outlined in the “Guide to the Expression of Uncertainty in Measurement” (GUM) and the Monte Carlo method (as detailed in Supplement 1 to the GUM). To illustrate the practical application of the Monte Carlo method, real calibration data is used from both the DC voltage primary standard (JVS supraVOLTcontrol system) and the primary standard for magnetic flux density of the Electrical Measurements Department of the General Directorate “National Center for Metrology” at the Bulgarian Institute of Metrology (BIM). DC resistance calibration is also considered. For a quantitative assessment of the outcomes derived from these two methods, the numerical tolerance associated with the expanded uncertainty has been used as a comparative metric. The results obtained via the GUM method are robustly corroborated by those generated through the Monte Carlo approach, thereby highlighting the reliability and consistency of both methods.

title: Remote-Sensing Image Object Detection with Adaptive Spatial Attention
authors: Yang Chen, Zhao Chen
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Data Mining (ICDM)
abstract: Object detection represents a key research focus within computer vision and finds broad application. However, remote-sensing image detection continues to face numerous challenges, mainly owing to factors such as the inherently low resolution of small targets, their tiny size, mutual occlusion, scale variations, and illumination changes in complex background environments. In this work, we propose VANet, an enhanced single-stage detection framework. The architecture integrates a Vision Transformer (ViT) backbone, designed to capture broad contextual relationships, with an Adaptive Spatial Attention (ASA) module that selectively accentuates salient regions while attenuating irrelevant background clutter. VANet achieves strong performance on the DOTA and COCO datasets, reaching 79.5% and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{7 9. 1 \%} \text{mAP}_{\mathbf{0. 5}}$</tex>, respectively.

title: A Decision Support System for Ideological and Political Education in Universities Based on Deep Neural Networks and Reinforcement Learning
authors: Yan Wang, Li Chen
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Modern Education and Information Management (ICMEIM)
abstract: This paper presents an innovative education decision support system based on Deep Neural Networks (DNN) and Reinforcement Learning (RL) to enhance the effectiveness of ideological and political education. The system combines DNN for personalized learning path recommendations and RL for real-time feedback adjustments, dynamically optimizing learning strategies according to students' behavior and performance. Experimental results show that the proposed system outperforms traditional rule-based recommendation systems in terms of precision, recall, and F 1 -score. Additionally, the system demonstrated an average performance improvement of 20 % in student learning outcomes after real-time feedback adjustments. The integration of deep learning and reinforcement learning allows for more adaptive, efficient, and personalized education strategies, making the proposed system highly applicable for modern educational settings. The paper also discusses the system's advantages, limitations, and potential directions for future research in expanding its capabilities and improving scalability.

title: Enhancing Genetic Algorithm Efficiency: A Comparative Study of Serial and Parallel Computation for TSP
authors: M Mallegowda, Tresa Maria Josylin, Anusha M
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Computing and Communication Technologies (CONECCT)
abstract: The Traveling Salesman Problem (TSP) is a well-known NP-hard combinatorial optimization problem with applications in logistics, transportation, and network design. Traditional approaches, including exact and heuristic methods, often struggle with large problem instances due to their high computational complexity. Genetic Algorithms (GAs) have emerged as an effective metaheuristic for solving TSP, but their performance can be further enhanced using parallelization techniques. This paper presents a Parallel Genetic Algorithm (PGA) framework for solving TSP by leveraging distributed and multi-threaded computing architectures. The proposed approach implements parallelism at different levels, including population distribution, fitness evaluation, and genetic operations, to accelerate convergence and improve solution quality. We analyse the impact of various parallelization strategies on performance metrics such as execution time, scalability, and solution accuracy. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed PGA significantly outperforms traditional sequential GAs, achieving faster convergence and better route optimization. Additionally, we explore the tradeoffs between computational efficiency and solution optimality across different parallel execution models. The findings highlight the effectiveness of parallel genetic algorithms in tackling large-scale TSP instances and provide insights into designing efficient evolutionary algorithms for combinatorial optimization problems.

title: Dynamical Analysis of a Class of Memristive Neural Networks
authors: Yantao Yang, Fang Xu
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Trends in Computational Intelligence (NTCI)
abstract: During the past few years, alongside the rapid advancement of the fields of neuromorphic computing and brain-inspired chips, memristors, as a new type of nanodevice, have attracted widespread attention due to their ability to simulate the dynamic characteristics of biological synapses. This paper takes a class of memristive Hindmarsh-Rose neural networks as the research object, and focuses on a systematic study of two core dynamic issues of the network under different parameter configurations: the number of equilibrium points and bifurcation behavior. The paper presents the number and distribution of equilibrium points under different parameter conditions, and derives the necessary and sufficient conditions for the occurrence of single-parameter Hopf bifurcation in the network. In the final part of this work, numerical simulation experiments are performed via Matlab to verify whether the theoretical proofs are vali, which provides important theoretical support for the subsequent dynamic regulation and functional optimization of memristive neural networks.

title: Expert Perspectives on Lean Management Practices: Insights From Multi-Industry Interviews
authors: János Kosztolányi, Zsolt Tégla
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Symposium on Computational Intelligence and Informatics (CINTI)
abstract: Lean management has become a widely applied approach beyond its manufacturing origins, aiming to increase efficiency, reduce waste, and deliver customer value. This study investigates how lean is interpreted and applied in practice across diverse organizational contexts. Expert interviews with experienced practitioners from manufacturing, service, and hybrid sectors were conducted to explore terminology use, tool adoption, role structures, cultural integration, and challenges of sustainability. The findings reveal significant variations in lean maturity, from isolated tool-based applications to deeply embedded frameworks supported by leadership and employee engagement. Leadership commitment, structured implementation approaches, and continuous improvement integration emerged as critical enablers of sustainable lean practices. The results provide a foundation for future quantitative research and offer practical guidance for organizations seeking to strengthen their lean transformation efforts.

title: Evaluating Real Deployment NDN Router Performance under the Interest Flooding Attack (IFA)
authors: Jupriyadi, Eueung Mulyana, Nana Rachmana Syambas
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Telecommunication Systems, Services, and Applications (TSSA)
abstract: Named Data Networking (NDN) is an innovative information-centric networking paradigm that transitions communication from host-to-host to content-centric interactions. Nonetheless, its stateful forwarding plane— especially the Pending Interest Table (PIT)—presents new security vulnerabilities, most prominently the Interest Flooding Attack (IFA). In an IFA, assailants overwhelm routers with unsolicited interest packets, depleting PIT resources and impairing the performance of legitimate traffic. This study investigates the real-world impacts of IFA through a practical testbed. We found a significant reduction in performance as a result of an IFA attack. We also found that the negative consequences for IFA are very localized: only the routers along the attack path saw steep increases in PIT entries, nInInterest, nOutInterest, nInData, and nOutData, and all other nodes were largely unaffected. This localized pressure—only to routers that forward or terminate malicious Interests— suggests that IFA does not create congestion across the entire network. These results support the use of mitigation actions that do not have to be applied network-wide. In other words, it is possible to target vulnerability points such as edge or core forwarding nodes without responding across the entire network topology. Ultimately, our work contributes to an understanding of the subtle implications of IFA on NDN performance and informs the design of effective, adaptive defenses.

title: 5G-Powered Remote Sensing for Real-Time Infrastructure Monitoring
authors: Shinki Katyayani Pandey, Mohammed Hussein Fallah, Otamirzaev Muzaffar Bakhodir Ugli, P. K. Chidambaram, S. Kannimuthu, Arun Sekar R, Karthikayen A, M. O Pallavi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems and Pioneering Innovations in Robotics and Electric Mobility (INSPIRE)
abstract: For urban infrastructure expansion, real-time, intelligent, and automated monitoring is needed for it to be able to ensure structural integrity and operational efficiency at the same time. This research envisages an inventive 5G friendly remote sensing technique that combines edgeAI, digital twins, and blockchain to empower and maintain that a kinetic infrastructure is being well attended to. The ultra-low latency 5G networks are used coupled with ultra high resolution sensor information to feed to an edge computing AI system for anomaly detection and predictive maintenance in real time. The digital twin model forms a virtual twin of the infrastructure assets to simulate structural degradation with AI-driven simulations and to optimize the maintenance schedule. Blockchain technology is employed to ensure data security and integrity and to create a tamper-proof distributed ledger for sensor data. To make the monitoring more accurate, the proposed system combines multiple sensors, i.e., LiDAR, thermal imaging, IoT sensors, and drone surveillance. The framework is tailored for critical infrastructure such as bridges, highways, railways, power grids, and smart buildings and enhances maintenance efficiency, decreases operational cost, and decreases failure risk. This shows through experimental results that conventional monitoring systems are not capable of achieving improved anomaly detection accuracy, lesser latency, and enhanced data security, as is the case with this new system. Through this, the research helps in developing the resilient, AI-powered, and secure infrastructure management solutions for making intelligent urban ecosystems and leveraging 5G connectivity for real-time, predictive, and autonomous infrastructure monitoring.

title: Integration of Real Time Embedded Hardware with Processing Sub-Systems for Long Range Radars
authors: Abhinandan Sarkar, Jayabrata Chakrabarty, M Sheik Althaf
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Computing and Communication Technologies (CONECCT)
abstract: Modern long range radars involve design and realization of complex sub-systems like Active Array Antenna Unit (AAAU), Multi-Channel Receivers, Real Time Embedded Hardware and Array Signal Processors and Radar Computer. It is a real challenge to integrate all these radar sub-systems for successful operation of different modes of the radar. The diversity of the problems faced during system integration is huge; some of the typical problems include packet loss within a sub-system, packet loss between multiple sub-systems, reception of variable length garbage data leading to dwell discard, difficulty of simultaneous parallel links validation at input and output due to unequal packet lengths because of difference in Packetization logic involving multiple protocols, etc to name a few. This paper discusses the various integration challenges that were faced during integration of real time embedded hardware with the rest of the processing sub-systems and the mechanism adapted to address the same. This work also serves as a guideline for future radar designs how to avoid the pitfalls already encountered in the present case.

title: CTAN: CNN-Transformer Hybrid Network with Dual-Pathway Attention for Gastric Intestinal Metaplasia Severity Grading
authors: Yufan Xue, Ruzhi Xu, Xiangwei Zheng
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Trends in Computational Intelligence (NTCI)
abstract: Gastric cancer incidence has demonstrated a significant upward trend in recent years, correspondingly elevating public awareness of preventive measures.Traditional medical image analysis predominantly relies on specialized expertise and accumulated clinical experience for identifying diagnostic features. While deep learning-assisted diagnosis has gained considerable traction in common disease detection, current endoscopic technologies primarily focus on IM identification rather than severity grading. To address this gap, we propose CTAN (ConTransAttenNet), a novel CNN-Transformer architecture with dual-pathway attention enhancement for IM severity classification. This framework synergistically integrates CNN’s local feature extraction capabilities with Transformer’s global connectivity while establishing a multi-dimensional attention synergy mechanism. Evaluated using our proprietary dataset of curated IM pathology images, this approach maintains expert-level clinical relevance while providing AI-driven objectivity and reproducibility, thereby establishing a new technical framework for IM monitoring.

title: Facility Layout Optimization using Multi-Agent Deep Reinforcement Learning in a Continuous Space Multi-Floor Setting
authors: Maximilian Krähschütz, Katharina Schmucker
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Symposium on Computational Intelligence and Informatics (CINTI)
abstract: Optimization and automation of facility layout problems (FLPs) is a critical step for developing layouts in many industries such as manufacturing, healthcare, and logistics, where layouts have significant impact on the material handling costs (MHC) and overall operational efficiency. Industrial FLPs often involve complex shaped components, continuous design spaces, and multi-floor layouts, presenting challenges that are difficult to handle for traditional approaches. To address these challenges, this paper presents a mulit-agent deep reinforcement learning (MADRL) approach based on the twin-delayed deep deterministic policy gradient (TD3) algorithm for optimizing unequal area facility layout problems (UAFLPs) in 3D space. The approach is proposed both in a centralized training centralized execution (CTCE) and centralized training decentralized execution (CTDE) setting. Three experiments with increasing complexity are executed to asses the performance of the MATD3 approach and to benchmark it with a single-agent TD3 approach. The results demonstrate that the MATD3 in a CTCE setting consistently performs better than in a CTDE setting and the single-agent TD3 across all experiments. It develops superior layouts regarding MHS and shows more stable learning compared to the other approaches, especially with increased problem complexity. These results highlight the potential of utilizing MADRL to develop facility layouts in real-world environments.

title: A Privacy-Preserving Multimodal Voice Assistant with Offline Retrieval-Augmented Generation
authors: Supriya A V, Gowreesha, Rolwin Melron Dsouza, Sharan, Shritij N Salian
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems and Pioneering Innovations in Robotics and Electric Mobility (INSPIRE)
abstract: This paper presents a privacy-preserving AI-based voice assistant designed to operate seamlessly in both online and offline modes, with the ability to switch dynamically between them. In the online mode, the system employs OpenAI’s GPT models for language understanding and Google’s speech APIs for speech processing. In offline mode, it integrates Whisper for speech-to-text (STT), Coqui for text-to-speech (TTS), and a locally hosted large language model (LLM) using Ollama, ensuring that all processing occurs locally to safeguard user data. To enhance knowledge retrieval in offline mode, Retrieval- Augmented Generation (RAG) is implemented using locally stored document embeddings. A graphical user interface (GUI) provides clear visual feedback and allows users to switch modes effortlessly. The modular, dual-mode architecture offers a balance between usability, accessibility, and privacy, making it suitable for applications in education, research, and professional domains. Experimental evaluation demonstrates that the system delivers accurate, contextually relevant responses with low latency while maintaining strong privacy guarantees.

title: Particularities in the Implementation of the Rotor Flux-Oriented Control Algorithm in Railway Electric Traction Systems
authors: Alexandru Bitoleanu, Mihaela Popescu, Constantin Vlad Suru
publish: 2025 14th International Symposium on Advanced Topics in Electrical Engineering (ATEE)
abstract: In electric railway traction systems with asynchronous motors and rotor field-oriented control, the motor control is achieved by means of a four-quadrant converter (PWM step-up rectifier) and a voltage inverter. Under these conditions, the supply voltage and the current through the motor are distorted, and the motor load capacity decreases. Consequently, a specific phenomenon that may occur is the loss of capacity assuring prescribed torque followed by the improper operation of the entire system. The paper investigates this phenomenon and identifies a solution.

title: Automatic Classification of Motorcycle Exhaust Noise with MFCC and CNN for Urban Noise Monitoring
authors: Khaerul Manaf, Luthfi Raynalfi Firdaus, Aldy Rialdy Atmadja, Raden Muhammad Adrian, Aedah Binti Abd Rahman, Kusmadi
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Telecommunication Systems, Services, and Applications (TSSA)
abstract: Motorcycle noise is one of the dominant sources of urban sound pollution, posing risks to environmental comfort and public health. Conventional measurement using sound level meters is often inefficient for large-scale or longterm monitoring. To address this challenge, this study presents an automated motorcycle noise detection system that integrates Mel-Frequency Cepstral Coefficients (MFCC) for feature extraction with a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) for classification. The dataset consists of 598 audio samples: 537 secondary data from Kaggle and 61 primary field recordings from real motorcycles under idle and constant gas conditions. MFCC was applied to convert raw audio signals into representative spectral features, which were then processed by a CNN to learn noise patterns effectively. The best CNN configuration (RMSprop optimizer with Uniform kernel and 80:20 data ratio) achieved 91.19% accuracy, with an F1-score of 0.82 for the noisy class. These results highlight the effectiveness of combining MFCC and CNN for real-time noise monitoring, offering a practical tool to support policymakers and environmental stakeholders in regulating vehicle noise emissions.

title: Solution of Minimum-cost Maximum-flow Problem with Interval Capacities at the DBMS Level
authors: Artem Miroshnikov, Yuri V. Lubenets, Dmitrij Kashirin
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: The minimum-cost maximum-flow problem is a fundamental challenge in network optimization, with applications spanning logistics, telecommunications, and resource allocation. Traditional models assume precise arc capacities—an assumption often violated in real-world scenarios where parameters are uncertain. This article addresses this gap by introducing a novel approach to solving the minimum-cost maximum-flow problem in which arc capacities are represented as intervals, thereby accounting for data uncertainty directly within the database layer.The proposed method is implemented at the level of the PostgreSQL DBMS, leveraging its extensibility through SQL and the procedural language PL/pgSQL. The solution models the network as a database table and formulates the interval-valued problem. By exploiting PostgreSQL’s advanced features, including user-defined functions, an algorithm was developed that computes the robust maximum flow and subsequently determines its minimum cost, providing a guaranteed solution for all capacity realizations within the specified intervals.The article demonstrates that complex combinatorial optimization under uncertainty can be efficiently integrated directly into a relational database management system. The in-database implementation eliminates the need for data transfer to external application programs, enhances scalability for large network graphs, and provides a practical, robust decision-making tool for data-driven applications. Experiments on artificially generated networks confirm the feasibility and efficiency of the proposed method.

title: Development of a web application for sharing and geo-positioning of video clips
authors: Angel Chekichev, Ahmed Karaibrahimov, Hristo Kanevski, Stefan Sadkov, Serghei Staicov
abstract: The subject of this research is the development of a comprehensive digital solution addressing the challenges of visibility and accessibility faced by creators of geographically oriented video content. Although these challenges appear diverse, they share common characteristics that can be resolved through an integrated web-based approach. The proposed system is a web application designed for sharing and geo-positioning video clips, linking each video to its real-world location on an interactive map. By allowing users to explore videos directly through geographic navigation, the platform enhances the visibility of both the represented locations and the video creators themselves. This approach not only serves as an innovative promotional tool for destinations but also increases viewership and potential monetization opportunities for content authors. The study aims to evaluate the technological feasibility, usability, and overall effectiveness of such a platform for both users and digital content creators.

title: DeepSignBridge: A Real-Time Translation System for Peruvian Sign Language Based on Transformers and Hybrid Computer Vision Models
authors: Gerardo Vilcamiza
publish: 2025 15th IEEE International Conference on Pattern Recognition Systems (ICPRS)
abstract: This work presents DeepSignBridge, a real-time system that bridges communication between deaf and hearing individuals by translating Peruvian Sign Language (PSL) into written Spanish. To achieve this, a fully custom dataset was created from scratch, containing balanced samples recorded under standardized conditions to ensure high-quality gesture representation. The system integrates two complementary deeplearning models: KPoseFormer, a transformer-based temporal sequence classifier using MediaPipe keypoints, and SkelMaxViT, a hybrid vision transformer that combines MaxViT spatial encoding with temporal transformers. This dual-model approach allows comparative evaluation and enhances system robustness, providing flexibility between faster inference and higher accuracy according to computational constraints and environmental conditions. The models achieved top-1 accuracies of 88.89% and 94.72%, respectively, and showed reliable real-time translation performance. Furthermore, the system was validated with deaf students from specialized education centers in Lima, Peru, obtaining excellent user acceptance and confirming its potential as an inclusive assistive tool for everyday communication.

title: Enhancing Gamified Active Directory Cyber Ranges with NIS2 Compliance Integration
authors: Imre Pardi, Anna Bánáti
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Symposium on Computational Intelligence and Informatics (CINTI)
abstract: Cybersecurity education increasingly benefits from realistic, gamified simulation environments such as Cyber Ranges. A design proposal is presented for integrating an automated NIS2 compliance assessment module into an existing Active Directory (AD)-based, gamified Cyber Range used in academic training. The platform’s capabilities are aimed to be extended beyond detection and incident response to include regulatory compliance evaluation. Technical and procedural controls derived from the NIS2 directive will be automatically checked by the proposed module, such as privileged account management, password policies, logging configurations, patch management, and backup procedures. The motivation, architecture, educational workflow, and expected benefits of the module, along with potential challenges and future development directions, are outlined in this paper.

title: A Compact and Low-Cost Optical Sensor System for OD600 Measurement
authors: V Dheeraj, Aditya Joshi, Shishira M Iyar, Kushal P Koundinya, S Risheek, P Nagaraju
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Computing and Communication Technologies (CONECCT)
abstract: This paper presents a low-cost and compact design of a spectrophotometer that measures the Optical Density (OD) of a sample at 600 nm (OD600), which is the most common way to measure microbial growth in a solution. The design consists of a MicroFluidic (MF) card which holds the microbial sample, which is sandwiched between two Printed Circuit Boards (PCBs). The two PCBs together house the electronics needed for OD600 measurement. The design was validated against the UV-VIS spectrophotometer currently available in market using CuSO 4 solutions of varying concentrations.

title: A Pattern of String Insulators Behavior During up-and-down Test Method
authors: Marian Costea, Ileana Băran, Tudor Leonida
publish: 2025 14th International Symposium on Advanced Topics in Electrical Engineering (ATEE)
abstract: The application of the up-and-down test method for determining the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5 0 \%}$</tex> disruptive discharge voltage for insulation tested under impulse voltage conditions is recommended by standards due to its advantages. Voltage measurements can be conducted using a peak voltmeter or a digital recorder. During this type of test, recording the exact time of chopping (the time when disruptive discharges occur) is not necessary. However, this study aims to identify patterns in the behavior of different rated voltage insulator strings when tested with lightning impulse voltage, recording not only the peak value but also the time to chopping. It also seeks to determine the “disruptive effect,” as defined in the equal areas theory, which allows for the evaluation of disruptive voltage for impulse wave shapes that differ from standardized ones, based on the insulator's behavior during the up-and-down test under standardized lightning impulse voltage.

title: Effect of Training Epochs on Multi-Label Emotion Classification Using RoBERTa with Focal Loss
authors: Yoppy Sazaki, Ahmad Fadhil Yusof, Ab Razak Che Hussin, Chan Weng Howe
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Telecommunication Systems, Services, and Applications (TSSA)
abstract: This study examines the effect of training epochs on multi-label emotion classification using the RoBERTa-Large model with Focal Loss, evaluated on the GoEmotions dataset. Experiments were conducted with three, four, and five epochs to analyze performance variations. Results show that training for four epochs consistently produced the best performance, achieving a Macro-F1 of 0.472, Micro-F1 of 0.634, and Average Precision of 0.662, while reducing Hamming Loss to 0.079. Extending training to five epochs led to a slight decline across most metrics, suggesting the onset of overfitting. At the label level, minority-class performance improved at four epochs but degraded at five, indicating a trade-off between overall effectiveness and fairness in representation. These findings highlight that epoch selection is a critical yet often overlooked factor in multi-label emotion classification. The study provides practical guidance for selecting epoch budgets to balance accuracy and fairness in imbalanced datasets.

title: Is 42 the Answer?: A Practitioner’s Tale of Measurements
authors: Sigrid Eldh
abstract: As IEEE Software celebrates its 42nd year, it is hard not to think of the book The Hitchhiker’s Guide to the Galaxy by Douglas Adams, where the supercomputer had the answer 42 of “life, universe and everything” but forgot the question. As with any company, government, industry, university, organization, institution, or research funding agency that I have worked with, there has always been a need to measure success, the progress, and the impact, beyond its sales. The answer always being 42 (the correct answer) as most (managers) are aiming to show (good) results, receive bonuses, and please the organization.

title: A New Vision on Software Sustainability and Its Engineering
authors: Patricia Lago, Ivano Malavolta
abstract: Data centers are growing like weeds to make the AI revolution possible and consume a lot of electricity. Some have concluded that nuclear power is the solution to keep the servers humming. Talking about “Impact of software” for 15 years in IEEE Software it is time to dedicate a column to sustainable computing. This column summarizes the main points from Patricia Lago’s keynote at the 47th International Conference on Software Engineering (ICSE 2025). There is more to come: the March/April 2026 issue of IEEE Software will be dedicated to “Green Clean Software Sustainability.”—Michiel van Genuchten and Les Hatton

title: Analysis of Regularities in Information Flows based on the Use of Fuzzy Numbers and Continued Fractions
authors: Pavel Igorevich Karasev, Fedor Myhailovich Pyrshev, Ilyas Radikovich Safin, Gulnara Shaukatovna Utesheva, Huda Lafta Majeed
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: The analysis of information flows is becoming more complicated every day due to the fact that data is often noisy, distorted and contains inaccuracies. Classical statistical methods are not able to correctly identify patterns in such information flows. The article suggests an approach to identify hidden patterns using fuzzy numbers and continued fractions.

title: Application of AI in the education of ICT students: advantages and disadvantages
authors: Marinela Petrova
abstract: Artificial Intelligence (AI) is being used more and more in education and is changing the way students learn Information and Communication Technology (ICT). Today, technology is becoming an important part of learning and helps both teachers and students. More and more schools and universities are using AI systems to make learning more interesting and effective. This leads to changes in the traditional way of teaching and requires new skills from everyone involved. AI opens new opportunities for learning and preparing for the future in the world of technology.

title: Identification and Analysis of Learning Behaviors in Physics Classroom Based on Deep Learning
authors: Qin Zhang
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Modern Education and Information Management (ICMEIM)
abstract: This paper designs a deep learning-based model for learning behavior recognition and analysis. It utilizes YOLO and DeepSORT techniques for object detection and tracking, and HRNet for human keypoint extraction. The skeleton stream employs ST-GCN/CTR-GCN techniques to represent spatiotemporal structure, while the RGB stream employs TimeSformer and VideoMAE techniques to capture visual semantics. Finally, a multimodal feature set is constructed through fusion, and Cross-Attention is leveraged to achieve multi-label classification, user engagement prediction, and security event identification across multiple task levels. The experiments use the SAV dataset released in 2024. Experimental analysis demonstrates that multimodal fusion significantly outperforms single-stream models in various classroom scenarios, with particularly significant improvements in robustness in experimental exploratory classrooms. In-depth ablation experiments, error case analysis, and teaching application testing demonstrate that the model achieves significant improvements in recognition accuracy and generalization, effectively assisting in teaching evaluation, process monitoring, and safety warnings. The introduction of deep learning technology into learning behavior analysis in physics classrooms provides a new quantitative tool for educational decision-making.

title: Data Analysis and Visualization Practices: Purposes and Obstacles for User-Centered Solutions
authors: Ana Silva, Alexandra Ribeiro, Rosane Sampaio, Emanuel Sousa, Iara Margolis
publish: 2025 International Conference on Graphics and Interaction (ICGI)
abstract: This study explores data analysis and visualization practices among professionals from Portugal and Brazil, revealing common challenges across fields such as health, education, technology, and social services. Based on seven focus groups with 19 participants, the research identifies three user profiles (Academia & Intervention, Strategic, and Operational) and outlines a three-stage workflow: collection, analysis, and presentation. Each stage presents recurring obstacles, including fragmented platforms, low interoperability, manual processes, insufficient training, and limited tool usability, particularly for large-scale or qualitative datasets. Despite the geographic diversity, no significant differences were found between countries. Participants expressed a strong desire for integrated, user-friendly platforms that support the full workflow, provide intelligent assistance, and enable customization. The findings highlight the need for user-centered solutions that align with real-world demands, promote statistical literacy, and enhance data-driven decision-making.

title: Predicting Big Data Applications Runtime on Spark Cluster using Machine Learning Techniques
authors: Khan Umar Farooq, H A Sanjay, G C Akshatha
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Computing and Communication Technologies (CONECCT)
abstract: Apache Spark has emerged as a leading open source platform for distributed data analytics, largely due to its efficient in-memory processing that supports large-scale datasets. Nonetheless, the runtime performance of Spark applications is subject to several factors ranging from data attributes and system configurations to the design of the underlying algorithms. In order to forecast execution behaviors effectively, it is crucial to account for parameters such as the durations of jobs, stages, and tasks, along with memory allocation, utilization patterns, and I/O overhead during data shuffling. This study introduces a prediction model that employs machine learning techniques to estimate execution metrics using an initial set of performance data. The model’s effectiveness is demonstrated through its application to two case studies Wordcount and Average Word Length deployed on a Spark cluster, with the accuracy metrics underscoring its robust predictive capability.

title: Performance Evaluation of Spiking Neural Network using Sinabs for Classification of Cotton Weeds
authors: J Mrudula, M. Santhosh
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Computing and Communication Technologies (CONECCT)
abstract: The growth of weeds in cotton fields leads to significant crop yield losses, with increased weed growth occurring in areas between cotton plants. To manage this, it is crucial to classify the weeds to identify their presence and deploy automated machinery for removal. While Deep Learning techniques have been widely used for classification tasks, they come with the drawbacks of high energy consumption and substantial memory usage. Recently, Spiking Neural Networks have gained attention in image processing because of their compatibility with low-power neuromorphic hardware. This paper evaluates the performance of a Spiking Neural Network using the Integrate and Fire Neuron model to classify weeds in cotton fields. To increase computational efficiency, bilinear interpolation is employed during data preprocessing. A Pytorch-based library, Sinabs is used to convert a Convolutional Neural Network to a Spiking Neural Network. Three classes of cotton weed images from a publicly available source are used, and the results are presented in terms of accuracy, training time and neuron spiking output for sample images. The loss value for the network is 1.78. The accuracy values obtained for 3 classes of weeds are $84.47 \%$ for Convolutional Neural Network and $\mathbf{8 3. 3 4 \%}$ for converted Spiking Neural Network.

title: Integrated Model Controlled Research in Wide Context
authors: László Horváth
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Symposium on Computational Intelligence and Informatics (CINTI)
abstract: This paper is about latest research of research in the background of founding the Virtual Research Laboratory (VRL). As it was introduced formerly, this laboratory is an attempt to establish three paradigm research in collaborative space of actual research making model context level connections in industrial-scientific research projects possible on the cloud. Research is represented in and controlled by all-in-one reactive, autonomous and contextual Experimental Model of Research (EMR). Context definitions from and to outside of EMR ensure connection between EMR and industrial research projects, application of research results, and cyber physical environments. EMR controls well-defined research mainly in high automation related topics considering continuously extending area of applied informatics. In this paper after citation of most relevant research results, by others and at founding of VRL, prerequisites for conceptual, methodological, and system level development of VRL are explained. Following this, central position of EMR in research at VRL, control of virtual and physical research activities by EMR, and main model representations applied in EMR are outlined. Finally, selected issues are explained about application related issues at VRL regarding research activities and their results.

title: The Optimization of 2.4 GHz Array Antennas
authors: Claudia Constantinescu, Adina Giurgiuman, Claudia Pacurar, Calin Munteanu, Marian Gliga, Sergiu Andreica
publish: 2025 14th International Symposium on Advanced Topics in Electrical Engineering (ATEE)
abstract: Starting from a basic antenna designed to operate at 2.4 GHz, this paper investigates systematic optimization of its geometry to enhance performance. After exploring shape modifications aimed at increasing either bandwidth or the gain of a single element, the optimized structure is employed to form antenna arrays that maintain the same bandwidth while achieving higher gain. Various array configurations and element spacings are examined to assess their influence on radiation characteristics. The results indicate that reducing the interelement distance improves the overall gain of the array. Corner rounding (filleting) has negligible impact on the S-parameters or gain, whereas chamfering the corners shifts the resonance to a higher frequency and reduces radiation efficiency. Three different spacings were considered between the antennas and for each of them chamfering and fillet were varied. Overall, the study demonstrates that arraying elements effectively increases antenna gain, in our case from 1.14 dB for an antenna to 4.57 dB for four antennas in an array, but careful consideration of the array's physical dimensions is essential. The principal contribution is demonstrating that the interaction between patchcorner geometry and inter-element spacing can be exploited to optimize array performance.

title: SCALA: Split Federated Learning With Concatenated Activations and Logit Adjustments
authors: Jiarong Yang, Yuan Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Network Science and Engineering
abstract: Split Federated Learning (SFL) is a distributed machine learning framework where the models are split and trained on the server and clients. However, data heterogeneity and partial client participation result in label distribution skew, which severely degrades learning performance. To address this issue, we propose SFL with Concatenated Activations and Logit Adjustments (SCALA), in which activations from client-side models are concatenated as the input of the server-side model to centrally adjust label distribution across different clients, and logit adjustments in the loss functions of both server-side and client-side models are performed to deal with the label distribution variation across different subsets of participating clients. Theoretical analysis demonstrates that the concatenation of activations reduces the impact of data heterogeneity, while logit adjustments in loss functions enhance the recognition of low-frequency labels at the cost of sacrificing the recognition of high-frequency labels.
