title: Multi-Gateway Feeder Link Switching Optimization in Multi-Shell LEO Mega-Constellations
authors: Seonghoon Kim, Inyoung Choi, Yonghwa Lee, Jihwan P. Choi
abstract: This paper addresses the challenges of feeder link switching in non-terrestrial networks (NTNs) by leveraging low Earth orbit (LEO) mega-constellations with multiple shells and multiple gateway (GW) deployments. Due to the high mobility of LEO satellites and frequent feeder link disruptions, it is critical to maintain reliable feeder link connectivity. To tackle these challenges, we propose a novel bilevel optimization framework that combines virtual network embedding (VNE) with advanced feeder link switching strategies. To manage the trade-off between link quality and switching frequency, lower-level optimization maximizes the data transmitted per feeder link connection using a path-finding algorithm with bisection search. The upper-level VNE problem enhances the connectivity between the satellites in the LEO mega-constellation and the ground infrastructure by constructing a dedicated virtual network for NTN GWs. Simulation results based on the Starlink Gen II constellation demonstrate that our proposed method consistently ensures 100% satellite activation, while baseline benchmarks achieve 93% satellite activation rates in the real-world GW deployments. Our optimization framework is well-suited for multiple shell deployments of LEO mega-constellations with multiple GW supports, paving the way for globally connected NTNs.

title: Semantic Entity Alignment and Non-Corresponding Reasoning for Text-to-Image Person Re-identification
authors: Wanru Peng, Houjin Chen, Yanfeng Li, Jia Sun, Luyifu Chen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Information Forensics and Security
abstract: With the rapid development of intelligent surveillance technology, the massive amount of multimodal data (e.g., videos, images, and text) has imposed higher demands on efficient information retrieval and security. Traditional single-modal retrieval methods struggle to meet practical requirements, making multimodal image-text retrieval a research hotspot in this field. Existing approaches, however, still face challenges in fine-grained semantic alignment and suffer from rigid matching mechanisms. To address these issues, this paper introduces SeaNcr, a novel framework that integrates cross-modal semantic entity alignment with non-correspondence reasoning. Our method constructs class-level entity representations enhanced by saliency-guided masking to capture discriminative semantic features. A pseudo-frozen asynchronous optimization strategy is introduced to maintain semantic consistency across modalities by associating stable entity representations with dynamically updated encoder features. Moreover, to overcome rigid matching, we design a non-correspondence reasoning module that jointly leverages intra-modal similarity and cross-modal mutual nearest neighbor constraints, optimizing matching flexibility and generalization. Extensive experiments validate that SeaNcr significantly enhances cross-modal feature representation and retrieval robustness, achieving state-of-the-art performance on multiple person re-identification benchmarks.

title: SymScrab: Physical Layer Encryption for LoRa by Permuting the Baseband Signal
authors: Zhenghao Zhang, Mike Burmester, Yingying Chen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Information Forensics and Security
abstract: LoRa has emerged as a strong wireless communication technology for IoT devices. The security challenges of LoRa have also raised various concerns. We propose SymScrab, a simple physical layer solution that significantly improves the security of LoRa without affecting the communication performance or consuming more communication resources. SymScrab encrypts the message by scrambling the baseband samples with a pseudo-random permutation, which is easy to recover by the legitimate receiver who has the same permutation, but impossible for an adversary. We further propose a physical layer Message Integrity Check (MIC) that rejects spoofed packets because spoofed packets do not exhibit expected physical layer features. We provide a rigorous security analysis of SymScrab and prove guarantees for confidentiality and integrity. We implement SymScrab as an extension to the open-source implementation of LoRa, and test it with both over-the-air experiments and simulations. The results confirm that SymScrab does not negatively affect communication performance.

title:
Calibratable Oscillatory Neurons Based on VO
                    <sub>2</sub>
                    Memristors for Precision Neuromorphic Computing
authors: Zhiyuan Li, Jie Gong, Wei Tang, Beining Zhang, Weihao Niu, Zhengzhe Zhang, Zhiyuan Liu, Xiangshui Miao, Rui Yang
abstract: Mott memristors, characterized by stable and volatile threshold-switching behavior, offer significant potential for artificial neurons in neuromorphic computing systems. However, their practical implementation remains limited by challenges in achieving forming-free, high uniformity, and stability, due to the difficulty of growing high-quality Mott materials. In this work, we demonstrate forming-free VO<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub> memristors with excellent uniformity (cycle-to-cycle (C2C) variation: 0.26%) and ultrahigh endurance (>10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">12</sup> cycles), enabled by a Cr<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub>O<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sub> buffer layer at a low deposition temperature of 280 °C. Based on the device, we implement one-transistor-one-memristor (1T1M) calibratable oscillatory neurons that enable high-accuracy spike encoding through gate voltage calibration. These calibratable neurons demonstrate superior recognition accuracy in image classification tasks based on spiking neural networks, highlighting their potential for robust neuromorphic computing.

title: Diversity Alignment: A New Framework for Simultaneously Optimal Polar Coding over AWGN and Block-Fading Channels
authors: Hyosang Ju, Jisang Park, Min Jang, Donghun Lee, Charlie Zhang, Sang-Hyo Kim
publish: IEEE Journal on Selected Areas in Communications
abstract: We propose a polar coding scheme for block fading channels, aiming to achieve maximum diversity while maintaining the performance under additive white Gaussian noise channels (AWGNC). The key idea is diversity alignment, which aligns maximum diversity with information bits through proper codeword bit to fading block mapping. We first develop a low-complexity diversity analysis tool based on Boolean approximation under genie-aided successive cancellation decoding which can be used for arbitrary bit-to-block mapping. Second, we propose a tractable optimal block mapping for M = 2 fading blocks and develop fast search algorithms for general M ≥ 2, achieving optimal low-rate diversity coding (dc = M at R = 1/M) for a wide range of M. Moreover, our scheme can be applied to achieve optimal high-rate diversity-2 coding (dc = 2 at R = (M−1)/M) with good AWGNC codes. We show that appropriate block-mapping can achieve both low-rate and high-rate optimal diversity simultaneously. Numerical results demonstrate that our framework provides accurate diversity analysis and the proposed DA scheme outperforms conventional interleavers under block fading channels while preserving AWGNC performance. The proposed can play a crucial role in supporting the URLLC communication in future systems, where channel is quickly changing but high reliability is required.

title: Adaptive NN-Based Event-Triggered Consensus for Linear Multi-Agent Systems With Uncertainties
authors: Kai Zhang, Huanhuan Tian, Peijun Wang, Jinjun Shan, Tingwen Huang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Control of Network Systems
abstract: This paper explores the leader-following consensus of linear multi-agent systems with matched uncertainties under undirected graph. Firstly, we employ a neural network (NN) to approximate the nonlinear uncertainties. Then, an adaptive NN-based event-triggered (ET) feedback control scheme is designed. This scheme mitigates the chattering effect resulting from high-frequency switching by incorporating an adaptive boundary layer method. Notably, the proposed dynamic triggering function relies only on agents' local state, without continuous communication with neighboring agents. It is theoretically shown that consensus error is ultimately uniformly bounded. Additionally, Zeno behavior is also shown to be excluded. Finally, two numerical examples are presented to confirm the theoretical results.

title: A Machine Learning Framework for Large-Scale Behavioral Monitoring to Assess Thermotolerance in Dairy Cows
authors: Nseabasi Udondian, Daniel Ogbuigwe, Mostafa Mahmoud Selim, Ahmed Abdelmoamen Ahmed, Madi Bacon, Daigle Courtney
abstract: Based on projected climatic trends, the U.S. dairy industry faces escalating heat stress challenges, with milk production losses projected to reach 1.4 kg/day per cow by the 2050s and 1.9 kg/day per cow by the 2080s, resulting in economic losses of $1.7 billion and $2.2 billion, respectively. While extensive cooling mechanisms are in place, they cannot fully mitigate heat stress effects. Thermotolerance, influenced by physiological and behavioral traits, varies significantly among individual cows and is crucial for sustaining dairy productivity. This paper presents an approach for automatically monitoring and recognizing behavior for dairy cows potentially relevant to thermotolerance, which utilizes various Machine Learning (ML) (e.g., CNN and YOLOv8) and Computer Vision (CV) (e.g., Video Processing and Annotation) techniques aimed at quantifying key behavioral indicators, specifically drinking frequency, brush use-behaviors, and social interactions such as headbutting. We evaluated the developed system using two different video datasets. The first dataset was captured using cameras installed at a side angle, while the second dataset was obtained using top-down camera views. Evaluation results showed that the YOLOv8 and CNN models achieved classification accuracies of 93% and 96%, respectively, on the first dataset, while the second dataset yielded 94% for YOLOv8 and 96% for CNN. Beyond experimental validation, the model is currently deployed for large-scale analysis of over 38,000 video recordings from a commercial ranch in Texas. This deployment enables automated extraction of behavioral event counts, specifically drinking and brushing, for each video, providing high-resolution behavioral summaries at scale. These findings show the robustness and operational viability of the system. The insights gained from this work hold significant promise for advancing genetic selection and management practices, equipping the dairy industry to proactively address heat stress and enhance overall herd resilience in the face of evolving climatic challenges.

title: Stacked Intelligent Metasurface Enhanced Integrated Communication and Computation
authors: Qiyu Chen, Qiao Qi, Jiancheng An, Zhaohui Yang, Xiaoming Chen, Chongwen Huang, Chau Yuen
abstract: As the sixth-generation (6G) networks evolve towards a deep integration of communication and computation (ICC), they face challenges of inherent interference and resource competition between heterogeneous services. To address this issue, this paper investigates an uplink ICC system enhanced by a stacked intelligent metasurface (SIM), where SIM’s unique multi-layer structure transforms the wireless channel into a controllable, task-oriented medium. The system is designed to support the coexistence of over-the-air computation (AirComp) tasks, which require high-precision results, and traditional tasks that demand high-quality communication. To this end, we formulate a joint optimization framework aiming to minimize the total mean squared error (MSE) of all computation tasks while strictly guaranteeing the communication quality of service (QoS). To solve the highly non-convex problem of synergistically designing the system resources, we propose an efficient alternating optimization (AO) algorithm. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed algorithm not only converges rapidly but also achieves up to a 95.2% reduction in total computation MSE compared to an ICC system without SIM, while also significantly outperforming other benchmark schemes, validating the great potential of SIM in proactively managing multi-service conflicts and enabling efficient ICC.

title: Secure and efficient multicast content distribution
authors: Masahide Sasaki, Kazuhisa Matsuzono, Masaru Fukushima, Mikio Fujiwara
abstract: This paper proposes a multicast content distribution method over quantum key distribution (QKD) networks that improves delivery latency and resilience to link bandwidth limitations through mesh network design, while also contributing to reduced key consumption. Although QKD ensures information-theoretic security, its limited key generation rate poses challenges for scalable content delivery. To address this, we introduce a mechanism using random linear network coding in mesh topologies, where nodes adaptively collect and forward packets based on network conditions such as bandwidth and link quality. Evaluations show that our method enables low-latency delivery even under constrained bandwidth scenarios, and can suppress key usage compared to conventional IP multicast over single-tree topologies, depending on network scale and structure.

title: A Simple High-Frequency Signal Injection-Based Multi-Vector Predictive Encoderless Control Technique for Pmsm Drives
authors: Jilin Qiu, Zhenbin Zhang, Haitao Li, Xiaoyang Wang, Guangze Chen, Shichang Zhou, Yilin Wang, Zhen Li
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Predictive Control of Electrical Drives and Power Electronics (PRECEDE)
abstract: In recent years, model predictive control (MPC) has emerged as a powerful approach for encoderless permanent magnet synchronous motor (PMSM) drives. However, conventional MPC cannot seamlessly incorporate high-frequency signal injection (HFSI), resulting in unstable encoderless operation at zero and low speeds. To address this limitation, we propose a multi-vector predictive encoderless scheme that simply combines multiple predictive voltage vectors with injected high-frequency signals for accurate rotor-position estimation. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method effectively injects high-frequency voltage signals and achieves stable encoderless operation in the zero- and low-speed regions.

title: Secure state estimation against sparse sensor attacks: a distributed adaptive saturation method
authors: Qingjie Wang, Jianan Zhang, Yining Qian, An-Yang Lu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: This paper investigates the problem of distributed secure state estimation for cyber-physical systems under sparse sensor attacks. Traditional centralized methods struggle with high computational complexity in large-scale systems, while existing distributed approaches either require strong robustness constraints for graphs or face challenges due to local unobservability. To address these challenges, we propose a distributed adaptive saturation method. This method designs an adaptive saturation function for each node to limit the impact of attacks on the estimation residual. Additionally, it integrates a consensus protocol to enable cooperative estimation of nodes, effectively mitigating the influence of malicious attacks. Theoretical analysis shows that the algorithm ensures consensus estimation under fixed attack channels, with estimation errors ultimately bounded. Furthermore, by refining the saturation mechanism for each node, the algorithm is extended to scenarios with time-varying attacks. Simulation experiments validate that the proposed method effectively handles sparse sensor attacks, reduces computational complexity, and significantly enhances system robustness.

title: Mean-square Stability and Stabilization under An Energy Harvesting Sensor
authors: Zhipei Hu, Daniel W. C. Ho, Shuo Zhao, Shuqi Chen, Feiqi Deng
abstract: This paper is concerned with the problem of mean-square stability and stabilization under an energy harvesting sensor, where the sensor can harvest energy from the external environment. When the sensor's energy is insufficient to maintain regular communication between the sensor and the controller, the sampled data packets are regarded as missing. Otherwise, they can be successfully transmitted in the communication network. To address this problem, we first establish a continuous-time modeling framework for a class of randomly sampled systems with an energy harvesting sensor. Then, a corresponding discrete-time stochastic model is constructed. By establishing the equivalence between the continuous-time and resulting discrete-time systems, a stabilizing controller is designed to guarantee the mean-square stability of randomly sampled systems. In particular, the limit of the probability of successfully transmitting sampled packets is derived, which plays a critical role in the equivalence analysis of systems, as well as the controller design. Finally, a practical example is provided to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed controller design strategy, where both energy-harvestingconstrained and energy-harvesting-constraint-free scenarios are illustrated.

title: A Visual-Based Target Tracking Framework for UAV Using Model Predictive Contouring Control
authors: Yongzhe Du, Huiping Li, Xinyuan Huang, Zengfu Wang, Lingchao Bu
abstract: Tracking moving targets is fundamental task in many applications of uncrewed aerial vehicles (UAVs). In practice, the visual information is hard to be processed in real time for detecting fast-moving and agile targets, and the conventional control method is difficult to track them. To address the challenge, a monocular vision based comprehensive framework for UAVs to track fast moving targets is proposed. In particular, the real-time visual target detection and measurement method with YOLOv8 is designed, and the model predictive contouring control is employed as the UAV control algorithm to optimize the control process, enabling the UAV to follow randomly moving targets. Finally, experimental results verify the effectiveness of the proposed framework under realistic scenarios.

title: An Integrated Sensing-Computing Processor for Spectral-Based Chinese Herbal Medicine Classification With Algorithm-FPGA Co-Design
authors: Hui Zhang, Hai Wang, Bingrui Zhao, Tongzhi Niu, Yunkang Cao, Yaonan Wang
abstract: Hyperspectral imaging has demonstrated strong potential for the classification of Chinese herbal medicines (CHM). However, conventional push-broom systems rely on back-end PCs for spectral analysis, resulting in substantial data transfer overhead and limiting their applicability in real-time, energy-efficient edge scenarios. To address this, we propose an integrated sensing–computing processor. A complete hyperspectral imaging electronics system is developed, along with an dual-branch model, push-broom vision transformer (PBViT), which combines a frequency-domain encoding branch with an improved ViT architecture and contains only 0.075 MB of parameters. On the CHM dataset, PBViT achieves state-of-the-art performance with an OA of 0.978, AA of 0.942, and Kappa of 0.950, surpassing traditional machine learning, convolutional, and ViT-based methods. Leveraging quantization-aware training (QAT), the model is compressed to 8-bit precision with negligible accuracy loss. We further develop an FPGA-based accelerator for PBViT, achieving 502 GOPS throughput and 32.2 <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\mu \mathbf{s}$</tex-math></inline-formula> latency per <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$9\boldsymbol{\times} 9$</tex-math></inline-formula> patch, with a power consumption of 14.42 W. This yields energy efficiency improvements of 6.24<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\boldsymbol{\times}$</tex-math></inline-formula> and 63<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\boldsymbol{\times}$</tex-math></inline-formula> over an RTX 4090 Laptop GPU and an Intel i9-13900HX CPU, respectively. The proposed processor delivers high efficiency for real-time, edge-side pharmaceutical identification and can also be applied to fields such as the food industry and agriculture.

title: Osprey Optimization Algorithm Based Power Quality Enhanced Grid Interfaced Green Energy Fed Electric Vehicle Charging for Industrial/ House Hold Consumers
authors: Koganti Srilakshmi, Praveen Kumar Balachandran, Muhammad Ammirrul Atiqi Mohd Zainuri
abstract: In the current scenario, integration of clean energy sources and EVs are encouraged into the local distribution network. This research designs a UPQC by optimally selecting the gains of a FOPIDC, the inductance and resistance values of filters, and the gain parameters for the PIC of the storage battery and wind energy systems. It also optimizes the parameters of DC-DC boost and buck-boost converters using the Osprey Optimization Algorithm (OOA). Additionally, this work employs a Levenberg-Marquardt Back propagation (LMBP) neural network (NN) control for accurate reference signal generation. The main goal is to address PQ issues like interruptions, sags, harmonic distortion, swell, DC-link voltage balancing, and reduce the total harmonic distortion (THD) of the source current in a grid-connected system that integrates wind energy systems (WES), solar energy, and EVs. The study also introduces a novel power flow algorithm that manages the transfer of power between the renewable sources, grid, EVs and battery storage, thereby facilitating seamless power exchange between solar/wind/battery systems, the grid, and consumer/ industrial loads. This facilitates to ensure a consistent power supply, efficient demand fulfillment, and optimal use of generated power. The study demonstrates that the optimized UPQC, collectively with power flow management, can successfully address PQ issues and achieve efficient power sharing with reduced THD levels of 3.58%, 1.22%, and 4.36%. To exhibit the performance of the system comparison is carried out with standard genetic algorithm (GA) and particle swarm optimization (PSO) algorithms.

title: Joint Learning for Feature Reconstruction and Prediction in Agricultural Semantic Segmentation from Incomplete Satellite Image Time Series
authors: Yuze Wang, Mariana Belgiu, Haiyang Wu, Dandan Zhong, Yangyang Cao, Haifeng Li, Chao Tao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Satellite Image Time Series (SITS) is crucial for semantic segmentation (SS) in agriculture applications. However, cloud contamination introduces time gaps in SITS, disrupting temporal dependencies and causing feature shifts, which decreases the performance of models pre-trained on complete SITS. Existing methods typically address this challenge by reconstructing the entire SITS before prediction or using data augmentation to simulate missing data. Yet, full reconstruction may introduce noise and redundancy, whereas the data augmentation model can only handle limited missing patterns, leading to poor generalization. We propose a joint learning framework with feature reconstruction and prediction to address incomplete SITS more effectively. Specifically, we simulate temporal missing scenarios using temporal masks. The two tasks are guided by both ground-truth labels and the teacher model trained on complete SITS. The prediction task constrains the model from selectively reconstructing temporal features, ensuring they align with the teacher’s complete representations and are beneficial for prediction. It reduces unnecessary reconstruction and limits noise propagation. By integrating reconstructed features into the prediction task, the model avoids learning shortcuts and maintains its ability to handle varied missing patterns and complete SITS. The experiments show strong generalization capabilities in multiple aspects: (1) Different SS tasks, including cropland extraction and crop classification; (2) Different study areas, including Hunan Province,Western France, and Catalonia; (3) Different sensors, primarily Sentinel-2 and PlanetScope; (4) Different numbers of time gaps, while retaining the model’s performance on complete SITS; (5) Different model architectures, including seven typical backbones. The source codes are available at: https://github.com/wangyuze-csu/Joint_FRP.

title: Cost Optimization of UAV Swarm Network for Persistent Emergency Communication
authors: Changtong Liu, Xin Xin, Yueyue Dai, Du Xu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Green Communications and Networking
abstract: Unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) are a promising solution for emergency communications due to their rapid deployment and capability of flexible network formation. This flexibility enables UAVs to dynamically adjust their positions and link configurations to form stable multi-hop networks, thereby establishing resilient data links from isolated disaster areas to remote base stations. However, sustaining such a persistent UAV swarm network is challenging due to limited onboard energy, the scarcity of available UAVs, and complex coordination in emergencies. This paper aims to minimize the number of UAVs required while ensuring continuous multi-hop connectivity for all target areas under energy constraints. We propose a UAV swarm planning strategy based on non-fixed relay points (USP-NFRP), jointly optimizing UAV-to-target associations, trajectories, and the backhaul topology connecting target areas to the base station. First, we propose a periodic rotation path (PRP) method to efficiently manage UAV replacements and assignments at disaster sites. We also provide a mathematical proof of its effectiveness. Second, we propose a dynamic tree backhaul link (DTBL) method that ensures persistent and seamless network connectivity. It is achieved by adjusting the positional roles of relay nodes (fixed or non-fixed) during path planning and dynamically configuring tree-based backhaul links during UAV missions. Finally, we develop a max-min ant system-based path planning algorithm (MMAS-PP) to optimize UAV trajectories and the sequence of task executions. Simulation results show that the proposed strategy reduces the number of UAVs by up to 30.9% compared with baselines.

title: Can utilities serve as the vital missing link in the “human smart grid"? – Experts’ opinion about smart grid actors
authors: Noémi Piricz
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Symposium on Computational Intelligence and Informatics (CINTI)
abstract: Since the beginning of the $21{ }^{\text {st }}$ century, the development of info-communication technology, coupled with the growing demand for renewable energy sources, has made the need to rethink the electricity networks. The need for a more decentralised electricity network has emerged, in contrast to the large centralised system. A smart grid is an electricity network that uses information and communication technologies to gather information about the habits of suppliers and consumers, and then uses this information to automatically increase the efficiency, reliability, economy and sustainability of the grid. We are currently living in an era of energy transition, with smart grids operating mainly through pilot projects. In our research, we analysed in-depth interviews with smart grid experts, mainly practitioners, to find out how they perceive the problems and challenges of smart grid management. As little empirical research has been published so far on the attitudes of utilities of smart grids, our research is unique. We have found that smart grid experts with extensive experience focus primarily on utilities, in their view they are the key players in smart grids. In addition, some of them are aware of the complexity of smart grid management.

title: Bee Swarm and Particle Swarm Algorithms for Solving Optimization Problems
authors: Aleksander Kuznetsov, Albina Akhmetyanova, Svetlana Mustafina
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: This article describes the application of bee swarm and particle swarm algorithms to finding the extremum of a complex function without knowing its gradients, using the Rosenbrock function as an example. These algorithms are applied to real-world problems in which the objective function is implicitly defined and known only from the results of a computational experiment or measurements. They can be applied to resource inventory management and energy problems, such as fuel and energy cost allocation. A software implementation of the algorithms in Python was developed and implemented. Quantitative performance evaluations of the swarm algorithms were obtained using three criteria: convergence rate, accuracy of the approximate solution, and stability of results across repeated runs. It was found that the bee colony algorithm demonstrated stability and the ability to perform global search, especially with increasing problem complexity. The particle swarm method demonstrates high convergence rates on smooth functions but is prone to premature stabilization at local minima.

title: Trusted Medical AI: Blockchain-Backed Device Authentication With Digital Twin-Enhanced XAI for Lung Cancer Detection
authors: Gabriel Chukwunonso Amaizu, Akshita Maradapu Vera Venkata Sai, Zuobin Xiong, Yingshu Li
publish: 2025 IEEE International Performance, Computing, and Communications Conference (IPCCC)
abstract: Lung cancer remains the leading cause of cancer-related deaths worldwide, mainly due to late diagnosis and limited availability of expert pathologists. Although Artificial Intelligence (AI) and DT technologies offer promising avenues for early detection, their adoption in clinical settings introduces significant concerns around data security, system vulnerabilities, and model trust. In response, this paper proposes a novel, trusted medical AI framework that combines blockchain-based device authentication, explainable artificial intelligence (XAI), and DT technologies to enhance diagnostic accuracy, data integrity, and system resilience. The proposed system leverages ResNet for lung condition classification from CT scans, augmented by Grad-CAM for visual explainability, enabling clinicians to interpret AI-driven decisions confidently. A blockchain-based whitelist mechanism authenticates medical devices before data contribution, mitigating risks of tampered or unverified input. Furthermore, the framework integrates explainable digital twin visualization to simulate patient-specific predictions and embeds a vulnerability detection layer to identify and mitigate software flaws in medical IoT and DT components. This comprehensive solution addresses key challenges in real-world healthcare: ensuring data authenticity, interpretability, and cyber resilience, paving the way for secure, transparent, and trustworthy AI-driven diagnostics.

title: Features of Using Nonlinear Dynamics Methods for Object's Functioning Stability Analyzing
authors: Olga Ivanets, Rimvidas Khrashchevskyi, Maryna Arkhyrei, Vladyslav Shlykov, Oleksii Horskyi, Nataliia Bilak
publish: 2025 XXXV International Scientific Symposium Metrology and Metrology Assurance (MMA)
abstract: The study of chaotic behavior of dynamic systems is one of the rapidly developing areas of stability theory. The paper analyzes one of such systems, namely the stability of homeostasis functioning, which is characterized by a certain variability as a result of reaction to the external environment. Analysis of the state of homeostasis is especially important in studies of a human operator, whose professional activity is associated with the constant influence of destabilization factors, in particular, the operator of the aviation industry, in which the human factor occupies a special place. Therefore, the article considers the urgent task of developing methodological approaches to analyzing the stability of the state of operators based on existing biodata to obtain additional useful insights that will expand the understanding of the phase state of a biological object based on time series. The use of nonlinear dynamics methods makes it possible to analyze the phase state of an object and study the chaotic nature of its behavior, which in turn makes it possible, based on the additional information obtained, to assess the level of stability of the operator's functional state, which makes it possible to predict violations and, as a result, eliminate the threat of failure to fulfill duties in the professional sphere, and reduce the overall level of risk in the socio-technical system.

title: SCAM-QUAVs: Side Channel Attacks Mitigation and Countermeasures of Quantum-Safe UAVs
authors: G. Hemanth Kumar, Durbadal Chattaraj, Dilip Kumar Jang Bahadur Saini, Naveen Kulkarni, Sharanabasappa Tadkal, P Ranjima
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Computing and Communication Technologies (CONECCT)
abstract: Side channel attacks pose a security threat to aerospace and unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs), especially in defense scenarios where ensuring resilience and safeguarding data confidentiality is of utmost importance. These attacks take advantage of information leaks like power usage patterns, electromagnetic emissions, timing fluctuations, and sound signals to steal cryptographic keys and sensor data or control instructions. Due to the increasing complexity of these attacks, it is crucial to assess the current mitigation methods to find effective defense tactics and steer future research in the right direction. This survey consolidates and analyzes diverse strategies to enhance security measures such as encryption safeguards, hardwarebased protections, obscuring software code, AI-powered anomaly detection, and shielding signals. In this study, the balance among security needs, computational performance, and system limitations is provided by highlighting a review of current options. Furthermore, we highlight research obstacles and upcoming paths like quantum-proof encryption methods, advanced artificial intelligence-powered intrusion detection, and innovative protective measures to strengthen the durability of future aerospace and UAV defense systems against new side channel risks. By amalgamating existing progress, this analysis offers valuable perspective for researchers, technicians, and decision-makers striving to create stronger security infrastructures.

title: Forecasting a set of energy security indicators using neural networks
authors: Elena Bicova, Irina Vasiliev, Larisa Moraru
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Electrical and Electronics Engineering (ISEEE)
abstract: Forecasting the values of indicators is an energy security task. One of the indicators of energy security is gross oil consumption, the forecasting of which allows to see the prospective use of fuel types and changes in the structure of the energy balance. MultiLayer Perceptron (MLP) neural networks were used to construct short-term forecasts for 2 years ahead. Time series of different lengths were considered with 80, 88, 126 initial points, which were the values of gross oil consumption of each month. Such data are available in national statistics since 2015. The simulation was performed with different neural network parameters. The number of hidden neurons was minimal (1 or 2) and maximal (4, 6, 8, 9). Identity, logistic, hyperbolic and exponential functions in various combinations were used as the activation functions of hidden neurons and the output neuron. A series of models were obtained, which were analyzed using network performance analysis and graphical visualization. Forecasts showed close results in all models in terms of convergence of calculated and actual values (at the level of 5–8%). Annual values of gross oil consumption were calculated using the best calculation model. During the modeling process, it was found that increasing the number of hidden neurons and the type of activation functions slightly affects the performance of neural networks, and increasing the length of the series improves the quality of the forecast. The quality of forecasts for the last two years was checked. The discrepancy between the predicted and actual annual values for these years was 7.7% and (-4.6%), and for the entire series of values, on average, it was (-1.4%). The use of neural networks for short-term forecasting showed satisfactory results, and the method can be used to forecast other indicators.

title: Adaptive Sparse Convolutional Networks with Differentiable Binarization for Infrared Small-Target Detection
authors: Shuanglin Wu, Chao Xiao, Jungang Yang, Wei An
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: The infrared target is small in size and occupies a low proportion in images, causing a significant imbalance between the background and the target regions. To address the sparse data, the standard “dense” implementation of traditional convolutions is inefficient. In this paper, we propose an adaptive sparse convolutional network with differentiable binarization for infrared small-target detection. Specifically, we introduce a differentiable binarization module to adaptively learn target and background region features. Subsequently, we divide the features into significant and redundant parts and employ sparse convolution for lightweight feature extraction. Therefore, our method can accurately locate small targets while efficiently address redundancy in the background regions. Experimental results on public datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: Research on the Contemporaneous Behavior of Regular Employees in Enterprise Operations Management in the Digital-Intelligent Era
authors: Hongyu Dong, Jingwen Liu, Fengyi Wang, Shuang Liu, Yipeng Zhou, Yaping Fu
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Trends in Computational Intelligence (NTCI)
abstract: In the digital-intelligent era, employee behavioral efficiency directly impacts enterprise operational management effectiveness. Scientifically analyzing behavioral efficiency facilitates responsible corporate cost reduction and efficiency improvement. Using e-commerce warehouse pickers’ operational behaviors as a case study, this research enhances forecasting accuracy of operational efficiency through cluster analysis of picker behavioral patterns. By constructing multidimensional features based on domain knowledge, we implement K-means++ clustering and evaluate clustering effectiveness using silhouette coefficients and visualization methods. From the perspective of operational behavior computing, we design a novel PERT strategy integrated forecasting algorithm framework. Analyzing daily behavioral data from 773 pickers in a logistics enterprise between March 14 and September 9, 2021, an innovative multidimensional feature that integrates productivity metrics, work stability coefficients, and attendance pattern characteristics is designed. Results demonstrate that the proposed domain-knowledge-integrated “clustering-forecasting” framework accurately forecasts contemporaneous regular employee behavioral efficiency while establishing an end-to-end research paradigm from raw data to precise predictive decision-making.

title: XR Menu Interaction: User Study of Hand and Controller-Based Designs
authors: João Teles, Inês Cruz, Paulo Dias, Stefan W. Kauling, Beatriz Santos
publish: 2025 International Conference on Graphics and Interaction (ICGI)
abstract: Menu interaction in Mixed Reality (XR) is a particularly complex aspect of user experience, especially when using hands-only input. Different menu designs offer distinct tradeoffs between speed, accuracy, intuitiveness, physical effort, and visibility. These tradeoffs are rarely one-size-fits-all, and their real impact on user performance and satisfaction remains underexplored. To address this, our work investigates how these design differences influence interaction quality, aiming to identify which menu style offers the best overall compromise for practical use. In this context, the paper proposes to evaluate different menus for hand interaction in XR. In this work, we propose and evaluate three different design menus, each tested with hand-tracking and controller input (1-Radial Wrist Menu, 2-Radial Motion Menu, 3-Mobile Phone Menu, see in section III), using Aratall's<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup>1http://www.aratall.com prototype application for 3D urban planning, PassageXR as a case study. A user study was conducted to evaluate the three proposals regarding selection speed, responsiveness, and overall user satisfaction. Our results show that while the Mobile Phone Menu offers the fastest selection times, Radial Menus are preferred overall due to their comfort, ease of use, and potential for muscle memory.

title: Patched Forecasting with Gumbel-Based Selector for Sparse Mobile Crowd Sensing
authors: Victor Li, Carson Lam, Ting Li
publish: 2025 IEEE International Performance, Computing, and Communications Conference (IPCCC)
abstract: Mobile Crowd Sensing (MCS) is a promising paradigm for collecting large-scale data by using distributed sensors on smartphones and wearables. However, building comprehensive spatiotemporal fields of measurements with continuous sensing at all locations and time cycles is often impractical and costly. To address this, we leverage our proposed Learned Gumbel-Based Active Sparse MCS framework, utilizing an Encoder-Decoder Time Series Transformer that reconstructs the full spatiotemporal field for a given sensing cycle using the data collected by a small subset of available sensors. The framework incorporates a selector that actively employs the Gumbel distribution to dynamically pick the most effective sensors for the next sensing cycle. Rather than applying a single selector layer across all sensors, we introduce a patched forecasting approach to account for temporal patterns inherent in sensing cycles. Each patch forecasts its own subsequence of the time series while simultaneously selecting a subset of sensors to reuse in the next sensing cycle.

title: Skysat Can Detect Blackberry Invasive Plants in Australia
authors: Jordan Pont, Richard A. Crabbe
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: In Australia, blackberry is one of the Weeds of National Significance (WoNS), as this weed causes significant environmental and economic problems to businesses and communities. Despite the growing need from government bodies to leverage satellite earth observation for the management of WoNS, limited studies have been conducted in Australia exploring the application of satellite remote sensor data for the detection of blackberry. This research examined the efficacy of high-resolution imagery sourced from the SkySat earth imaging satellites combined with a random forest (RF) classification algorithm for detecting blackberry infestations in Australia. The study estimated the change in blackberry infestation between El Niño and La Niña seasons. The RF model using spectral information alone achieved a producer accuracy of 99.1% and a user accuracy of 98.7% while using the textural GLCM features alone, the producer accuracy was 91% and user accuracy was 95.5%. The combination of the spectral and textural GLCM features produced an RF model that achieved a producer accuracy of 98.2% while the user accuracy was 99.4%. The study observed that blackberry infestations were fivefold higher during the period coinciding with the climatic phenomenon La Niña, which was characterised by widespread changes in rainfall patterns and temperatures. This study paves the way for future investigations into satellite remote sensing and machine learning for managing WoNS in Australia.

title: Methodology for Assessing the Influence of Geometric Parameters of Open Resonators on the Metrological Characteristics of Energy Losses
authors: Mykola Kundenko, Ivaylo Blagov, Antonina Rybalka, Vitalii Mardziavko, Andrii Rudenko
publish: 2025 XXXV International Scientific Symposium Metrology and Metrology Assurance (MMA)
abstract: The paper considers the current problems of the development of open resonators (ORs), which are widely used in modern RF and microwave systems of spectroscopy, quantum electronics, sensors and communications. Particular attention is paid to the influence of power losses — diffraction, ohmic and excitation-related — on the Q-factor and efficiency of ORs. It is shown that accurate modeling of the coupling coefficients of slot elements is a complex task that requires simplified theoretical models and experimental verification. It is established that slot elements provide stable frequency characteristics and effective spectrum compression in semi-symmetric ORs. Methods for estimating losses using Fresnel numbers, approximation formulas and adjustment parameters are proposed. The results presented allow us to deepen our understanding of the loss mechanisms and optimize the design of high-frequency resonators, increasing their efficiency in practical applications.

title: Techno-Economic Assessment of a Potential Solar Power Tower in Azerbaijan
authors: Faig Kalbaliyev
publish: 2025 14th International Symposium on Advanced Topics in Electrical Engineering (ATEE)
abstract: This study presents a comprehensive techno-economic assessment of potential Solar Power Tower (SPT) plants in Azerbaijan, focusing on three representative capacities of 50 <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{MW}, 200 \text{MW}$</tex>, and 1 GW. The analysis places particular emphasis on capital expenditure (CAPEX), operation and maintenance (O&M) costs, levelized cost of electricity (LCOE), and payback periods under the prevailing tariff structure for renewable electricity in the country. For the smaller configurations of 50 MW and 200 MW, the results indicate an LCOE of approximately <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.0759 \text{USD} / \text{kWh}$</tex>, accompanied by a payback period of nearly 19.3 years. These values highlight the financial challenges faced by small- and medium-scale CSP projects, which remain economically constrained when benchmarked against the current regulated electricity tariff of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.085 \text{AZN} / \text{kWh} (\approx 0.05 \text{USD} / \text{kWh})$</tex>. By contrast, the 1 GW case demonstrates a clear advantage of economies of scale: the unit investment cost declines significantly, reducing the LCOE to 0.0395 USD/kWh and shortening the payback period to 7.99 years. This substantial improvement illustrates the pivotal role that large-scale projects could play in overcoming cost barriers and achieving financial viability. Ultimately, this study highlights that while small projects represent the realistic entry point for Azerbaijan, long-term cost reductions and supportive policy measures will be crucial to enable the transition toward economically viable large-scale SPT development.

title: Composite Anomaly Detection Method for Energy Consumption Data
authors: Oleg Yu. Maryasin, Leonid Tihomirov
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: The article presents a composite anomaly detection method for energy consumption data that can be effective when there are collective anomalies in data. This method comprises three key stages. Stage one detects change points for time series properties to split the series into segments. At stage two, the segments are classified for collective anomalies presence using anomaly analysis methods that work well for collective anomalies. The result of the second stage is the detection of collective anomalies in the data. At stage three, collective anomalies are excluded from the data, and only the remaining point anomalies are searched for using the anomaly analysis methods effective in point anomaly detection. The advantage of the proposed complex approach is that it allows for a high data anomalies detection efficiency.

title: Analysis of the Wireless Energy Focusing by a Non-uniformly Spaced Antenna Array
authors: Ivan A. Panov, Tatiana K. Artemova
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: The possibility of using a linear antenna array with a non-equidistant arrangement of elements to create a radiation power flux density to ensure wireless energy transmission was analyzed. The antenna array was supposed to be powered with equal amplitude without the ability to control the phase of the signal in individual antenna elements. Such scenarios of using an antenna array can occur when organizing virtual antenna arrays, for example, on mobile media. To minimize the influence of the radiation patterns of individual antenna elements, the study was conducted using the example of half-wave dipoles in a plane perpendicular to the axis of the dipoles. The effect of the placement of antenna elements in the centers of even or odd Fresnel zones of an equivalent focusing system on the properties of the antenna array was studied by numerical simulation. The dependences of the radiation pattern and the gain coefficient on the equivalent focal length, and the frequency dependences of the array gain for different focal lengths are obtained. The behavior of the radiation power flux density generated by the antenna array on the distance from the center of the array is shown. The spatial distributions of the radiation power flux density created by a non-equidistant antenna array and an equidistant array with the same aperture size are compared. Despite the use of a single and suboptimal method for controlling the antenna array parameters, such a structure can be used for wireless charging of low-power devices.

title: Integral Metrics of HDR Image Quality
authors: Mykola Patlaienko, Olena Osharovska, Andrii Doroshuk, Valentina Solodka, Ivan Tomashevskyi, Oleksandr Hohniak
abstract: This paper presents a study of the quality metrics influence on a high-dynamic-range image reconstruction from a single low-dynamic-range image. The paper proposes an integrated quality index formed from weighted objective metrics, namely, the peak signal-to-noise ratio, the structural similarity index, and the correlation coefficient. These metrics are calculated for luminance and color-difference signals. Tables of metric values are provided for six intermediate images corresponding to six different exposures, from underexposed to overexposed. The quality index is calculated for each intermediate image involved in the reconstruction of the high-dynamic-range image. Using the set of quality indices, a probability density function is constructed, and statistical metrics are determined. The proposed method allows to predict the quality of the reconstructed high-dynamic-range image, taking into account the contribution of each intermediate image with different exposure times. Based on the analysis of statistical moments, a conclusion is drawn regarding the possibility of optimizing the number of intermediate images.

title: Automated meal planning using ontologies and rules in evolutionary search
authors: Abbas F. H. Alharan, István Vassányi
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Symposium on Computational Intelligence and Informatics (CINTI)
abstract: Computerized dietary meal planning can support the prevention or management of chronic diseases. In this paper, we propose a simple and flexible approach based on evolutionary computation to generate weekly meal plans observing structural, numerical as well as harmony constraints, using a configurable dietary rule base and a limited food database. The method is based on a set of ontologies for modeling expert concepts, a structural model, and a rule base with three types of dietary rules that can describe a wide range of requirements. Besides, we propose an extension of the NSGA-II evolutionary algorithm to support the enforcement of the rules, and a reinforcement learning based mutation operator. The approach has been validated in a smallscale proof-of-concept study with a limited set of foods and rules. The results show the viability of the proposed mutation operator and that the effect of dietary rules can be controlled via the model parameters. Further work is needed to extend the proposed approach to more realistic food and rule bases.

title: MLOps Challenges in Deploying High-Performance Vision Models: An Empirical Analysis
authors: P A Abdul Hakkeem, Anusha Ottakandathil, Bijoy A. Jose, Anand Harikrishnan, Kiran Elengickal
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Computing and Communication Technologies (CONECCT)
abstract: The recent advancements in AI and cloud computing have moved the deployment of high-performance AI models from on-premise infrastructure to cloud-native infrastructure. Even though on-premise infrastructure is cost-effective, the cloud-native infrastructure helps develop scalable and fault-tolerant applications. Therefore, it is very important to choose the right architecture for the deployment based on the need of the application to have a scalable and cost-effective solution. The goal of this research is to study the challenges of deploying high-performance AI models in cloud environments and explore different deployment architectures. Automatic Number Plate Recognition (ANPR) is chosen as the problem for the experiment since ANPR is a high-performance system that has high concurrent uses across multiple organizations.

title: Assessing Ground Deformation in Sydney Associated with WestConnex Construction via Dual-Polarization Sentinel-1 InSAR Analysis
authors: Alex Hay-Man Ng, Jianfei Wang, Zheyuan Du, Hua Wang, Linlin Ge
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: The WestConnex project, Sydney's largest urban road infrastructure initiative, has improved connectivity while introducing risks of land subsidence due to extensive underground tunneling. This study examines land stability along the WestConnex corridors using time-series InSAR (TS-InSAR) analysis with dual-polarization Sentinel-1 SAR data. A streamlined approach for persistent scatterer candidate selection, based on the amplitude dispersion index and noise variance, is implemented to enhance measurement point density. Results reveal significant subsidence patterns, with vertical displacement rates peaking at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$15 ~\text{mm} / \text{yr}$</tex> near key intersections and construction zones. These findings demonstrate the effectiveness of polarimetric TS-InSAR in monitoring deformation and highlight the critical role of advanced remote sensing techniques in mitigating risks associated with urban infrastructure development.

title: GDPR requirements for the use of artificial intelligence-based IT systems in financial institutions in Hungary
authors: István Oláh, Sándor Magyar
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Symposium on Computational Intelligence and Informatics (CINTI)
abstract: This study reviews the key provisions of the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), focusing on the data protection aspects of using artificial intelligence (AI) in the financial sector. Financial institutions using AI solutions must thoroughly understand how algorithms work and comply with GDPR requirements, particularly with regard to transparency, data minimisation, purpose limitation, and storage limitation. The study also highlights the specific data protection challenges posed by biometric data and automated decision-making systems. To comply with the GDPR, financial institutions must operate processes supplemented by human oversight alongside AI-based decision-making processes. While the introduction of AI can bring significant benefits to financial institutions, strict compliance with GDPR requirements is essential to ensure data protection and legal certainty.

title: Advanced Credential-Stealing Malware Detection: Static and Dynamic Analysis of Snake Keylogger
authors: M Akshaya Krishna, P Swetha, Prasad B Honnavalli
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Symposium on Computational Intelligence and Informatics (CINTI)
abstract: In recent years, there has been a significant rise in the deployment of information-stealing malware, with keyloggers emerging as a persistent threat to individuals, enterprises, and critical information systems. Among these, Snake Keylogger, a.NET-based malware first identified in November 2020, has gained notoriety for its credential-stealing and keylogging capabilities. It primarily propagates through phishing and spear phishing campaigns, typically utilizing malicious Office documents or PDFs to deliver downloader scripts via PowerShell. Once executed, Snake Keylogger captures keystrokes, steals saved credentials, extracts clipboard data, and takes screenshots to exfiltrate sensitive information. As of 2025, Snake Keylogger has continued to evolve, adopting advanced evasion techniques such as process hollowing, the use of suspended child processes for payload injection, and heavily obfuscated code, all of which complicate detection and response efforts. Notably, security reports indicate increasing prevalence and spikes in zero-day detections, underscoring its continued threat to both personal and organizational cybersecurity. In this work, the results of static and dynamic analysis of a snake keylogger are presented. The findings from this analysis contribute to the development of more robust detection, defence, and mitigation strategies against Snake Keylogger and similarly evolving malware familie

title: Antifragility: A Novel Security Defense Mechanism for Network Defense Systems
authors: Xiran Wang, Bingtao Ding, Leyi Shi, Juan Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Trends in Computational Intelligence (NTCI)
abstract: The influx of massive network device nodes has increased the security threats faced by complex network systems. However, the application of traditional active defense technologies to complex network systems always assumes that the occurrence of network attacks and their impact on the system can be evaluated. In other words, complex network defense systems can achieve robustness against predictable network attacks, but they may still remain fragile when facing unpredictable attacks, or even “Black Swan” attacks. Inspired by the antifragility exhibited by flora and fauna in ecosystems, this paper innovatively studies the antifragility security defense mechanism in the field of network security, aiming to enhance the security defense capabilities of complex network defense systems. Firstly, we define the concept of antifragility for the complex network defense system. Then, the antifragility complex network defense system model is constructed, which includes cyber deception module, service redundancy module and learning and evolution module. To evaluate whether the complex network defense system model possesses antifragility, we propose an antifragility assessment method for the complex network defense system, which analyzes how the system benefits under network attack pressures. Finally, the security and reliability of the antifragility complex network defense system are verified through experiments.

title: Research on DC Bus Ripple Voltage Suppression Strategy for Three-phase AC-DC-AC Converters Based on Active Power Decoupling
authors: Ruichun Gong, Xinyu Zhao
publish: 2025 International Conference on Trustworthy Big Data and Artificial Intelligence (ICTBAI)
abstract: In view of the generation mechanism and hazards of Direct Current ( DC ) bus ripple voltage in traditional three-phase Alternating Current-Direct Current-Alternating Current (AC-DC-AC) converters, this paper proposes a suppression strategy for DC bus ripple voltage in three-phase AC-DC-AC converters based on active power decoupling (APD) technology. First, analyzed the circuit topology and basic control principle of the three-phase AC-DC-AC converter, and then constructed a simulation circuit model of the three-phase AC- DC-AC converter in the MWORKS software environment. analyzed the DC bus ripple voltage characteristics and the output voltage waveforms of the three-phase Sinusoidal Pulse Width Modulation (SPWM) inverter before and after adding the decoupling circuit. Simulation results show that the ratio of the maximum fluctuation range of the ripple voltage to the DC component decreases from 4.5% before decoupling to 0.4%, the DC bus voltage is significantly improved, and the waveform distortion degree of the output voltage of the SPWM inverter is also obviously reduced.

title: Design and Analysis of the Feedback Control Loops for Li-Ion Battery Charger
authors: Andrei Armasu, Dorin O. Neacşu
publish: 2025 14th International Symposium on Advanced Topics in Electrical Engineering (ATEE)
abstract: This paper presents the design and analysis of the feedback control loops for a DC/DC converter used for charging Li-Ion batteries with a constant current - constant voltage charging algorithm. The design is performed in Matlab®, and it allows the component selection to be verified with LTSpice®. The circuit under investigation features the use of the LTC4020 integrated circuit developed by Analog Devices as controller for the converter.

title: Autonomous Aerial Navigation in GPS-Denied Environments
authors: Aarathy Variar, Bhadra R, Afrah Fathima, Remitha U, G. Sreenandhini, Devamithra K H, Jayaresmi J, Sumithra M D
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems and Pioneering Innovations in Robotics and Electric Mobility (INSPIRE)
abstract: In the absence of reliable GPS or GNSS navigation systems, commercial drones fail to complete their tasks successfully. This paper proposes an autonomous navigation system that does not rely on GPS, GNSS or external markers. It instead utilizes custom navigation algorithms in place of traditional positioning systems. The navigation system employs a stereo depth camera, LiDAR, and an optical flow sensor. To process environmental data more efficiently, the system employs a 'tunnel vision' approach, which narrows the field of view to reduce computational load. This is complemented by a sliding window algorithm for processing the area in a linear manner, systematically searching for landable/landing zones. These algorithms can be effectively applied in GPS-denied environments, such as disaster-stricken areas, to facilitate rapid assessment and mapping of affected zones.

title: Peer Assessment in Engineering Education: Sharing Experiences with LearnEval Platform
authors: Elvira Popescu, Gabriel Badea
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Electrical and Electronics Engineering (ISEEE)
abstract: Peer assessment has gained growing attention as a strategy to enhance collaborative learning, critical thinking, and student engagement. Despite its benefits, implementing peer assessment poses various logistical challenges. To address these issues, we designed and developed LearnEval, an innovative peer assessment platform that provides comprehensive support for diverse instructional contexts and workflows. This keynote paper reports on a seven-year deployment of LearnEval across several computer engineering courses. We provide an overview of the platform’s design principles and functionalities, and we describe the course settings in which peer assessment was applied. We also present a summary of the findings and share our long-term experience with the system. Results are encouraging, indicating that LearnEval usability is perceived as good, with the majority of students being satisfied and engaged with the platform.

title: Research and Practice on the Innovative Teaching Model of “Four-in-One” Linking “Three Educations”
authors: Xiuling He, Chunxia Liu, Linlin Chu
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Modern Education and Information Management (ICMEIM)
abstract: In response to the problems in traditional teaching such as abstract theories, limited experimental conditions, and insufficient engineering practice abilities of students, which lead to “students' fear and reluctance, low learning interest, and difficulties for teachers to teach”, the “four-in-one” linkage collaborative “three education” teaching model innovation and practice have been constructed. During the teaching process, based on the OBE concept, through mixed teaching methods such as “combination of virtual and real elements + project-driven approach”, students were enabled to make a transformation from “receiving teaching” to “guiding learning”. During the teaching process, based on the implementation of the “student-centered” teaching model, students are fully enabled to autonomously construct their learning patterns in terms of emotions, cognition, and other aspects. Utilizing AI intelligent tools and information technology to optimize teaching content and improve informationbased teaching resources has enhanced learning outcomes. At the same time, a diversified evaluation system has been established, with an increase in process-based evaluations. Finally, a teaching system with a closed loop of teaching, learning and assessment is formed through evaluation of achievement, student evaluation, and peer review records, etc., to meet the standards for the cultivation of applied undergraduate students.

title: Fallen Powered Two-Wheeler Indication System under Low Visibility Conditions
authors: Vinay Kumar Yadav, P Sanjana, Sunil Bhaskar, Rakesh Maheshwari, S Gayatri, S Pranav, Amit Jain
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Computing and Communication Technologies (CONECCT)
abstract: Accidents involving powered two-wheelers, such as motorcycles and scooters, pose significant safety risks, particularly under low-visibility conditions. Rapid detection and response to these incidents are crucial to minimize injuries and fatalities. This paper presents the development of a system for indicating a fallenpowered two-wheeler that will alert nearby people about the fallen two-wheelers. It will enhance visibility where it cannot be directly visible owing to dark or geometrical conditions with audible loud sirens and lights. The system was designed using a micro-electro-mechanical system (MEMS) accelerometer, a microcontroller, and an alarm system to enhance accident detection and alert mechanisms. MEMS accelerometer continuously monitored the orientation and motion of the two-wheeler. Upon detecting an abnormal tilt or sudden impact that is indicative of a fall, the microcontroller processes the accelerometer data to confirm the occurrence of an accident. Once confirmed, the system activates an integrated alarm comprising visual (light) and auditory (sound) signals. These alarms are designed to penetrate low-visibility conditions, such as fog, rain, or darkness, ensuring that nearby individuals or emergency responders quickly locate the fallen vehicle. This innovative approach offers a cost-effective solution to enhance road safety for powered two-wheeler(PTW) users, potentially reducing response times and improving outcomes in accident scenarios. The implications of this system will make PTWs safer and inspire simplicity and modularity in their implementation in the PTW industry.

title: Large Language Models for Title/Abstract Screening in Systematic Literature Reviews: A Case Study in Precision Livestock Farming
authors: Márk Zrubka, Márta Alexy, Katalin Takácsné György, Zsombor Zrubka
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Symposium on Computational Intelligence and Informatics (CINTI)
abstract: Large language models (LLMs) are gaining popularity in systematic literature review automation, and they are even acknowledged as second reviewers along humans by the Cochrane Handbook. In this study, we tested the performance of two LLMs in the title/abstract screening process in a systematic review on precision livestock farming costbenefit analyses. We assessed the screening accuracy, sensitivity and specificity of the GPT-4o Mini and Claude 3.5 Sonnet models, as well as a human rater. We also compared the time and costs of completing the title/abstract screening by two human raters versus one human assisted by LLMs. LLMassisted screening required less time and money than two human raters, but it was also less accurate, resulting in extra work to rescreen discrepancies. Nevertheless, combining LLMs with the human ratings improved the quality of the screening output. Our results suggest that the tested LLMs are not as reliable as expert humans, however, they can assist in the title/abstract screening process and improve the quality of work with very low extra resources.

title: Region-Aware Image Enhancement Using SRGAN on DIV2K Dataset
authors: Amol G. Patil, Neha Shetty, Mahadevappa Mahadevappa, Nidhi Balse, Suhas Shirol, Amith Telgar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems and Pioneering Innovations in Robotics and Electric Mobility (INSPIRE)
abstract: In real world applications, image resolution is limited by acquisition constraints, resulting in blurred, low-detail results that prohibit correct interpretation. This project attempts to restore high-frequency details from such low-resolution inputs using a deep learning-based super-resolution algorithm. Although classic interpolation or CNN-based approaches try pixel-level precision, they tend to fail to reconstruct realistic textures and sharp structures. To address this, we use a super-resolution model with perceptual quality adversarial training that emphasizes visual realism over minimizing reconstruction error. This is also illustrated on a chosen image region of pixels, and it really leads to notable improvement in edge sharpness and texture coherence. Performance is measured quantitatively in terms of PSNR and SSIM metrics with values of 31.09 dB and 0.8313 respectively and further confirmed in terms of visual comparison and pixel-wise error heatmaps. With emphasis laid on both qualitative and quantitative measures, this project demonstrates a successful approach to the problem of rendering high-resolution imagery from poor-quality data.

title: Application of Generative Adversarial Network (GAN) for Synthetic Training Data Creation to Improve Performance of ANN Classifier for Extracting Built-Up Pixels from Landsat Satellite Imagery
authors: Amritendu Mukherjee, Dipanwita Sinha Mukherjee, Parthasarathy Ramachandran
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Training a neural network for pixel based classification task using low resolution Landsat images is difficult as the size of the training data is usually small due to less number of available pixels that represent a single class without any mixing with other classes. Due to this scarcity of training data, neural network may not be able to attain expected level of accuracy. This limitation could be overcome using a generative network that aims to generate synthetic data having the same distribution as the sample data with which it is trained. In this work, we have proposed a methodology for improving the performance of ANN classifier to identify built-up pixels in the Landsat7 image with the help of developing a simple GAN architecture that could generate synthetic training pixels when trained using original set of sample built-up pixels. To ensure that the marginal and joint distributions of all the bands corresponding to the generated and original set of pixels are indistinguishable, non-parametric Kolmogorov-Smirnov Test and Ball Divergence based Equality of Distributions Test have been performed respectively. It has been observed that the overall accuracy and kappa coefficient of the ANN model for built-up classification have continuously improved from 0.9331 to 0.9983 and 0.8277 to 0.9958 respectively, with the inclusion of generated sets of built-up pixels to the original one.

title: Real-Time Machine Vision Intelligence: Object Recognition and Dynamic Tracking
authors: Sergey Edward Lyshevski, Serhii Kovbasa, Anton Holosha
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Symposium on Computational Intelligence and Informatics (CINTI)
abstract: This paper focuses on machine vision intelligence by solving problems in object detection, dynamic tracking, object governance, and trajectory estimation. The developed learning algorithms support pattern regularity analytics and object matching. The pertained vector-matrix arithmetic operations are processed by convolutional neural networks. The trained, validated and verified models are implemented by a resourceconstrained edge hardware accelerator. Captured images and video streams yield data content, on which information perception is achieved for different scenes, perspectives, distance, visibility, etc. Custom datasets are developed by annotating images and objects for application-specific object classes. The trained networks and synthesized minimal-complexity models support real-time actionable intelligence, applicable in aerial, automotive, industrial, robotic, space and other systems. Experimental studies are conducted investigating scalable and reconfigurable hardware. The findings advance data-driven actionable recognition, timeliness, behavioral analysis and contextual understanding. The proposed explicit methodology and interpretable algorithms enable functionality, enhance operational decentralized intelligence, as well as may support semi-, full- and swarm autonomy in relevant and operational environments.

title: DSM-UNet: Dual Swin-Mamba UNet with Cross-Level Skip Connections for Medical Image Segmentation
authors: Zliengtian Lu, Ruifeng Zhou, Longfeng Shen, Wei Zhao
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Trends in Computational Intelligence (NTCI)
abstract: Medical image segmentation faces critical challenges from blurred boundaries and inter-patient anatomical variations, which significantly limit clinical applications. Traditional U-Net architectures, constrained by the local receptive fields of convolutional operations, fail to effectively model long-range dependencies and lack adaptive feature fusion strategies for diverse anatomical characteristics, resulting in low segmentation accuracy for small organs and large boundary localization errors. To address these issues, we propose DSM-UNet, a novel architecture integrating dual-path Swin Transformers and Mamua dlocks with cross-level skip connections. The network employs an innovative dual-branch synergy mechanism. the Swin branch captures gloval anatomical structural relationships through hierarchical window attention, while the Mamba branch dynamically models individual anatomical variations via selective state-space processing. Cross-level s.ip connections enable multi-scale feature complementarity, specifically enhancing boundary details and small-organ feature representation. Experimental results on the Synapse multi-organ abdominal dataset demonstrate that DSM-UNet achieves an average Dice score of $80.12 \%$, outperforming the current model SwinUNet by $0.99 \%$, with particularly significant improvements in organs susceptible to individual variations (e.g., gallbladder and left kidney). On the ACDC cardiac dataset, DSM-UNet attains an $88.47 \%$ Dice score for myocardium segmentation, a $\mathbf{2 . 8 5 \%}$ improvement over SwinUNet, while maintaining comparable boundary distance error (HD). Ablation studies further validate that the Mamba module’s adaptability to individual variations and cross-level connections’ boundary refinement contribute $\mathbf{1 . 2 \%}$ and $\mathbf{0 . 8 \%}$ Dice improvements, respectively. In summary, DSM-UNet effectively balances global structural modeling and dynamic individual adaptability through the synergistic integration of Swin and Mamba, providing an efficient and robust solution for medical image segmentation challenges.

title: Reinforcement Learning-Driven High-Level Drone Navigation with ML-Enhanced PID Stability Control
authors: C Varshah, S Indra Priyadharshni, T Raja Sree
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Computing and Communication Technologies (CONECCT)
abstract: This paper introduces an architecture for high-level drone navigation with reinforcement learning (RL) while providing low-level stability via a pre-tuned proportional-integralderivative (PID) controller. In contrast to traditional navigation that uses only hand-crafted control policies, our method adopts deep reinforcement learning for planning waypoint-based trajectories and stability through Bayesian optimization (BO)tuned PID control. The framework integrates a model-free RL algorithm -proximal policy optimization (PPO) - to learn optimal navigation policies, where the BO-tuned PID controller is responsible for stabilizing thrust, roll, pitch, and yaw. Our approach is deployed in a 3D PyBullet simulation environment where the drone follows given waypoints and steers around obstacles. The hybrid RL-BO-tuned-PID method guarantees accurate tracking through RL’s adaptability and classical control’s robustness. By experimental verification, we show that our framework performs stable flight and efficient waypoint navigation and surpasses the RL-only baselineline methods in convergence rate, trajectory smoothness, and control stability. This work contributes to the field of autonomous aerial robotics by offering a systematic way of combining RL with BO-tuned PID control for improved drone navigation and stability in turbulent environments where altitude must be maintained and the drone should not drift away.

title: X-Flow: Explanation-Augmented prompting for LLM-Based Intrusion Detection
authors: Iván Pizarro, Ricardo Ñanculef, Carlos Valle
publish: 2025 15th IEEE International Conference on Pattern Recognition Systems (ICPRS)
abstract: The increasing complexity of cyberattacks demands more intelligent Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS) to identify or mitigate the effects of malicious activities in networks. While Large Language Models (LLMs) have shown promise in many tasks, current approaches using zero-shot and few-shot classification have shown limited results for flow-based intrusion detection, with zero-shot yielding poor performance for the more complex attack types and few-shot exhibiting high variance. This paper introduces X-Flow, a two-stage explanation-guided approach that leverages LLM-generated explanations to enhance LLM-based network intrusion detection.
